Utah Code Annotated - Title 58 - Occupations and Professions
============================================================

Utah Code Annotated - Title 58 - Chapter 1 - Division of Professional Licensing Act
***********************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-102 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
For purposes of this title:Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-102(1): 58-67-102 "Ablative procedure" is as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-102(2): 58-67-102; Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act; Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act "Cosmetic medical procedure":
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-102(2)(a): 58-67-102 is as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-102(2)(b): Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act; Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act except for
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-102(3): "Department" means the Department of Commerce.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-102(4): "Director" means the director of the Division of Professional Licensing.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-102(5): 58-1-103 "Division" means the Division of Professional Licensing created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-102(6): "Executive director" means the executive director of the Department of Commerce.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-102(7): "Licensee" includes any holder of a license, certificate, registration, permit, student card, or apprentice card authorized under this title.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-102(8): (8)(a)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-102(8)(a): (8)(a)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-102(8)(a)(i): "Nonablative procedure" means a procedure that is expected or intended to alter living tissue, but not intended or expected to excise, vaporize, disintegrate, or remove living tissue.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-102(8)(a)(ii): (8)(a)(i) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-102(8)(b): "Nonablative procedure" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-102(8)(b)(i): a superficial procedure;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-102(8)(b)(ii): the application of permanent make-up; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-102(8)(b)(iii): the use of photo therapy and lasers for neuromusculoskeletal treatments that are performed by an individual licensed under this title who is acting within their scope of practice.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-102(9): "Pain clinic" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-102(9)(a): a clinic that advertises its primary purpose is the treatment of chronic pain; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-102(9)(b): a clinic in which greater than 50% of the clinic's annual patient population receive treatment primarily for non-terminal chronic pain using Schedule II-III controlled substances.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-102(10): "Superficial procedure" means a procedure that is expected or intended to temporarily alter living skin tissue and may excise or remove stratum corneum but have no appreciable risk of damage to any tissue below the stratum corneum.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-102(11): 58-1-501(1) "Unlawful conduct" has the meaning given in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-102(12): 58-1-501(2) "Unprofessional conduct" has the meaning given in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-103 Division created to administer licensing laws.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
There is created within the Department of Commerce the Division of Professional Licensing.  The division shall administer and enforce all licensing laws of

Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-104 Director of division -- Appointment -- Duties.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-104(1): The division shall be under the supervision, direction, and control of a director.  The director shall be appointed by the executive director with the approval of the governor.  The director shall hold office at the pleasure of the governor.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-104(2): The director shall perform all duties, functions, and responsibilities assigned to the division by law or rule and, where provided, with the collaboration and assistance of the boards established under this title.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-105 Employment of staff.
---------------------------------------------------
The director, with the approval of the executive director, may employ necessary staff, including specialists and professionals, to assist him in performing the duties, functions, and responsibilities of the division.

Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-106 Division -- Duties, functions, and responsibilities.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-106(1): Title 52, Chapter 4, Open and Public Meetings Act The duties, functions, and responsibilities of the division include the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-106(1)(a): prescribing, adopting, and enforcing rules to administer this title;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-106(1)(b): investigating the activities of any person whose occupation or profession is regulated or governed by the laws and rules administered and enforced by the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-106(1)(c): subpoenaing witnesses, taking evidence, and requiring by subpoena duces tecum the production of any books, papers, documents, records, contracts, recordings, tapes, correspondence, or information relevant to an investigation upon a finding of sufficient need by the director or by the director's designee;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-106(1)(d): taking administrative and judicial action against persons in violation of the laws and rules administered and enforced by the division, including the issuance of cease and desist orders;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-106(1)(e): seeking injunctions and temporary restraining orders to restrain unauthorized activity;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-106(1)(f): Title 52, Chapter 4, Open and Public Meetings Act complying with
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-106(1)(g): issuing, refusing to issue, revoking, suspending, renewing, refusing to renew, or otherwise acting upon any license;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-106(1)(h): preparing and submitting to the governor and the Legislature an annual report of the division's operations, activities, and goals;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-106(1)(i): preparing and submitting to the executive director a budget of the expenses for the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-106(1)(j): establishing the time and place for the administration of examinations; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-106(1)(k): preparing lists of licensees and making these lists available to the public at cost upon request unless otherwise prohibited by state or federal law.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-106(2): (1)(k); Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act The division may not include home telephone numbers or home addresses of licensees on the lists prepared under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-106(3): (1); (3)(a); (3)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-106(3)(a): (1) The division may provide the home address or home telephone number of a licensee on a list prepared under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-106(3)(b): (3)(a) A request under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-106(3)(c): (3)(a) The division shall provide, by rule, what constitutes proper identification under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-106(4): Title 63G, Chapter 2, Government Records Access and Management Act; (4)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-106(4)(a): Title 63G, Chapter 2, Government Records Access and Management Act Notwithstanding any contrary provisions in
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-106(4)(a)(i): the division's contracted agents when sharing the information in compliance with state or federal law; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-106(4)(a)(ii): a person who is evaluating the progress or monitoring the compliance of an individual who has been disciplined by the division under this title.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-106(4)(b): (4) The division may make rules to implement the provisions of this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-106(5): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act All rules made by the division under this title shall be made in accordance with


Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-107 Applicability -- Relationship to specific chapters under title.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The provisions of this chapter uniformly apply to the administration and enforcement of this title.  However, unless expressly prohibited in this chapter, any provision of this chapter may be supplemented or altered by specific chapters of this title.

--------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-108(1): 58-1-109(3); Title 13, Chapter 1, Department of Commerce; Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act; 63G-4-103(1) The division and all boards created under this title, including the members of a board designated under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-108(2): 63G-4-502 Before proceeding under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-108(3): Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act Notwithstanding


Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-109 Presiding officers -- Content of orders -- Recommended orders -- Final orders -- Appeal of orders.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-109(1): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act; Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-109(1)(a): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act Unless otherwise specified by statute or rule made in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-109(1)(b): Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act Under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-109(2): 63G-4-102(4); 63G-4-204; 63G-4-207; 63G-4-209 Unless otherwise specified by the director, an administrative law judge shall be designated as the presiding officer to conduct formal adjudicative proceedings in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-109(3): (3)(a); 58-1-201(3); (3)(b)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-109(3)(a): Unless otherwise specified by the director, the licensing board of the profession that is the subject of the proceedings shall be designated as the presiding officer to serve as fact finder at the evidentiary hearing in a formal adjudicative proceeding.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-109(3)(b): (3)(a); 58-1-201(3); (3)(b)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-109(3)(b)(i): (3)(a) If the licensing board is composed of seven or more members, the director may designate any odd number of board members to represent the licensing board as the presiding officer under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-109(3)(b)(ii): 58-1-201(3); (3)(b)(i) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-109(4): (3)(b); (3)(a); (4)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-109(4)(a): At the close of an evidentiary hearing in an adjudicative proceeding, unless otherwise specified by the director, the presiding officer who served as the fact finder at the hearing shall issue a recommended order based on the record developed at the hearing determining all issues pending before the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-109(4)(b): (3)(b); (3)(a) If the director designates certain licensing board members under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-109(4)(c): (4)(b) The licensing board shall issue a recommended order based on the review under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-109(5): (5); (8)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-109(5)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-109(5)(a)(i): The director shall issue a final order affirming the recommended order or modifying or rejecting all or any part of the recommended order and entering new findings of fact, conclusions of law, statement of reasons, and order based on the director's personal attendance at the hearing or a review of the record developed at the hearing.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-109(5)(a)(ii): Before modifying or rejecting a recommended order, the director shall consult with the presiding officer who issued the recommended order.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-109(5)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-109(5)(b)(i): If the director issues a final order modifying or rejecting a recommended order, the licensing board of the profession that is the subject of the proceeding may, by a two-thirds majority vote of all board members, petition the executive director or designee within the department to review the director's final order.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-109(5)(b)(ii): The executive director's decision shall become the final order of the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-109(5)(c): (5); (8) This Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-109(6): If the director is unable for any reason to rule on a recommended order of a presiding officer, the director may designate another person within the division to issue a final order.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-109(7): If the director or the director's designee does not initiate additional fact finding or  issue a final order within 20 calendar days after the day on which the recommended order of the presiding officer is issued, the recommended order becomes the final order of the director or the director's designee.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-109(8): The final order of the director may be appealed by filing a request for agency review with the executive director or the executive director's designee within the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-109(9): 63G-4-203(1)(i); 63G-4-208; 63G-4-209 The content of all orders shall comply with the requirements of Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-111 Tax credit certificate -- Psychiatrists and psychiatric mental health nurse practitioners -- Underserved populations.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-111(1): Chapter 31b, Nurse Practice Act; 58-31b-102; Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act; Chapter 67b, Interstate Medical Licensure Compact; Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act; 17-50-501; (1)(d); Chapter 81, Retired Volunteer Health Care Practitioner Act As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-111(1)(a): "Average of 30 hours or more per week" means that the quotient calculated when dividing the claimant's total hours providing licensed services in the state during the taxable year by the number of weeks in which the claimant is licensed in the state during the taxable year is greater than or equal to 30.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-111(1)(b): "Licensed services" means the provision of behavioral health treatment in the state and within the scope of practice of a psychiatrist, a psychiatric mental health nurse practitioner, or a volunteer health practitioner.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-111(1)(c): Chapter 31b, Nurse Practice Act; 58-31b-102 "Psychiatric mental health nurse practitioner" means an individual who:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-111(1)(c)(i): Chapter 31b, Nurse Practice Act; 58-31b-102 is licensed under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-111(1)(c)(ii): holds a certification recognized by the American Nurses Credentialing Center of the American Association of Colleges of Nursing as a psychiatric mental health nurse practitioner.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-111(1)(d): Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act; Chapter 67b, Interstate Medical Licensure Compact; Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act "Psychiatrist" means an individual who:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-111(1)(d)(i): Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act; Chapter 67b, Interstate Medical Licensure Compact; Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act is licensed as a physician under:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-111(1)(d)(i)(A): Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-111(1)(d)(i)(B): Chapter 67b, Interstate Medical Licensure Compact
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-111(1)(d)(i)(C): Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-111(1)(d)(ii): is board eligible for a psychiatry specialization recognized by the American Board of Medical Specialists or the American Osteopathic Association's Bureau of Osteopathic Specialists.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-111(1)(e): 17-50-501 "Underserved population" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-111(1)(e)(i): 17-50-501 an individual located in a county of the third, fourth, fifth, or sixth class, as designated in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-111(1)(e)(ii): a Native American Indian.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-111(1)(f): (1)(d); Chapter 81, Retired Volunteer Health Care Practitioner Act "Volunteer retired psychiatrist" means an individual:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-111(1)(f)(i): (1)(d) described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-111(1)(f)(ii): Chapter 81, Retired Volunteer Health Care Practitioner Act
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-111(1)(f)(ii)(A): Chapter 81, Retired Volunteer Health Care Practitioner Act licensed under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-111(1)(f)(ii)(B): previously or currently board certified in psychiatry.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-111(2): 59-10-1111(2); (4)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-111(2)(a): 59-10-1111(2); (4) An individual who seeks to obtain a state income tax credit under Subsections

Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-111(3)(a): (1)(c)(ii); (d)(ii) the date on which the individual obtained a license and the specialization described in Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-111(3)(b)(i): an attestation that the individual was licensed on or after January 1, 2017, to provide licensed services; or

Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-112 Data collection.
-----------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-112(1): 26B-1-425; 26B-4-705 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-112(1)(a): 26B-1-425 "Council" means the Utah Health Workforce Advisory Council created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-112(1)(b): 26B-4-705 "Information center" means the Utah Health Workforce Information Center created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-112(2): 26B-4-705(3)(a); (3); (2)(c)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-112(2)(a): 26B-4-705(3)(a); (3) In accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-112(2)(b): The data should focus on:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-112(2)(b)(i): identifying workforce shortages;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-112(2)(b)(ii): identifying labor market indicators;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-112(2)(b)(iii): determining the educational background of a licensee; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-112(2)(b)(iv): determining whether Utah is retaining a stable health workforce.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-112(2)(c): After the council approves data to be collected, the department shall request the data from a licensee when a licensee applies for a license or renews the licensee's license.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-112(2)(d): The department shall send the obtained data to the information center.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-112(2)(e): (2)(c) A licensee may not be denied a license for failing to provide the data described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-112(3): Chapter 31b, Nurse Practice Act; Chapter 60, Mental Health Professional Practice Act; Chapter 61, Psychologist Licensing Act; Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act; Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act; Chapter 69, Dentist and Dental Hygienist Practice Act; Chapter 70a, Utah Physician Assistant Act; (3)(a); Chapter 5a, Podiatric Physician Licensing Act; Chapter 17b, Pharmacy Practice Act; Chapter 24b, Physical Therapy Practice Act; Chapter 40, Recreational Therapy Practice Act; Chapter 41, Speech-Language Pathology and Audiology Licensing Act; Chapter 42a, Occupational Therapy Practice Act; Chapter 44a, Nurse Midwife Practice Act; Chapter 54, Radiologic Technologist, Radiologist Assistant, and Radiology Practical Technician Licensing Act; Chapter 57, Respiratory Care Practices Act; (3)(a); (b); (3)(a); (3)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-112(3)(a): Chapter 31b, Nurse Practice Act; Chapter 60, Mental Health Professional Practice Act; Chapter 61, Psychologist Licensing Act; Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act; Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act; Chapter 69, Dentist and Dental Hygienist Practice Act; Chapter 70a, Utah Physician Assistant Act The department shall prioritize data collection for each profession licensed under:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-112(3)(a)(i): Chapter 31b, Nurse Practice Act
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-112(3)(a)(ii): Chapter 60, Mental Health Professional Practice Act

Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-201 Boards -- Appointment -- Membership -- Terms -- Vacancies -- Quorum -- Per diem and expenses -- Chair -- Financial interest or faculty position in professional school that teaches continuing education prohibited.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-201(1): (1)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-201(1)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-201(1)(a)(i): The executive director shall appoint the members of the boards established under this title.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-201(1)(a)(ii): In appointing the board members the executive director shall give consideration to recommendations by members of the respective professions and the professions' organizations.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-201(1)(b): Each board shall be composed of five members, four of whom are licensed or certified practitioners in good standing of the profession the board represents, and one of whom is a member of the general public, unless otherwise provided under the specific licensing chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-201(1)(c): (1)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-201(1)(c)(i): The name of each individual appointed to a board shall be submitted to the governor for confirmation or rejection.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-201(1)(c)(ii): (1)(a) If an appointee is rejected by the governor, the executive director shall appoint another individual in the same manner as set forth in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-201(2): (2)(b); (2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-201(2)(a): (2)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-201(2)(a)(i): (2)(b) Except as required by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-201(2)(a)(ii): Upon the expiration of the term of a board member, the board member shall continue to serve until a successor is appointed, but for a period not to exceed six months from the expiration date of the board member's term.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-201(2)(b): (2)(a) Notwithstanding the requirements of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-201(2)(c): A board member may not serve more than two consecutive terms, and a board member who ceases to serve on a board may not serve again on that board until after the expiration of a two-year period beginning from that cessation of service.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-201(2)(d): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-201(2)(d)(i): When a vacancy occurs in the board membership for any reason, the replacement shall be appointed for the unexpired term.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-201(2)(d)(ii): After filling that term, the replacement board member may be appointed for only one additional full term.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-201(2)(e): The director, with the approval of the executive director, may remove a board member and replace the board member in accordance with this section for the following reasons:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-201(2)(e)(i): the board member fails or refuses to fulfill the responsibilities and duties of a board member, including attendance at board meetings;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-201(2)(e)(ii): the board member engages in unlawful or unprofessional conduct; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-201(2)(e)(iii): if appointed to the board position as a licensed member of the board, the board member fails to maintain a license that is active and in good standing.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-201(3): 58-1-109(3)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-201(3)(a): A majority of the board members constitutes a quorum.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-201(3)(b): 58-1-109(3) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-201(4): 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107; 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107 A board member may not receive compensation or benefits for the board member's service, but may receive per diem and travel expenses in accordance with:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-201(4)(a): 63A-3-106 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-201(4)(b): 63A-3-107 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-201(4)(c): 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107 rules made by the Division of Finance under Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-201(5): Each board shall annually designate one of the board's members to serve as chair for a one-year period.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-201(6): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act A board member may not be a member of the faculty of, or have a financial interest in, a vocational or professional college or school that provides continuing education to any licensee if that continuing education is required by statute or rule made in accordance with

Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-202(1)(a): recommending to the director appropriate rules and statutory changes to improve the health, safety, and financial welfare of the public, including changes to remove regulations that are no longer necessary or effective in protecting the public and enhancing commerce;

Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-203 Duties, functions, and responsibilities of division in collaboration with board -- Construction Services Commission.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-203(1): The following duties, functions, and responsibilities of the division shall be performed by the division with the collaboration and assistance of the appropriate board:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-203(1)(a): defining which schools, colleges, universities, departments of universities, military educational and training programs, or other institutions of learning are reputable and in good standing with the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-203(1)(b): prescribing license qualifications;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-203(1)(c): prescribing rules governing applications for licenses;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-203(1)(d): providing for a fair and impartial method of examination of applicants;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-203(1)(e): defining unprofessional conduct, by rule, to supplement the definitions under this chapter or other licensing chapters;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-203(1)(f): establishing advisory peer committees to the board and prescribing their scope of authority; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-203(1)(g): establishing conditions for reinstatement and renewal of licenses.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-203(2): (1); (1); Title 58, Chapter 55, Utah Construction Trades Licensing Act Notwithstanding Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-301 License application -- Licensing procedure.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-301(1): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act; Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act; 63G-2-302(1)(i); (1)(b)(ii)(B); 63G-2-302
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-301(1)(a): Each license applicant shall apply to the division in writing upon forms available from the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-301(1)(b): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act; Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act Each completed application shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-301(1)(b)(i): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act contain documentation of the particular qualifications required of the applicant under this title or rules made by the division in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-301(1)(b)(ii): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act include the applicant's:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-301(1)(b)(ii)(A): full legal name; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-301(1)(b)(ii)(B): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act social security number, or other satisfactory evidence of the applicant's identity permitted under rules made by the division in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-301(1)(b)(iii): be verified by the applicant; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-301(1)(b)(iv): be accompanied by the appropriate fees.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-301(1)(c): 63G-2-302(1)(i) An applicant's social security number is a private record under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-301(1)(d): (1)(b)(ii)(B); 63G-2-302 The division may designate an applicant's evidence of identity under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-301(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-301(2)(a): The division shall issue a license to an applicant who submits a complete application if the division determines that the applicant meets the qualifications of licensure.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-301(2)(b): The division shall provide a written notice of additional proceedings to an applicant who submits a complete application, but who has been, is, or will be placed under investigation by the division for conduct directly bearing upon the applicant's qualifications for licensure, if the outcome of additional proceedings is required to determine the division's response to the application.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-301(2)(c): The division shall provide a written notice of denial of licensure to an applicant who submits a complete application if the division determines that the applicant does not meet the qualifications of licensure.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-301(2)(d): The division shall provide a written notice of incomplete application and conditional denial of licensure to an applicant who submits an incomplete application, which notice shall advise the applicant that the application is incomplete and that the application is denied, unless the applicant corrects the deficiencies within the time period specified in the notice and otherwise meets all qualifications for licensure.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-301(3): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act The division may only issue a license to an applicant under this title if the applicant meets the requirements for that license as established under this title and by division rule made in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-301(4): If an applicant meets all requirements for a specific license, the division shall issue the license to the applicant.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-301(5): (5); (5)(c); Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act; (5)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-301(5)(a): (5) As used in this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-301(5)(a)(i): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-301(5)(a)(i)(A): "Competency-based licensing requirement" means a practical assessment of knowledge and skills that clearly demonstrate a person is prepared to engage in an occupation or profession regulated by this title, and which the director determines is at least as effective as a time-based licensing requirement at demonstrating proficiency and protecting the health and safety of the public.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-301(5)(a)(i)(B): "Competency-based licensing requirement" may include any combination of training, experience, testing, or observation.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-301(5)(a)(ii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-301(5)(a)(ii)(A): "Time-based licensing requirement" means a specific number of hours, weeks, months, or years of education, training, supervised training, or other experience that an applicant for licensure under this title is required to complete before receiving a license under this title.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-301(5)(a)(ii)(B): "Time-based licensing requirement" does not include an associate degree, a bachelor's degree, or a graduate degree from an accredited institution of higher education.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-301(5)(b): (5)(c); Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act Subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-301(5)(c): (5)(b) If a time-based licensing requirement involves a program that must be approved or accredited by a specific entity or board, the director may only allow an applicant to complete a competency-based licensing requirement as an alternative to completing the time-based licensing requirement under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-301.3 Waiver of licensing fees.
----------------------------------------------------------
An individual applying for initial licensure or licensure renewal under this title may apply for initial licensure or licensure renewal without paying the fees described in SubsectionUtah Code Annotated § 58-1-301.3(1): on full-time active service with a branch of the armed forces of the United States, including an applicant who is on full-time active duty orders with the National Guard or reserve component of the armed forces; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-301.3(2): 35A-3-302; 35A-3-401 receiving public assistance through one of the following programs administered by the Department of Workforce Services:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-301.3(2)(a): 35A-3-302 the Family Employment Program described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-301.3(2)(b): 35A-3-401 General Assistance described in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-301.7 Change of information.
-------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-301.7(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-301.7(1)(a): An applicant, licensee, or certificate holder shall notify the division within 10 business days of a change in mailing address or email address.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-301.7(1)(b): When providing a mailing address, the individual may provide a post office box or other mail drop location.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-301.7(1)(c): In addition to providing a mailing address, an applicant, licensee, or certificate holder shall provide to the division, in a form approved by the division, an email address.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-301.7(2): An applicant, licensee, or certificate holder is considered to have received a notification that has been sent to the most recent:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-301.7(2)(a): mailing address provided to the division by the applicant, licensee, or certificate holder; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-301.7(2)(b): email address furnished to the division by the applicant, licensee, or certificate holder.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-302 License by endorsement.
------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-302(1): As used in this section, "license" means an authorization that permits the holder to engage in the practice of a profession regulated under this title.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-302(2): (4); (7) Subject to Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-302(2)(a): the division determines that the license issued in the other state, district, or territory encompasses a similar scope of practice as the license sought in this state;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-302(2)(b): the applicant has at least one year of experience practicing under the license issued in the other state, district, or territory; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-302(2)(c): the applicant's license is in good standing in the other state, district, or territory where the license was issued.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-302(3): (4); (7) Subject to Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-302(3)(a): has been licensed in another state, district, or territory of the United States, or in a jurisdiction outside of the United States, if:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-302(3)(a)(i): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-302(3)(a)(i)(A): the division determines that the applicant's education, experience, and skills demonstrate competency in the profession for which the licensure is sought in this state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-302(3)(a)(i)(B): the applicant has at least one year of experience practicing under the license issued in the other state, district, territory, or jurisdiction; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-302(3)(a)(ii): the division determines that the licensure requirements of the other state, district, territory, or jurisdiction at the time the license was issued were substantially similar to the current requirements for the license sought in this state; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-302(3)(b): has never been licensed in a state, district, or territory of the United States, or in a jurisdiction outside of the United States, if:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-302(3)(b)(i): the applicant was educated in or obtained relevant experience in a state, district, or territory of the United States, or a jurisdiction outside of the United States; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-302(3)(b)(ii): the division determines that the education or experience was substantially similar to the current education or experience requirements for the license sought in this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-302(4): The division may refuse to issue a license to an applicant under this section if:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-302(4)(a): the division determines that there is reasonable cause to believe that the applicant is not qualified to receive the license in this state; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-302(4)(b): the applicant has a previous or pending disciplinary action related to the applicant's license.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-302(5): 63J-1-504 Before the division issues a license to an applicant under this section, the applicant shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-302(5)(a): 63J-1-504 pay a fee determined by the department under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-302(5)(b): produce satisfactory evidence of the applicant's identity, qualifications, and good standing in the profession for which licensure is sought in this state.

Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-302(7): 58-1-107 In accordance with Section


Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-302.1 Temporary license for telemedicine.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-302.1(1): 26-60-102 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-302.1(1)(a): "Nonresident health care license" means a health care license issued by another state, district, or territory of the United States.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-302.1(1)(b): 26-60-102 "Telemedicine service" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-302.1(2): An individual with a temporary license issued under this section is authorized to provide a telemedicine service if:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-302.1(2)(a): the telemedicine service is a service the individual is licensed to perform under the nonresident health care license of the state, district, or territory that issued the nonresident health care license;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-302.1(2)(b): at the time the telemedicine service is performed, the patient is located in Utah; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-302.1(2)(c): performing the telemedicine service would not otherwise violate state law.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-302.1(3): (2); 58-1-302 The division shall issue a temporary license described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-302.1(3)(a): 58-1-302 the individual has completed an application for a license by endorsement in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-302.1(3)(b): the division determines that they will not be able to process the application within 15 days from the day on which the application is submitted.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-302.1(4): 58-1-302 The division may not charge a fee for a temporary license issued under this section beyond the fee required for a license issued under Section


Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-303 Temporary license.
-------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-303(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-303(1)(a): The division may issue a temporary license to a person who has met all license requirements except the passing of an examination. In this case:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-303(1)(a)(i): the licensee shall take the next available examination; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-303(1)(a)(ii): the temporary license automatically expires upon release of official examination results if the applicant fails the examination.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-303(1)(b): The division may issue a temporary license to a person licensed in another state or country who is in Utah temporarily to teach or assist a Utah resident licensed to practice an occupation or profession under this title.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-303(1)(c): The division may issue a temporary license to a person licensed in another state who met the requirements for licensure in that state, which were equal to or greater than the requirements for licensure of this state at the time the license was obtained in the other state, upon a finding by the division, in collaboration with the appropriate board, that the issuance of a temporary license is necessary to or justified by:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-303(1)(c)(i): a local or national emergency or any governmental action causing an unusual circumstance that might be reasonably considered to materially jeopardize the public health, safety, or welfare if a temporary license is not issued;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-303(1)(c)(ii): a lack of necessary available services in any community or area of the state from an occupation or profession licensed under this title, if the lack of services might be reasonably considered to materially jeopardize the public health, safety, or welfare if a temporary license is not issued; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-303(1)(c)(iii): a need to first observe an applicant for licensure in this state in a monitored or supervised practice of the applicant's occupation or profession before a decision is made by the division either to grant or deny the applicant a regular license.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-303(2): (1)(a) The division may not issue a temporary license to a person who qualifies for one under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-303(3): The division may not issue a temporary license to a person solely because there is a competitive advantage enjoyed or a competitive disadvantage suffered by any party caused by the absence of a licensed person, unless in addition there is or will be a material risk presented to the public health, safety, or welfare.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-304 Restricted license.
--------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-304(1): The division may issue a restricted or probationary license to an applicant for licensure, renewal, or reinstatement of licensure if:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-304(1)(a): the applicant appears to meet the qualifications for licensure, but has engaged in unlawful, unprofessional, or other conduct bearing upon the applicant's qualifications; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-304(1)(b): the division determines the need to observe the applicant in a monitored or supervised practice of the applicant's occupation or profession or to attach other reasonable restrictions or conditions upon the applicant in order to accommodate licensure, while protecting the public health, safety, and welfare.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-304(2): Issuance of a restricted or probationary license is considered a partial denial of licensure that is subject to agency review.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-305 Inactive license.
------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-305(1): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-305(1)(a): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act In accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-305(1)(b): The rules shall specify the requirements and procedures for placing a license on inactive status, the length of time a license may remain on inactive status, and the requirements and procedures to activate an inactive license.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-305(2): Except as otherwise specified by rule, an inactive licensee has no right or privilege to engage in the practice of the licensed occupation or profession.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-305(3): The division shall waive the renewal fee for a person holding or applying for an inactive license, if at the time of the application for or renewal of the inactive license, the person is on full-time active service with a branch of the armed forces of the United States, including a person who is on full-time active duty orders with the National Guard or reserve component of the armed forces.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-306 Surrender of license.
----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-306(1): The division may, by written agreement, accept the voluntary surrender of a license.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-306(2): Unless otherwise stated in the written agreement, tender and acceptance of a voluntary surrender of a license does not foreclose the division from pursuing additional disciplinary or other action authorized under this title or in rules adopted under this title.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-306(3): Unless otherwise stated in the written agreement, tender and acceptance of a voluntary surrender of a license terminates all rights and privileges associated with the license.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-306(4): Unless otherwise stated in the written agreement, the surrendered rights and privileges of licensure may be reacquired only by reapplying for licensure and meeting the requirements for a new or reinstated license set forth under this title or in rules adopted under this title.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-306(5): Unless otherwise stated in the written agreement, documentation of tender and acceptance of a voluntary surrender of a license is a public record.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-306(6): Unless otherwise stated in the written agreement, when a  tender and acceptance of a voluntary surrender of a license occurs while adjudicative proceedings are pending against the licensee for unprofessional or unlawful conduct, the division may report the surrender of license to appropriate state and federal agencies and licensing data banks.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307 Exemptions from licensure.
---------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(1): Except as otherwise provided by statute or rule, the following individuals may engage in the practice of their occupation or profession, subject to the stated circumstances and limitations, without being licensed under this title:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(1)(a): an individual serving in the armed forces of the United States, the United States Public Health Service, the United States Department of Veterans Affairs, or other federal agencies while engaged in activities regulated under this chapter as a part of employment with that federal agency if the individual holds a valid license to practice a regulated occupation or profession issued by any other state or jurisdiction recognized by the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(1)(b): a student engaged in activities constituting the practice of a regulated occupation or profession while in training in a recognized school approved by the division to the extent the activities are supervised by qualified faculty, staff, or designee and the activities are a defined part of the training program;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(1)(c): an individual engaged in an internship, residency, preceptorship, postceptorship, fellowship, apprenticeship, or on-the-job training program approved by the division while under the supervision of qualified individuals;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(1)(d): an individual residing in another state and licensed to practice a regulated occupation or profession in that state, who is called in for a consultation by an individual licensed in this state, and the services provided are limited to that consultation;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(1)(e): an individual who is invited by a recognized school, association, society, or other body approved by the division to conduct a lecture, clinic, or demonstration of the practice of a regulated occupation or profession if the individual does not establish a place of business or regularly engage in the practice of the regulated occupation or profession in this state;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(1)(f): an individual licensed under the laws of this state, other than under this title, to practice or engage in an occupation or profession, while engaged in the lawful, professional, and competent practice of that occupation or profession;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(1)(g): an individual licensed in a health care profession in another state who performs that profession while attending to the immediate needs of a patient for a reasonable period during which the patient is being transported from outside of this state, into this state, or through this state;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(1)(h): an individual licensed in another state or country who is in this state temporarily to attend to the needs of an athletic team or group, except that the practitioner may only attend to the needs of the athletic team or group, including all individuals who travel with the team or group in any capacity except as a spectator;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(1)(i): an individual licensed and in good standing in another state, who is in this state:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(1)(i)(i): temporarily, under the invitation and control of a sponsoring entity;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(1)(i)(ii): for a reason associated with a special purpose event, based upon needs that may exceed the ability of this state to address through its licensees, as determined by the division; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(1)(i)(iii): for a limited period of time not to exceed the duration of that event, together with any necessary preparatory and conclusionary periods; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(1)(j): the spouse of an individual serving in the armed forces of the United States while the individual is stationed within this state, provided:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(1)(j)(i): the spouse holds a valid license to practice a regulated occupation or profession issued by any other state or jurisdiction recognized by the division; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(1)(j)(ii): the license is current and the spouse is in good standing in the state of licensure.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(2): (1)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(2)(a): (1) A practitioner temporarily in this state who is exempted from licensure under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(2)(b): Violation of a limitation imposed by this section constitutes grounds for removal of exempt status, denial of license, or other disciplinary proceedings.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(3): An individual who is licensed under a specific chapter of this title to practice or engage in an occupation or profession may engage in the lawful, professional, and competent practice of that occupation or profession without additional licensure under other chapters of this title, except as otherwise provided by this title.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(4): 26B-7-301; (4); (5); Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act; Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act; Chapter 31b, Nurse Practice Act; Chapter 31e, Nurse Licensure Compact - Revised; Chapter 44a, Nurse Midwife Practice Act; Chapter 17b, Pharmacy Practice Act; Chapter 57, Respiratory Care Practices Act; Chapter 69, Dentist and Dental Hygienist Practice Act; Chapter 70a, Utah Physician Assistant Act; (4); (5); 26B-4-116; 58-17b-620(3); (6); 26A-1-126; Title 26B, Chapter 4, Part 8, Uniform Emergency Volunteer Health Practitioners Act; Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act; Chapter 55, Utah Construction Trades Licensing Act Upon the declaration of a national, state, or local emergency, a public health emergency as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(4)(a): suspend the requirements for permanent or temporary licensure of individuals who are licensed in another state for the duration of the emergency while engaged in the scope of practice for which they are licensed in the other state;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(4)(b): (4); (5); Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act; Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act; Chapter 31b, Nurse Practice Act; Chapter 31e, Nurse Licensure Compact - Revised; Chapter 44a, Nurse Midwife Practice Act; Chapter 17b, Pharmacy Practice Act; Chapter 57, Respiratory Care Practices Act; Chapter 69, Dentist and Dental Hygienist Practice Act; Chapter 70a, Utah Physician Assistant Act modify, under the circumstances described in this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(4)(b)(i): Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act; Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act a physician under

Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(4)(b)(vi): Chapter 69, Dentist and Dental Hygienist Practice Act a dentist and dental hygienist under

Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(5)(b): must be engaged in the distribution of medicines or medical devices in response to the emergency or declaration; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(5)(c): 26B-4-801 must be employed by or volunteering for:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(5)(c)(i): a local or state department of health; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(5)(c)(ii): 26B-4-801 a host entity as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(6): (8); 26B-7-323(1); (6)(b)(ii)(A); (D) In accordance with the protocols established under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(6)(a): use a vaccine, antiviral, antibiotic, or other prescription medication that is not a controlled substance to prevent or treat a disease or condition that gave rise to, or was a consequence of, the emergency; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(6)(b): (6)(b)(ii)(A); (D) distribute a vaccine, antiviral, antibiotic, or other prescription medication that is not a controlled substance:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(6)(b)(i): if necessary, to replenish a commercial pharmacy in the event that the commercial pharmacy's normal source of the vaccine, antiviral, antibiotic, or other prescription medication is exhausted; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(6)(b)(ii): (6)(b)(ii)(A); (D) for dispensing or direct administration to treat the disease or condition that gave rise to, or was a consequence of, the emergency by:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(6)(b)(ii)(A): a pharmacy;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(6)(b)(ii)(B): a prescribing practitioner;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(6)(b)(ii)(C): a licensed health care facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(6)(b)(ii)(D): a federally qualified community health clinic; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(6)(b)(ii)(E): (6)(b)(ii)(A); (D) a governmental entity for use by a community more than 50 miles from a person described in Subsections

Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(8): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act The Department of Health and Human Services shall establish by rule, made in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(8)(a): coordinate the distribution of:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(8)(a)(i): a vaccine, an antiviral, an antibiotic, or other prescription medication that is not a controlled substance received by the Department of Health and Human Services from the strategic national stockpile to local health departments; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(8)(a)(ii): a vaccine, an antiviral, an antibiotic, or other non-controlled prescription medication received by a local health department to emergency personnel within the local health department's geographic region;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(8)(b): authorize the dispensing, administration, or distribution of a vaccine, an antiviral, an antibiotic, or other prescription medication that is not a controlled substance to the contact of a patient without a patient-practitioner relationship, if the contact's condition is the same as that of the physician's or physician assistant's patient; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(8)(c): authorize the administration, distribution, or dispensing of a vaccine, an antiviral, an antibiotic, or other non-controlled prescription medication to an individual who:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(8)(c)(i): is working in a triage situation;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(8)(c)(ii): is receiving preventative or medical treatment in a triage situation;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(8)(c)(iii): does not have coverage for the prescription in the individual's health insurance plan;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(8)(c)(iv): is involved in the delivery of medical or other emergency services in response to the declared national, state, or local emergency; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(8)(c)(v): otherwise has a direct impact on public health.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(9): (8) The Department of Health and Human Services shall give notice to the division upon implementation of the protocol established under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307 Exemptions from licensure.
---------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(1): Except as otherwise provided by statute or rule, the following individuals may engage in the practice of their occupation or profession, subject to the stated circumstances and limitations, without being licensed under this title:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(1)(a): an individual serving in the armed forces of the United States, the United States Public Health Service, the United States Department of Veterans Affairs, or other federal agencies while engaged in activities regulated under this chapter as a part of employment with that federal agency if the individual holds a valid license to practice a regulated occupation or profession issued by any other state or jurisdiction recognized by the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(1)(b): a student engaged in activities constituting the practice of a regulated occupation or profession while in training in a recognized school approved by the division to the extent the activities are supervised by qualified faculty, staff, or designee and the activities are a defined part of the training program;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(1)(c): an individual engaged in an internship, residency, preceptorship, postceptorship, fellowship, apprenticeship, or on-the-job training program approved by the division while under the supervision of qualified individuals;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(1)(d): an individual residing in another state and licensed to practice a regulated occupation or profession in that state, who is called in for a consultation by an individual licensed in this state, and the services provided are limited to that consultation;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(1)(e): an individual who is invited by a recognized school, association, society, or other body approved by the division to conduct a lecture, clinic, or demonstration of the practice of a regulated occupation or profession if the individual does not establish a place of business or regularly engage in the practice of the regulated occupation or profession in this state;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(1)(f): an individual licensed under the laws of this state, other than under this title, to practice or engage in an occupation or profession, while engaged in the lawful, professional, and competent practice of that occupation or profession;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(1)(g): an individual licensed in a health care profession in another state who performs that profession while attending to the immediate needs of a patient for a reasonable period during which the patient is being transported from outside of this state, into this state, or through this state;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(1)(h): an individual licensed in another state or country who is in this state temporarily to attend to the needs of an athletic team or group, except that the practitioner may only attend to the needs of the athletic team or group, including all individuals who travel with the team or group in any capacity except as a spectator;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(1)(i): an individual licensed and in good standing in another state, who is in this state:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(1)(i)(i): temporarily, under the invitation and control of a sponsoring entity;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(1)(i)(ii): for a reason associated with a special purpose event, based upon needs that may exceed the ability of this state to address through its licensees, as determined by the division; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(1)(i)(iii): for a limited period of time not to exceed the duration of that event, together with any necessary preparatory and conclusionary periods; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(1)(j): the spouse of an individual serving in the armed forces of the United States while the individual is stationed within this state, provided:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(1)(j)(i): the spouse holds a valid license to practice a regulated occupation or profession issued by any other state or jurisdiction recognized by the division; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(1)(j)(ii): the license is current and the spouse is in good standing in the state of licensure.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(2): (1)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(2)(a): (1) A practitioner temporarily in this state who is exempted from licensure under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(2)(b): Violation of a limitation imposed by this section constitutes grounds for removal of exempt status, denial of license, or other disciplinary proceedings.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(3): An individual who is licensed under a specific chapter of this title to practice or engage in an occupation or profession may engage in the lawful, professional, and competent practice of that occupation or profession without additional licensure under other chapters of this title, except as otherwise provided by this title.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(4): 26B-7-301; (4); (5); Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act; Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act; Chapter 31b, Nurse Practice Act; Chapter 31e, Nurse Licensure Compact - Revised; Chapter 44a, Nurse Midwife Practice Act; Chapter 17b, Pharmacy Practice Act; Chapter 57, Respiratory Care Practices Act; Chapter 69, Dentist and Dental Hygienist Practice Act; Chapter 70a, Utah Physician Assistant Act; (4); (5); 53-2d-402; 58-17b-620(3); (6); 26A-1-126; Title 26B, Chapter 4, Part 8, Uniform Emergency Volunteer Health Practitioners Act; Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act; Chapter 55, Utah Construction Trades Licensing Act Upon the declaration of a national, state, or local emergency, a public health emergency as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(4)(a): suspend the requirements for permanent or temporary licensure of individuals who are licensed in another state for the duration of the emergency while engaged in the scope of practice for which they are licensed in the other state;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(4)(b): (4); (5); Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act; Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act; Chapter 31b, Nurse Practice Act; Chapter 31e, Nurse Licensure Compact - Revised; Chapter 44a, Nurse Midwife Practice Act; Chapter 17b, Pharmacy Practice Act; Chapter 57, Respiratory Care Practices Act; Chapter 69, Dentist and Dental Hygienist Practice Act; Chapter 70a, Utah Physician Assistant Act modify, under the circumstances described in this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(4)(b)(i): Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act; Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act a physician under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307(4)(b)(ii): Chapter 31b, Nurse Practice Act; Chapter 31e, Nurse Licensure Compact - Revised a nurse under

Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-307.1 Delegation of health care services -- Division duties.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The division, in consultation with the Department of Health, shall identify by rule made in accordance with

Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-308 Term of license -- Expiration of license -- Renewal of license -- Reinstatement of license -- Application procedures.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-308(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-308(1)(a): Each license issued under this title shall be issued in accordance with a two-year renewal cycle established by rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-308(1)(b): A renewal period may be extended or shortened by as much as one year to maintain established renewal cycles or to change an established renewal cycle.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-308(2): Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-308(2)(a): The expiration date of a license shall be shown on the license.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-308(2)(b): A license that is not renewed prior to the expiration date shown on the license automatically expires.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-308(2)(c): A license automatically expires prior to the expiration date shown on the license upon the death of a licensee who is a natural person, or upon the dissolution of a licensee that is a partnership, corporation, or other business entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-308(2)(d): If the existence of a dissolved partnership, corporation, or other business entity is reinstated prior to the expiration date shown upon the entity's expired license issued by the division, the division shall, upon written application, reinstate the applicant's license, unless it finds that the applicant no longer meets the qualifications for licensure.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-308(2)(e): Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act Expiration of licensure is not an adjudicative proceeding under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-308(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-308(3)(a): The division shall notify each licensee in accordance with procedures established by rule that the licensee's license is due for renewal and that unless an application for renewal is received by the division by the expiration date shown on the license, together with the appropriate renewal fee and documentation showing completion of or compliance with renewal qualifications, the license will not be renewed.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-308(3)(b): Examples of renewal qualifications which by statute or rule the division may require the licensee to document completion of or compliance with include:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-308(3)(b)(i): continuing education;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-308(3)(b)(ii): continuing competency;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-308(3)(b)(iii): quality assurance;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-308(3)(b)(iv): utilization plan and protocol;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-308(3)(b)(v): financial responsibility;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-308(3)(b)(vi): certification renewal; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-308(3)(b)(vii): calibration of equipment.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-308(4): (3); 58-1-301(2)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-308(4)(a): (3)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-308(4)(a)(i): (3) An application for renewal that complies with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-308(4)(a)(ii): A renewed license shall be issued to applicants who submit a complete application, unless it is apparent to the division that the applicant no longer meets the qualifications for continued licensure.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-308(4)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-308(4)(b)(i): The division may evaluate or verify documentation showing completion of or compliance with renewal requirements on an entire population or a random sample basis, and may be assisted by advisory peer committees.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-308(4)(b)(ii): If necessary, the division may complete its evaluation or verification subsequent to renewal and, if appropriate, pursue action to suspend or revoke the license of a licensee who no longer meets the qualifications for continued licensure.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-308(4)(c): 58-1-301(2) The application procedures specified in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-308(5): 63J-1-504; Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act; 58-1-301(2)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-308(5)(a): 63J-1-504; Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act Any license that is not renewed may be reinstated:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-308(5)(a)(i): 63J-1-504 upon submission of an application for reinstatement, payment of the renewal fee together with a reinstatement fee determined by the department under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-308(5)(a)(ii): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-308(5)(a)(ii)(A): at any time within two years after nonrenewal; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-308(5)(a)(ii)(B): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act between two years and five years after nonrenewal, if established by rule made by the division in consultation with the applicable licensing board in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-308(5)(b): 58-1-301(2) The application procedures specified in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-308(5)(c): Except as otherwise provided by rule, a license that is reinstated no later than 120 days after it expires shall be retroactively reinstated to the date it expired.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-308(6): (5)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-308(6)(a): (5)(a) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-308(6)(b): Each licensee under this title who has been active in the licensed occupation or profession while in the full-time employ of the United States government or under license to practice that occupation or profession in any other state or territory of the United States may reinstate the licensee's license without taking an examination by submitting an application for reinstatement, paying the current annual renewal fee and the reinstatement fee, and submitting documentation showing completion of or compliance with any renewal qualifications at any time within six months after reestablishing domicile within Utah or terminating full-time government service.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-309 Laws and rules examination.
----------------------------------------------------------
In addition to qualifications for licensure or renewal of licensure enumerated in specific practice acts under this title, the division may by rule require an applicant to pass an examination of the laws and rules relevant to the occupation or profession to ensure familiarity with these laws and rules.

Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-310 Application for division determination regarding criminal conviction.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-310(1): An individual with a criminal record may apply to the division at any time for a determination of whether the individual's criminal record would disqualify the individual from obtaining a license in an occupation or profession regulated by this title if the individual has completed or were to complete all other licensing requirements for the occupation or profession.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-310(2): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act To receive a determination, the individual shall submit the application described in this section in a form prescribed by the division and shall include information regarding:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-310(2)(a): the individual's complete criminal conviction history;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-310(2)(b): what occupational or professional license the individual is interested in seeking;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-310(2)(c): what licensing requirements have been met by the individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-310(2)(d): what licensing requirements have not yet been met by the individual; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-310(2)(e): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act any other information required by the division as established by division rule made in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-310(3): 63J-1-504 The division may charge the individual a fee, established in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-310(4): Within 30 days of the day on which the division receives a completed application from an individual for a determination under this section, based on the statutory authority and administrative rules governing the occupation or profession at the time of the application, the division shall provide a written determination to the individual of whether the individual's criminal record would disqualify the individual from obtaining a license in an occupation or profession regulated by this title if the individual were to complete all other licensing requirements.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-310(5): (4) If the individual's criminal record would disqualify the individual from obtaining a license in an occupation or profession regulated by this title, the written determination described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-311 Required examinations in languages in addition to English.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
In order to encourage economic development in the state, the department may offer any required examination under this title, which is prepared by a national testing organization, in languages in addition to English.
