Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-401 Grounds for denial of license -- Disciplinary proceedings -- Time limitations -- Sanctions.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-401(1): The division shall refuse to issue a license to an applicant and shall refuse to renew or shall revoke, suspend, restrict, place on probation, or otherwise act upon the license of a licensee who does not meet the qualifications for licensure under this title.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-401(2): (7); 58-31b-401(7); 58-60-108(2); 58-61-401(2); 58-67-401(2); 58-68-401(2); 58-70a-401(2); 58-81-105 The division may refuse to issue a license to an applicant and may refuse to renew or may revoke, suspend, restrict, place on probation, issue a public reprimand to, or otherwise act upon the license of a licensee for the following reasons:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-401(2)(a): (7) subject to the provisions of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-401(2)(b): the applicant or licensee has engaged in unlawful conduct as defined by statute under this title;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-401(2)(c): the applicant or licensee has been determined to be mentally incompetent by a court of competent jurisdiction; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-401(2)(d): 58-31b-401(7); 58-60-108(2); 58-61-401(2); 58-67-401(2); 58-68-401(2); 58-70a-401(2); 58-81-105 subject to Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-401(3): A licensee whose license to practice an occupation or profession regulated by this title has been suspended, revoked, placed on probation, or restricted may apply for reinstatement of the license at reasonable intervals and upon compliance with conditions imposed upon the licensee by statute, rule, or terms of the license suspension, revocation, probation, or restriction.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-401(4): (1); (2) The division may issue cease and desist orders to:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-401(4)(a): (1); (2) a licensee or applicant who may be disciplined under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-401(4)(b): a person who engages in or represents that the person is engaged in an occupation or profession regulated under this title; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-401(4)(c): a person who otherwise violates this title or a rule adopted under this title.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-401(5): 58-1-502 The division may impose an administrative penalty in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-401(6): (6)(b); (6)(b)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-401(6)(a): (6)(b) The division may not take disciplinary action against a person for unprofessional or unlawful conduct under this title, unless the division enters into a stipulated agreement or initiates an adjudicative proceeding regarding the conduct within four years after the conduct is reported to the division, except under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-401(6)(b): (6)(b)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-401(6)(b)(i): The division may not take disciplinary action against a person for unprofessional or unlawful conduct more than 10 years after the occurrence of the conduct, unless the proceeding is in response to a civil or criminal judgment or settlement and the proceeding is initiated within one year following the judgment or settlement.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-401(6)(b)(ii): (6)(b)(i) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-401(7): When the division is determining whether to refuse to issue a license to an applicant, or to refuse to renew the license of a licensee, based solely on the criminal conviction of an applicant or licensee, the division shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-401(7)(a): provide individualized consideration to the applicant or licensee;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-401(7)(b): determine whether the criminal conviction bears a substantial relationship to the applicant's or licensee's ability to safely or competently practice the occupation or profession; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-401(7)(c): consider the applicant's or licensee's current circumstances, which may include any of the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-401(7)(c)(i): the age of the applicant or licensee when the applicant or licensee committed the offense;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-401(7)(c)(ii): the time that has elapsed since the applicant or licensee committed the offense;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-401(7)(c)(iii): whether the applicant or licensee has completed the applicant's or licensee's criminal sentence;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-401(7)(c)(iv): whether the applicant has completed or is actively participating in rehabilitative drug or alcohol treatment;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-401(7)(c)(v): any testimonials or recommendations from other individuals provided by the applicant or licensee, including a progress report from the applicant's or licensee's probation or parole officer;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-401(7)(c)(vi): other evidence of rehabilitation provided by the applicant or licensee;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-401(7)(c)(vii): the education and training of the applicant or licensee;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-401(7)(c)(viii): the employment history of the applicant or licensee; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-401(7)(c)(ix): other relevant information provided by the applicant or licensee.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-402 Administrative review -- Special appeals boards.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-402(1): (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-402(1)(a): Any applicant who has been denied a license to practice on the basis of credentials, character, a criminal record, or failure to pass a required examination, or who has been refused renewal or reinstatement of a license to practice on the basis that the applicant does not meet qualifications for continued licensure in any occupation or profession under the jurisdiction of the division may submit a request for agency review to the executive director within 30 days following notification of the denial of a license or refusal to renew or reinstate a license.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-402(1)(b): (2) The executive director shall determine whether the circumstances for denying an application for an initial license or for renewal or reinstatement of a license would justify calling a special appeals board under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-402(2): A special appeals board shall consist of three members appointed by the executive director as follows:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-402(2)(a): one member from the occupation or profession in question who is not on the board of that occupation or profession;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-402(2)(b): one member from the general public who is neither an attorney nor a practitioner in an occupation or profession regulated by the division; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-402(2)(c): one member who is a resident lawyer currently licensed to practice law in this state who shall serve as chair of the special appeals board.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-402(3): Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act The special appeals board shall comply with the procedures and requirements of
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-402(4): 63G-4-401; 63G-4-403
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-402(4)(a): Within a reasonable amount of time following the conclusion of a hearing before a special appeals board, the board shall enter an order based upon the record developed at the hearing.  The order shall state whether a legal basis exists for denying the application for an initial license or for renewal or reinstatement of a license that is the subject of the appeal.  The order is not subject to further agency review.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-402(4)(b): 63G-4-401; 63G-4-403 The division or the applicant may obtain judicial review of the decision of the special appeals board in accordance with Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-402(5): 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107; 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107 A member may not receive compensation or benefits for the member's service, but may receive per diem and travel expenses in accordance with:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-402(5)(a): 63A-3-106 Section

Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501 Unlawful and unprofessional conduct.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(1): (1)(f)(i) "Unlawful conduct" means conduct, by any person, that is defined as unlawful under this title and includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(1)(a): practicing or engaging in, representing oneself to be practicing or engaging in, or attempting to practice or engage in any profession requiring licensure under this title if the person is:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(1)(a)(i): not licensed to do so or not exempted from licensure under this title; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(1)(a)(ii): restricted from doing so by a suspended, revoked, restricted, temporary, probationary, or inactive license;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(1)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(1)(b)(i): impersonating another licensee or practicing a profession under a false or assumed name, except as permitted by law; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(1)(b)(ii): for a licensee who has had a license under this title reinstated following disciplinary action, practicing the same profession using a different name than the name used before the disciplinary action, except as permitted by law and after notice to, and approval by, the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(1)(c): knowingly employing any other person to practice or engage in or attempt to practice or engage in any profession licensed under this title if the employee is not licensed to do so under this title;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(1)(d): knowingly permitting the person's authority to practice or engage in any profession licensed under this title to be used by another, except as permitted by law;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(1)(e): obtaining a passing score on a licensure examination, applying for or obtaining a license, or otherwise dealing with the division or a licensing board through the use of fraud, forgery, or intentional deception, misrepresentation, misstatement, or omission;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(1)(f): (1)(f)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(1)(f)(i): issuing, or aiding and abetting in the issuance of, an order or prescription for a drug or device to a person located in this state:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(1)(f)(i)(A): without prescriptive authority conferred by a license issued under this title, or by an exemption to licensure under this title; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(1)(f)(i)(B): with prescriptive authority conferred by an exception issued under this title or a multistate practice privilege recognized under this title, if the prescription was issued without first obtaining information, in the usual course of professional practice, that is sufficient to establish a diagnosis, to identify underlying conditions, and to identify contraindications to the proposed treatment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(1)(f)(ii): (1)(f)(i) Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(1)(g): aiding or abetting any other person to violate any statute, rule, or order regulating a profession under this title.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(2): (4); 58-1-401; 58-1-501.5; 78B-3-403; (5); 58-1-501.6
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(2)(a): (4); 58-1-401; 58-1-501.5 "Unprofessional conduct" means conduct, by a licensee or applicant, that is defined as unprofessional conduct under this title or under any rule adopted under this title and includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(2)(a)(i): violating any statute, rule, or order regulating an a profession under this title;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(2)(a)(ii): violating, or aiding or abetting any other person to violate, any generally accepted professional or ethical standard applicable to an occupation or profession regulated under this title;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(2)(a)(iii): (4) subject to the provisions of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(2)(a)(iv): 58-1-401 engaging in conduct that results in disciplinary action, including reprimand, censure, diversion, probation, suspension, or revocation, by any other licensing or regulatory authority having jurisdiction over the licensee or applicant in the same profession if the conduct would, in this state, constitute grounds for denial of licensure or disciplinary proceedings under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(2)(a)(v): engaging in conduct, including the use of intoxicants, drugs, narcotics, or similar chemicals, to the extent that the conduct does, or might reasonably be considered to, impair the ability of the licensee or applicant to safely engage in the profession;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(2)(a)(vi): practicing or attempting to practice a profession regulated under this title despite being physically or mentally unfit to do so;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(2)(a)(vii): practicing or attempting to practice a or profession regulated under this title through gross incompetence, gross negligence, or a pattern of incompetency or negligence;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(2)(a)(viii): practicing or attempting to practice a profession requiring licensure under this title by any form of action or communication which is false, misleading, deceptive, or fraudulent;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(2)(a)(ix): practicing or attempting to practice a profession regulated under this title beyond the scope of the licensee's competency, abilities, or education;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(2)(a)(x): practicing or attempting to practice a profession regulated under this title beyond the scope of the licensee's license;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(2)(a)(xi): verbally, physically, mentally, or sexually abusing or exploiting any person through conduct connected with the licensee's practice under this title or otherwise facilitated by the licensee's license;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(2)(a)(xii): acting as a supervisor without meeting the qualification requirements for that position that are defined by statute or rule;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(2)(a)(xiii): issuing, or aiding and abetting in the issuance of, an order or prescription for a drug or device:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(2)(a)(xiii)(A): without first obtaining information in the usual course of professional practice, that is sufficient to establish a diagnosis, to identify conditions, and to identify contraindications to the proposed treatment; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(2)(a)(xiii)(B): with prescriptive authority conferred by an exception issued under this title, or a multi-state practice privilege recognized under this title, if the prescription was issued without first obtaining information, in the usual course of professional practice, that is sufficient to establish a diagnosis, to identify underlying conditions, and to identify contraindications to the proposed treatment;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(2)(a)(xiv): 58-1-501.5 violating a provision of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(2)(a)(xv): violating the terms of an order governing a license; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(2)(a)(xvi): violating Section 58-1-511.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(2)(b): 78B-3-403; (5); 58-1-501.6 "Unprofessional conduct" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(2)(b)(i): 78B-3-403; (5) a health care provider, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(2)(b)(ii): 58-1-501.6 notwithstanding Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(2)(b)(ii)(A): does not guarantee any results regarding any health care service;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(2)(b)(ii)(B): fully discloses on the health care provider's website that the health care provider deviates from medical norms or established practices with a conspicuous statement; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(2)(b)(ii)(C): includes the health care provider's contact information on the website.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(3): Unless otherwise specified by statute or administrative rule, in a civil or administrative proceeding commenced by the division under this title, a person subject to any of the unlawful and unprofessional conduct provisions of this title is strictly liable for each violation.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(4): (2)(a)(iii); 76-3-203.5; Title 76, Chapter 5, Part 4, Sexual Offenses; Title 76, Chapter 5b, Sexual Exploitation Act; Title 76, Chapter 6, Part 5, Fraud; Title 76, Chapter 6, Part 4, Theft The following are not evidence of engaging in unprofessional conduct under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(4)(a): an arrest not followed by a conviction; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(4)(b): 76-3-203.5; Title 76, Chapter 5, Part 4, Sexual Offenses; Title 76, Chapter 5b, Sexual Exploitation Act; Title 76, Chapter 6, Part 5, Fraud; Title 76, Chapter 6, Part 4, Theft a conviction for which an individual's incarceration has ended more than seven years before the date of the division's consideration, unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(4)(b)(i): after the incarceration the individual has engaged in additional conduct that results in another conviction, a plea of nolo contendere, or a plea of guilty or nolo contendere that is held in abeyance pending the successful completion of probation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(4)(b)(ii): 76-3-203.5; Title 76, Chapter 5, Part 4, Sexual Offenses; Title 76, Chapter 5b, Sexual Exploitation Act; Title 76, Chapter 6, Part 5, Fraud; Title 76, Chapter 6, Part 4, Theft the conviction was for:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(4)(b)(ii)(A): 76-3-203.5 a violent felony as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(4)(b)(ii)(B): Title 76, Chapter 5, Part 4, Sexual Offenses; Title 76, Chapter 5b, Sexual Exploitation Act a felony related to a criminal sexual act under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(4)(b)(ii)(C): Title 76, Chapter 6, Part 5, Fraud; Title 76, Chapter 6, Part 4, Theft a felony related to criminal fraud or embezzlement, including a felony under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(5): (2)(b)(i) In accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(5)(a): the health care provider does not deviate outside of the health care provider's scope of practice and possesses the education, training, and experience to competently and safely administer the alternative health care service;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(5)(b): the health care provider does not provide an alternative health care service that is otherwise contrary to any state or federal law;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(5)(c): the alternative health care service has reasonable potential to be of benefit to the patient to whom the alternative health care service is to be given;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(5)(d): the potential benefit of the alternative health care service outweighs the known harms or side effects of the alternative health care service;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(5)(e): the alternative health care service is reasonably justified under the totality of the circumstances;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(5)(f): after diagnosis but before providing the alternative health care service:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(5)(f)(i): the health care provider educates the patient on the health care services that are within the medical norms and established practices;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(5)(f)(ii): the health care provider discloses to the patient that the health care provider is recommending an alternative health care service that deviates from medical norms and established practices;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(5)(f)(iii): the health care provider discusses the rationale for deviating from medical norms and established practices with the patient;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(5)(f)(iv): the health care provider discloses any potential risks associated with deviation from medical norms and established practices; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(5)(f)(v): the patient signs and acknowledges a notice of deviation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(5)(g): before providing an alternative health care service, the health care provider discloses to the patient that the patient may enter into an agreement describing what would constitute the health care provider's negligence related to deviation.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(6): As used in this section, "notice of deviation" means a written notice provided by a health care provider to a patient that:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(6)(a): is specific to the patient;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(6)(b): indicates that the health care provider is deviating from medical norms or established practices in the health care provider's recommendation for the patient's treatment;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(6)(c): describes how the alternative health care service deviates from medical norms or established practices;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(6)(d): describes the potential risks and benefits associated with the alternative health care service;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(6)(e): describes the health care provider's reasonably justified rationale regarding the reason for the deviation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501(6)(f): provides clear and unequivocal notice to the patient that the patient is agreeing to receive the alternative health care service which is outside medical norms and established practices.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.3 Health professional prescribing exceptions for expedited partner therapy for sexually transmitted diseases.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.3(1): 58-17b-102 For purposes of this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.3(1)(a): 58-17b-102 "Drug to treat a sexually transmitted disease" means a drug:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.3(1)(a)(i): 58-17b-102 as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.3(1)(a)(ii): that is:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.3(1)(a)(ii)(A): an antibiotic; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.3(1)(a)(ii)(B): prescribed in accordance with guidelines from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention for patient delivered expedited partner therapy in the management of sexually transmitted disease.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.3(1)(b): "Partner" means a person:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.3(1)(b)(i): with whom a practitioner does not have a bonafide practitioner-patient relationship; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.3(1)(b)(ii): who is identified as, or claims to be a sexual partner of a patient.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.3(1)(c): "Patient" means a person who:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.3(1)(c)(i): has a sexually transmitted disease; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.3(1)(c)(ii): has a bonafide practitioner-patient relationship with a practitioner.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.3(1)(d): "Sexually transmitted disease" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.3(1)(d)(i): gonorrhea; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.3(1)(d)(ii): chlamydia.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.3(2): This section does not require a practitioner or a licensee under this chapter to prescribe or dispense a drug to treat a sexually transmitted disease for patient delivered expedited partner therapy.  A practitioner's or licensee's decision to use expedited partner therapy as allowed by this section is voluntary.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.3(3): 58-1-501; 58-17b-501; 58-17b-502; (3); 58-17b-610; (3) Notwithstanding Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.3(3)(a): (3); 58-17b-610 a practitioner, in accordance with this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.3(3)(a)(i): issues a prescription for a drug to treat a sexually transmitted disease to a partner by:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.3(3)(a)(i)(A): writing "partner of (patient name)" on the prescription order; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.3(3)(a)(i)(B): giving the partner's prescription to the patient for subsequent use by the partner; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.3(3)(a)(ii): 58-17b-610 notwithstanding Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.3(3)(b): (3) a pharmacist, in accordance with this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.3(3)(b)(i): a person who:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.3(3)(b)(i)(A): claims to be a partner; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.3(3)(b)(i)(B): presents a prescription for the drug to the pharmacist which is written for the unnamed partner of a named patient;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.3(3)(b)(ii): the patient for the subsequent use by the unnamed partner; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.3(3)(b)(iii): an agent of the patient or partner.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.3(4): (3); 58-17b-602; 58-17b-613
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.3(4)(a): (3); 58-17b-602 For purposes of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.3(4)(a)(i): the partner does not have to be identified on the prescription order by information that would disclose the identity of the partner; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.3(4)(a)(ii): when dispensing a drug to treat a sexually transmitted disease directly to the partner, the patient's identifying information may, but does not need to, be included on the partner's drug label.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.3(4)(b): 58-17b-613 Information provided by a pharmacist to a patient or the patient's agent for subsequent use by a partner satisfies the requirements of patient counseling for both the patient and the partner under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.3(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.3(5)(a): The Legislature finds that the prevention and treatment of sexually transmitted diseases in the state is a compelling public health issue.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.3(5)(b): A practitioner or licensee under this chapter is not liable for a medical malpractice action if the use of expedited partner therapy is in compliance with this section, except for those acts which are grossly negligent or willful and wanton.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.5 Anatomic pathology services -- Billing violations.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.5(1): 26B-2-201; Chapter 31b, Nurse Practice Act; Chapter 73, Chiropractic Physician Practice Act; Chapter 69, Dentist and Dental Hygienist Practice Act; Chapter 44a, Nurse Midwife Practice Act; Chapter 16a, Utah Optometry Practice Act; Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act; Chapter 5a, Podiatric Physician Licensing Act; Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act; Chapter 70a, Utah Physician Assistant Act; 31A-1-301; 31A-1-301 As used in this section, the following definitions apply:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.5(1)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.5(1)(a)(i): "Anatomic pathology services" including "technical or professional component of anatomic pathology services" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.5(1)(a)(i)(A): histopathology or surgical pathology, meaning the gross examination of, histologic processing of, or microscopic examination of human organ tissue performed by a physician or under the supervision of a physician;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.5(1)(a)(i)(B): cytopathology, meaning the examination of human cells, from fluids, aspirates, washings, brushings, or smears, including the pap test examination performed by a physician or under the supervision of a physician;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.5(1)(a)(i)(C): hematology, meaning the microscopic evaluation of human bone marrow aspirates and biopsies performed by a physician or under the supervision of a physician and peripheral human blood smears when the attending or treating physician or other practitioner of the healing arts or a technologist requests that a blood smear be reviewed by a pathologist;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.5(1)(a)(i)(D): subcellular pathology and molecular pathology; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.5(1)(a)(i)(E): blood bank services performed by a pathologist.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.5(1)(a)(ii): "Anatomic pathology services" including "technical or professional component of anatomic pathology services" does not include the initial collection or packaging of a sample for transport.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.5(1)(b): "Clinical laboratory" or "laboratory" means a facility for the biological, microbiological, serological, chemical, immunohematological, hematological, biophysical, cytological, pathological, or other examination of materials derived from the human body for the purpose of providing information for the diagnosis, prevention, or treatment of any disease or impairment of human beings or the assessment of the health of human beings.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.5(1)(c): 26B-2-201 "Health care facility" has the meaning provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.5(1)(d): Chapter 31b, Nurse Practice Act; Chapter 73, Chiropractic Physician Practice Act; Chapter 69, Dentist and Dental Hygienist Practice Act; Chapter 44a, Nurse Midwife Practice Act; Chapter 16a, Utah Optometry Practice Act; Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act; Chapter 5a, Podiatric Physician Licensing Act; Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act; Chapter 70a, Utah Physician Assistant Act "Health care provider" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.5(1)(d)(i): Chapter 31b, Nurse Practice Act an advanced practice registered nurse licensed under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.5(1)(d)(ii): Chapter 73, Chiropractic Physician Practice Act a chiropractic physician licensed under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.5(1)(d)(iii): Chapter 69, Dentist and Dental Hygienist Practice Act a dentist licensed under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.5(1)(d)(iv): Chapter 44a, Nurse Midwife Practice Act a nurse midwife licensed under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.5(1)(d)(v): Chapter 16a, Utah Optometry Practice Act an optometrist licensed under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.5(1)(d)(vi): Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act an osteopathic physician and surgeon licensed under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.5(1)(d)(vii): Chapter 5a, Podiatric Physician Licensing Act a podiatric physician licensed under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.5(1)(d)(viii): Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act a physician and surgeon licensed under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.5(1)(d)(ix): Chapter 70a, Utah Physician Assistant Act a physician assistant licensed under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.5(1)(e): 31A-1-301; 31A-1-301 "Insurer" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.5(1)(e)(i): 31A-1-301 any entity offering accident and health insurance as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.5(1)(e)(ii): workers' compensation benefits;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.5(1)(e)(iii): a health maintenance organization; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.5(1)(e)(iv): 31A-1-301 any self-insurance, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.5(2): (2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.5(2)(a): A health care provider who orders anatomic pathology services for a patient from an independent physician or laboratory may not directly or indirectly mark up, charge a commission, or make a profit on the anatomic pathology service provided by the independent physician or laboratory.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.5(2)(b): (2)(a) Nothing in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.5(2)(b)(i): restricts the ability of a health care provider, who has not performed or supervised either the technical or professional component of the anatomic pathology service, to obtain payment for services related solely to the collection and packaging of a sample and administrative billing costs; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.5(2)(b)(ii): restricts the ability of the lab function in the Department of Health and Human Services to bill for services.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.5(3): A health care provider when billing a patient directly for anatomic pathology services provided by an independent physician or laboratory shall furnish an itemized bill which conforms with the billing practices of the American Medical Association that conspicuously discloses the charge for each anatomic pathology service, physician or laboratory name, and address for each anatomic pathology service rendered to the patient by the physician or laboratory that performed the anatomic pathology service.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.5(4): (3) The disclosure to be made under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.5(5): Failure to comply with the requirements of this section shall be considered to be unprofessional conduct.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.6 Health care provider advertisements and disclosure -- Unprofessional conduct.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
For purposes of this section:Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.6(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.6(1)(a): "Advertisement" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.6(1)(a)(i): billboards;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.6(1)(a)(ii): written documents such as:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.6(1)(a)(ii)(A): brochures;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.6(1)(a)(ii)(B): pamphlets;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.6(1)(a)(ii)(C): direct mail solicitations;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.6(1)(a)(ii)(D): radio, television, and telephone solicitation scripts; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.6(1)(a)(ii)(E): telephone directories;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.6(1)(a)(iii): media, including television, radio, and Internet websites; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.6(1)(a)(iv): any other means of promotion intended to directly or indirectly induce a person to enter into an agreement for services with a health care provider.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.6(1)(b): "Advertisement" does not include materials that provide information about health care provider networks established by health insurance carriers.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.6(2): 78B-3-403 "Health care provider" means a natural person who is:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.6(2)(a): 78B-3-403 defined as a health care provider in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.6(2)(b): licensed under this title.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.6(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.6(3)(a): This section does not provide authority for a health care provider to advertise the services offered by the health care provider.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.6(3)(b): If a health care provider's licensing authority and professional ethics permit the health care provider to advertise, the provisions of this section apply to any advertisement for the health care provider's services, on or after July 1, 2011.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.6(4): An advertisement for a health care provider's services that includes the health care provider's name shall identify the license type, as used by the division, under which the health care provider is practicing.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.6(5): Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act; 58-67-102; Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act; 58-68-102
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.6(5)(a): Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act; 58-67-102 A physician licensed under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.6(5)(b): Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act; 58-68-102 A physician licensed under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.6(6): It is unprofessional conduct if a health care provider violates this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.7 Standards of conduct for prescription drug education -- Academic and commercial detailing.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.7(1): 58-37-2 For purposes of this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.7(1)(a): "Academic detailing":
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.7(1)(a)(i): means a health care provider who is licensed under this title to prescribe or dispense a prescription drug and employed by someone other than a pharmaceutical manufacturer:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.7(1)(a)(i)(A): for the purpose of countering information provided in commercial detailing; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.7(1)(a)(i)(B): to disseminate educational information about prescription drugs to other health care providers in an effort to better align clinical practice with scientific research; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.7(1)(a)(ii): does not include a health care provider who:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.7(1)(a)(ii)(A): is disseminating educational information about a prescription drug as part of teaching or supervising students or graduate medical education students at an institution of higher education or through a medical residency program;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.7(1)(a)(ii)(B): is disseminating educational information about a prescription drug to a patient or a patient's representative; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.7(1)(a)(ii)(C): is acting within the scope of practice for the health care provider regarding the prescribing or dispensing of a prescription drug.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.7(1)(b): "Commercial detailing" means an educational practice employed by a pharmaceutical manufacturer in which clinical information and evidence about a prescription drug is shared with health care professionals.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.7(1)(c): 58-37-2 "Manufacture" is as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.7(1)(d): "Pharmaceutical manufacturer" is a person who manufactures a prescription drug.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.7(2): (3)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.7(2)(a): (3) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.7(2)(b): An academic detailer and a commercial detailer who educate another health care provider about prescription drugs through written or oral educational material is subject to federal regulations regarding:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.7(2)(b)(i): false and misleading advertising in 21 C.F.R., Part 201 (2007);
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.7(2)(b)(ii): prescription drug advertising in 21 C.F.R., Part 202 (2007); and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.7(2)(b)(iii): the federal Office of the Inspector General's Compliance Program Guidance for Pharmaceutical Manufacturers issued in April 2003, as amended.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.7(2)(c): A person who is injured by a violation of this section has a private right of action against a person engaged in academic detailing, if:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.7(2)(c)(i): the actions of the person engaged in academic detailing, that are a violation of this section, are:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.7(2)(c)(i)(A): the result of gross negligence by the person; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.7(2)(c)(i)(B): willful and wanton behavior by the person; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.7(2)(c)(ii): the damages to the person are reasonable, foreseeable, and proximately caused by the violations of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.7(3): 31A-1-301; 26B-3-902; 26B-2-201; 58-17b-102; 13-5b-102; 26B-2-201
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.7(3)(a): 31A-1-301 For purposes of this Subsection, "accident and health insurance":
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.7(3)(a)(i): 31A-1-301 means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.7(3)(a)(ii): includes a self-funded health benefit plan and an administrator for a self-funded health benefit plan.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.7(3)(b): 26B-3-902; 26B-2-201; 58-17b-102; 13-5b-102 This section does not apply to a person who engages in academic detailing if that person is engaged in academic detailing on behalf of:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.7(3)(b)(i): 26B-3-902 a person who provides accident and health insurance, including when the person who provides accident and health insurance contracts with or offers:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.7(3)(b)(i)(A): the state Medicaid program, including the Primary Care Network within the state's Medicaid program;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.7(3)(b)(i)(B): 26B-3-902 the Children's Health Insurance Program created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.7(3)(b)(i)(C): a Medicare plan; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.7(3)(b)(i)(D): a Medicare supplement plan;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.7(3)(b)(ii): 26B-2-201 a hospital as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.7(3)(b)(iii): 58-17b-102 any class of pharmacy as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.7(3)(b)(iv): 13-5b-102 an integrated health system as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.7(3)(b)(v): a medical clinic.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.7(3)(c): 26B-2-201 This section does not apply to communicating or disseminating information about a prescription drug for the purpose of conducting research using prescription drugs at a health care facility as defined in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.8 Occupational and professional identification of health care providers -- Unlawful and unprofessional conduct -- Penalties.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.8(1): 78B-3-403; (1)(e)(i); (ii); 58-1-501.6 For purposes of this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.8(1)(a): "Badge" means a tag or badge in plain view:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.8(1)(a)(i): attached to a health care provider's clothing; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.8(1)(a)(ii): hanging from a lanyard around a health care provider's neck.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.8(1)(b): "Clothing" means a health care provider's outermost article of clothing that is visible to others.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.8(1)(c): "Deceptive or misleading conduct" means any affirmative communication or representation that falsely states, describes, holds out, or details an individual's licensure, training, education, or profession.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.8(1)(d): 78B-3-403 "Health care provider" means a natural person who is:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.8(1)(d)(i): 78B-3-403 defined as a health care provider in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.8(1)(d)(ii): licensed under this title.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.8(1)(e): (1)(e)(i); (ii) "Identification" means a badge or stitching, or permanent writing in plain view on clothing that:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.8(1)(e)(i): includes the health care provider's name;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.8(1)(e)(ii): includes the license type held by the health care provider;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.8(1)(e)(iii): is worn in a manner that is visible and apparent to others; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.8(1)(e)(iv): (1)(e)(i); (ii) contains the information required by Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.8(1)(e)(iv)(A): in a manner and of sufficient size that can be easily read; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.8(1)(e)(iv)(B): on both sides of the badge, unless the badge or tag is attached to clothing in a way that prevents the badge from rotating.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.8(1)(f): 58-1-501.6 "License type" means a designation of the license type that satisfies the requirements of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.8(1)(g): "Patient encounter" means an interaction in a health care facility, health care clinic, or office in which a patient can see a health care provider delivering services directly to a patient.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.8(2): (3); (4) Beginning January 1, 2015, except as provided in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.8(3): A health care provider's identification may be covered if required under sterilization or isolation protocols.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.8(4): A health care provider is not required to wear identification:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.8(4)(a): if wearing identification would jeopardize the health care provider's safety; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.8(4)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.8(4)(b)(i): in an office in which:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.8(4)(b)(i)(A): the license type and names of all health care providers working in the office are displayed on the office door; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.8(4)(b)(i)(B): each health care provider working in the office has the health care provider's license posted prominently in the office and readily visible to a patient; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.8(4)(b)(ii): if the office is an office:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.8(4)(b)(ii)(A): of a solo health care provider; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.8(4)(b)(ii)(B): of a single type of health care provider.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.8(5): An individual who is a student or is in training to obtain a license as a health care provider shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.8(5)(a): wear identification during patient encounters that identifies the person as in training, or a student, for the particular license type; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.8(5)(b): otherwise comply with the provisions of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.8(6): It is unprofessional conduct if a health care provider violates this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.8(7): It is unlawful conduct if an individual:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.8(7)(a): wears identification in a patient encounter that suggests that the individual is practicing or engaging in an occupation or profession that the individual may not lawfully practice or engage in under this title; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.8(7)(b): engages in deceptive or misleading conduct.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-501.8(8): 58-1-502 An individual who violates this section is subject to Section


Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-502 Unlawful and unprofessional conduct -- Penalties.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-502(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-502(1)(a): Unless otherwise specified in this title, a person who violates the unlawful conduct provisions defined in this title is guilty of a class A misdemeanor.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-502(1)(b): Unless a specific fine amount is specified elsewhere in this title, the director or the director's designee may assess an administrative fine of up to $1,000 for each instance of unprofessional or unlawful conduct defined in this title.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-502(2): 58-1-501(1)(a); (1)(c); (1)(g); (2)(a)(xv); Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act; (2); 58-1-501(1)(a); (1)(c); (1)(g); (2)(a)(xv); (2)(b)(i); 58-1-501(1)(a); (1)(c); (1)(g); (2)(a)(xv); 58-1-401; Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act; 58-1-401(6); (2)(a); (2)(a); (2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-502(2)(a): 58-1-501(1)(a); (1)(c); (1)(g); (2)(a)(xv); Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act In addition to any other statutory penalty for a violation related to a specific occupation or profession regulated by this title, if upon inspection or investigation, the division concludes that a person has violated Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-502(2)(a)(i): issue a citation to the person according to this section and any pertinent rules;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-502(2)(a)(ii): attempt to negotiate a stipulated settlement; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-502(2)(a)(iii): Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act notify the person to appear before an adjudicative proceeding conducted under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-502(2)(b): (2); 58-1-501(1)(a); (1)(c); (1)(g); (2)(a)(xv); (2)(b)(i); 58-1-501(1)(a); (1)(c); (1)(g); (2)(a)(xv)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-502(2)(b)(i): (2); 58-1-501(1)(a); (1)(c); (1)(g); (2)(a)(xv) The division may assess a fine under this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-502(2)(b)(i)(A): an uncontested citation;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-502(2)(b)(i)(B): a stipulated settlement; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-502(2)(b)(i)(C): a finding of a violation in an adjudicative proceeding.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-502(2)(b)(ii): (2)(b)(i); 58-1-501(1)(a); (1)(c); (1)(g); (2)(a)(xv) The division may, in addition to or in lieu of a fine under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-502(2)(c): 58-1-401 Except for a cease and desist order, the division may not assess the licensure sanctions cited in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-502(2)(d): Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act A citation shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-502(2)(d)(i): be in writing;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-502(2)(d)(ii): describe with particularity the nature of the violation, including a reference to the provision of the chapter, rule, or order alleged to have been violated;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-502(2)(d)(iii): Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act clearly state that the recipient must notify the division in writing within 20 calendar days of service of the citation if the recipient wishes to contest the citation at a hearing conducted under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-502(2)(d)(iv): clearly explain the consequences of failure to timely contest the citation or to make payment of a fine assessed by the citation within the time specified in the citation.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-502(2)(e): The division may issue a notice in lieu of a citation.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-502(2)(f): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-502(2)(f)(i): If within 20 calendar days from the service of the citation, the person to whom the citation was issued fails to request a hearing to contest the citation, the citation becomes the final order of the division and is not subject to further agency review.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-502(2)(f)(ii): The period to contest a citation may be extended by the division for cause.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-502(2)(g): The division may refuse to issue or renew, suspend, revoke, or place on probation the license of a licensee who fails to comply with a citation after it becomes final.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-502(2)(h): The failure of an applicant for licensure to comply with a citation after it becomes final is a ground for denial of license.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-502(2)(i): 58-1-401(6) Subject to the time limitations described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-502(2)(j): (2)(a); (2)(a); (2)(a) The director or the director's designee shall assess fines according to the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-502(2)(j)(i): (2)(a) for the first offense handled pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-502(2)(j)(ii): (2)(a) for a second offense handled pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-502(2)(j)(iii): (2)(a) for each subsequent offense handled pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-502(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-502(3)(a): An action for a first or second offense that has not yet resulted in a final order of the division may not preclude initiation of a subsequent action for a second or subsequent offense during the pendency of a preceding action.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-502(3)(b): The final order on a subsequent action is considered a second or subsequent offense, respectively, provided the preceding action resulted in a first or second offense, respectively.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-502(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-502(4)(a): The director may collect a penalty that is not paid by:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-502(4)(a)(i): referring the matter to a collection agency; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-502(4)(a)(ii): bringing an action in the district court of the county where the person against whom the penalty is imposed resides or in the county where the office of the director is located.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-502(4)(b): A county attorney or the attorney general of the state shall provide legal assistance and advice to the director in an action to collect a penalty.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-502(4)(c): A court may award reasonable attorney fees and costs to the prevailing party in an action brought by the division to collect a penalty.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-503 Maximum civil penalty for violation of court order.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-503(1): If any written order issued under this title or if an injunction or temporary restraining order  issued by a court of competent jurisdiction relating to this title is violated, the court may impose a civil penalty of not more than $2,000 for each day the written order, injunction, or temporary restraining order is violated, if the person in violation has received notice of the written order, injunction, or temporary restraining order.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-503(2): All penalties ordered under this section shall be  deposited into the General Fund.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-504 Court-ordered discipline.
--------------------------------------------------------
The division shall promptly withhold, suspend, restrict, or reinstate the use of a license issued under this title if so ordered by a court.

Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-505 Cosmetic medical procedure supervisor.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-505(1): 58-1-506; 58-1-506; Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act; Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act; 58-67-102; Chapter 31b, Nurse Practice Act; 58-31b-102 For purposes of this section and Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-505(1)(a): 58-1-506 "Cosmetic medical facility" means a physician's office or a facility that has a supervisor who performs the supervision required in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-505(1)(b): Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act; Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act; 58-67-102; Chapter 31b, Nurse Practice Act; 58-31b-102 "Supervisor" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-505(1)(b)(i): Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act; Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act; 58-67-102 a physician with an unrestricted license under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-505(1)(b)(ii): Chapter 31b, Nurse Practice Act; 58-31b-102 an advanced practice registered nurse with an unrestricted license under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-505(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-505(2)(a): An individual authorized by this title to perform a cosmetic medical procedure shall be supervised by a supervisor when performing a medical procedure.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-505(2)(b): Cosmetic medical procedures may only be performed in a cosmetic medical facility.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-505(2)(c): A supervisor may delegate the supervisory role only to another individual who is qualified as a supervisor.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506 Supervision of cosmetic medical procedures.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(1): (2)(f)(i); (iii); Chapter 70a, Utah Physician Assistant Act; (2)(f)(i); (iii); (2)(f)(i); (iii) For purposes of this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(1)(a): (2)(f)(i); (iii); Chapter 70a, Utah Physician Assistant Act "Delegation group A" means the following who are licensed under this title, acting within their respective scopes of practice, and qualified under Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(1)(a)(i): Chapter 70a, Utah Physician Assistant Act a physician assistant, if acting in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(1)(a)(ii): a registered nurse;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(1)(a)(iii): a master esthetician; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(1)(a)(iv): an electrologist, if evaluating for or performing laser hair removal.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(1)(b): (2)(f)(i); (iii); (2)(f)(i); (iii) "Delegation group B" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(1)(b)(i): (2)(f)(i); (iii) a practical nurse or an esthetician who is licensed under this title, acting within their respective scopes of practice, and qualified under Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(1)(b)(ii): (2)(f)(i); (iii) a medical assistant who is qualified under Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(1)(c): "Direct cosmetic medical procedure supervision" means the supervisor:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(1)(c)(i): has authorized the procedure to be done on the patient by the supervisee; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(1)(c)(ii): is present and available for a face-to-face communication with the supervisee when and where a cosmetic medical procedure is performed.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(1)(d): "General cosmetic medical procedure supervision" means the supervisor:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(1)(d)(i): has authorized the procedure to be done on the patient by the supervisee;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(1)(d)(ii): is available in a timely and appropriate manner in person to evaluate and initiate care for a patient with a suspected adverse reaction or complication; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(1)(d)(iii): is located within 60 minutes or 60 miles of the cosmetic medical facility.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(1)(e): "Hair removal review" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(1)(e)(i): conducting an in-person, face-to-face interview of a patient based on the responses provided by the patient to a detailed medical history assessment that was prepared by the supervisor;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(1)(e)(ii): evaluating for contraindications and conditions that are part of the treatment plan; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(1)(e)(iii): if the patient history or patient presentation deviates in any way from the treatment plan, referring the patient to the supervisor and receiving clearance from the supervisor before starting the treatment.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(1)(f): "Indirect cosmetic medical procedure supervision" means the supervisor:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(1)(f)(i): has authorized the procedure to be done on the patient by the supervisee;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(1)(f)(ii): has given written instructions to the person being supervised;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(1)(f)(iii): is present within the cosmetic medical facility in which the person being supervised is providing services; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(1)(f)(iv): is available to:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(1)(f)(iv)(A): provide immediate face-to-face communication with the person being supervised; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(1)(f)(iv)(B): evaluate the patient, as necessary.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(2): Chapter 70a, Utah Physician Assistant Act; (2)(c); (2)(d); (3)(c)(ii); (2)(b) A supervisor supervising a nonablative cosmetic medical procedure for hair removal shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(2)(a): have an unrestricted license to practice medicine or advanced practice registered nursing in the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(2)(b): develop the medical treatment plan for the procedure;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(2)(c): conduct a hair removal review, or delegate the hair removal review to a member of delegation group A, of the patient prior to initiating treatment or a series of treatments;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(2)(d): personally perform the nonablative cosmetic medical procedure for hair removal, or authorize and delegate the procedure to a member of delegation group A or B;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(2)(e): Chapter 70a, Utah Physician Assistant Act during the nonablative cosmetic medical procedure for hair removal provide general cosmetic medical procedure supervision to individuals in delegation group A performing the procedure, except physician assistants, who shall act in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(2)(f): (2)(c); (2)(d); (3)(c)(ii); (2)(b) verify that a person to whom the supervisor delegates an evaluation under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(2)(f)(i): (2)(b) has received appropriate training regarding the medical procedures developed under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(2)(f)(ii): has an unrestricted license under this title or is performing under the license of the supervising physician and surgeon; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(2)(f)(iii): has maintained competence to perform the nonablative cosmetic medical procedure through documented education and experience of at least 80 hours, as further defined by rule, regarding:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(2)(f)(iii)(A): the appropriate standard of care for performing nonablative cosmetic medical procedures;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(2)(f)(iii)(B): physiology of the skin;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(2)(f)(iii)(C): skin typing and analysis;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(2)(f)(iii)(D): skin conditions, disorders, and diseases;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(2)(f)(iii)(E): pre- and post-procedure care;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(2)(f)(iii)(F): infection control;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(2)(f)(iii)(G): laser and light physics training;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(2)(f)(iii)(H): laser technologies and applications;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(2)(f)(iii)(I): safety and maintenance of lasers;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(2)(f)(iii)(J): cosmetic medical procedures an individual is permitted to perform under this title;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(2)(f)(iii)(K): recognition and appropriate management of complications from a procedure; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(2)(f)(iii)(L): cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR).
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(3): (2); Chapter 70a, Utah Physician Assistant Act; (3)(a)(ii); Chapter 70a, Utah Physician Assistant Act; (3)(c); (2)(f)(iii) For a nonablative cosmetic medical procedure other than hair removal under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(3)(a): Chapter 70a, Utah Physician Assistant Act a physician who has an unrestricted license to practice medicine, a nurse practitioner who has an unrestricted license for advanced practice registered nursing, or a physician assistant acting in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(3)(a)(i): develop a treatment plan for the nonablative cosmetic medical procedure; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(3)(a)(ii): conduct an in-person face-to-face evaluation of the patient prior to the initiation of a treatment protocol or series of treatments; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(3)(b): (3)(a)(ii) a nurse practitioner or physician assistant conducting an in-person face-to-face evaluation of a patient under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(3)(b)(i): inspect the patient's skin for any discoloration unrelated to the tattoo and any other indication of cancer or other condition that should be treated or further evaluated before the tattoo is removed;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(3)(b)(ii): refer a patient with any such condition to a physician for treatment or further evaluation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(3)(b)(iii): shall not supervise a nonablative cosmetic medical procedure to remove a tattoo on the patient until the patient has been approved for the tattoo removal by a physician who has evaluated the patient; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(3)(c): Chapter 70a, Utah Physician Assistant Act; (3)(c); (2)(f)(iii) the supervisor supervising the procedure shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(3)(c)(i): have an unrestricted license to practice medicine or advanced practice registered nursing;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(3)(c)(ii): Chapter 70a, Utah Physician Assistant Act personally perform the nonablative cosmetic medical procedure or:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(3)(c)(ii)(A): authorize and provide general cosmetic medical procedure supervision for the nonablative cosmetic medical procedure that is performed by a registered nurse or a master esthetician;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(3)(c)(ii)(B): Chapter 70a, Utah Physician Assistant Act authorize and provide supervision as provided in
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(3)(c)(ii)(C): authorize and provide direct cosmetic medical procedure supervision for the nonablative cosmetic medical procedure that is performed by an esthetician; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(3)(c)(iii): (3)(c); (2)(f)(iii) verify that a person to whom the supervisor delegates a procedure under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(3)(c)(iii)(A): has received appropriate training regarding the medical procedures to be performed;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(3)(c)(iii)(B): has an unrestricted license and is acting within the person's scope of practice under this title; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(3)(c)(iii)(C): (2)(f)(iii) is qualified under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(4): (2); (3) A supervisor performing or supervising a cosmetic medical procedure under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(4)(a): the supervisor's name is prominently posted at the cosmetic medical facility identifying the supervisor;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(4)(b): a copy of the supervisor's license is displayed on the wall of the cosmetic medical facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(4)(c): the patient receives written information with the name and licensing information of the supervisor who is supervising the nonablative cosmetic medical procedure and the person who is performing the nonablative cosmetic medical procedure;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(4)(d): the patient is provided with a telephone number that is answered within 24 hours for follow-up communication; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(4)(e): the cosmetic medical facility's contract with a master esthetician who performs a nonablative cosmetic medical procedure at the facility is kept on the premises of the facility.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(5): Failure to comply with the provisions of this section is unprofessional conduct.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-506(6): Chapter 73, Chiropractic Physician Practice Act A chiropractic physician licensed under


Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-507 Cosmetic medical procedure -- Truth in advertising.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Beginning July 1, 2013, a facility that performs a cosmetic medical procedure as defined in SectionUtah Code Annotated § 58-1-507(1): Chapter 31b, Nurse Practice Act
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-507(2): Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-507(3): Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act


Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-508 Failure to follow certain health care claims practices -- Penalties.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-508(1): As used in this section, "health care provider" means an individual who is licensed to provide health care services under this title.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-508(2): 31A-26-313 The division may assess a fine of up to $500 per violation against a health care provider that violates Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-508(3): (2); 31A-26-313 The division shall waive the fine described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-508(3)(a): the health care provider demonstrates to the division that the health care provider mitigated and reversed any damage to the insured caused by the health care provider or third party's violation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-508(3)(b): 31A-26-313 the insured does not pay the full amount due on the bill that is the subject of the violation, including any interest, fees, costs, and expenses, within 120 days after the day on which the health care provider or third party makes a report to a credit bureau or takes an action in violation of Section


Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-509 Patient consent for certain medical examinations.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-509(1): 78B-3-403; 26B-4-101; 58-1-307(1)(b); (c) As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-509(1)(a): 78B-3-403; 26B-4-101; 58-1-307(1)(b); (c) "Health care provider" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-509(1)(a)(i): 78B-3-403 an individual who is:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-509(1)(a)(i)(A): 78B-3-403 a healthcare provider as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-509(1)(a)(i)(B): licensed under this title;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-509(1)(a)(ii): 26B-4-101 emergency medical service personnel as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-509(1)(a)(iii): 58-1-307(1)(b); (c) an individual described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-509(1)(b): "Patient examination" means a medical examination that requires contact with the patient's sexual organs.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-509(2): (3) A health care provider may not perform a patient examination on an anesthetized or unconscious patient unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-509(2)(a): (3) the health care provider obtains consent from the patient or the patient's representative in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-509(2)(b): a court orders performance of the patient examination for the collection of evidence;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-509(2)(c): the performance of the patient examination is within the scope of care for a procedure or diagnostic examination scheduled to be performed on the patient; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-509(2)(d): the patient examination is immediately necessary for diagnosis or treatment of the patient.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-509(3): To obtain consent to perform a patient examination on an anesthetized or unconscious patient, before performing the patient examination, the health care provider shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-509(3)(a): provide the patient or the patient's representative with a written or electronic document that:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-509(3)(a)(i): is provided separately from any other notice or agreement;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-509(3)(a)(ii): contains the following heading at the top of the document in not smaller than 18-point bold face type: "CONSENT FOR EXAMINATION OF PELVIC REGION";
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-509(3)(a)(iii): specifies the nature and purpose of the patient examination;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-509(3)(a)(iv): names one or more primary health care providers whom the patient or the patient's representative may authorize to perform the patient examination;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-509(3)(a)(v): states whether there may be a student or resident that the patient or the patient's representative authorizes to:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-509(3)(a)(v)(A): perform an additional patient examination; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-509(3)(a)(v)(B): observe or otherwise be present at the patient examination, either in person or through electronic means; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-509(3)(a)(vi): provides the patient or the patient's representative with a series of check boxes that allow the patient or the patient's representative to:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-509(3)(a)(vi)(A): consent to the patient examination for diagnosis or treatment and an additional patient examination performed by a student or resident for an educational or training purpose;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-509(3)(a)(vi)(B): consent to the patient examination only for diagnosis or treatment; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-509(3)(a)(vi)(C): refuse to consent to the patient examination;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-509(3)(b): obtain the signature of the patient or the patient's representative on the written or electronic document while witnessed by a third party; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-509(3)(c): sign the written or electronic document.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-509 Patient consent for certain medical examinations.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-509(1): 78B-3-403; 53-2d-101; 58-1-307(1)(b); (c) As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-509(1)(a): 78B-3-403; 53-2d-101; 58-1-307(1)(b); (c) "Health care provider" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-509(1)(a)(i): 78B-3-403 an individual who is:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-509(1)(a)(i)(A): 78B-3-403 a healthcare provider as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-509(1)(a)(i)(B): licensed under this title;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-509(1)(a)(ii): 53-2d-101 emergency medical service personnel as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-509(1)(a)(iii): 58-1-307(1)(b); (c) an individual described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-509(1)(b): "Patient examination" means a medical examination that requires contact with the patient's sexual organs.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-509(2): (3) A health care provider may not perform a patient examination on an anesthetized or unconscious patient unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-509(2)(a): (3) the health care provider obtains consent from the patient or the patient's representative in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-509(2)(b): a court orders performance of the patient examination for the collection of evidence;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-509(2)(c): the performance of the patient examination is within the scope of care for a procedure or diagnostic examination scheduled to be performed on the patient; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-509(2)(d): the patient examination is immediately necessary for diagnosis or treatment of the patient.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-509(3): To obtain consent to perform a patient examination on an anesthetized or unconscious patient, before performing the patient examination, the health care provider shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-509(3)(a): provide the patient or the patient's representative with a written or electronic document that:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-509(3)(a)(i): is provided separately from any other notice or agreement;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-509(3)(a)(ii): contains the following heading at the top of the document in not smaller than 18-point bold face type: "CONSENT FOR EXAMINATION OF PELVIC REGION";
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-509(3)(a)(iii): specifies the nature and purpose of the patient examination;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-509(3)(a)(iv): names one or more primary health care providers whom the patient or the patient's representative may authorize to perform the patient examination;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-509(3)(a)(v): states whether there may be a student or resident that the patient or the patient's representative authorizes to:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-509(3)(a)(v)(A): perform an additional patient examination; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-509(3)(a)(v)(B): observe or otherwise be present at the patient examination, either in person or through electronic means; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-509(3)(a)(vi): provides the patient or the patient's representative with a series of check boxes that allow the patient or the patient's representative to:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-509(3)(a)(vi)(A): consent to the patient examination for diagnosis or treatment and an additional patient examination performed by a student or resident for an educational or training purpose;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-509(3)(a)(vi)(B): consent to the patient examination only for diagnosis or treatment; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-509(3)(a)(vi)(C): refuse to consent to the patient examination;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-509(3)(b): obtain the signature of the patient or the patient's representative on the written or electronic document while witnessed by a third party; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-509(3)(c): sign the written or electronic document.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-510 Anesthesia and sedation requirements -- Unprofessional conduct -- Whistleblower protection.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-510(1): Chapter 5a, Podiatric Physician Licensing Act; 58-31b-301(2)(e); Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act; Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act; Chapter 69, Dentist and Dental Hygienist Practice Act; 58-69-301(4) As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-510(1)(a): Chapter 5a, Podiatric Physician Licensing Act; 58-31b-301(2)(e); Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act; Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act; Chapter 69, Dentist and Dental Hygienist Practice Act; 58-69-301(4) "Anesthesia or sedation provider" means an individual who is licensed:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-510(1)(a)(i): Chapter 5a, Podiatric Physician Licensing Act under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-510(1)(a)(ii): 58-31b-301(2)(e) under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-510(1)(a)(iii): Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-510(1)(a)(iv): Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-510(1)(a)(v): Chapter 69, Dentist and Dental Hygienist Practice Act; 58-69-301(4) as a dentist under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-510(1)(b): "Deep sedation" means a drug-induced depression of consciousness where an individual:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-510(1)(b)(i): cannot be easily aroused;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-510(1)(b)(ii): responds purposefully following repeated or painful stimulation;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-510(1)(b)(iii): may not be able to independently maintain ventilatory function;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-510(1)(b)(iv): may require assistance in maintaining a patent airway; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-510(1)(b)(v): usually maintains cardiovascular function.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-510(1)(c): "General anesthesia" means a drug-induced loss of consciousness where an individual:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-510(1)(c)(i): cannot be aroused, even by painful stimulation;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-510(1)(c)(ii): is often unable to maintain ventilatory function;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-510(1)(c)(iii): often requires assistance in maintaining a patent airway and positive pressure ventilation may be required because of depressed spontaneous ventilation or drug-induced depression of neuromuscular function; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-510(1)(c)(iv): may not be able to maintain cardiovascular function.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-510(1)(d): "General anesthetic" means a drug identified as a general anesthetic by the federal Food and Drug Administration.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-510(1)(e): "Minimal sedation" means a drug-induced state where an individual:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-510(1)(e)(i): responds normally to verbal commands;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-510(1)(e)(ii): may have reduced cognitive function and physical coordination; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-510(1)(e)(iii): maintains airway reflexes, ventilatory function, and cardiovascular function.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-510(1)(f): "Moderate sedation" means a drug-induced depression of consciousness where an individual:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-510(1)(f)(i): responds purposefully to verbal commands, either alone or accompanied by light tactile stimulation;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-510(1)(f)(ii): maintains a patent airway;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-510(1)(f)(iii): maintains spontaneous ventilation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-510(1)(f)(iv): usually maintains cardiovascular function.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-510(2): (4); (2)(a); (4) An anesthesia or sedation provider may not cause a patient to undergo moderate sedation, deep sedation, or general anesthesia, in an outpatient setting that is not an emergency department without:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-510(2)(a): (4) first providing the following information in writing and verbally:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-510(2)(a)(i): the level of anesthesia or sedation being administered;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-510(2)(a)(ii): the identity, type of license, and training of the provider who is performing the procedure for which the anesthesia or sedation will be administered;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-510(2)(a)(iii): (4) the identity, type of license, and a description of the training described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-1-510(2)(a)(iv): a description of the monitoring that will occur during the sedation or anesthesia, including descriptions related to the monitoring of the patient's oxygenation, ventilation, and circulation;
