Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-502(8): (1); (7); 58-1-501(1) falsely making an entry in, or altering, a medical record with the intent to conceal:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-502(8)(a): a wrongful or negligent act or omission of an individual licensed under this chapter or an individual under the direction or control of an individual licensed under this chapter; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-502(8)(b): (1); (7); 58-1-501(1) conduct described in Subsections


Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-503 Penalty for unlawful conduct.
--------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-503(1): (2); 58-16a-501; 58-1-501(1)(a); (1)(c) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-503(2): 58-16a-501(2) A person who violates Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-601 Scope of practice.
---------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-601(1): 58-37-4 An optometrist may:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-601(1)(a): provide optometric services not specifically prohibited under this chapter or division rules if the services are within the optometrist's training, skills, and scope of competence; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-601(1)(b): 58-37-4 prescribe or administer pharmaceutical agents for the eye and its adnexa, including oral agents, subject to the following conditions:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-601(1)(b)(i): an optometrist may prescribe oral antibiotics for only eyelid related ocular conditions or diseases, and other ocular conditions or diseases specified by division rule; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-601(1)(b)(ii): 58-37-4 an optometrist may administer or prescribe a hydrocodone combination drug, or a Schedule III controlled substance, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-601(1)(b)(ii)(A): the substance is administered or prescribed for pain of the eye or adnexa;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-601(1)(b)(ii)(B): the substance is administered orally or topically or is prescribed for oral or topical use;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-601(1)(b)(ii)(C): the amount of the substance administered or prescribed does not exceed a 72-hour quantity; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-601(1)(b)(ii)(D): if the substance is prescribed, the prescription does not include refills.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-601(2): 58-37-4; (1)(b) An optometrist may not:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-601(2)(a): perform surgery, including laser surgery; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-601(2)(b): 58-37-4; (1)(b) prescribe or administer a Schedule II controlled substance, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-601(3): 31A-22-618; 31A-45-303 For purposes of Sections


Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-701 Form of practice.
--------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-701(1): An optometrist licensed under this chapter may engage in practice as an optometrist or in the practice of optometry only as an individual licensee.  However, as an individual licensee he may be:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-701(1)(a): an individual operating as a business proprietor;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-701(1)(b): an employee of another person or corporation;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-701(1)(c): a partner in a lawfully organized partnership;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-701(1)(d): a lawfully formed professional corporation;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-701(1)(e): a lawfully organized limited liability company;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-701(1)(f): a lawfully organized business corporation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-701(1)(g): any other form of organization recognized by the state and which is not prohibited by division rule made in collaboration with the board.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-701(2): 58-16a-301 Regardless of the form in which a licensee engages in the practice of optometry, the licensee may only permit the practice of optometry in that form of practice to be conducted by an individual:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-701(2)(a): 58-16a-301 licensed in Utah as an optometrist under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-701(2)(b): who is able to lawfully and competently engage in the practice of optometry.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-702 Medical records -- Electronic records.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-702(1): Medical records maintained by a licensee shall meet the standards and ethics of the profession.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-702(2): (1) Medical records under this section may be maintained by any electronic means if the records comply with Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-801 Contact lens and ophthalmic lens seller or provider.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-801(1): A person may sell or provide contact lenses if the person:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-801(1)(a): does so in the ordinary course of trade from a permanently located and established place of business;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-801(1)(b): does not perform refractions, over-refractions, or attempts to traffic upon assumed skill in testing the eye;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-801(1)(c): provides all contact lenses consistent with and in accordance with a valid contact lens prescription;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-801(1)(d): does not fit contact lenses;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-801(1)(e): provides a contact lens to a patient after:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-801(1)(e)(i): receiving an unexpired verbal or written prescription; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-801(1)(e)(ii): sending a contact lens prescription verification to the prescribing optometrist or physician, regardless of whether the prescribing optometrist or physician responds to or confirms the verification, provided that:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-801(1)(e)(ii)(A): the person has all of the information necessary to fill the prescription;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-801(1)(e)(ii)(B): the prescribing optometrist or physician has not informed the person that the prescription has expired or is otherwise inaccurate prior to the person shipping or hand-delivering the contact lens to the patient;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-801(1)(e)(ii)(C): the person confirms a valid, unexpired contact lens prescription for the patient if the person is aware that the patient provided inaccurate prescription information in his last order; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-801(1)(e)(ii)(D): the person informs the patient that the prescription has expired or that there is a medical problem associated with the prescription if the information is communicated by the prescribing optometrist or physician to the person within 72 hours of the contact lens prescription verification being sent; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-801(1)(f): maintains patient information, including the method and date of any prescription verification, for no less than seven years.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-801(2): (2)(b); 58-16a-102(8)(b); (2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-801(2)(a): (2)(b); 58-16a-102(8)(b) A person may engage in the activities described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-801(2)(a)(i): 58-16a-102(8)(b) provides the ophthalmic lenses consistent with and in accordance with a prescription from a licensed physician or optometrist that is unexpired as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-801(2)(a)(ii): dispenses the ophthalmic lenses within or from the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-801(2)(a)(iii): does so in the ordinary course of trade from a permanently located and established place of business;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-801(2)(a)(iv): does not perform refractions, over-refractions, or attempt to traffic upon assumed skill in licensed physician or optometrist testing of the eye; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-801(2)(a)(v): complies with impact tolerance standards based on ANSI Z80.1-2010, American National Standard for Ophthalmics - Prescription Lenses.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-801(2)(b): (2)(a) In accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-801(2)(b)(i): sell, reproduce, or dispense ophthalmic lenses;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-801(2)(b)(ii): fit or adjust ophthalmic lenses or frames;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-801(2)(b)(iii): assist with the selection of frames for ophthalmic lenses;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-801(2)(b)(iv): measure pupillary distance and interpret pupillary distance measurements; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-801(2)(b)(v): measure or interpret the reading segment height in bifocal, tri-focal, progressive, or multi-focal lenses.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-801(3): (1); (2) Nothing in this section may be construed as requiring a person to be licensed or certified in any way under this or any another chapter of this title to sell contact lenses in accordance with Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-901 Title.
---------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Contact Lens Consumer Protection Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-902 Policy.
----------------------------------------
It is the policy of the state that citizens who wear contact lenses pursuant to valid prescriptions should not be unreasonably denied the opportunity to purchase their contact lenses from their retailer of choice.

Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-903 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-903(1): "Alternative channels of distribution" means any mail order company, Internet retailer, pharmacy, buying club, department store, or mass merchandise outlet, without regard to whether it is associated with a prescriber, unless the account meets the definition of a competitor as provided for in this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-903(2): "Competitor" means an entity that manufactures contact lenses and sells those lenses within the state in direct competition with any other manufacturer.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-903(3): "Manufacturer" means a manufacturer, its parents, subsidiaries, affiliates, successors, and assigns.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-903(4): "Prescriber" means an individual licensed or authorized to prescribe contact lenses under this title.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-904 Certification of availability of contact lenses  -- Exceptions.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-904(1): Beginning July 1, 2006, a manufacturer of contact lenses doing business in the state shall certify by affidavit to the Attorney General those brands of contact lenses produced, marketed, distributed, or sold by the manufacturer in the state that are made available in a commercially reasonable and nondiscriminatory manner to:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-904(1)(a): prescribers;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-904(1)(b): entities associated with prescribers; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-904(1)(c): alternative channels of distribution.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-904(2): (1) Notwithstanding any other provision of law, a manufacturer shall only sell, market, or distribute lenses in Utah that have been certified under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-904(3): (1); (2) Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-904(3)(a): rigid gas permeable lenses;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-904(3)(b): bitoric gas permeable lenses;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-904(3)(c): bifocal gas permeable lenses;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-904(3)(d): keratoconus lenses;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-904(3)(e): custom soft toric lenses that are manufactured for an individual patient and are not mass marketed or mass produced; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-904(3)(f): custom designed lenses that are manufactured for an individual patient and are not mass marketed or mass produced.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-904(4): Any time a brand ceases to be made available after July 1, 2006, the manufacturer shall immediately certify that fact by affidavit to the Attorney General.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-905 Manufacturers' conduct.
--------------------------------------------------------
Nothing in SectionUtah Code Annotated § 58-16a-905(1): sell to a competitor;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-905(2): sell contact lenses to different contact lens distributors or customers at the same price;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-905(3): open or maintain any account for a contact lens seller who is not in substantial compliance with Utah and federal law regarding the sale of contact lenses;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-905(4): decide whether a low volume account with a contact lens seller is a direct account or handled through a distributor; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-905(5): sell to customers in all geographic areas lenses that are being test marketed on a limited basis in one geographic area.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-905.1 Contact lens manufacturer or distributor -- Prohibited conduct.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A contact lens manufacturer or a contact lens distributor may not:Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-905.1(1): take any action, by agreement, unilaterally, or otherwise, that has the effect of fixing or otherwise controlling the price that a contact lens retailer charges or advertises for contact lenses; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-905.1(2): discriminate against a contact lens retailer based on whether the contact lens retailer:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-905.1(2)(a): sells or advertises contact lenses for a particular price;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-905.1(2)(b): operates in a particular channel of trade;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-905.1(2)(c): is a person authorized by law to prescribe contact lenses; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-905.1(2)(d): is associated with a person authorized by law to prescribe contact lenses.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-906 Penalties for violations.
----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-906(1): 58-16a-904 A person who knowingly and intentionally violates a provision of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-16a-906(2): 58-16a-904; 58-16a-905.1 The attorney general may bring a civil action or seek an injunction and a civil penalty against any person who violates a provision of Section


Utah Code Annotated - Title 58 - Chapter 17b - Pharmacy Practice Act
********************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-101 Title.
---------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Pharmacy Practice Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
In addition to the definitions in SectionUtah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(1): "Administering" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(1)(a): the direct application of a prescription drug or device, whether by injection, inhalation, ingestion, or by any other means, to the body of a human patient or research subject by another person; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(1)(b): the placement by a veterinarian with the owner or caretaker of an animal or group of animals of a prescription drug for the purpose of injection, inhalation, ingestion, or any other means directed to the body of the animal by the owner or caretaker in accordance with written or verbal directions of the veterinarian.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(2): "Adulterated drug or device" means a drug or device considered adulterated under 21 U.S.C. Sec. 351 (2003).
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(3)(a): "Analytical laboratory" means a facility in possession of prescription drugs for the purpose of analysis.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(3)(b): "Analytical laboratory" does not include a laboratory possessing prescription drugs used as standards and controls in performing drug monitoring or drug screening analysis if the prescription drugs are prediluted in a human or animal body fluid, human or animal body fluid components, organic solvents, or inorganic buffers at a concentration not exceeding one milligram per milliliter when labeled or otherwise designated as being for in vitro diagnostic use.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(4): "Animal euthanasia agency" means an agency performing euthanasia on animals by the use of prescription drugs.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(5): "Automated pharmacy systems" includes mechanical systems which perform operations or activities, other than compounding or administration, relative to the storage, packaging, dispensing, or distribution of medications, and which collect, control, and maintain all transaction information.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(6): "Beyond use date" means the date determined by a pharmacist and placed on a prescription label at the time of dispensing that indicates to the patient or caregiver a time beyond which the contents of the prescription are not recommended to be used.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(7): 58-17b-201 "Board of pharmacy" or "board" means the Utah State Board of Pharmacy created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(8): "Branch pharmacy" means a pharmacy or other facility in a rural or medically underserved area, used for the storage and dispensing of prescription drugs, which is dependent upon, stocked by, and supervised by a pharmacist in another licensed pharmacy designated and approved by the division as the parent pharmacy.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(9): "Centralized prescription processing" means the processing by a pharmacy of a request from another pharmacy to fill or refill a prescription drug order or to perform processing functions such as dispensing, drug utilization review, claims adjudication, refill authorizations, and therapeutic interventions.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(10): "Class A pharmacy" means a pharmacy located in Utah that is authorized as a retail pharmacy to compound or dispense a drug or dispense a device to the public under a prescription order.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(11): "Class B pharmacy":
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(11)(a): means a pharmacy located in Utah:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(11)(a)(i): that is authorized to provide pharmaceutical care for patients in an institutional setting; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(11)(a)(ii): whose primary purpose is to provide a physical environment for patients to obtain health care services; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(11)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(11)(b)(i): includes closed-door, hospital, clinic, nuclear, and branch pharmacies; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(11)(b)(ii): pharmaceutical administration and sterile product preparation facilities.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(12): "Class C pharmacy" means a pharmacy that engages in the manufacture, production, wholesale, or distribution of drugs or devices in Utah.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(13): "Class D pharmacy" means a nonresident pharmacy.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(14): "Class E pharmacy" means all other pharmacies.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(15): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(15)(a): "Closed-door pharmacy" means a pharmacy that:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(15)(a)(i): provides pharmaceutical care to a defined and exclusive group of patients who have access to the services of the pharmacy because they are treated by or have an affiliation with a specific entity, including a health maintenance organization or an infusion company; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(15)(a)(ii): engages exclusively in the practice of telepharmacy and does not serve walk-in retail customers.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(15)(b): "Closed-door pharmacy" does not include a hospital pharmacy, a retailer of goods to the general public, or the office of a practitioner.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(16): "Collaborative pharmacy practice" means a practice of pharmacy whereby one or more pharmacists have jointly agreed, on a voluntary basis, to work in conjunction with one or more practitioners under protocol whereby the pharmacist may perform certain pharmaceutical care functions authorized by the practitioner or practitioners under certain specified conditions or limitations.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(17): "Collaborative pharmacy practice agreement" means a written and signed agreement between one or more pharmacists and one or more practitioners that provides for collaborative pharmacy practice for the purpose of drug therapy management of patients and prevention of disease of human subjects.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(18): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(18)(a): "Compounding" means the preparation, mixing, assembling, packaging, or labeling of a limited quantity drug, sterile product, or device:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(18)(a)(i): as the result of a practitioner's prescription order or initiative based on the practitioner, patient, or pharmacist relationship in the course of professional practice;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(18)(a)(ii): for the purpose of, or as an incident to, research, teaching, or chemical analysis and not for sale or dispensing; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(18)(a)(iii): in anticipation of prescription drug orders based on routine, regularly observed prescribing patterns.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(18)(b): "Compounding" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(18)(b)(i): the preparation of prescription drugs by a pharmacist or pharmacy intern for sale to another pharmacist or pharmaceutical facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(18)(b)(ii): the preparation by a pharmacist or pharmacy intern of any prescription drug in a dosage form which is regularly and commonly available from a manufacturer in quantities and strengths prescribed by a practitioner; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(18)(b)(iii): the preparation of a prescription drug, sterile product, or device which has been withdrawn from the market for safety reasons.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(19): "Confidential information" has the same meaning as "protected health information" under the Standards for Privacy of Individually Identifiable Health Information, 45 C.F.R.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(20): 58-37-2 "Controlled substance" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(21): "Dietary supplement" has the same meaning as Public Law
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(22): "Dispense" means the interpretation, evaluation, and implementation of a prescription drug order or device or nonprescription drug or device under a lawful order of a practitioner in a suitable container appropriately labeled for subsequent administration to or use by a patient, research subject, or an animal.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(23): Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act; Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act; Chapter 70a, Utah Physician Assistant Act; Chapter 31b, Nurse Practice Act; Chapter 16a, Utah Optometry Practice Act "Dispensing medical practitioner" means an individual who is:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(23)(a): Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act; Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act; Chapter 70a, Utah Physician Assistant Act; Chapter 31b, Nurse Practice Act; Chapter 16a, Utah Optometry Practice Act currently licensed as:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(23)(a)(i): Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act a physician and surgeon under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(23)(a)(ii): Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act an osteopathic physician and surgeon under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(23)(a)(iii): Chapter 70a, Utah Physician Assistant Act a physician assistant under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(23)(a)(iv): Chapter 31b, Nurse Practice Act a nurse practitioner under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(23)(a)(v): Chapter 16a, Utah Optometry Practice Act an optometrist under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(23)(b): licensed by the division under the Pharmacy Practice Act to engage in the practice of a dispensing medical practitioner.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(24): "Dispensing medical practitioner clinic pharmacy" means a closed-door pharmacy located within a licensed dispensing medical practitioner's place of practice.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(25): "Distribute" means to deliver a drug or device other than by administering or dispensing.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(26): (26)(a)(i); (ii); (iii); (iv)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(26)(a): (26)(a)(i); (ii); (iii); (iv) "Drug" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(26)(a)(i): a substance recognized in the official United States Pharmacopoeia, official Homeopathic Pharmacopoeia of the United States, or official National Formulary, or any supplement to any of them, intended for use in the diagnosis, cure, mitigation, treatment, or prevention of disease in humans or animals;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(26)(a)(ii): a substance that is required by any applicable federal or state law or rule to be dispensed by prescription only or is restricted to administration by practitioners only;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(26)(a)(iii): a substance other than food intended to affect the structure or any function of the body of humans or other animals; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(26)(a)(iv): (26)(a)(i); (ii); (iii); (iv) substances intended for use as a component of any substance specified in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(26)(b): "Drug" does not include dietary supplements.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(27): "Drug regimen review" includes the following activities:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(27)(a): evaluation of the prescription drug order and patient record for:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(27)(a)(i): known allergies;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(27)(a)(ii): rational therapy-contraindications;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(27)(a)(iii): reasonable dose and route of administration; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(27)(a)(iv): reasonable directions for use;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(27)(b): evaluation of the prescription drug order and patient record for duplication of therapy;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(27)(c): evaluation of the prescription drug order and patient record for the following interactions:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(27)(c)(i): drug-drug;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(27)(c)(ii): drug-food;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(27)(c)(iii): drug-disease; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(27)(c)(iv): adverse drug reactions; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(27)(d): evaluation of the prescription drug order and patient record for proper utilization, including over- or under-utilization, and optimum therapeutic outcomes.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(28): "Drug sample" means a prescription drug packaged in small quantities consistent with limited dosage therapy of the particular drug, which is marked "sample", is not intended to be sold, and is intended to be provided to practitioners for the immediate needs of patients for trial purposes or to provide the drug to the patient until a prescription can be filled by the patient.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(29): "Electronic signature" means a trusted, verifiable, and secure electronic sound, symbol, or process attached to or logically associated with a record and executed or adopted by a person with the intent to sign the record.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(30): "Electronic transmission" means transmission of information in electronic form or the transmission of the exact visual image of a document by way of electronic equipment.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(31): Title 26B, Chapter 2, Part 2, Health Care Facility Licensing and Inspection "Hospital pharmacy" means a pharmacy providing pharmaceutical care to inpatients of a general acute hospital or specialty hospital licensed by the Department of Health and Human Services under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(32): "Legend drug" has the same meaning as prescription drug.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(33): "Licensed pharmacy technician" means an individual licensed with the division, that may, under the supervision of a pharmacist, perform the activities involved in the technician practice of pharmacy.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(34): "Manufacturer" means a person or business physically located in Utah licensed to be engaged in the manufacturing of drugs or devices.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(35): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(35)(a): "Manufacturing" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(35)(a)(i): the production, preparation, propagation, conversion, or processing of a drug or device, either directly or indirectly, by extraction from substances of natural origin or independently by means of chemical or biological synthesis, or by a combination of extraction and chemical synthesis, and includes any packaging or repackaging of the substance or labeling or relabeling of its container; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(35)(a)(ii): the promotion and marketing of such drugs or devices.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(35)(b): "Manufacturing" includes the preparation and promotion of commercially available products from bulk compounds for resale by pharmacies, practitioners, or other persons.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(35)(c): "Manufacturing" does not include the preparation or compounding of a drug by a pharmacist, pharmacy intern, or practitioner for that individual's own use or the preparation, compounding, packaging, labeling of a drug, or incident to research, teaching, or chemical analysis.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(36): "Medical order" means a lawful order of a practitioner which may include a prescription drug order.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(37): "Medication profile" or "profile" means a record system maintained as to drugs or devices prescribed for a pharmacy patient to enable a pharmacist or pharmacy intern to analyze the profile to provide pharmaceutical care.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(38): "Misbranded drug or device" means a drug or device considered misbranded under 21 U.S.C. Sec. 352 (2003).
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(39): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(39)(a): "Nonprescription drug" means a drug which:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(39)(a)(i): may be sold without a prescription; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(39)(a)(ii): is labeled for use by the consumer in accordance with federal law.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(39)(b): "Nonprescription drug" includes homeopathic remedies.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(40): "Nonresident pharmacy" means a pharmacy located outside of Utah that sells to a person in Utah.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(41): "Nuclear pharmacy" means a pharmacy providing radio-pharmaceutical service.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(42): "Out-of-state mail service pharmacy" means a pharmaceutical facility located outside the state that is licensed and in good standing in another state, that:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(42)(a): ships, mails, or delivers by any lawful means a dispensed legend drug to a patient in this state pursuant to a lawfully issued prescription;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(42)(b): provides information to a patient in this state on drugs or devices which may include, but is not limited to, advice relating to therapeutic values, potential hazards, and uses; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(42)(c): counsels pharmacy patients residing in this state concerning adverse and therapeutic effects of drugs.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(43): "Patient counseling" means the written and oral communication by the pharmacist or pharmacy intern of information, to the patient or caregiver, in order to ensure proper use of drugs, devices, and dietary supplements.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(44): "Pharmaceutical administration facility" means a facility, agency, or institution in which:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(44)(a): prescription drugs or devices are held, stored, or are otherwise under the control of the facility or agency for administration to patients of that facility or agency;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(44)(b): prescription drugs are dispensed to the facility or agency by a licensed pharmacist or pharmacy intern with whom the facility has established a prescription drug supervising relationship under which the pharmacist or pharmacy intern provides counseling to the facility or agency staff as required, and oversees drug control, accounting, and destruction; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(44)(c): prescription drugs are professionally administered in accordance with the order of a practitioner by an employee or agent of the facility or agency.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(45): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(45)(a): "Pharmaceutical care" means carrying out the following in collaboration with a prescribing practitioner, and in accordance with division rule:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(45)(a)(i): designing, implementing, and monitoring a therapeutic drug plan intended to achieve favorable outcomes related to a specific patient for the purpose of curing or preventing the patient's disease;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(45)(a)(ii): eliminating or reducing a patient's symptoms; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(45)(a)(iii): arresting or slowing a disease process.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(45)(b): "Pharmaceutical care" does not include prescribing of drugs without consent of a prescribing practitioner.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(46): "Pharmaceutical facility" means a business engaged in the dispensing, delivering, distributing, manufacturing, or wholesaling of prescription drugs or devices within or into this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(47): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(47)(a): "Pharmaceutical wholesaler or distributor" means a pharmaceutical facility engaged in the business of wholesale vending or selling of a prescription drug or device to other than a consumer or user of the prescription drug or device that the pharmaceutical facility has not produced, manufactured, compounded, or dispensed.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(47)(b): "Pharmaceutical wholesaler or distributor" does not include a pharmaceutical facility carrying out the following business activities:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(47)(b)(i): intracompany sales;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(47)(b)(ii): the sale, purchase, or trade of a prescription drug or device, or an offer to sell, purchase, or trade a prescription drug or device, if the activity is carried out between one or more of the following entities under common ownership or common administrative control, as defined by division rule:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(47)(b)(ii)(A): hospitals;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(47)(b)(ii)(B): pharmacies;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(47)(b)(ii)(C): chain pharmacy warehouses, as defined by division rule; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(47)(b)(ii)(D): other health care entities, as defined by division rule;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(47)(b)(iii): the sale, purchase, or trade of a prescription drug or device, or an offer to sell, purchase, or trade a prescription drug or device, for emergency medical reasons, including supplying another pharmaceutical facility with a limited quantity of a drug, if:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(47)(b)(iii)(A): the facility is unable to obtain the drug through a normal distribution channel in sufficient time to eliminate the risk of harm to a patient that would result from a delay in obtaining the drug; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(47)(b)(iii)(B): the quantity of the drug does not exceed an amount reasonably required for immediate dispensing to eliminate the risk of harm;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(47)(b)(iv): the distribution of a prescription drug or device as a sample by representatives of a manufacturer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(47)(b)(v): the distribution of prescription drugs, if:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(47)(b)(v)(A): the facility's total distribution-related sales of prescription drugs does not exceed 5% of the facility's total prescription drug sales; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(47)(b)(v)(B): the distribution otherwise complies with 21 C.F.R. Sec. 1307.11.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(48): "Pharmacist" means an individual licensed by this state to engage in the practice of pharmacy.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(49): "Pharmacist-in-charge" means a pharmacist currently licensed in good standing who accepts responsibility for the operation of a pharmacy in conformance with all laws and rules pertinent to the practice of pharmacy and the distribution of drugs, and who is personally in full and actual charge of the pharmacy and all personnel.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(50): "Pharmacist preceptor" means a licensed pharmacist in good standing with one or more years of licensed experience.  The preceptor serves as a teacher, example of professional conduct, and supervisor of interns in the professional practice of pharmacy.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(51): "Pharmacy" means any place where:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(51)(a): drugs are dispensed;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(51)(b): pharmaceutical care is provided;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(51)(c): drugs are processed or handled for eventual use by a patient; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(51)(d): drugs are used for the purpose of analysis or research.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(52): 31A-46-102 "Pharmacy benefits manager or coordinator" means a person or entity that provides a pharmacy benefits management service as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(53): "Pharmacy intern" means an individual licensed by this state to engage in practice as a pharmacy intern.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(54): (54)(a); (d) "Pharmacy manager" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(54)(a): a pharmacist-in-charge;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(54)(b): a licensed pharmacist designated by a licensed pharmacy to consult on the pharmacy's administration;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(54)(c): an individual who manages the facility in which a licensed pharmacy is located;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(54)(d): an individual who oversees the operations of a licensed pharmacy;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(54)(e): (54)(a); (d) an immediate supervisor of an individual described in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(54)(f): another operations or site manager of a licensed pharmacy.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(55): "Pharmacy technician training program" means an approved technician training program providing education for pharmacy technicians.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(56): Part 8, Dispensing Medical Practitioner and Dispensing Medical Practitioner Clinic Pharmacy; (23)(a); 58-17b-805; 58-37-2
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(56)(a): Part 8, Dispensing Medical Practitioner and Dispensing Medical Practitioner Clinic Pharmacy; (23)(a) "Practice as a dispensing medical practitioner" means the practice of pharmacy, specifically relating to the dispensing of a prescription drug in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(56)(b): 58-17b-805; 58-37-2 "Practice as a dispensing medical practitioner" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(56)(b)(i): using a vending type of dispenser as defined by the division by administrative rule; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(56)(b)(ii): 58-17b-805; 58-37-2 except as permitted by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(57): "Practice as a licensed pharmacy technician" means engaging in practice as a pharmacy technician under the general supervision of a licensed pharmacist and in accordance with a scope of practice defined by division rule made in collaboration with the board.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(58): 58-67-201; Title 26B, Chapter 4, Part 5, Treatment Access; 58-17b-627 "Practice of pharmacy" includes the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(58)(a): providing pharmaceutical care;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(58)(b): collaborative pharmacy practice in accordance with a collaborative pharmacy practice agreement;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(58)(c): 58-67-201 compounding, packaging, labeling, dispensing, administering, and the coincident distribution of prescription drugs or devices, provided that the administration of a prescription drug or device is:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(58)(c)(i): pursuant to a lawful order of a practitioner when one is required by law; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(58)(c)(ii): 58-67-201 in accordance with written guidelines or protocols:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(58)(c)(ii)(A): established by the licensed facility in which the prescription drug or device is to be administered on an inpatient basis; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(58)(c)(ii)(B): 58-67-201 approved by the division, in collaboration with the board and, when appropriate, the Physicians Licensing Board, created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(58)(d): participating in drug utilization review;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(58)(e): ensuring proper and safe storage of drugs and devices;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(58)(f): maintaining records of drugs and devices in accordance with state and federal law and the standards and ethics of the profession;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(58)(g): providing information on drugs or devices, which may include advice relating to therapeutic values, potential hazards, and uses;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(58)(h): providing drug product equivalents;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(58)(i): supervising pharmacist's supportive personnel, pharmacy interns, and pharmacy technicians;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(58)(j): providing patient counseling, including adverse and therapeutic effects of drugs;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(58)(k): providing emergency refills as defined by rule;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(58)(l): telepharmacy;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(58)(m): formulary management intervention;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(58)(n): Title 26B, Chapter 4, Part 5, Treatment Access prescribing and dispensing a self-administered hormonal contraceptive in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(58)(o): 58-17b-627 issuing a prescription in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(59): "Practice of telepharmacy" means the practice of pharmacy through the use of telecommunications and information technologies.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(60): "Practice of telepharmacy across state lines" means the practice of pharmacy through the use of telecommunications and information technologies that occurs when the patient is physically located within one jurisdiction and the pharmacist is located in another jurisdiction.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(61): "Practitioner" means an individual currently licensed, registered, or otherwise authorized by the appropriate jurisdiction to prescribe and administer drugs in the course of professional practice.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(62): "Prescribe" means to issue a prescription:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(62)(a): orally or in writing; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(62)(b): by telephone, facsimile transmission, computer, or other electronic means of communication as defined by division rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(63): "Prescription" means an order issued:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(63)(a): by a licensed practitioner in the course of that practitioner's professional practice or by collaborative pharmacy practice agreement; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(63)(b): for a controlled substance or other prescription drug or device for use by a patient or an animal.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(64): "Prescription device" means an instrument, apparatus, implement, machine, contrivance, implant, in vitro reagent, or other similar or related article, and any component part or accessory, which is required under federal or state law to be prescribed by a practitioner and dispensed by or through a person or entity licensed under this chapter or exempt from licensure under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(65): "Prescription drug" means a drug that is required by federal or state law or rule to be dispensed only by prescription or is restricted to administration only by practitioners.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(66): (66)(a); Part 8, Dispensing Medical Practitioner and Dispensing Medical Practitioner Clinic Pharmacy "Repackage":
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(66)(a): means changing the container, wrapper, or labeling to further the distribution of a prescription drug; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(66)(b): (66)(a); Part 8, Dispensing Medical Practitioner and Dispensing Medical Practitioner Clinic Pharmacy does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(66)(b)(i): (66)(a) Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(66)(b)(ii): Part 8, Dispensing Medical Practitioner and Dispensing Medical Practitioner Clinic Pharmacy changing or altering a label as necessary for a dispensing practitioner under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(67): "Research using pharmaceuticals" means research:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(67)(a): conducted in a research facility, as defined by division rule, that is associated with a university or college in the state accredited by the Northwest Commission on Colleges and Universities;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(67)(b): requiring the use of a controlled substance, prescription drug, or prescription device;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(67)(c): that uses the controlled substance, prescription drug, or prescription device in accordance with standard research protocols and techniques, including, if required, those approved by an institutional review committee; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(67)(d): that includes any documentation required for the conduct of the research and the handling of the controlled substance, prescription drug, or prescription device.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(68): "Retail pharmacy" means a pharmaceutical facility dispensing prescription drugs and devices to the general public.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(69): 76-7-301
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(69)(a): "Self-administered hormonal contraceptive" means a self-administered hormonal contraceptive that is approved by the United States Food and Drug Administration to prevent pregnancy.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(69)(b): "Self-administered hormonal contraceptive" includes an oral hormonal contraceptive, a hormonal vaginal ring, and a hormonal contraceptive patch.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(69)(c): 76-7-301 "Self-administered hormonal contraceptive" does not include any drug intended to induce an abortion, as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(70): "Self-audit" means an internal evaluation of a pharmacy to determine compliance with this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(71): "Supervising pharmacist" means a pharmacist who is overseeing the operation of the pharmacy during a given day or shift.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(72): "Supportive personnel" means unlicensed individuals who:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(72)(a): may assist a pharmacist, pharmacist preceptor, pharmacy intern, or licensed pharmacy technician in nonjudgmental duties not included in the definition of the practice of pharmacy, practice of a pharmacy intern, or practice of a licensed pharmacy technician, and as those duties may be further defined by division rule adopted in collaboration with the board; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(72)(b): are supervised by a pharmacist in accordance with rules adopted by the division in collaboration with the board.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(73): 58-1-501; 58-17b-501 "Unlawful conduct" means the same as that term is defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(74): 58-1-501; 58-17b-502 "Unprofessional conduct" means the same as that term is defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-102(75): "Veterinary pharmaceutical facility" means a pharmaceutical facility that dispenses drugs intended for use by animals or for sale to veterinarians for the administration for animals.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-103 Administrative inspections.
------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-103(1): Part 3, Licensing; Part 3, Licensing The division may for the purpose of ascertaining compliance with the provisions of this chapter, require a self-audit or enter and inspect the business premises of a person:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-103(1)(a): Part 3, Licensing licensed under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-103(1)(b): Part 3, Licensing who is engaged in activities that require a license under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-103(2): (1); 58-17b-504 Before conducting an inspection under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-103(2)(a): give proper identification;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-103(2)(b): request to see the applicable license or licenses;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-103(2)(c): describe the nature and purpose of the inspection; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-103(2)(d): 58-17b-504 provide upon request, the authority of the division to conduct the inspection and the penalty for refusing to permit the inspection as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-103(3): (1); (2); Part 3, Licensing; (3) In conducting an inspection under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-103(3)(a): Part 3, Licensing examine any record, prescription, order, drug, device, equipment, machine, electronic device or media, or area related to activities for which a license has been issued or is required by
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-103(3)(b): reproduce any record or media at the division's own cost;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-103(3)(c): take a drug or device for further analysis if considered necessary;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-103(3)(d): temporarily seize a drug or device that is suspected to be adulterated, misbranded, outdated, or otherwise in violation of this chapter, pending an adjudicative proceeding on the matter;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-103(3)(e): box and seal drugs suspected to be adulterated, outdated, misbranded, or otherwise in violation of this chapter; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-103(3)(f): (3) dispose of or return a drug or device obtained under this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-103(4): (1) An inspection described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-103(5): Chapter 37, Utah Controlled Substances Act; 58-17b-504 If, upon inspection, the division concludes that a person has violated the provisions of this chapter or


Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-201 Board -- Membership -- Qualifications -- Terms.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-201(1): There is created the Utah State Board of Pharmacy consisting of five pharmacists, one pharmacy technician, and one member of the general public.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-201(1)(a): The public member of the board shall be a Utah resident who:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-201(1)(a)(i): is 21 years of age or older;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-201(1)(a)(ii): has never been licensed to engage in the practice of pharmacy;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-201(1)(a)(iii): has never been the spouse of a person licensed to engage in the practice of pharmacy;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-201(1)(a)(iv): has never held any material financial interest in pharmacy practice; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-201(1)(a)(v): has never engaged in any activity directly related to the practice of pharmacy.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-201(1)(b): The licensed pharmacist and licensed pharmacy technician members of the board shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-201(1)(b)(i): have been Utah residents continuously for at least three years;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-201(1)(b)(ii): have at least five years experience in the practice of pharmacy in good standing with the division in Utah after licensure; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-201(1)(b)(iii): maintain licensure in good standing to engage in the practice of pharmacy or practice as a pharmacy technician in Utah for the duration of the appointment.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-201(2): 58-1-201 The board shall be appointed and serve in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-201(3): 58-1-202; 58-1-203; 58-37f-202 The duties and responsibilities of the board are in accordance with Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-201(3)(a): assist the division in reviewing complaints concerning the unlawful or unprofessional conduct of a licensee; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-201(3)(b): advise the division in its investigation of these complaints.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-201(4): (3) A board member who has, under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-201(5): 58-1-201(2)(e); Chapter 37, Utah Controlled Substances Act A board member may be removed in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-201(5)(a): refusal or inability for any reason of a board member to perform his duties as a member of the Board in an efficient, responsible, and professional manner;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-201(5)(b): misuse of appointment to obtain personal, pecuniary, or material gain or advantage for himself or another through such appointment; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-201(5)(c): Chapter 37, Utah Controlled Substances Act violation of the laws governing the practice of pharmacy or


Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-301 License required -- License classifications for individuals.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-301(1): 58-1-307; 58-17b-309 A license is required to engage in the practice of pharmacy, telepharmacy, pharmacy technician, or dispensing medical practitioner except as specifically provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-301(2): The division shall issue to an individual who qualifies under this chapter a license in the classification of:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-301(2)(a): pharmacist;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-301(2)(b): pharmacy intern;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-301(2)(c): pharmacy technician;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-301(2)(d): dispensing medical practitioner; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-301(2)(e): pharmacy technician trainee.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-302 License required -- License classifications for pharmacy facilities.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-302(1): 58-1-307; Title 4, Chapter 41a, Cannabis Production Establishments and Pharmacies; Chapter 88, Part 2, Dispensing Practice A license is required to act as a pharmacy, except:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-302(1)(a): 58-1-307 as specifically exempted from licensure under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-302(1)(b): Title 4, Chapter 41a, Cannabis Production Establishments and Pharmacies for the operation of a medical cannabis pharmacy under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-302(1)(c): Chapter 88, Part 2, Dispensing Practice to operate a licensed dispensing practice under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-302(2): The division shall issue a pharmacy license to a facility that qualifies under this chapter in the classification of a:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-302(2)(a): class A pharmacy;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-302(2)(b): class B pharmacy;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-302(2)(c): class C pharmacy;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-302(2)(d): class D pharmacy;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-302(2)(e): class E pharmacy; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-302(2)(f): dispensing medical practitioner clinic pharmacy.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-302(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-302(3)(a): Each place of business shall require a separate license.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-302(3)(b): If multiple pharmacies exist at the same address, a separate license shall be required for each pharmacy.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-302(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-302(4)(a): The division may further define or supplement the classifications of pharmacies.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-302(4)(b): The division may impose restrictions upon classifications to protect the public health, safety, and welfare.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-302(5): Each pharmacy shall have a pharmacist-in-charge, except as otherwise provided by rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-302(6): Whenever an applicable statute or rule requires or prohibits action by a pharmacy, the pharmacist-in-charge and the owner of the pharmacy shall be responsible for all activities of the pharmacy, regardless of the form of the business organization.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-303 Qualifications for licensure as a pharmacist.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-303(1): 63J-1-504; 58-1-501 An applicant for licensure as a pharmacist shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-303(1)(a): submit an application in a form prescribed by the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-303(1)(b): 63J-1-504 pay a fee as determined by the department under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-303(1)(c): 58-1-501 complete a criminal background check and be free from criminal convictions as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-303(1)(d): have no physical or mental condition of a nature which prevents the applicant from engaging in the practice of pharmacy with reasonable skill, competency, and safety to the public;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-303(1)(e): have graduated and received a professional entry degree from a school or college of pharmacy which is accredited by the Accreditation Council on Pharmacy Education;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-303(1)(f): have completed an internship meeting standards established by division rule made in collaboration with the board; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-303(1)(g): have successfully passed examinations required by division rule made in collaboration with the board.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-303(2): (1)(a); (d); (f); (g) An applicant for licensure as a pharmacist whose pharmacy education was completed at a foreign pharmacy school shall, in addition to the requirements under Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-303(3): 63J-1-504; 58-1-501; (1) An applicant for a license by endorsement as a pharmacist under this section shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-303(3)(a): submit a written application in the form prescribed by the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-303(3)(b): 63J-1-504 pay the fee determined by the department under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-303(3)(c): 58-1-501 complete a criminal background check and be free from criminal convictions as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-303(3)(d): have no physical or mental condition of a nature which prevents the applicant from engaging in the practice of pharmacy with reasonable skill, competency, and safety to the public;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-303(3)(e): have lawfully practiced as a licensed pharmacist a minimum of 2,000 hours in the four years immediately preceding the date of application;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-303(3)(f): (1) produce satisfactory evidence of completing the professional education required under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-303(3)(g): be currently licensed in good standing as a pharmacist in another state, territory, or possession of the United States;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-303(3)(h): produce satisfactory evidence that the examination requirements are or were at the time the license was issued, equal to those of this state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-303(3)(i): pass the jurisprudence examination prescribed by division rule made in collaboration with the board.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-304 Qualifications for licensure of pharmacy intern.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
An applicant for licensure as a pharmacy intern shall:Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-304(1): submit an application in a form prescribed by the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-304(2): 63J-1-504 pay a fee determined by the department under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-304(3): 58-1-501 complete a criminal background check and be free from criminal convictions as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-304(4): have no physical or mental condition of a nature which prevents the applicant from engaging in the practice of pharmacy with reasonable skill, competency, and safety to the public;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-304(5): meet the preliminary educational qualifications required by division rule made in collaboration with the board; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-304(6): meet one of the following educational criteria:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-304(6)(a): be a current pharmacy student, a resident, or fellow in a program approved by division rule made in collaboration with the board; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-304(6)(b): have graduated from a foreign pharmacy school and received certification of equivalency from a credentialing agency approved by division rule made in collaboration with the board.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-305 Qualifications for licensure of pharmacy technician.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-305(1): 63J-1-504; 58-1-501 An applicant for licensure as a pharmacy technician shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-305(1)(a): submit an application in a form prescribed by the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-305(1)(b): 63J-1-504 pay a fee determined by the department under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-305(1)(c): 58-1-501 complete a criminal background check and be free from criminal convictions as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-305(1)(d): have no physical or mental condition of a nature which prevents the applicant from engaging in practice as a pharmacy technician with reasonable skill, competency, and safety to the public;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-305(1)(e): have completed a program and curriculum of education and training, meeting standards established by division rule made in collaboration with the board; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-305(1)(f): successfully complete the examinations requirement within the time periods established by division rule made in collaboration with the board.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-305(2): A pharmacist whose license has been denied, revoked, suspended, or restricted for disciplinary purposes is not eligible to be a licensed pharmacy technician while on probation with the division.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-305.1 Qualifications for licensure of pharmacy technician trainee.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-305.1(1): 63J-1-504 An applicant for licensure as a pharmacy technician trainee shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-305.1(1)(a): submit an application to the division on a form created by the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-305.1(1)(b): 63J-1-504 pay a fee established by the division in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-305.1(1)(c): unless exempted by the division, submit a completed criminal background check;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-305.1(1)(d): demonstrate, as determined by the division, that the applicant does not have a physical or mental condition that would prevent the applicant from engaging in practice as a pharmacy technician with reasonable skill, competency, and safety to the public;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-305.1(1)(e): submit evidence that the applicant is enrolled in a training program approved by the division; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-305.1(1)(f): satisfy any other criteria established by division rule made in collaboration with the board.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-305.1(2): A pharmacist whose license has been denied, revoked, suspended, or restricted for disciplinary purposes is not eligible to be licensed as a pharmacy technician trainee during division probation.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-306 Qualifications for licensure as a pharmacy.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-306(1): 63J-1-504; Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act; 58-17b-307; 58-17b-103 Each applicant for licensure under this section, except for those applying for a class D license, shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-306(1)(a): submit a written application in the form prescribed by the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-306(1)(b): 63J-1-504 pay a fee as determined by the department under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-306(1)(c): satisfy the division that the applicant, and each owner, officer, or manager of the applicant have not engaged in any act, practice, or omission, which when considered with the duties and responsibilities of a licensee under this section indicates there is cause to believe that issuing a license to the applicant is inconsistent with the interest of the public's health, safety, or welfare;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-306(1)(d): demonstrate the licensee's operations will be in accordance with all federal, state, and local laws relating to the type of activity engaged in by the licensee, including regulations of the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration and Food and Drug Administration;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-306(1)(e): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act maintain operating standards established by division rule made in collaboration with the board and in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-306(1)(f): 58-17b-307 for each pharmacy manager, submit fingerprint cards and consent to a fingerprint background check in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-306(1)(g): 58-17b-103 acknowledge the division's authority to inspect the licensee's business premises pursuant to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-306(2): 63J-1-504; 58-17b-307 Each applicant applying for a class D license shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-306(2)(a): submit a written application in the form prescribed by the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-306(2)(b): 63J-1-504 pay a fee as determined by the department under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-306(2)(c): present to the division verification of licensure in the state where physically located and verification that such license is in good standing;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-306(2)(d): satisfy the division that the applicant and each of the applicant's pharmacy managers has not engaged in any act, practice, or omission, which when considered with the duties and responsibilities of a licensee under this section, indicates there is cause to believe that issuing a license to the applicant is inconsistent with the interest of the public's health, safety, or welfare;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-306(2)(e): 58-17b-307 for each pharmacy manager, submit fingerprint cards and consent to a fingerprint background check in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-306(2)(f): provide a statement of the scope of pharmacy services that will be provided and a detailed description of the protocol as described by rule by which pharmacy care will be provided, including any collaborative practice arrangements with other health care practitioners;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-306(2)(g): sign an affidavit attesting that any healthcare practitioners employed by the applicant and physically located in Utah have the appropriate license issued by the division and in good standing;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-306(2)(h): sign an affidavit attesting that the applicant will abide by the pharmacy laws and regulations of the jurisdiction in which the pharmacy is located; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-306(2)(i): if an applicant engages in compounding, submit the most recent inspection report:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-306(2)(i)(i): conducted within two years before the application for licensure; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-306(2)(i)(ii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-306(2)(i)(ii)(A): conducted as part of the National Association of Boards of Pharmacy Verified Pharmacy Program; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-306(2)(i)(ii)(B): performed by the state licensing agency of the state in which the applicant is a resident and in accordance with the National Association of Boards of Pharmacy multistate inspection blueprint program.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-306(3): Each license issued under this section shall be issued for a single, specific address, and is not transferable or assignable.

Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-307(4)(c): provide the results from the state, regional, and nationwide criminal history background checks to the division.

Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-307(8): The division may not disseminate outside of the division any criminal history record information that the division obtains from the Bureau of Criminal Identification or the Federal Bureau of Investigation under the criminal background check requirements of this section.

Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-309 Exemptions from licensure.

Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-309.7 Opioid treatment program.
------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-309.7(1): 58-31b-102; 58-31b-102; 58-70a-102; 26B-2-103 As used in this section:
