Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-310 Continuing education.
------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-310(1): The division in collaboration with the board may establish by rule continuing education requirements for each classification of licensure under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-310(2): (1); 26B-4-219 The division shall accept and apply toward an hour requirement that the division establishes under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-401 Grounds for denial of licensure -- Disciplinary proceedings.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Grounds for the following action regarding a license issued under this chapter shall be in accordance with SectionUtah Code Annotated § 58-17b-401(1): refusal to issue a license to an applicant;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-401(2): refusal to renew the license of a licensee;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-401(3): to revoke, suspend, restrict, or place on probation the license of a licensee;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-401(4): to issue a public or private reprimand to a licensee;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-401(5): to issue cease and desist orders; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-401(6): to issue an administrative fine or citation.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-501 Unlawful conduct.
--------------------------------------------------
"Unlawful conduct" includes:Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-501(1): 58-17b-103 knowingly preventing or refusing to permit an authorized agent of the division to conduct an inspection pursuant to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-501(2): failing to deliver the license, permit, or certificate to the division upon demand, if it has been revoked, suspended, or refused;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-501(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-501(3)(a): using the title "pharmacist," "druggist," "pharmacy intern," "pharmacy technician," or a term having similar meaning, except by a person licensed as a pharmacist, pharmacy intern, or pharmacy technician; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-501(3)(b): conducting or transacting business under a name that contains, as part of that name, the words "drugstore," "pharmacy," "drugs," "medicine store," "medicines," "drug shop," "apothecary," "prescriptions," or a term having a similar meaning, or in any manner advertising, otherwise describing, or referring to the place of the conducted business or profession, unless the place is a pharmacy issued a license by the division, except an establishment selling nonprescription drugs and supplies may display signs bearing the words "packaged drugs," "drug sundries," or "nonprescription drugs," and is not considered to be a pharmacy or drugstore by reason of the display;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-501(4): buying, selling, causing to be sold, or offering for sale, a drug or device that bears, or the package bears or originally did bear, the inscription "sample," "not for resale," "for investigational or experimental use only," or other similar words, except when a cost is incurred in the bona fide acquisition of an investigational or experimental drug;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-501(5): using to a person's own advantages or revealing to anyone other than the division, board, and its authorized representatives, or to the courts, when relevant to a judicial or administrative proceeding under this chapter, information acquired under authority of this chapter or concerning a method of process that is a trade secret;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-501(6): procuring or attempting to procure a drug or to have someone else procure or attempt to procure a drug:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-501(6)(a): by fraud, deceit, misrepresentation, or subterfuge;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-501(6)(b): by forgery or alteration of a prescription or a written order;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-501(6)(c): by concealment of a material fact;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-501(6)(d): by use of a false statement in a prescription, chart, order, or report; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-501(6)(e): by theft;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-501(7): filling, refilling, or advertising the filling or refilling of prescriptions for a consumer or patient residing in this state if the person is not licensed:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-501(7)(a): under this chapter; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-501(7)(b): in the state from which he is dispensing;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-501(8): requiring an employed pharmacist, pharmacy intern, pharmacy technician, or authorized supportive personnel to engage in conduct in violation of this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-501(9): being in possession of a prescription drug for an unlawful purpose;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-501(10): Title 26B, Chapter 4, Part 5, Treatment Access dispensing a prescription drug to a person who does not have a prescription from a practitioner, except as permitted under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-501(11): dispensing a prescription drug to a person who the person dispensing the drug knows or should know is attempting to obtain drugs by fraud or misrepresentation;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-501(12): selling, dispensing, distributing, or otherwise trafficking in prescription drugs when not licensed to do so or when not exempted from licensure; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-501(13): a person using a prescription drug or controlled substance that was not lawfully prescribed for the person by a practitioner.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-502 Unprofessional conduct.
--------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-502(1): (2); 58-17b-503; Title 58, Chapter 37, Utah Controlled Substances Act; Title 26B, Chapter 4, Part 5, Treatment Access; Title 4, Chapter 41a, Cannabis Production Establishments and Pharmacies; Title 26B, Chapter 4, Part 2, Cannabinoid Research and Medical Cannabis; (1)(a); (o); 58-1-501(1) "Unprofessional conduct" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-502(1)(a): willfully deceiving or attempting to deceive the division, the board, or their agents as to any relevant matter regarding compliance under this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-502(1)(b): (2) except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-502(1)(b)(i): paying or offering rebates to practitioners or any other health care providers, or receiving or soliciting rebates from practitioners or any other health care provider; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-502(1)(b)(ii): paying, offering, receiving, or soliciting compensation in the form of a commission, bonus, rebate, kickback, or split fee arrangement with practitioners or any other health care provider, for the purpose of obtaining referrals;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-502(1)(c): misbranding or adulteration of any drug or device or the sale, distribution, or dispensing of any outdated, misbranded, or adulterated drug or device;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-502(1)(d): engaging in the sale or purchase of drugs or devices that are samples or packages bearing the inscription "sample" or "not for resale" or similar words or phrases;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-502(1)(e): 58-17b-503 except as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-502(1)(f): an act in violation of this chapter committed by a person for any form of compensation if the act is incidental to the person's professional activities, including the activities of a pharmacist, pharmacy intern, or pharmacy technician;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-502(1)(g): Title 58, Chapter 37, Utah Controlled Substances Act violating:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-502(1)(g)(i): the federal Controlled Substances Act, Title II, P.L. 91-513;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-502(1)(g)(ii): Title 58, Chapter 37, Utah Controlled Substances Act
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-502(1)(g)(iii): rules or regulations adopted under either act;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-502(1)(h): requiring or permitting pharmacy interns or technicians to engage in activities outside the scope of practice for their respective license classifications, as defined in this chapter and division rules made in collaboration with the board, or beyond their scope of training and ability;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-502(1)(i): administering:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-502(1)(i)(i): without appropriate training, as defined by rule;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-502(1)(i)(ii): without a physician's order, when one is required by law; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-502(1)(i)(iii): in conflict with a practitioner's written guidelines or written protocol for administering;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-502(1)(j): disclosing confidential patient information in violation of the provisions of the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996, Pub. L. No. 104-191, 110 Stat. 1936, as amended, or other applicable law;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-502(1)(k): engaging in the practice of pharmacy without a licensed pharmacist designated as the pharmacist-in-charge;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-502(1)(l): failing to report to the division any adverse action taken by another licensing jurisdiction, government agency, law enforcement agency, or court for conduct that in substance would be considered unprofessional conduct under this section;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-502(1)(m): as a pharmacist or pharmacy intern, compounding a prescription drug in a dosage form which is regularly and commonly available from a manufacturer in quantities and strengths prescribed by a practitioner;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-502(1)(n): Title 26B, Chapter 4, Part 5, Treatment Access failing to act in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-502(1)(o): Title 4, Chapter 41a, Cannabis Production Establishments and Pharmacies; Title 26B, Chapter 4, Part 2, Cannabinoid Research and Medical Cannabis violating the requirements of
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-502(1)(p): (1)(a); (o); 58-1-501(1) falsely making an entry in, or altering, a medical record with the intent to conceal:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-502(1)(p)(i): a wrongful or negligent act or omission of an individual licensed under this chapter or an individual under the direction or control of an individual licensed under this chapter; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-502(1)(p)(ii): (1)(a); (o); 58-1-501(1) conduct described in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-502(2): (1)(b) Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-502(2)(a): giving or receiving a price discount based on purchase volume;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-502(2)(b): passing along a pharmaceutical manufacturer's rebate; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-502(2)(c): providing compensation for services to a veterinarian.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-502(3): Title 26B, Chapter 4, Part 2, Cannabinoid Research and Medical Cannabis; 26B-4-201; 58-1-501(2)(b)(i) "Unprofessional conduct" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-502(3)(a): Title 26B, Chapter 4, Part 2, Cannabinoid Research and Medical Cannabis; 26B-4-201 in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-502(3)(b): 58-1-501(2)(b)(i) if a pharmacist reasonably believes that a prescription drug will have adverse or harmful effects on an individual and warns the individual of the potential effects, filling a prescription prescribed by a health care provider who:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-502(3)(b)(i): is operating within the health care provider's scope of practice; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-502(3)(b)(ii): 58-1-501(2)(b)(i) is deviating from a medical norm or established practice in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-502(4): (3); Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act; (3)(a); (b) Notwithstanding Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-503 Exception to unprofessional conduct.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-503(1): Title 26B, Chapter 2, Part 2, Health Care Facility Licensing and Inspection; 26B-2-201 For purposes of this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-503(1)(a): Title 26B, Chapter 2, Part 2, Health Care Facility Licensing and Inspection "Licensed intermediate care facility for people with an intellectual disability" means an intermediate care facility for people with an intellectual disability that is licensed as a nursing care facility or a small health care facility under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-503(1)(b): 26B-2-201 "Nursing care facility" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-503(1)(c): "Unit pack" means a tamper-resistant nonreusable single-dose single-drug package with identification that indicates the lot number and expiration date for the drug.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-503(2): Part 9, Charitable Prescription Drug Recycling Act A pharmacist may accept and redistribute an unused drug, or part of it, after it has left the premises of the pharmacy:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-503(2)(a): Part 9, Charitable Prescription Drug Recycling Act in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-503(2)(b): if:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-503(2)(b)(i): the drug was prescribed to a patient in a nursing care facility, licensed intermediate care facility for people with an intellectual disability, or state prison facility, county jail, or state hospital;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-503(2)(b)(ii): the drug was stored under the supervision of a licensed health care provider according to manufacturer recommendations;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-503(2)(b)(iii): the drug is in a unit pack or in the manufacturer's sealed container;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-503(2)(b)(iv): the drug was returned to the original dispensing pharmacy;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-503(2)(b)(v): the drug was initially dispensed by a licensed pharmacist or licensed pharmacy intern; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-503(2)(b)(vi): accepting back and redistributing of the drug complies with federal Food and Drug Administration and Drug Enforcement Administration regulations; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-503(2)(c): if:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-503(2)(c)(i): the pharmacy has attempted to deliver the drug to a patient or a patient's agent via the United States Postal Service, a licensed common carrier, or supportive personnel;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-503(2)(c)(ii): the drug is returned to the pharmacy by the same person or carrier that attempted to deliver the drug; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-503(2)(c)(iii): in accordance with United States Food and Drug Administration regulations and rules established by the division, a pharmacist at the pharmacy determines that the drug has not been adversely affected by the drug's attempted delivery and return.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-504 Penalty for unlawful or unprofessional conduct -- Fines -- Citations.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-504(1): 58-1-501(1)(a)(i); 58-17b-501(7); (11) Any person who violates any of the unlawful conduct provisions of Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-504(3): (5); 58-17b-401; 58-17b-505
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-504(3)(a): (5); 58-17b-401 Subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-504(3)(a)(i): assess administrative penalties; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-504(3)(a)(ii): take any other appropriate administrative action.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-504(3)(b): 58-17b-505 An administrative penalty imposed pursuant to this section shall be deposited in the General Fund as a dedicated credit to be used by the division for pharmacy licensee education and enforcement as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-504(4): 58-17b-501 If a licensee has been convicted of violating Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-504(5): 58-17b-501; 58-17b-502; Chapter 37, Utah Controlled Substances Act; Chapter 37f, Controlled Substance Database Act; Chapter 1, Division of Professional Licensing Act; Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act; 58-17b-501; 58-17b-502; Chapter 37, Utah Controlled Substances Act; Chapter 37f, Controlled Substance Database Act; Chapter 1, Division of Professional Licensing Act; (5); 58-17b-501; 58-17b-502; Chapter 37, Utah Controlled Substances Act; Chapter 1, Division of Professional Licensing Act; 58-17b-401; Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-504(5)(a): 58-17b-501; 58-17b-502; Chapter 37, Utah Controlled Substances Act; Chapter 37f, Controlled Substance Database Act; Chapter 1, Division of Professional Licensing Act; Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act If upon inspection or investigation, the division concludes that a person has violated the provisions of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-504(5)(b): 58-17b-501; 58-17b-502; Chapter 37, Utah Controlled Substances Act; Chapter 37f, Controlled Substance Database Act; Chapter 1, Division of Professional Licensing Act; (5); 58-17b-501; 58-17b-502; Chapter 37, Utah Controlled Substances Act; Chapter 1, Division of Professional Licensing Act Any person who is in violation of the provisions of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-504(5)(c): 58-17b-401 Except for an administrative fine and a cease and desist order, the licensure sanctions cited in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-504(5)(d): Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act Each citation shall be in writing and specifically describe with particularity the nature of the violation, including a reference to the provision of the chapter, rule, or order alleged to have been violated.  The citation shall clearly state that the recipient must notify the division in writing within 20 calendar days of service of the citation in order to contest the citation at a hearing conducted under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-504(5)(e): Each citation issued under this section, or a copy of each citation, may be served upon any person upon whom a summons may be served:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-504(5)(e)(i): in accordance with the Utah Rules of Civil Procedure;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-504(5)(e)(ii): personally or upon the person's agent by a division investigator or by any person specially designated by the director; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-504(5)(e)(iii): by mail.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-504(5)(f): If within 20 calendar days from the service of a citation, the person to whom the citation was issued fails to request a hearing to contest the citation, the citation becomes the final order of the division and is not subject to further agency review.  The period to contest the citation may be extended by the division for cause.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-504(5)(g): The division may refuse to issue or renew, suspend, revoke, or place on probation the license of a licensee who fails to comply with the citation after it becomes final.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-504(5)(h): The failure of an applicant for licensure to comply with a citation after it becomes final is a ground for denial of license.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-504(5)(i): No citation may be issued under this section after the expiration of one year following the date on which the violation that is the subject of the citation is reported to the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-504(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-504(6)(a): The director may collect a penalty that is not paid by:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-504(6)(a)(i): referring the matter to a collection agency; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-504(6)(a)(ii): bringing an action in the district court of the county where the person against whom the penalty is imposed resides or in the county where the office of the director is located.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-504(6)(b): A county attorney or the attorney general of the state shall provide legal assistance and advice to the director in an action to collect a penalty.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-504(6)(c): A court shall award reasonable attorney fees and costs to the prevailing party in an action brought by the division to collect a penalty.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-505 Educational and enforcement fund.
------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-505(1): 58-17b-504 The director may use the money collected pursuant to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-505(1)(a): education and training of licensees under this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-505(1)(b): enforcement of this chapter by:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-505(1)(b)(i): investigating unprofessional or unlawful conduct;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-505(1)(b)(ii): providing legal representation to the division when legal action is taken against a person engaging in unprofessional or unlawful conduct;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-505(1)(b)(iii): monitoring compliance of renewal requirement; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-505(1)(b)(iv): education and training of division staff and board members.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-505(2): (1) All funding for the purposes listed in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-505(3): Any penalty which is not paid may be collected by the director by either referring the matter to a collection agency or bringing an action in the district court of the county in which the person against whom the penalty is imposed resides or in the county where the office of the director is located.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-505(4): Any county attorney or the attorney general of the state is to provide legal assistance and advice to the director in any action to collect the penalty.  In any action brought to enforce the provisions of this section, reasonable attorney's fees and costs shall be awarded in which the person against whom the penalty is imposed resides or in the county where the office of the director is located.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-506 Petitioning for reinstatement of licensure.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Any person whose license to practice pharmacy in this state has been revoked, suspended, or surrendered voluntarily or by action of the division, shall have the right at reasonable intervals, to petition the division for reinstatement of such license.  Such petition shall be made in writing and in the form prescribed by the division.  Upon investigation and hearing, the division may, in its discretion, grant or deny such petition, or it may modify its original finding to reflect any circumstances that have changed sufficiently to warrant such modifications.  The division, also at its discretion, may require such person to pass an examination or examinations for re-entry into the practice of pharmacy.

Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-507 Opiate antagonist -- Immunity from liability -- Exclusion from unlawful or unprofessional conduct.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-507(1): 26B-4-501; 26B-4-501 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-507(1)(a): 26B-4-501 "Opiate antagonist" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-507(1)(b): 26B-4-501 "Opiate-related drug overdose event" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-507(2): 26B-4-510(2) A person licensed under this chapter that dispenses an opiate antagonist to an individual with a prescription for an opiate antagonist, to an overdose outreach provider with a prescription for an opiate antagonist, or pursuant to a standing prescription drug order issued in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-507(3): Title 26B, Chapter 4, Part 5, Treatment Access The provisions of this section and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-507(4): 26B-4-512(1)(a)(i)(A); (1)(a)(i)(F); 26B-4-510(2) It is not unprofessional conduct or unlawful conduct for a licensee under this chapter to dispense an opiate antagonist to a person, including a person described in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-507(5): 26B-4-509(2)(a)(iii) It is not unprofessional conduct or unlawful conduct for a licensee under this chapter to dispense an opiate antagonist to an overdose outreach provider if the overdose outreach provider has a prescription for the opiate antagonist from a licensed prescriber issued pursuant to Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-601 General operating standards.
-------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-601(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-601(1)(a): The division shall make rules relating to the operations and conduct of facilities, individuals, and entities which are regulated under this chapter, to protect the public health, safety, and welfare.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-601(1)(b): The rules shall be consistent with the regulations of the Federal Food and Drug Administration and Drug Enforcement Administration, this chapter, and all other laws relating to activities and persons regulated under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-601(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-601(2)(a): This chapter does not prevent, restrict, or in any other manner interfere with the sale of nonprescription drugs.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-601(2)(b): The division may not make any rules under this chapter that require nonprescription drugs to be sold by a licensed pharmacist or only in a pharmaceutical facility.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-601(2)(c): The sale or distribution of nonprescription drugs does not constitute the practice of pharmacy.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-602 Prescription orders -- Information required -- Alteration -- Labels -- Signatures -- Dispensing in pharmacies.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-602(1): 58-1-501.3 Except as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-602(1)(a): the prescriber's name, address, and telephone number, and, if the order is for a controlled substance, the patient's age and the prescriber's DEA number;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-602(1)(b): the patient's name and address or, in the case of an animal, the name of the owner and species of the animal;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-602(1)(c): the date of issuance;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-602(1)(d): the name of the medication or device prescribed and dispensing instructions, if necessary;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-602(1)(e): the directions, if appropriate, for the use of the prescription by the patient or animal and any refill, special labeling, or other instructions;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-602(1)(f): the prescriber's signature if the prescription order is written;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-602(1)(g): if the order is an electronically transmitted prescription order, the prescribing practitioner's electronic signature; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-602(1)(h): if the order is a hard copy prescription order generated from electronic media, the prescribing practitioner's electronic or manual signature.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-602(2): (1)(a) The requirement of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-602(3): Unless it is for a Schedule II controlled substance, a prescription order may be dispensed by a pharmacist or pharmacy intern upon an oral prescription of a practitioner only if the oral prescription is promptly reduced to writing.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-602(4): (4)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-602(4)(a): (4)(b) Except as provided under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-602(4)(b): A pharmacist or pharmacy intern dispensing or compounding a prescription may alter or make additions to the prescription after receiving permission of the prescriber and may make entries or additions on the prescription required by law or necessitated in the compounding and dispensing procedures.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-602(5): (7); (5)(a)(i); (vi); Title 26B, Chapter 2, Part 2, Health Care Facility Licensing and Inspection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-602(5)(a): (7) Each drug dispensed shall have a label securely affixed to the container indicating the following minimum information:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-602(5)(a)(i): the name, address, and telephone number of the pharmacy;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-602(5)(a)(ii): the serial number of the prescription as assigned by the dispensing pharmacy;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-602(5)(a)(iii): the filling date of the prescription or its last dispensing date;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-602(5)(a)(iv): the name of the patient, or in the case of an animal, the name of the owner and species of the animal;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-602(5)(a)(v): the name of the prescriber;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-602(5)(a)(vi): the directions for use and cautionary statements, if any, which are contained in the prescription order or are needed;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-602(5)(a)(vii): (7) except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-602(5)(a)(viii): the beyond use date.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-602(5)(b): (5)(a)(i); (vi); Title 26B, Chapter 2, Part 2, Health Care Facility Licensing and Inspection The requirements described in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-602(5)(b)(i): a pharmaceutical administration facility; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-602(5)(b)(ii): Title 26B, Chapter 2, Part 2, Health Care Facility Licensing and Inspection a hospital licensed under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-602(6): A hospital pharmacy that dispenses a prescription drug that is packaged in a multidose container to a hospital patient may provide the drug in the multidose container to the patient when the patient is discharged from the hospital if:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-602(6)(a): the pharmacy receives a discharge order for the patient; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-602(6)(b): the pharmacy labels the drug with the:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-602(6)(b)(i): patient's name;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-602(6)(b)(ii): drug's name and strength;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-602(6)(b)(iii): directions for use of the drug, if applicable; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-602(6)(b)(iv): pharmacy's name and phone number.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-602(7): If the prescriber specifically indicates the name of the prescription product should not appear on the label, then any of the trade, generic, chemical, established proprietary, and established nonproprietary names and the strength of dosage form may not be included.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-602(8): 58-17b-602.5 Prescribers are encouraged to include on prescription labels the information described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-602(9): A pharmacy may only deliver a prescription drug to a patient or a patient's agent:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-602(9)(a): in person at the pharmacy; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-602(9)(b): via the United States Postal Service, a licensed common carrier, or supportive personnel, if the pharmacy takes reasonable precautions to ensure the prescription drug is:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-602(9)(b)(i): delivered to the patient or patient's agent; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-602(9)(b)(ii): returned to the pharmacy.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-602.1 Dispensing quantity or dosage form different from prescription.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-602.1(1): Without specific authorization from a prescriber, a pharmacist or pharmacy intern may dispense:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-602.1(1)(a): a prescription in a quantity different than the quantity prescribed if the prescribed quantity or package size is not commercially available; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-602.1(1)(b): a prescription in a dosage form different than the dosage form prescribed, if in the professional judgement of the pharmacist or pharmacy intern, dispensing a different dosage form is in the best interest of the patient.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-602.1(2): This section does not apply if:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-602.1(2)(a): the substitute would change the bioavailability of the medication;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-602.1(2)(b): the substitute would change the treatment parameters; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-602.1(2)(c): the prescriber has written or clearly designated "dispense as written" on the prescription.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-602.5 Information on prescription labels -- Education outreach.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The division, in order to assist emergency responders in quickly determining the physical condition of a patient at the scene of an emergency, as well as for the benefit of physicians and consumers, shall:Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-602.5(1): 58-17b-602 provide information on the pharmacy licensing website recommending that prescribers, pharmacists, and pharmacy interns include information on the label of a drug dispensed under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-602.5(2): (1) as part of the website information, specify that information described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-603 Identification of pharmacy personnel.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-603(1): All individuals employed in a pharmacy facility having any contact with the public or patients receiving services from that pharmacy facility shall wear on their person a clearly visible and readable identification showing the individual's name and position.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-603(2): When communicating by any means, written, verbal, or electronic, pharmacy personnel must identify themselves as to licensure classification.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-604 Medication profiles.
-----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-604(1): Each pharmacy shall establish a medication profile system for pharmacy patients according to the standards established by division rules made in collaboration with the board.  The rules shall indicate the method for recording all prescription information.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-604(2): The pharmacy shall maintain the medication profile for any pharmacy patient who expresses a desire for that professional service.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-604(3): The pharmacy may charge an appropriate professional fee for this service and for copying or providing information in the medication profile to another authorized person.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-604(4): A pharmacist, pharmacy intern, or pharmacy technician may not release or discuss the information contained in a prescription or patient's medication profile to anyone except:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-604(4)(a): the pharmacy patient in person or the pharmacy patient's legal guardian or designee;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-604(4)(b): a lawfully authorized federal, state, or local drug enforcement officer;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-604(4)(c): a third party payment program administered under terms authorized by the pharmacy patient;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-604(4)(d): a pharmacist, pharmacy intern, or pharmacy technician providing pharmacy services to the patient or a prescribing practitioner providing professional services to the patient;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-604(4)(e): another pharmacist, pharmacy intern, pharmacy technician, or prescribing practitioner to whom the patient has requested a prescription transfer; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-604(4)(f): the pharmacy patient's attorney, after the presentation of a written authorization signed by the:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-604(4)(f)(i): patient, before a notary public;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-604(4)(f)(ii): parent or lawful guardian, if the patient is a minor;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-604(4)(f)(iii): lawful guardian, if the patient is incompetent; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-604(4)(f)(iv): personal representative, if the patient is deceased.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605 Drug product equivalents.
----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605(1): 58-17b-102; 58-17b-605.5; (1)(b)(i); (9) For the purposes of this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605(1)(a): 58-17b-102; 58-17b-605.5
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605(1)(a)(i): 58-17b-102 "Drug" is as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605(1)(a)(ii): 58-17b-605.5 "Drug" does not mean a "biological product" as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605(1)(b): (1)(b)(i); (9) "Drug product equivalent" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605(1)(b)(i): a drug product that is designated as the therapeutic equivalent of another drug product in the Approved Drug Products with Therapeutic Equivalence Evaluations prepared by the Center for Drug Evaluation and Research of the United States Food and Drug Administration; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605(1)(b)(ii): (1)(b)(i); (9) notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605(2): (6) A pharmacist or pharmacy intern dispensing a prescription order for a specific drug by brand or proprietary name may substitute a drug product equivalent for the prescribed drug only if:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605(2)(a): the purchaser specifically requests or consents to the substitution of a drug product equivalent;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605(2)(b): the drug product equivalent is of the same generic type and is designated the therapeutic equivalent in the approved drug products with therapeutic equivalence evaluations prepared by the Center for Drug Evaluation and Research of the Federal Food and Drug Administration;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605(2)(c): the drug product equivalent is permitted to move in interstate commerce;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605(2)(d): the pharmacist or pharmacy intern counsels the patient on the use and the expected response to the prescribed drug, whether a substitute or not, and the substitution is not otherwise prohibited by this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605(2)(e): (6) the prescribing practitioner has not indicated that a drug product equivalent may not be substituted for the drug, as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605(2)(f): the substitution is not otherwise prohibited by law.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605(3)(a): Each out-of-state mail service pharmacy dispensing a drug product equivalent as a substitute for another drug into this state shall notify the patient of the substitution either by telephone or in writing.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605(3)(b): Each out-of-state mail service pharmacy shall comply with the requirements of this chapter with respect to a drug product equivalent substituted for another drug, including labeling and record keeping.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605(4): Pharmacists or pharmacy interns may not substitute without the prescriber's authorization on trade name drug product prescriptions unless the product is currently categorized in the approved drug products with therapeutic equivalence evaluations prepared by the Center for Drug Evaluation and Research of the Federal Food and Drug Administration as a drug product considered to be therapeutically equivalent to another drug product.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605(5): A pharmacist or pharmacy intern who dispenses a prescription with a drug product equivalent under this section assumes no greater liability than would be incurred had the pharmacist or pharmacy intern dispensed the prescription with the drug product prescribed.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605(6)(a): If, in the opinion of the prescribing practitioner, it is in the best interest of the patient that a drug product equivalent not be substituted for a prescribed drug, the practitioner may indicate a prohibition on substitution either by writing "dispense as written" or signing in the appropriate space where two lines have been preprinted on a prescription order and captioned "dispense as written" or "substitution permitted".
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605(6)(b): If the prescription is communicated orally by the prescribing practitioner to the pharmacist or pharmacy intern, the practitioner shall indicate the prohibition on substitution and that indication shall be noted in writing by the pharmacist or pharmacy intern with the name of the practitioner and the words "orally by" and the initials of the pharmacist or pharmacy intern written after it.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605(7): A pharmacist or pharmacy intern who substitutes a drug product equivalent for a prescribed drug shall communicate the substitution to the purchaser.  The drug product equivalent container shall be labeled with the name of the drug dispensed, and the pharmacist, pharmacy intern, or pharmacy technician shall indicate on the file copy of the prescription both the name of the prescribed drug and the name of the drug product equivalent dispensed in its place.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605(8): (8); (6)(a); (6)(a); (b); (8)(d); (8)(c)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605(8)(a): (8) For purposes of this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605(8)(a)(i): a generic drug for another generic drug;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605(8)(a)(ii): a generic drug for a nongeneric drug;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605(8)(a)(iii): a nongeneric drug for another nongeneric drug; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605(8)(a)(iv): a nongeneric drug for a generic drug.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605(8)(b): (6)(a); (6)(a); (b) A prescribing practitioner who makes a finding under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605(8)(c): (8)(d) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605(8)(d): (8)(c) Notification under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605(9): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act; 58-67-201; 58-68-201; (2)(b); (4)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605(9)(a): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act; 58-67-201; 58-68-201 The division shall designate by rule made in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605(9)(b): (2)(b); (4) Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605(10): Failure of a licensed medical practitioner to specify that no substitution is authorized does not constitute evidence of negligence.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605.5 Interchangeable biological products.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605.5(1): For the purposes of this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605.5(1)(a): "Biological product" means the same as that term is defined in 42 U.S.C. Sec. 262.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605.5(1)(b): "Interchangeable biological product" means a biological product that the federal Food and Drug Administration:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605.5(1)(b)(i): has:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605.5(1)(b)(i)(A): licensed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605.5(1)(b)(i)(B): determined meets the standards for interchangeability pursuant to 42 U.S.C. Sec. 262(k)(4); or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605.5(1)(b)(ii): has determined is therapeutically equivalent as set forth in the latest edition of or supplement to the federal Food and Drug Administration's Approved Drug Products with Therapeutic Equivalence Evaluations.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605.5(2): (6) A pharmacist or pharmacy intern dispensing a prescription order for a specific biological product by brand or proprietary name may substitute an interchangeable biological product for the prescribed biological product only if:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605.5(2)(a): the purchaser specifically requests or consents to the substitute of an interchangeable biological product;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605.5(2)(b): the interchangeable biological product is permitted to move in interstate commerce;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605.5(2)(c): the pharmacist or pharmacy intern counsels the patient on the use and the expected response to the prescribed biological product, whether a substitute or not, and the substitution is not otherwise prohibited by this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605.5(2)(d): (6) the prescribing practitioner has not prohibited the substitution of an interchangeable biological product for the prescribed biological product, as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605.5(2)(e): the substitution is not otherwise prohibited by law.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605.5(3): Each out-of-state mail service pharmacy dispensing an interchangeable biological product as a substitute for another biological product into this state shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605.5(3)(a): notify the patient of the substitution either by telephone or in writing; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605.5(3)(b): comply with the requirements of this chapter with respect to an interchangeable biological product substituted for another biological product, including labeling and record keeping.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605.5(4): Pharmacists or pharmacy interns may not substitute without the prescriber's authorization biological product prescriptions unless the product has been determined by the United States Food and Drug Administration to be interchangeable with the prescribed biological product.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605.5(5): A pharmacist or pharmacy intern who dispenses a prescription with an interchangeable biological product under this section assumes no greater liability than would be incurred had the pharmacist or pharmacy intern dispensed the prescription with the biological product prescribed.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605.5(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605.5(6)(a): If, in the opinion of the prescribing practitioner, it is in the best interest of the patient that an interchangeable biological product not be substituted for a prescribed biological product, the practitioner may prohibit a substitution either by writing "dispense as written" or by signing in the appropriate space where two lines have been preprinted on a prescription order and captioned "dispense as written" or "substitution permitted."
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605.5(6)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605.5(6)(b)(i): If the prescription is communicated orally by the prescribing practitioner to the pharmacist or pharmacy intern, the practitioner shall direct the prohibition or substitution.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605.5(6)(b)(ii): The pharmacist or pharmacy intern shall make a written note of the practioner's direction by writing the name of the practitioner and the words "orally by" and the initials of the pharmacist or pharmacy intern written after it.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605.5(7): A pharmacist or pharmacy intern who substitutes an interchangeable biological product for a prescribed biological product shall communicate the substitution to the purchaser.  The interchangeable biological product container shall be labeled with the name of the interchangeable biological product dispensed, and the pharmacist, pharmacy intern, or pharmacy technician shall indicate on the file copy of the prescription both the name of the prescribed biological product and the name of the interchangeable biological product dispensed in its place.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605.5(8): (8) Within five business days following the dispensing of a biological product, the dispensing pharmacist or the pharmacist's designee shall make an entry of the specific product provided to the patient, including the name of the product and the manufacturer.  The communication shall be conveyed by making an entry into an interoperable electronic medical records system, through an electronic prescribing technology, a pharmacy benefit management system, or a pharmacy record that is electronically accessible by the prescriber.  Entry into an electronic records system as described in this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605.5(8)(a): there is no FDA-approved interchangeable biological product for the product prescribed;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605.5(8)(b): a refill prescription is not changed from the product dispensed on the prior filling of the prescription; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-605.5(8)(c): the product is paid for using cash or cash equivalent.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-606 Restrictive drug formulary prohibited.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-606(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-606(1)(a): "Generic form" means a prescription drug that is available in generic form and has an A rating in the United States Pharmacopeia and Drug Index.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-606(1)(b): "Legend drug" has the same meaning as prescription drug.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-606(1)(c): "Restrictive drug formulary" means a list of legend drugs, other than drugs for cosmetic purposes, that are prohibited by the Department of Health and Human Services from dispensation, but are approved by the Federal Food and Drug Administration.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-606(2): A practitioner may prescribe legend drugs in accordance with this chapter that, in his professional judgment and within the lawful scope of his practice, he considers appropriate for the diagnosis and treatment of his patient.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-606(3): (4) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-606(4): When a multisource legend drug is available in the generic form, the Department of Health and Human Services may only reimburse for the generic form of the drug unless the treating physician demonstrates to the Department of Health and Human Services a medical necessity for dispensing the nongeneric, brand-name legend drug.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-606(5): (4) The Department of Health and Human Services pharmacists may override the generic mandate provisions of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-606(6): This section does not affect the state's ability to exercise the exclusion options available under the Federal Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1990.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-607 Drug substitution is not the practice of medicine -- Other causes of action not denied.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-607(1): The substitution of any drug by a licensed pharmacist or pharmacy intern under this chapter does not constitute the practice of medicine.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-607(2): This chapter may not be construed to deny any individual a cause of action against a pharmacist, pharmacy intern, or his employer for violations of this chapter, including failure to observe accepted standards of care of the pharmaceutical profession.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-608 Emergency refills.
---------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-608(1): (1)(h) If a prescription may not be refilled otherwise, a pharmacist or pharmacy intern may refill the prescription in an emergency without the prescribing practitioner's authorization if:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-608(1)(a): the prescription is for a drug that is not a controlled substance;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-608(1)(b): the patient is currently using the drug prescribed;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-608(1)(c): the prescribing practitioner is not available promptly to authorize the refill;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-608(1)(d): the pharmacist or pharmacy intern, or another pharmacist or pharmacy intern at the same pharmacy, has not previously dispensed a refill for the prescription under this section;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-608(1)(e): refilling the prescription is in the interest of the patient's health;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-608(1)(f): in the professional judgment of the pharmacist or pharmacy intern the prescription should be refilled;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-608(1)(g): (1)(h) except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-608(1)(h): the pharmacist or pharmacy intern dispenses no more than the amount necessary to address the emergency.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-608(2): (1) If the prescription for a drug dispensed under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-608(2)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-608(2)(a)(i): the prescription has expired within the past 30 days; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-608(2)(a)(ii): no refills are remaining on the prescription; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-608(2)(b): the amount dispensed does not exceed the lesser of:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-608(2)(b)(i): a 30-day supply; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-608(2)(b)(ii): the quantity last dispensed at the pharmacy pursuant to the prescription as either a fill or a refill.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-608(3): A pharmacist or pharmacy intern who dispenses a prescription refill under this section shall inform the prescribing practitioner of the emergency refill as soon as practicable.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-608.1 Refills of legend drug prescriptions.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-608.1(1): If a prescription for a legend drug includes authorization for one or more refills, a pharmacist or pharmacy intern may dispense one or more of the refills at the time the drug is dispensed, if:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-608.1(1)(a): the drug is not a controlled substance;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-608.1(1)(b): the prescription does not include "Dispense quantity written," or some other notation having similar meaning;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-608.1(1)(c): the total dosage units dispensed, including the units for both the prescription and any refills, do not exceed a 100-day supply; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-608.1(1)(d): in the professional judgment of the pharmacist or pharmacy intern, the refill or refills should be dispensed at the time the prescription is dispensed.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-608.1(2): A pharmacist or pharmacy intern may dispense a refill of a prescription for a liquid legend drug administered to the eye once an amount of time has passed after which a patient should have used 70% of the dosage units of the drug according to a practitioner's instructions.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-608.2 Insulin prescriptions and diabetes supplies.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-608.2(1): As used in this section, "exhausted prescription" means a prescription for an insulin that the patient is currently using that:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-608.2(1)(a): expired no earlier than six months before the patient requests the pharmacist for a refill; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-608.2(1)(b): is not expired and has no refills remaining.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-608.2(2): If a valid prescription for insulin includes an authorization for one or more refills, a pharmacist may combine refills to dispense a supply for 100 days but may not exceed the total supply authorized by the refills.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-608.2(3): 58-17b-608; (2) Notwithstanding Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-608.2(4): (3) A pharmacist may dispense insulin for an exhausted prescription described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-608.2(5): (3); (5)(a) Before a pharmacist may dispense insulin under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-608.2(5)(a): attempt to contact the prescribing practitioner to inform the prescribing practitioner that the patient's prescription has expired; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-608.2(5)(b): (5)(a) notify the patient of the outcome of the attempt described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-608.2(6): (3) Within 30 days after the day on which a pharmacist dispenses insulin under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-608.2(6)(a): the amount of insulin dispensed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-608.2(6)(b): the type of insulin dispensed.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-608.2(7): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act A pharmacist may dispense a therapeutic equivalent when filling a prescription for:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-608.2(7)(a): a glucometer;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-608.2(7)(b): diabetes test strips;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-608.2(7)(c): lancets;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-608.2(7)(d): syringes;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-608.2(7)(e): needles; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-608.2(7)(f): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act other supplies for treating diabetes designated by rule made by the division in accordance with


Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-609 Limitation on prescriptions and refills -- Controlled Substances Act not affected -- Legend drugs.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-609(1): 58-16a-102; 58-17b-608.2; Chapter 37, Utah Controlled Substances Act Except as provided in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-609(2): 58-17b-608.2 Except as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-609(3): A practitioner may not be prohibited from issuing a new prescription for the same drug orally, in writing, or by electronic transmission.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-609(4): Chapter 37, Utah Controlled Substances Act Nothing in this chapter affects
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-609(5): A prescription for a legend drug written by a licensed prescribing practitioner in another state may be filled or refilled by a pharmacist or pharmacy intern in this state if the pharmacist or pharmacy intern verifies that the prescription is valid.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-610 Patients' immediate needs -- Dispensing drug samples.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-610(1): This chapter may not be construed to prevent the personal administration of drugs or medicines by practitioners licensed to prescribe in order to supply the immediate needs of the practitioner's patients.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-610(2): Immediate need for a patient includes giving out drug samples that:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-610(2)(a): are not Schedule II drugs, opioids, or benzodiazepines;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-610(2)(b): are prepackaged by the original manufacturer;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-610(2)(c): are provided to the prescribing practitioner free of charge and provided to the patient free of any direct or indirect charge;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-610(2)(d): do not exceed a 30-day supply for:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-610(2)(d)(i): controlled substances; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-610(2)(d)(ii): non-controlled substances, unless a prescribing practitioner documents that providing more than a 30-day supply is medically necessary; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-610(2)(e): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-610(2)(e)(i): are marked on the immediate container to indicate that the drug is a sample; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-610(2)(e)(ii): are recorded in the patient's chart with the name and number of samples provided.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-610(3): (2) A prescribing practitioner who provides samples for a patient shall comply with Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-610.5 Dispensing in emergency department -- Patient's immediate need.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-610.5(1): Chapter 37, Utah Controlled Substances Act As used in this section, "controlled substance" means a substance classified as a controlled substance by the federal Controlled Substances Act, Title II, Pub. L. No. 91-513 et seq., or by
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-610.5(2): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act The division shall adopt administrative rules in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-610.5(2)(a): the hospital pharmacy is closed;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-610.5(2)(b): in the professional judgment of the practitioner, dispensing the drug is necessary for the patient's immediate needs;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-610.5(2)(c): dispensing the prescription drug meets protocols established by the hospital pharmacy; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-610.5(2)(d): the practitioner dispenses only a sufficient amount of the prescription drug as necessary to last until a pharmacy can fill the prescription.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-610.5(3): (2) A practitioner in an emergency department may dispense a prescription drug in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-610.5(4): (2) Under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-610.6 Hospital pharmacy dispensing prescription drugs.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-610.6(1): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act The division shall make rules, in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-610.6(1)(a): the individual is discharged from the hospital on the same day that the hospital pharmacy dispenses the prescription drug to the individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-610.6(1)(b): the class A pharmacy with which the patient has an established pharmacy-patient relationship:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-610.6(1)(b)(i): is not open at the time of the patient's discharge; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-610.6(1)(b)(ii): unable to dispense the medication for any reason;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-610.6(1)(c): the hospital pharmacy dispenses a quantity of the prescription drug that is not more than a 72-hour supply; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-610.6(1)(d): dispensing the prescription drug complies with protocols established by the hospital pharmacy.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-610.6(2): (1) A hospital pharmacy may dispense a prescription drug in accordance with rules made under Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-611 Pharmacy records.
--------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-611(1): Each pharmacy shall maintain its prescription files and other records in accordance with this chapter, division rules made in collaboration with the board, and federal regulations.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-611(2): Each out-of-state mail service pharmacy shall maintain its prescription files in accordance with applicable rules or regulations of the state in which its facilities are located and federal regulations.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-612 Supervision -- Pharmacist-in-charge.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-612(1): 58-17b-102(70); Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act; (1)(a); (1)(b); (1)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-612(1)(a): Any pharmacy, except a wholesaler, distributor, out-of-state mail service pharmacy, or class E pharmacy, shall be under the general supervision of at least one pharmacist licensed to practice in Utah.  One pharmacist licensed in Utah shall be designated as the pharmacist-in-charge, whose responsibility it is to oversee the operation of the pharmacy.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-612(1)(b): 58-17b-102(70); Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act; (1)(a) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-612(1)(b)(i): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act the pharmacy is located in an area of need as defined by the division, in consultation with the board, by rule made in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-612(1)(b)(ii): (1)(a) the supervising pharmacist described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-612(1)(b)(iii): the telepharmacy system maintains records and files quarterly reports as required by division rule to assure that patient safety is not compromised; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-612(1)(b)(iv): the arrangement is approved by the division in collaboration with the board.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-612(1)(c): (1)(b) Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-612(1)(d): (1)(b) A supervising pharmacist may not supervise more than two pharmacies simultaneously under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-612(2): Each out-of-state mail service pharmacy shall designate and identify to the division a pharmacist holding a current license in good standing issued by the state in which the pharmacy is located and who serves as the pharmacist-in-charge for all purposes under this chapter.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-613 Patient counseling.
----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-613(1): A pharmacy shall verbally offer to counsel a patient or a patient's agent in a personal face-to-face discussion regarding each prescription drug dispensed, if the patient or patient's agent:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-613(1)(a): delivers the prescription in person to the pharmacist or pharmacy intern; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-613(1)(b): receives the drug in person at the time it is dispensed at the pharmacy facility.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-613(2): A pharmacist or pharmacy intern at a pharmacy that receives a prescription from a patient by means other than personal delivery, and that dispenses prescription drugs to the patient by means other than personal delivery, shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-613(2)(a): provide patient counseling to a patient regarding each prescription drug the pharmacy dispenses; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-613(2)(b): provide each patient with a toll-free telephone number by which the patient can contact a pharmacist or pharmacy intern at the pharmacy for counseling.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-613(3): (1); (2) Notwithstanding the provisions of Subsections


Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-614 Notification.
----------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-614(1): A pharmacy shall report in writing to the division not later than 10 business days:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-614(1)(a): before the date of:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-614(1)(a)(i): a permanent closure of the pharmacy facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-614(1)(a)(ii): a change of name or ownership of the pharmacy facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-614(1)(a)(iii): a change of location of the pharmacy facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-614(1)(a)(iv): a sale or transfer of any controlled substance as a result of the permanent closing or change of ownership of the pharmacy facility; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-614(1)(a)(v): any matter or occurrence that the division requires by rule to be reported; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-614(1)(b): after the day on which:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-614(1)(b)(i): a final administrative disciplinary order is issued against the pharmacy license holder by the regulatory or licensing agency of the state in which the pharmacy is located if the pharmacy is a class D pharmacy;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-614(1)(b)(ii): a final order against a pharmacist is issued who is designated as the pharmacist-in-charge of the pharmacy by the regulatory or licensing agency of the state in which the pharmacy is located if the pharmacy is a class D pharmacy; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-614(1)(b)(iii): any matter or occurrence that the division requires by rule to be reported.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-614(2): A pharmacy shall report in writing to the division a disaster, accident, or emergency that may affect the purity or labeling of a drug, medication, device, or other material used in the diagnosis or treatment of injury, illness, or disease immediately upon the occurrence of the disaster, accident, or emergency as defined by rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-614(3): A reporting pharmacy shall maintain a copy of any notification required by this section for two years and make a copy available for inspection.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-615 Sale of prescription drugs not in normal course of business.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-615(1): As used in this section, "seller" means a person selling prescription drugs or devices owned or lawfully controlled by him, or a party arranging for the sale of prescription drugs or devices owned by or lawfully controlled by another person, including salvage companies that acquire prescription drugs and devices from, or act as an agent or representative for freight haulers and forwarders.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-615(2): (3) Any sale of prescription drugs in bankruptcy, at public auction, at freight liquidation sales, or any other sale of prescription drugs other than in the normal course of business or practice shall comply with the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-615(2)(a): a seller of prescription drugs shall be licensed by the division as a prescription drug distributor or wholesaler with a regular license, or a temporary license for that sale only, before engaging in the sale of any prescription drugs; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-615(2)(b): (3) a person licensed as a pharmacy under this chapter may not acquire by purchase or other means prescription drugs or devices outside the normal course of business within the meaning of this section unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-615(2)(b)(i): (3) the prescription drugs or devices are accompanied by a certificate signed by a licensed pharmacist employed or retained by the seller, as required in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-615(2)(b)(ii): the licensee acquiring the prescription drugs or devices employs a qualified pharmacist who is responsible for determining that all prescription drugs being acquired do not pose any threat to the public welfare if introduced into commerce than would be presented by the acquisition of those prescription drugs and devices in the normal course of business through established channels of prescription drug distribution.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-615(3): A seller of prescription drugs outside the normal course of business shall retain the services of a qualified pharmacist licensed to practice in the state to serve as either an employee or independent consultant to determine if the:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-615(3)(a): prescription drugs and devices to be offered for sale have been transported, stored, and distributed in accordance with applicable federal, state, and local laws; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-615(3)(b): condition of the prescription drugs and devices to be offered for sale has been adversely affected by the circumstances of transportation, storage, or distribution.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-615(4): The written notice provided to the division prior to the sale of any prescription drugs or devices under this section shall contain written verification of the pharmacist retained by the seller, stating the drugs or devices offered for sale have not been adversely affected by the circumstances of transportation, storage, or distribution.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-615(5): (3) A pharmacist employed by a seller under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-616 Drug stock sales -- Labeling.
--------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-616(1): A manufacturer, wholesaler, or distributor of prescription drugs may not sell or give any prescription drug to any person, unless the prescription drug stock container bears a label containing information as defined by rule, the name and place of business of the manufacturer of the finished dosage form of the drug, and if different from the manufacturer, the name and place of business of the packer or distributor.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-616(2): Each tablet or capsule shall be marked with an identification code or monogram, unless waived by the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-616(3): Each stock package shall bear an expiration date and lot number.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-617 Limitations on distribution of prescription drugs by pharmaceutical manufacturers or wholesalers.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-617(1): A pharmaceutical manufacturer or pharmaceutical wholesaler may not provide a prescription drug to any person, except as defined by rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-617(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-617(2)(a): Prescription drugs that are not controlled substances may be:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-617(2)(a)(i): distributed or provided as drug samples to a person licensed within the state to sell, prescribe, administer, or conduct research with legend drugs; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-617(2)(a)(ii): supplied in connection with a manufacturer's patient assistance program to be distributed to qualifying patients enrolled in the program.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-617(2)(b): Controlled substance prescription drugs may be sold or provided only:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-617(2)(b)(i): upon the issuance of an order or request by a person appropriately licensed under state and federal law to sell, prescribe, administer, or conduct research with prescription drugs; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-617(2)(b)(ii): upon the establishment of documents in the possession of the manufacturer or distributor recording the purchaser, type of drug, quantity of drug, date of shipment, and date of delivery.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-617(3): Purchasers or those in receipt of drugs under this section shall maintain records in accordance with federal and state laws regarding controlled substances.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-618 Compliance with state and federal laws.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
The entities licensed under Sections

Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-620 Prescriptions issued within the public health system.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-620(2): (3); Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act When it is necessary to treat a reportable disease or non-emergency condition that has a direct impact on public health, a health department may implement the prescription procedure described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-620(2)(a): a clinic; or

Utah Code Annotated § 58-17b-620(6)(b): All prescriptions issued shall contain all information required under this chapter and rules adopted under this chapter.
