Utah Code Annotated - Title 58 - Chapter 38a - Controlled Substances Advisory Committee Act
*******************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-101 Title.
---------------------------------------
This chapter is referred to as the "Controlled Substances Advisory Committee Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-102 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-102(1): "Committee" means the Controlled Substances Advisory Committee created in this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-102(2): 58-37-4 "Controlled substance schedule" or "schedule" means a schedule as defined under Section


Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-201 Controlled Substances Advisory Committee.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
There is created within the Division of Professional Licensing the Controlled Substances Advisory Committee.  The committee consists of:Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-201(1): the director of the Department of Health or the director's designee;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-201(2): the State Medical Examiner or the examiner's designee;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-201(3): the commissioner of the Department of Public Safety or the commissioner's designee;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-201(4): 53-10-401 the director of the Bureau of Forensic Services created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-201(5): the director of the Utah Poison Control Center or the director's designee;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-201(6): one physician who is a member of the Physicians Licensing Board and is designated by that board;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-201(7): one pharmacist who is a member of the Utah State Board of Pharmacy and is designated by that board;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-201(8): one dentist who is a member of the Dentist and Dental Hygienist Licensing Board and is designated by that board;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-201(9): one physician who is currently licensed and practicing in the state, to be appointed by the governor;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-201(10): one psychiatrist who is currently licensed and practicing in the state, to be appointed by the governor;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-201(11): one individual with expertise in substance abuse addiction, to be appointed by the governor;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-201(12): one representative from the Statewide Association of Prosecutors, to be designated by that association;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-201(13): one naturopathic physician who is currently licensed and practicing in the state, to be appointed by the governor;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-201(14): one advanced practice registered nurse who is currently licensed and practicing in this state, to be appointed by the governor; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-201(15): one member of the public, to be appointed by the governor.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-202 Terms of committee service.
------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-202(1): 58-38a-201(1); (2); (3); (4)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-202(1)(a): 58-38a-201(1); (2); (3); (4) Members of the advisory committee shall serve terms of four years, except that the members under Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-202(1)(b): Vacancies in the committee occurring otherwise than by the expiration of a term shall be filled for the unexpired term in the same manner as original appointments.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-202(2): 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107; 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107 A member may not receive compensation or benefits for the member's service, but may receive per diem and travel expenses in accordance with:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-202(2)(a): 63A-3-106 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-202(2)(b): 63A-3-107 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-202(2)(c): 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107 rules made by the Division of Finance pursuant to Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-202(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-202(3)(a): The director of the Department of Health, or the director's designee, is the chair of the committee.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-202(3)(b): The advisory committee meets at the call of the chair or at the call of a majority of the committee members.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-202(3)(c): The advisory committee meets annually and more often as required to carry out its duties under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-202(3)(d): Seven members of the advisory committee constitute a quorum.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-202(3)(e): Action by the committee requires a majority vote of a quorum.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-203 Duties of the committee.
---------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-203(1): The committee serves as a consultative and advisory body to the Legislature regarding:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-203(1)(a): the movement of a controlled substance from one schedule or list to another;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-203(1)(b): the removal of a controlled substance from any schedule or list; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-203(1)(c): the designation of a substance as a controlled substance and the placement of the substance in a designated schedule or list.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-203(2): On or before September 30 of each year, the committee shall submit to the Health and Human Services Interim Committee a written report:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-203(2)(a): describing any substances recommended by the committee for scheduling, rescheduling, listing, or deletion from the schedules or list by the Legislature; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-203(2)(b): stating the reasons for the recommendation.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-203(3): 58-37-2 In advising the Legislature regarding the need to add, delete, relist, or reschedule a substance, the committee shall consider:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-203(3)(a): the actual or probable abuse of the substance, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-203(3)(a)(i): the history and current pattern of abuse both in Utah and in other states;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-203(3)(a)(ii): the scope, duration, and significance of abuse;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-203(3)(a)(iii): the degree of actual or probable detriment to public health which may result from abuse of the substance; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-203(3)(a)(iv): the probable physical and social impact of widespread abuse of the substance;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-203(3)(b): the biomedical hazard of the substance, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-203(3)(b)(i): its pharmacology, including the effects and modifiers of the effects of the substance;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-203(3)(b)(ii): its toxicology, acute and chronic toxicity, interaction with other substances, whether controlled or not, and the degree to which it may cause psychological or physiological dependence; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-203(3)(b)(iii): the risk to public health and the particular susceptibility of segments of the population;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-203(3)(c): 58-37-2 whether the substance is an immediate precursor, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-203(3)(d): the current state of scientific knowledge regarding the substance, including whether there is any acceptable means to safely use the substance under medical supervision;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-203(3)(e): the relationship between the use of the substance and criminal activity, including whether:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-203(3)(e)(i): persons engaged in illicit trafficking of the substance are also engaged in other criminal activity;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-203(3)(e)(ii): the nature and relative profitability of manufacturing or delivering the substance encourages illicit trafficking in the substance;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-203(3)(e)(iii): the commission of other crimes is one of the recognized effects of abuse of the substance; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-203(3)(e)(iv): addiction to the substance relates to the commission of crimes to facilitate the continued use of the substance;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-203(3)(f): whether the substance has been scheduled by other states; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-203(3)(g): whether the substance has any accepted medical use in treatment in the United States.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-203(4): 59-14-102; 32B-1-102 The committee's duties under this chapter do not include tobacco products as defined in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-204 Guidelines for scheduling or listing drugs.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-204(1): 58-37-4
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-204(1)(a): The committee shall recommend placement of a substance in Schedule I if it finds:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-204(1)(a)(i): that the substance has high potential for abuse; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-204(1)(a)(ii): that an accepted standard has not been established for safe use in treatment for medical purposes.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-204(1)(b): 58-37-4 The committee may recommend placement of a substance in Schedule I under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-204(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-204(2)(a): The committee shall recommend placement of a substance in Schedule II if it finds that:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-204(2)(a)(i): the substance has high potential for abuse;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-204(2)(a)(ii): the substance has a currently accepted medical use in treatment in the United States, or a currently accepted medical use subject to severe restrictions; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-204(2)(a)(iii): the abuse of the substance may lead to severe psychological or physiological dependence.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-204(2)(b): The committee may recommend placement of a substance in Schedule II if it finds that the substance is classified as a controlled substance in Schedule II under federal law.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-204(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-204(3)(a): The committee shall recommend placement of a substance in Schedule III if it finds that:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-204(3)(a)(i): the substance has a potential for abuse that is less than the potential for substances listed in Schedules I and II;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-204(3)(a)(ii): the substance has a currently accepted medical use in treatment in the United States; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-204(3)(a)(iii): abuse of the substance may lead to moderate or low physiological dependence or high psychological dependence.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-204(3)(b): The committee may recommend placement of a substance in Schedule III if it finds that the substance is classified as a controlled substance in Schedule III under federal law.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-204(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-204(4)(a): The committee shall recommend placement of a substance in Schedule IV if it finds that:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-204(4)(a)(i): the substance has a low potential for abuse relative to substances in Schedule III;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-204(4)(a)(ii): the substance has currently accepted medical use in treatment in the United States; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-204(4)(a)(iii): abuse of the substance may lead to limited physiological dependence or psychological dependence relative to the substances in Schedule III.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-204(4)(b): The committee may recommend placement of a substance in Schedule IV if it finds that the substance is classified as a controlled substance in Schedule IV under federal law.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-204(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-204(5)(a): The committee shall recommend placement of a substance in Schedule V if it finds that:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-204(5)(a)(i): the substance has low potential for abuse relative to the controlled substances listed in Schedule IV;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-204(5)(a)(ii): the substance has currently accepted medical use in treatment in the United States; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-204(5)(a)(iii): the substance has limited physiological dependence or psychological dependence liability relative to the controlled substances listed in Schedule IV.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-204(5)(b): The committee may recommend placement of a substance in Schedule V under this chapter if it finds that the substance is classified as a controlled substance in Schedule V under federal law.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-38a-204(6): The committee may recommend placement of a substance on a controlled substance list if it finds that the substance has a potential for abuse and that an accepted standard has not been established for safe use in treatment for medical purposes.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 58 - Chapter 40 - Recreational Therapy Practice Act
*******************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-101 Title.
--------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Recreational Therapy Practice Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-102 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
In addition to the definitions in SectionUtah Code Annotated § 58-40-102(1): "Approved" means approval by the division in collaboration with the board when used to refer to a licensing requirement.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-102(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-102(2)(a): "Assessment" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-102(2)(a)(i): a systematic collection of data to identify the strengths and limitations of a person's physical, cognitive, social, behavioral, emotional, spiritual, and leisure capabilities; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-102(2)(a)(ii): interpreting and analyzing collected data to identify and determine a course of action for recreational therapy services for a patient.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-102(2)(b): "Assessment" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-102(2)(b)(i): a record review;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-102(2)(b)(ii): the implementation of standardized and non-standardized instruments, tests, and measurements; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-102(2)(b)(iii): the skilled observation and interview of a person.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-102(3): 58-40-201 "Board" means the Board of Recreational Therapy created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-102(4): "Practice of recreational therapy" means to engage in the paid performance of providing recreational therapy services according to the therapeutic recreation process to a person with an emotional, social, intellectual, or physical pathology.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-102(5): "Recreational therapy" or "therapeutic recreation" means a person-centered process that uses recreation and psychoeducational activities as intervention tools to improve the physical, cognitive, social, behavioral, emotional, or spiritual well-being of a person with an illness or a disability.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-102(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-102(6)(a): "Recreational therapy services" means using recreation and psychoeducational activities as intervention tools to improve or maintain the physical, cognitive, social, behavioral, emotional, or spiritual well-being of a person with an illness or a disability.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-102(6)(b): "Recreational therapy services" include:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-102(6)(b)(i): assessing a person's need for recreational therapy treatment or intervention;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-102(6)(b)(ii): developing an individualized treatment or intervention plan that identifies goals, objectives, and treatment strategies for a person;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-102(6)(b)(iii): implementing the individualized treatment or intervention plan;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-102(6)(b)(iv): documenting a person's response to the individualized treatment or intervention plan, including documenting the overall outcome of the person's treatment;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-102(6)(b)(v): regularly evaluating a person's response to the individualized treatment or intervention plan and modifying the plan when appropriate;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-102(6)(b)(vi): in collaboration with a person, the person's family, or other team members, developing a discharge or transition plan for the person;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-102(6)(b)(vii): serving as a resource to help a person find recreation opportunities that will promote the person's physical, cognitive, social, behavioral, emotional, or spiritual health and well-being; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-102(6)(b)(viii): organizing and managing recreational services according to a written plan of operation as defined by rule of the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-102(7): 58-40-602 "Treatment or intervention plan" means a written record containing the information required by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-102(8): 58-1-501; 58-40-501 "Unlawful conduct" is as defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-102(9): 58-1-501; 58-40-502 "Unprofessional conduct" is as defined in Sections


Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-103 Rulemaking.
-------------------------------------------
When exercising rulemaking authority under this chapter, the division shall comply with the requirements of

Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-201 Board.
--------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-201(1): There is created the Board of Recreational Therapy, consisting of:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-201(1)(a): two master therapeutic recreation specialists;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-201(1)(b): one therapeutic recreation specialist;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-201(1)(c): one therapeutic recreation technician; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-201(1)(d): one member of the general public.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-201(2): 58-1-201 The board shall be appointed and serve in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-201(3): 58-1-202; 58-1-203
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-201(3)(a): 58-1-202; 58-1-203 The duties and responsibilities of the board shall be in accordance with Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-201(3)(b): In addition, the board shall designate one of its members on a permanent rotating basis to:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-201(3)(b)(i): assist the division in reviewing complaints concerning the unlawful or unprofessional conduct of a licensee; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-201(3)(b)(ii): advise the division in its investigation of these complaints.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-201(4): (3) A board member who has, under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-301 Licensure required -- License classifications.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-301(1): 58-40-305; 58-1-307 A license is required to engage in the practice of recreational therapy, except as specifically provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-301(2): The division shall issue to a person who qualifies under this chapter a license in the classification of:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-301(2)(a): master therapeutic recreation specialist;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-301(2)(b): therapeutic recreation specialist; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-301(2)(c): therapeutic recreation technician.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-302 Qualifications for licensure.
-------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-302(1): 63J-1-504 An applicant for licensure under this chapter shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-302(1)(a): submit an application in a form prescribed by the division; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-302(1)(b): 63J-1-504 pay a fee determined by the department under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-302(2): (1) In addition to the requirements of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-302(2)(a): complete an approved graduate degree;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-302(2)(b): complete 4,000 qualifying hours of paid experience as:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-302(2)(b)(i): a licensed therapeutic recreation specialist if completed in the state; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-302(2)(b)(ii): a certified therapeutic recreation specialist certified by the National Council for Therapeutic Recreation Certification if completed outside of the state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-302(2)(c): pass an approved examination.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-302(3): (1) In addition to the requirements of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-302(3)(a): complete an approved:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-302(3)(a)(i): bachelor's degree in therapeutic recreation or recreational therapy;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-302(3)(a)(ii): bachelor's degree with an approved emphasis, option, or concentration in therapeutic recreation or recreational therapy; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-302(3)(a)(iii): graduate degree;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-302(3)(b): complete an approved practicum; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-302(3)(c): pass an approved examination.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-302(4): (1) In addition to the requirements of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-302(4)(a): have a high school diploma or GED equivalent;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-302(4)(b): complete an approved:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-302(4)(b)(i): educational course in therapeutic recreation taught by a licensed master therapeutic recreation specialist; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-302(4)(b)(ii): six semester hours or nine quarter hours in therapeutic recreation or recreational therapy from an accredited college or university;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-302(4)(c): complete an approved practicum under the supervision of:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-302(4)(c)(i): a licensed master therapeutic recreation specialist; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-302(4)(c)(ii): an on-site, full-time, employed therapeutic recreation specialist;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-302(4)(d): pass an approved examination; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-302(4)(e): complete a minimum of two hours of training in suicide prevention via a course that the division designates as approved.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-303 Term of license -- Expiration -- Renewal.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-303(1): The division shall issue a license under this chapter in accordance with a two-year renewal cycle established by rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-303(2): The division may, by rule, extend or shorten a renewal cycle by as much as one year to stagger the renewal cycles it administers.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-303(3): 58-1-308 A license automatically expires on the expiration date shown on the license unless the licensee renews it in accordance with Section


Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-304 Continuing education.
-----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-304(1): In collaboration with the board, the division shall make rules to provide that as a condition precedent for license renewal, a licensee shall complete continuing education requirements during each license period.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-304(2): (1) In addition to a continuing education requirement provided by the division under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-305 Exemptions from licensure.
----------------------------------------------------------
In addition to the exemptions from licensure in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-401 Grounds for denial of license -- Disciplinary proceedings.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Grounds for refusing to issue a license to an applicant, for refusal to renew the license of a licensee, for revoking, suspending, restricting, or placing on probation the license of a licensee, for issuing a public or private reprimand to a licensee, and for issuing a cease and desist order shall be in accordance with Section

Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-501 Unlawful conduct.
-------------------------------------------------
"Unlawful conduct" includes:Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-501(1): 58-1-307; 58-40-305 providing, leading, facilitating, teaching, or offering to provide or teach recreational therapy services unless licensed under this chapter or exempted from licensure under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-501(2): using the initials MTRS, TRS, or TRT, or other abbreviation, term, title, or sign relating to the practice of recreational therapy services unless licensed under this chapter.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-502 Unprofessional conduct.
-------------------------------------------------------
"Unprofessional conduct" includes:Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-502(1): failing to supervise a therapeutic recreation technician, a student intern, or a temporarily licensed therapeutic recreation specialist when required to do so under this chapter or by rule;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-502(2): failing to keep or maintain a recreational therapy treatment plan;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-502(3): failing to safeguard a person's right to privacy as to the person's identity, condition, diagnosis, personal effects, or other matters about which the licensee is privileged to know from providing recreational therapy services;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-502(4): failing to report to the division the unsafe, unethical, or illegal practice of a person who is providing recreational therapy services;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-502(5): making sexual advances to a patient, requesting sexual intercourse or sexual favors from a patient, or engaging in other verbal or physical conduct of a sexual nature in the presence of a patient;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-502(6): exploiting a patient or former patient for personal gain;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-502(7): possessing or dispensing illegal or non-prescribed prescription drugs or medications;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-502(8): using or being under the influence of alcohol or an illegal or non-prescribed prescription drug or medication while performing recreational therapy services; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-502(9): other actions as defined by division rule.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-601 Scope of practice.
--------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-601(1): A master therapeutic recreation specialist licensed under this chapter may:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-601(1)(a): practice recreational therapy:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-601(1)(a)(i): as an employee of a hospital, clinic, agency, or other facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-601(1)(a)(ii): in private practice; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-601(1)(a)(iii): as a consultant; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-601(1)(b): supervise and train other licensees under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-601(2): A therapeutic recreation specialist licensed under this chapter:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-601(2)(a): may practice recreational therapy as the employee of a hospital, clinic, agency, or other facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-601(2)(b): may not practice recreational therapy in private practice or as a consultant; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-601(2)(c): may supervise other licensees under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-601(3): 58-40-102(2)(a)(i); 58-40-102(2)(a)(ii) A therapeutic recreation technician:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-601(3)(a): may perform recreational therapy services if:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-601(3)(a)(i): under the supervision of a master therapeutic recreation specialist or a therapeutic recreation specialist employed full-time and on-site in the same hospital, clinic, or facility; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-601(3)(a)(ii): in consultation with a master therapeutic recreation specialist;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-601(3)(b): may maintain the ongoing documentation of services provided in accordance with a treatment or intervention plan if:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-601(3)(b)(i): under the supervision of either a master therapeutic recreation specialist or a therapeutic recreation specialist employed full-time and on-site in the same hospital, clinic, or facility; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-601(3)(b)(ii): in consultation with a master therapeutic recreation specialist;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-601(3)(c): 58-40-102(2)(a)(i) may perform the portion of an assessment described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-601(3)(d): 58-40-102(2)(a)(ii) may not perform the portion of an assessment described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-601(3)(e): may not prescribe or create a treatment or intervention plan; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-601(3)(f): may not approve or cosign a modification to a treatment or intervention plan.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-602 Recreational therapy treatment or intervention plans.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-602(1): A recreational therapy treatment or intervention plan shall be maintained for each patient receiving recreational therapy services under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-602(2): The treatment or intervention plan shall include:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-602(2)(a): goals and objectives for a patient that are developed from an assessment based on the strengths and limitations of the patient's physical, cognitive, social, behavioral, emotional, spiritual, and leisure capabilities;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-602(2)(b): the selection and adaptation of interventions designed to achieve and maintain the highest possible level of functional independence and quality of life for a patient;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-602(2)(c): a schedule for regular evaluation of goals and objectives to make changes to the treatment or intervention plan when required; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40-602(2)(d): expected outcomes related to the goals and objectives.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 58 - Chapter 40a - Athletic Trainer Licensing Act
*****************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-101 Title.
---------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Athletic Trainer Licensing Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-102 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
In addition to the definitions in SectionUtah Code Annotated § 58-40a-102(1): "Adequate records" means legible records that contain, at a minimum:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-102(1)(a): the athletic training service plan or protocol;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-102(1)(b): an evaluation of objective findings;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-102(1)(c): the plan of care and the treatment records; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-102(1)(d): written orders.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-102(2): "Athlete" means an individual, referee, coach, or athletic staff member who participates in exercises, sports, or games requiring physical strength, agility, flexibility, range of motion, speed, or stamina, and the exercises, sports, or games are of a type generally conducted in association with an educational institution or professional, amateur, or recreational sports club or organization.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-102(3): "Athletic injury" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-102(3)(a): an injury sustained by an athlete that affects the individual's participation or performance in sports, games, recreation, or exercise; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-102(3)(b): a condition that is within the scope of practice of an athletic trainer identified by a directing physician or physical therapist as benefitting from athletic training services.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-102(4): "Athletic trainer" means an individual who is licensed under this chapter and carries out the practice of athletic training.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-102(5): 58-40a-201 "Board" means the Athletic Trainers Licensing Board created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-102(6): 58-67-301; 58-68-301; Chapter 73, Chiropractic Physician Practice Act; Chapter 71, Naturopathic Physician Practice Act; 58-69-301 "Directing physician" means a physician and surgeon licensed under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-102(7): The "practice of athletic training" means the application by a licensed and certified athletic trainer of principles and methods of:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-102(7)(a): prevention of athletic injuries;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-102(7)(b): recognition, evaluation, and assessment of athletic injuries and conditions;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-102(7)(c): immediate care of athletic injuries, including common emergency medical situations;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-102(7)(d): rehabilitation and reconditioning of athletic injuries;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-102(7)(e): athletic training services administration and organization; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-102(7)(f): education of athletes.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-103 Duties of directing physician.
---------------------------------------------------------------
A directing physician shall provide direction to an athletic trainer by a verbal order when in the presence of the athletic trainer and by written order or by athletic training service plans or protocols when a directing physician is not present.

Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-201 Board composition -- Duties and responsibilities.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-201(1): 58-40a-102(6) There is created the Athletic Trainers Licensing Board consisting of four licensed athletic trainers, one member representative of the directing physicians referred to in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-201(2): 58-1-201 The board shall be appointed and serve in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-201(3): 58-1-202; 58-1-203 The board shall carry out the duties and responsibilities in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-201(3)(a): assist the division in reviewing complaints concerning the unlawful or unprofessional conduct of a licensee under this chapter; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-201(3)(b): advise the division of its investigation of these complaints.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-201(4): (3) A board member who has, under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-301 Licensure required.
----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-301(1): 58-1-307; 58-40a-305 A license is required to engage in the practice of athletic training, except as specifically provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-301(2): The division shall issue to an individual who qualifies under this chapter a license in the classification of athletic trainer.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-301(3): An individual may not use the title "licensed athletic trainer," or "athletic trainer," or abbreviations or insignias to imply that the individual is an athletic trainer unless the individual is licensed under this chapter.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-302 Qualifications for licensure.
--------------------------------------------------------------
The division shall issue a license to practice as an athletic trainer to an applicant who:Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-302(1): has obtained a bachelor's or advanced degree from an accredited four-year college or university and meets the minimum athletic training curriculum requirement established by the board by rule;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-302(2): has successfully completed the certification examination administered by the Board of Certification Inc. or equivalent examination approved or recognized by the board;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-302(3): is in good standing with and provides documentation of current certification by the Board of Certification Inc. or a nationally recognized credentialing agency approved by the board;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-302(4): submits an application to the division on a form prescribed by the division; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-302(5): 63J-1-504 pays the required licensing fee as determined by the department under Section


Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-303 Scope of practice.
---------------------------------------------------
An athletic trainer may:Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-303(1): prevent injuries by:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-303(1)(a): designing and implementing physical conditioning programs, which may include:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-303(1)(a)(i): strength and range of motion testing;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-303(1)(a)(ii): nutritional advisement; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-303(1)(a)(iii): psychosocial intervention and referral;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-303(1)(b): performing preparticipation screening;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-303(1)(c): fitting protective equipment;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-303(1)(d): designing and constructing protective products; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-303(1)(e): continuously monitoring changes in the environment;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-303(2): recognize and evaluate injuries by:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-303(2)(a): obtaining a history of the injury;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-303(2)(b): inspecting an injured body part and associated structures;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-303(2)(c): palpating bony landmarks and soft tissue structures; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-303(2)(d): performing clinical tests to determine the extent of an injury;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-303(3): provide immediate care of injuries by:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-303(3)(a): initiating cardiopulmonary resuscitation;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-303(3)(b): administering basic or advanced first aid;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-303(3)(c): removing athletic equipment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-303(3)(d): immobilizing and transporting an injured athlete;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-303(4): determine whether an athlete may return to participation or, if the injury requires further definitive care, refer the athlete to the appropriate directing physician;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-303(5): rehabilitate and recondition an injury by administering therapeutic exercise and therapeutic and physical modalities, including cryotherapy, thermotherapy, and intermittent compression, electrical stimulation, ultra sound, traction devices, or mechanical devices as directed by established, written athletic training service plans or protocols or upon the order of a directing physician;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-303(6): provide athletic training services administration, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-303(6)(a): implementing athletic training service plans or protocols;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-303(6)(b): writing organizational policies and procedures;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-303(6)(c): complying with governmental and institutional standards; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-303(6)(d): maintaining records to document services rendered; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-303(7): educate athletes to facilitate physical conditioning and reconditioning by designing and implementing appropriate programs to minimize the risk of injury.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-304 Term of license -- Expiration -- Renewal.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-304(1): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-304(1)(a): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act The division shall issue each license for an athletic trainer in accordance with a two-year renewal cycle established by rule in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-304(1)(b): The division may, by rule, extend or shorten a renewal period by as much as one year to stagger the renewal cycles it administers.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-304(2): 58-1-308 Each license automatically expires on the expiration date shown on the license unless the licensee renews it in accordance with Section


Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-305 Exemptions from licensure.
-----------------------------------------------------------
In addition to the exemptions from licensure in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-401 Grounds for denial of license.
---------------------------------------------------------------
The division may refuse to issue a license to an applicant, refuse to renew the license of a licensee, revoke, suspend, restrict, or place on probation the license of a licensee, issue a public or private reprimand to a licensee, and issue cease and desist orders in accordance with Section

Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-501 Unprofessional conduct.
--------------------------------------------------------
In addition to the provisions of SubsectionUtah Code Annotated § 58-40a-501(1): failing to report to the division an act or omission that violates a provision of this chapter by a licensee, applicant, or another individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-501(2): interfering with an investigation of a disciplinary proceeding by willful misrepresentation of facts or by use of threats or harassment against a client or witness to prevent that individual from providing evidence in a disciplinary proceeding, investigation, or other legal action;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-501(3): failing to maintain client confidentiality unless otherwise required by law;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-501(4): promoting an unnecessary device, treatment, intervention, or service for financial gain by the athletic trainer or a third party; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-40a-501(5): failing to maintain adequate records.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 58 - Chapter 41 - Speech-Language Pathology and Audiology Licensing Act
***************************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-1 Title of chapter.
-----------------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Speech-language Pathology and Audiology Licensing Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-2 Definitions.
------------------------------------------
In addition to the definitions in SectionUtah Code Annotated § 58-41-2(1): "ASHA" means the American Speech-Language-Hearing Association.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-2(2): "Association" means the Utah Speech-Language-Hearing Association.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-2(3): (4) "Audiologist" means a person who practices audiology or who holds himself out to the public directly or indirectly by any means, act, title, identification, performance, method, or procedure as one who nonmedically examines, measures, tests, interprets, evaluates, assesses, diagnoses, directs, instructs, treats, counsels, prescribes, and recommends for persons affected by or suspected of having disorders of or conditions of hearing loss, or assists persons in achieving the reception, communication, and perception of sound and determines the range, nature, and degree of hearing function related to communication needs, or provides audiology services and uses audio electronic equipment and provides audiology services and consultation regarding noise control and hearing conservation, conducts tests and interpretation of vestibular function and nystagmus, prepares ear impressions and provides ear molds, aids, accessories, prescriptions, and prostheses for hearing, evaluates sound environment and equipment, and calibrates instruments used in testing and supplementing auditory function.  A person is deemed to be an audiologist if the person directly or indirectly provides or offers to provide these services or functions set forth in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-2(4): "Audiology" means the application of principles, methods, and procedures, and measuring, testing, examining, interpreting, diagnosing, predicting, evaluating, prescribing, consulting, treating, instructing, and researching, which is related to hearing, vestibular function, and the disorders of hearing, to related language and speech disorders and to aberrant behavior related to hearing loss or vestibular function, for the purpose of preventing and modifying disorders related to hearing loss or vestibular function, and  planning, directing, managing, conducting, and participating in hearing conservation, evoked potentials evaluation, nonmedical tinnitus evaluation or treatment, noise control, habilitation, and rehabilitation programs, including hearing aid evaluation, assistive listening device evaluation, prescription, preparation, and dispensing, and auditory training and lip reading.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-2(5): "Audiology aide" means an individual who:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-2(5)(a): meets the minimum qualifications established by the board for audiology aides.  Those qualifications shall be substantial but less than those established by this chapter for licensing an audiologist;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-2(5)(b): does not act independently; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-2(5)(c): works under the personal direction and direct supervision of a licensed audiologist who accepts responsibility for the acts and performance of that audiology aide under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-2(6): 58-41-6 "Board" means the Speech-language Pathology and Audiology Licensing Board created under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-2(7): "CCC" means the certificate of clinical competence awarded by the American Speech-Language-Hearing Association.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-2(8): "CFY" means the clinical fellowship year prescribed by ASHA.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-2(9): "Disorder" means the condition of decreased, absent, or impaired auditory, speech, voice, or language function.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-2(10): "Hearing aid dealer" means one who sells, repairs, and adjusts hearing aids.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-2(11): Chapter 41a, Audiology and Speech-language Pathology Interstate Compact "Licensed audiologist" means any individual to whom a license has been issued under this chapter or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-2(12): Chapter 41a, Audiology and Speech-language Pathology Interstate Compact "Licensed speech-language pathologist" means any individual licensed under this chapter or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-2(13): "Person" means any individual, group, organization, partnership, or corporate body, except that only an individual may be licensed under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-2(14): "Practice of audiology" means rendering or offering to render to individuals, groups, agencies, organizations, industries, or the public any performance or service in audiology.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-2(15): "Practice of speech-language pathology" means rendering, prescribing, or offering to render to individuals, groups, agencies, organizations, industries or the public any service in speech-language pathology.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-2(16): "Prescribe" means to:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-2(16)(a): determine, specify, and give the directions, procedures, or rules for a person to follow in determining and ordering the preparation, delivery, and use of specific mechanical, acoustic, or electronic aids to hearing or speech; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-2(16)(b): determine or designate a remedy for a person.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-2(17): "Prescription" means a written or oral order for the delivery or execution of that which has been prescribed.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-2(18): (19) "Speech-language pathologist" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-2(18)(a): a person who practices speech-language pathology or who holds himself out to the public by any means, or by any service or function the person performs, directly or indirectly, or by using the terms "speech-language pathologist," "speech-language therapist," "language disability specialist," or any variation, derivation, synonym, coinage, or whatever expresses, employs, or implies these terms, names, or functions; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-2(18)(b): (19) a person who performs any of the functions described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-2(19): "Speech-language pathology" means the application of principles, methods, and procedures for the examination, measurement, prevention, testing, identification, evaluation, diagnosis, treatment, instruction, modification, prescription, restoration, counseling, habilitation, prediction, management, and research related to the development and the disorders or disabilities of human communication, speech, voice, language, cognitive communication, or oral, pharyngeal, or laryngeal sensorimotor competencies, for the purpose of identifying, evaluating, diagnosing, prescribing, preventing, managing, correcting, ameliorating, or modifying those disorders and their effects in individuals or groups of individuals.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-2(20): "Speech-language pathology aide" means an individual who:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-2(20)(a): meets the minimum qualifications established by the board for speech-language pathology aides.  Those qualifications shall be substantial but less than those established by this chapter for licensing a speech-language pathologist;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-2(20)(b): does not act independently; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-2(20)(c): works under the personal direction and direct supervision of a licensed speech-language pathologist who accepts the responsibility for the acts and performances of that speech-language pathology aide while working under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-2(21): "Treatment" means the services of a speech-language pathologist or audiologist to examine, diagnose, correct, or ameliorate speech or hearing disorders, abnormalities, behavior, or their effects.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-2(22): 58-1-501; 58-41-17 "Unprofessional conduct" as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-2(22)(a): failing to maintain a level of professional practice consistent with all initial and subsequent requirements by which a license is achieved or maintained under this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-2(22)(b): utilizing substandard or inappropriate facilities or equipment;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-2(22)(c): treating any disorder for which the licensee has not had the necessary training and experience; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-2(22)(d): 58-41-17 failing to comply with the requirements of Section


Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-3 Scope of licenses -- Practicing without license prohibited.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-3(1): Licensing shall be granted independently either in speech-language pathology or audiology.  A person shall be licensed in one or both areas when the person meets the respective qualifications.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-3(2): 58-41-4; Chapter 41a, Audiology and Speech-language Pathology Interstate Compact Except as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-3(2)(a): this chapter; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-3(2)(b): Chapter 41a, Audiology and Speech-language Pathology Interstate Compact


Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-4 Exemptions from chapter.
------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-4(1): 58-1-307; (1)(d); (e); 58-41-5; Title 53E, Public Education System -- State Administration; Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act; 26B-4-319 In addition to the exemptions from licensure in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-4(1)(a): a qualified person licensed in this state under any law existing in this state prior to May 13, 1975, engaging in the profession for which the person is licensed;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-4(1)(b): a medical doctor, physician, physician assistant, or surgeon licensed in this state, engaging in his or her specialty in the practice of medicine;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-4(1)(c): a hearing aid dealer or salesperson selling, fitting, adjusting, and repairing hearing aids, and conducting hearing tests solely for that purpose. However, a hearing aid dealer may not conduct audiologic testing on persons younger than 18 years old except under the direct supervision of an audiologist licensed under this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-4(1)(d): a person who has obtained a valid and current credential issued by the State Board of Education while specifically performing the functions of a speech-language pathologist or audiologist solely within the confines of, under the direction and jurisdiction of, and in the academic interest of the school employing the person;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-4(1)(e): a person employed as a speech-language pathologist or audiologist by federal government agencies or subdivisions or, prior to July 1, 1989, by state or local government agencies or subdivisions, while specifically performing speech-language pathology or audiology services solely within the confines of, under the direction and jurisdiction of, and in the specific interest of the agency or subdivision;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-4(1)(f): (1)(d); (e) a person identified in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-4(1)(g): a person employed by an accredited college or university as a speech-language pathologist or audiologist performing the services or functions described in this chapter if the services or functions are:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-4(1)(g)(i): performed solely as an assigned teaching function of the person's employment;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-4(1)(g)(ii): solely in academic interest and pursuit as a function of the person's employment;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-4(1)(g)(iii): in no way for the person's own interest; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-4(1)(g)(iv): provided for no fee, monetary or otherwise, other than the person's agreed institutional salary;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-4(1)(h): a person pursuing a course of study leading to a degree in speech-language pathology or audiology while enrolled in an accredited college or university, provided:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-4(1)(h)(i): those activities constitute an assigned, directed, and supervised part of the person's curricular study, and in no other interest;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-4(1)(h)(ii): that all examinations, tests, histories, charts, progress notes, reports, correspondence, documents, and records the person produces be identified clearly as having been conducted and prepared by a student in training;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-4(1)(h)(iii): that the person is obviously identified and designated by appropriate title clearly indicating the person's training status; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-4(1)(h)(iv): that the person does not hold out directly or indirectly to the public or otherwise represent that the person is qualified to practice independently;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-4(1)(i): a person trained in elementary audiometry and qualified to perform basic audiometric tests while employed by and under the direct supervision of a licensed medical doctor to perform solely for the licensed medical doctor, the elementary conventional audiometric tests of air conduction screening, air conduction threshold testing, and tympanometry;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-4(1)(j): a person performing the functions of a speech-language pathologist or audiologist for the sole purpose of obtaining required professional experience under the provisions of this chapter and only during the period the person is obtaining the required professional experience, if the person:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-4(1)(j)(i): meets all training requirements; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-4(1)(j)(ii): is professionally responsible to and under the supervision of a speech-language pathologist or audiologist who holds the CCC or a state license in speech-language pathology or audiology;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-4(1)(k): a corporation, partnership, trust, association, group practice, or similar organization engaging in speech-language pathology or audiology services without certification or license, if acting only through employees or consisting only of persons who are licensed under this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-4(1)(l): 58-41-5 a person who is not a resident of this state performing speech-language pathology or audiology services in this state if:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-4(1)(l)(i): the services are performed for no more than one month in any calendar year in association with a speech-language pathologist or audiologist licensed under this chapter; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-4(1)(l)(ii): 58-41-5 the person meets the qualifications and requirements for application for licensure described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-4(1)(m): Title 53E, Public Education System -- State Administration a person certified under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-4(1)(n): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act; 26B-4-319 a person who is:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-4(1)(n)(i): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act trained in newborn hearing screening as described in rules made by the Department of Health and Human Services in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-4(1)(n)(ii): 26B-4-319 working under the indirect supervision of a licensed audiologist responsible for a newborn hearing screening program established by the Department of Health and Human Services under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-4(2): No person is exempt from the requirements of this chapter who performs or provides any services as a speech-language pathologist or audiologist for which a fee, salary, bonus, gratuity, or compensation of any kind paid by the recipient of the service; or who engages any part of his professional work for a fee practicing in conjunction with, by permission of, or apart from his position of employment as speech-language pathologist or audiologist in any branch or subdivision of local, state, or federal government or as otherwise identified in this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-5 Licensure requirements.
-----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-5(1): 63J-1-504 To obtain and maintain a license as an audiologist beginning July 1, 2010, an applicant must:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-5(1)(a): 63J-1-504 submit a completed application in the form and content prescribed by the division and pay a fee to the department in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-5(1)(b): provide the committee with verification that the applicant is the legal holder of a clinical doctor's degree or AuD, in audiology, from an accredited university or college, based on a program of studies primarily in the field of audiology;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-5(1)(c): be in compliance with the regulations of conduct and codes of ethics for the profession of audiology;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-5(1)(d): submit to the board certified evidence of having completed at least one year of professional experience, at least 30 hours per week for an academic year, of direct clinical experience in treatment and management of patients, supervised and attested to by one holding an audiologist license under this chapter, the CCC, or their full equivalent; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-5(1)(e): pass a nationally standardized examination in audiology which is the same as or equivalent to the examination required for the CCC and with pass-fail criteria equivalent to current ASHA standards, and the board may require the applicant to pass an acceptable practical demonstration of clinical skills to an examining committee of licensed audiologists appointed by the board.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-5(2): (1)(a); (c); (d); (e) To obtain and maintain a license as an audiologist prior to July 1, 2010, an applicant shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-5(2)(a): (1)(a); (c); (d); (e) comply with Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-5(2)(b): provide the committee with verification that the applicant has received at least a master's degree in the area of audiology from an accredited university or college, based on a program of studies primarily in the field of audiology, and holds the CCC or its full equivalent.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-5(3): An individual who, prior to July 1, 2010, is licensed as an audiologist under this chapter is, on or after July 1, 2010, considered to hold a current license under this chapter as an audiologist and is subject to this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-5(4): (1)(a); (1)(b) To obtain and maintain a license as a speech-language pathologist, an applicant must:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-5(4)(a): (1)(a) comply with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-5(4)(b): provide the committee with verification that the applicant has received at least a master's degree in speech-language pathology from an accredited university or college, based on a program of studies primarily in the field of speech-language pathology;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-5(4)(c): be in compliance with the regulations of conduct and code of ethics for the profession of speech-language pathology;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-5(4)(d): (1)(b) comply with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-5(4)(e): pass a nationally standardized examination in speech-language pathology which is the same as or equivalent to the examination required for the CCC and with pass-fail criteria equivalent to current ASHA standards, and the board may require the applicant to pass an acceptable practical demonstration of clinical skills to an examining committee of licensed speech-language pathologists appointed by the board.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-5.5 Temporary licenses.
---------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-5.5(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-5.5(1)(a): The division may issue a temporary license to an applicant for an audiology license who:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-5.5(1)(a)(i): has obtained a master's or doctorate degree in audiology prior to July 1, 2010, or a clinical doctorate degree in audiology or AuD, after June 30, 2010; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-5.5(1)(a)(ii): is practicing audiology in a year of clinical fellowship.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-5.5(1)(b): The temporary license is valid for up to 12 months.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-5.5(2): 58-41-5(4)(d)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-5.5(2)(a): 58-41-5(4)(d) The division may issue a temporary license to an applicant for a speech-language pathology license who:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-5.5(2)(a)(i): 58-41-5(4)(d) has completed all requirements for licensure as a speech-language pathologist under this chapter, except for Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-5.5(2)(a)(ii): is practicing speech-language pathology in a year of clinical fellowship.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-5.5(2)(b): The temporary license is valid for up to 12 months.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-6 Board.
------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-6(1): There is created the Speech-language Pathologist and Audiologist Licensing Board, consisting of four speech-language pathologists or audiologists and one member of the general public.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-6(1)(a): The nonpublic members of the board shall be licensed to provide and shall be engaged in providing speech-language pathology or audiology services to the public as a major interest as follows:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-6(1)(a)(i): one member shall be in private practice as a primary professional interest and activity or shall be a provider or speech-language pathology or audiology services at large;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-6(1)(a)(ii): one member shall be from a nonschool clinic setting which provides ongoing speech-language pathology or audiology services;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-6(1)(a)(iii): one member shall be a provider of speech-language pathology and audiology services in the elementary or secondary schools; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-6(1)(a)(iv): one member shall be a provider of a speech-language pathology and audiology college or university training program.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-6(1)(b): At no time may the board consist of more than two members who represent speech-language pathology or more than two members who represent audiology.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-6(2): 58-1-201 The board shall be appointed and serve in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-6(3): 58-1-202; 58-1-203 The duties and responsibilities of the board shall be in accordance with Sections


Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-8 Issuance of license.
--------------------------------------------------
Upon the recommendation of the board the division shall issue licenses in accordance with Section

Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-9 Grounds for denial of license -- Resumption of practice.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-9(1): 58-1-401 Grounds for refusal to issue a license to an applicant, for refusal to renew the license of a licensee, to revoke, suspend, restrict, or place on probation the license of a licensee, to issue a public or private reprimand to a licensee, and to issue cease and desist orders shall be in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-9(2): After one year from the date of revocation of a license, application may be made to the board for relicensing.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-12 Term of license -- Expiration -- Renewal.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-12(1): Each license issued under this chapter shall be issued in accordance with a two-year renewal cycle established by rule.  A renewal period may be extended or shortened by as much as one year to maintain established renewal cycles or to change an established renewal cycle.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-12(2): At the time of renewal the licensee shall show satisfactory evidence of completion of scheduled graduate level professional training, related clinically to the profession of speech-language pathology or audiology, as may be established by the division by rule, in cooperation with the board.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-12(3): 58-1-308 Each license automatically expires on the expiration date shown on the license unless renewed by the licensee in accordance with Section


Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-13 Fees.
------------------------------------
The department shall set fees in cooperation with the board and in accordance with Section

Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-14 Single license for speech-language pathologist and audiologist -- Single fee.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
An applicant who qualifies to be licensed as both a speech-language pathologist and audiologist shall receive a single license reflecting licensure in both classifications.  A fee may only be assessed for a single license.

Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-15 Violation of chapter -- Penalties.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
A person who violates any provision of this chapter is, upon conviction, guilty of a class A misdemeanor.  Whenever any person other than a licensed speech-language pathologist or audiologist has engaged in any practice that constitutes an offense under this chapter, a court of appropriate jurisdiction may issue an injunction or other appropriate order restraining that conduct.

Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-16 Privileged communication.
--------------------------------------------------------
A person licensed under this chapter may not be examined or required to reveal any findings, examinations, or representation made by his client to him, or any advice or treatment given to his client in the course of professional practice, without the consent of his client or the client's representative.  A person employed by a person licensed  under this chapter may not be examined without the consent of the employer concerning any fact of which the employee has acquired knowledge in his professional capacity.

Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-17 Requirements for selling hearing aids.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-17(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-17(1)(a): "Hearing aid" means a wearable instrument or device designed or offered for the purpose of aiding or compensating for human hearing loss, including its parts, attachments, or accessories.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-17(1)(b): "Hearing aid" does not include a device that is surgically implanted in the cochlea or under the skin near the ear.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-17(2): A person licensed under this chapter who offers to sell a hearing aid to a consumer shall inform the consumer about hearing aids that work with assistive listening systems that are compliant with the ADA Standards for Accessible Design adopted by the United States Department of Justice in accordance with the Americans with Disabilities Act, 42 U.S.C. Sec. 12101 et seq.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-17(3): A person licensed under this chapter who sells a hearing aid to a consumer shall provide a written receipt or written contract to the consumer that provides the consumer with a 30-day right to cancel the purchase and to obtain a refund if the consumer returns the hearing aid to the seller in the same condition as when purchased, excluding ordinary wear and tear.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-17(4): The written receipt or contract shall notify the consumer of the 30-day right to cancel in at least 12-point font.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-17(5): The 30-day right to cancel shall commence from the date the hearing aid is originally delivered to the consumer or the date the written receipt or contract is delivered to the consumer, whichever is later.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-17(6): The 30-day period shall be tolled for any period during which the hearing aid seller, dealer, or fitter has possession or control of the hearing aid after its original delivery.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-41-17(7): Upon exercise of the 30-day right to cancel a hearing aid purchase, the seller of the hearing aid is entitled to a cancellation fee equal to the actual cost that will be incurred by the seller in order to return the hearing aid to the manufacturer, provided that the written receipt or contract states the exact amount that will be retained by the seller as a cancellation fee.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 58 - Chapter 41a - Audiology and Speech-language Pathology Interstate Compact
*********************************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 58-41a-101 Title.
---------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Audiology and Speech-Language Pathology Interstate Compact."

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
AUDIOLOGY AND SPEECH-LANGUAGE PATHOLOGY INTERSTATE COMPACT

Utah Code Annotated § 58-41a-103 Rulemaking authority.
------------------------------------------------------
The division may make rules in accordance with

Utah Code Annotated - Title 58 - Chapter 42a - Occupational Therapy Practice Act
********************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-101 Title.
---------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Occupational Therapy Practice Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-102 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
In addition to the definitions in SectionUtah Code Annotated § 58-42a-102(1): 58-42a-201 "Board" means the Board of Occupational Therapy created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-102(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-102(2)(a): "Individual treatment plan" means a written record composed for each client by a person licensed under this chapter to engage in the practice of occupational therapy.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-102(2)(b): "Individual treatment plan" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-102(2)(b)(i): planning and directing specific exercises and programs to improve sensory integration and motor functioning at the level of performance neurologically appropriate for the individual's stage of development;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-102(2)(b)(ii): establishing a program of instruction to teach a client skills, behaviors, and attitudes necessary for the client's independent productive, emotional, and social functioning;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-102(2)(b)(iii): analyzing, selecting, and adapting functional exercises to achieve and maintain the client's optimal functioning in activities of daily living and to prevent further disability; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-102(2)(b)(iv): planning and directing specific programs to evaluate and enhance perceptual, motor, and cognitive skills.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-102(3): "Occupational therapist" means a person licensed under this chapter to practice occupational therapy.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-102(4): "Occupational therapy aide" means a person who is not licensed under this chapter but who provides supportive services under the supervision of an occupational therapist or occupational therapy assistant.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-102(5): 58-42a-305; 58-42a-306 "Occupational therapy assistant" means a person licensed under this chapter to practice occupational therapy under the supervision of an occupational therapist as described in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-102(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-102(6)(a): "Practice of occupational therapy" means the therapeutic use of everyday life activities with an individual:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-102(6)(a)(i): that has or is at risk of developing an illness, injury, disease, disorder, condition, impairment, disability, activity limitation, or participation restriction; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-102(6)(a)(ii): to develop or restore the individual's ability to engage in everyday life activities by addressing physical, cognitive, psychosocial, sensory, or other aspects of the individual's performance.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-102(6)(b): "Practice of occupational therapy" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-102(6)(b)(i): establishing, remediating, or restoring an undeveloped or impaired skill or ability of an individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-102(6)(b)(ii): modifying or adapting an activity or environment to enhance an individual's performance;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-102(6)(b)(iii): maintaining and improving an individual's capabilities to avoid declining performance in everyday life activities;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-102(6)(b)(iv): promoting health and wellness to develop or improve an individual's performance in everyday life activities;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-102(6)(b)(v): performance-barrier prevention for an individual, including disability prevention;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-102(6)(b)(vi): evaluating factors that affect an individual's activities of daily living in educational, work, play, leisure, and social situations, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-102(6)(b)(vi)(A): body functions and structures;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-102(6)(b)(vi)(B): habits, routines, roles, and behavioral patterns;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-102(6)(b)(vi)(C): cultural, physical, environmental, social, virtual, and spiritual contexts and activity demands that affect performance; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-102(6)(b)(vi)(D): motor, process, communication, interaction, and other performance skills;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-102(6)(b)(vii): providing interventions and procedures to promote or enhance an individual's safety and performance in activities of daily living in educational, work, and social situations, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-102(6)(b)(vii)(A): the therapeutic use of occupations and exercises;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-102(6)(b)(vii)(B): training in self-care, self-management, home-management, and community and work reintegration;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-102(6)(b)(vii)(C): the development, remediation, or compensation of behavioral skills and physical, cognitive, neuromuscular, and sensory functions;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-102(6)(b)(vii)(D): the education and training of an individual's family members and caregivers;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-102(6)(b)(vii)(E): care coordination, case management, and transition services;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-102(6)(b)(vii)(F): providing consulting services to groups, programs, organizations, or communities,
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-102(6)(b)(vii)(G): modifying the environment and adapting processes, including the application of ergonomic principles;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-102(6)(b)(vii)(H): assessing, designing, fabricating, applying, fitting, and providing training in assistive technology, adaptive devices, orthotic devices, and prosthetic devices;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-102(6)(b)(vii)(I): assessing, recommending, and training an individual in techniques to enhance functional mobility, including wheelchair management;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-102(6)(b)(vii)(J): driver rehabilitation and community mobility;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-102(6)(b)(vii)(K): enhancing eating and feeding performance; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-102(6)(b)(vii)(L): applying physical agent modalities, managing wound care, and using manual therapy techniques to enhance an individual's performance skills, if the occupational therapist has received the necessary training as determined by division rule in collaboration with the board.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-102(7): 58-1-501; 58-42a-501 "Unlawful conduct" means the same as that term is defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-102(8): 58-1-501; 58-42a-502 "Unprofessional conduct" means the same as that term is defined in Sections
