Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-201 Board.
---------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-201(1): There is created the Board of Occupational Therapy consisting of three licensed occupational therapists, one licensed occupational therapy assistant, and one member of the general public.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-201(2): 58-1-201 The board shall be appointed and serve in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-201(3): 58-1-202; 58-1-203 The duties and responsibilities of the board shall be in accordance with Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-201(4): The board shall designate one of its members on a permanent or rotating basis to:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-201(4)(a): assist the division in reviewing complaints concerning the unlawful or unprofessional practice of a licensee; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-201(4)(b): advise the division in its investigation of these complaints.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-201(5): (4) A board member who has, under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-301 Licensure required -- License classification.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-301(1): 58-1-307; 58-42a-304 A license is required to engage in the practice of occupational therapy, except as specifically provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-301(2): The division shall issue to a person who qualifies under this chapter a license in the classification of:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-301(2)(a): occupational therapist; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-301(2)(b): occupational therapy assistant.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-301(3): Nothing in this chapter shall permit an individual licensed under this chapter to engage in the practice of mental health therapy.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-302 Qualifications for licensure.
--------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-302(1): 63J-1-504; Chapter 42b, Occupational Therapy Licensure Compact; 58-42a-302.1; Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act An applicant for licensure as an occupational therapist shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-302(1)(a): submit an application in a form as prescribed by the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-302(1)(b): 63J-1-504 pay a fee as determined by the department under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-302(1)(c): graduate with a bachelor's or graduate degree for the practice of occupational therapy from an education program accredited by the American Occupational Therapy Association's Accreditation Council for Occupational Therapy Education, a predecessor organization, or an equivalent organization as determined by division rule;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-302(1)(d): if applying for licensure on or after July 1, 2015, complete a minimum of 24 weeks of supervised fieldwork experience;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-302(1)(e): pass an examination approved by the division in consultation with the board and administered by the National Board for Certification in Occupational Therapy, or by another nationally recognized credentialing body as approved by division rule, to demonstrate knowledge of the practice, skills, theory, and professional ethics related to occupational therapy; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-302(1)(f): Chapter 42b, Occupational Therapy Licensure Compact; 58-42a-302.1; Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act if the applicant is applying to participate in the Occupational Therapy Licensure Compact under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-302(2): 63J-1-504; Chapter 42b, Occupational Therapy Licensure Compact; 58-42a-302.1; Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act All applicants for licensure as an occupational therapy assistant shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-302(2)(a): submit an application in a form as prescribed by the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-302(2)(b): 63J-1-504 pay a fee as determined by the department under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-302(2)(c): graduate from an educational program for the practice of occupational therapy as an occupational therapy assistant that is accredited by the American Occupational Therapy Association's Accreditation Council for Occupational Therapy Education, a predecessor organization, or an equivalent organization as determined by division rule;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-302(2)(d): if applying for licensure on or after July 1, 2015, complete a minimum of 16 weeks of supervised fieldwork experience;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-302(2)(e): pass an examination approved by the division in consultation with the board and administered by the National Board for Certification in Occupational Therapy, or by another nationally recognized credentialing body as approved by division rule, to demonstrate knowledge of the practice, skills, theory, and professional ethics related to occupational therapy; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-302(2)(f): Chapter 42b, Occupational Therapy Licensure Compact; 58-42a-302.1; Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act if the applicant is applying to participate in the Occupational Therapy Licensure Compact under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-302(3): 58-42a-302; Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act; 58-1-302; (1)(e); (2)(e) Notwithstanding the other requirements of this section, the division may issue a license as an occupational therapist or as an occupational therapy assistant to an applicant who:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-302(3)(a): 58-42a-302; Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act consents to a criminal background check in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-302(3)(b): 58-1-302; (1)(e); (2)(e)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-302(3)(b)(i): 58-1-302 meets the requirements of receiving a license by endorsement under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-302(3)(b)(ii): (1)(e); (2)(e) has been licensed in a state, district, or territory of the United States, or in a foreign country, where the education, experience, or examination requirements are not substantially equal to the requirements of this state, if the applicant passes the applicable examination described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-302.1 Criminal background check.
-------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-302.1(1): An applicant for licensure under this chapter who requires a criminal background check shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-302.1(1)(a): submit fingerprint cards in a form acceptable to the division at the time the license application is filed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-302.1(1)(b): consent to a fingerprint background check conducted by the Bureau of Criminal Identification and the Federal Bureau of Investigation regarding the application.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-302.1(2): 53-10-108; (2)(a); 53-10-108 The division shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-302.1(2)(a): 53-10-108 in addition to other fees authorized by this chapter, collect from each applicant submitting fingerprints in accordance with this section the fee that the Bureau of Criminal Identification is authorized to collect for the services provided under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-302.1(2)(b): (2)(a) submit from each applicant the fingerprint card and the fees described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-302.1(2)(c): 53-10-108 obtain and retain in division records a signed waiver approved by the Bureau of Criminal Identification in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-302.1(3): 53-10-108; (2)(b) The Bureau of Criminal Identification shall, in accordance with the requirements of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-302.1(3)(a): (2)(b) check the fingerprints submitted under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-302.1(3)(b): forward the fingerprints to the Federal Bureau of Investigation for a national criminal history background check; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-302.1(3)(c): provide the results from the state, regional, and nationwide criminal history background checks to the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-302.1(4): Title 53, Chapter 10, Part 2, Bureau of Criminal Identification For purposes of conducting a criminal background check required under this section, the division shall have direct access to criminal background information maintained under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-302.1(5): The division may not disseminate outside of the division any criminal history record information that the division obtains from the Bureau of Criminal Identification or the Federal Bureau of Investigation under the criminal background check requirements of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-302.1(6): 58-42a-302(2); Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act; 58-42a-302(2); (6)(b); Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-302.1(6)(a): 58-42a-302(2) A new occupational therapist assistant license issued under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-302.1(6)(b): Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act; 58-42a-302(2) Notwithstanding
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-302.1(6)(c): (6)(b) A person whose conditional license has been revoked under Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-302.1(7): The division may not issue a letter of qualification to participate in the Occupational Therapy Licensure Compact until the criminal background check described in this section is completed.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-303 Term of license -- Expiration -- Renewal.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-303(1): The division shall issue each license under this chapter in accordance with a two-year renewal cycle established by division rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-303(2): The division may by rule extend or shorten a renewal period by as much as one year to stagger the renewal cycles it administers.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-303(3): 58-1-308 Each license automatically expires on the expiration date shown on the license unless the licensee renews it in accordance with Section


Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-303.5 Continuing education.
--------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-303.5(1): As a condition for renewal of a license under this chapter, a licensee shall complete 24 hours of qualified continuing professional education, in accordance with standards defined by division rule in collaboration with the board, during each two-year licensure cycle.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-303.5(2): (1) If a renewal cycle is extended or shortened under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-304 Exemptions from licensure.
-----------------------------------------------------------
In addition to the exemptions from licensure in SectionUtah Code Annotated § 58-42a-304(1): a person licensed in the state who is engaging in the practice of the person's profession or occupation as defined in statute under which the person is licensed;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-304(2): a person pursuing a course of study leading to a degree for the practice of occupational therapy at an accredited education program, if that person is acting under appropriate supervision and is designated by a title that clearly indicates the person's status as a student; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-304(3): 58-42a-302 a person fulfilling the supervised fieldwork experience requirements for licensure described in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-305 Limitation upon occupational therapy services provided by an occupational therapy assistant and an occupational therapy aide.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-305(1): 58-42a-306 An occupational therapy assistant:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-305(1)(a): 58-42a-306 may only perform occupational therapy services under the supervision of an occupational therapist as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-305(1)(b): may not write an individual treatment plan;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-305(1)(c): may not approve or cosign modifications to an individual treatment plan; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-305(1)(d): may contribute to and maintain an individual treatment plan.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-305(2): An occupational therapy aide:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-305(2)(a): may only perform occupational therapy services under the direct supervision of an occupational therapist or an occupational therapy assistant;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-305(2)(b): may not write, modify, contribute, or maintain an individual treatment plan; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-305(2)(c): may only perform tasks that are repetitive and routine for which the aide has been trained and has demonstrated competence.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-306 Supervision requirements.
----------------------------------------------------------
An occupational therapist who is supervising an occupational therapy assistant shall:Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-306(1): write or contribute to an individual treatment plan before referring a client to a supervised occupational therapy assistant for treatment;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-306(2): approve and cosign on all modifications to the individual treatment plan;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-306(3): meet face to face with the supervised occupational therapy assistant as often as necessary but at least once every two weeks in person or by video conference, and at least one time every month in person, to adequately provide consultation, advice, training, and direction to the occupational therapy assistant;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-306(4): meet with each client who has been referred to a supervised occupational therapy assistant at least once each month, to further assess the patient, evaluate the treatment, and modify the individual's treatment plan, except that if the interval of client care occurs one time per month or less, the occupational therapist shall meet with the client at least once every four visits;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-306(5): supervise no more than two full-time occupational therapy assistants at one time, or four part-time occupational therapy assistants if the combined work hours of the assistants do not exceed 40 hours per week, unless otherwise approved by the division in collaboration with the board;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-306(6): remain responsible for client treatment provided by the occupational therapy assistant; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-306(7): fulfill any other supervisory responsibilities as determined by division rule.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-401 Denial of license -- Discipline.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
The division may refuse to issue a license to an applicant, refuse to renew the license of a licensee, revoke, suspend, restrict, or place on probation the license of a licensee, issue a public or private reprimand to a licensee, and issue a cease and desist order under the grounds specified in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-501 Unlawful conduct.
--------------------------------------------------
"Unlawful conduct," as defined in SectionUtah Code Annotated § 58-42a-501(1): 58-1-307; 58-42a-304 engaging or offering to engage in the practice of occupational therapy unless licensed under this chapter or exempted from licensure under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-501(2): using the title occupational therapist or occupational therapy assistant unless licensed under this chapter; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-501(3): obtaining a license under this chapter by means of fraud, misrepresentation, or concealment of a material fact.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-502 Unprofessional conduct.
--------------------------------------------------------
"Unprofessional conduct," as defined in SectionUtah Code Annotated § 58-42a-502(1): being convicted of a crime in any court except for minor offenses;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-502(2): violating a lawful order, rule, or regulation adopted by the division in consultation with the board;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-502(3): providing substandard care as an occupational therapist due to a deliberate or negligent act or failure to act regardless of whether actual injury to the client is established;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-502(4): providing substandard care as an occupational therapy assistant, including exceeding the authority to perform components of intervention selected and delegated by the supervising occupational therapist, regardless of whether actual injury to the client is established;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-502(5): knowingly delegating responsibilities related to the practice of occupational therapy to an individual, including an occupational therapy aide, who does not have the knowledge, skills, or abilities to perform those responsibilities;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-502(6): failing to provide appropriate supervision in accordance with this chapter to an occupational therapy assistant or occupational therapy aide;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-502(7): practicing as an occupational therapist or occupational therapy assistant when physical or mental impairment of the occupational therapist or occupational therapy assistant prevents the provision of competent services to clients;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-502(8): having had an occupational therapist, occupational therapy assistant, or equivalent license or application refused, revoked, suspended, or other disciplinary action taken in another state, United States territory, or country;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-502(9): engaging in sexual misconduct, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-502(9)(a): engaging in or soliciting a sexual relationship with a client;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-502(9)(b): making a sexual advance, requesting a sexual favor, or engaging in physical contact of a sexual nature with a client; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-502(9)(c): engaging in verbal or physical conduct of a sexual nature in the presence of a client; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-42a-502(10): abandoning or neglecting a client in need of immediate professional care without making reasonable arrangements for the continuation of care.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 58 - Chapter 42b - Occupational Therapy Licensure Compact
*************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 58-42b-101 Section 1 -- Purpose.
------------------------------------------------------
The purpose of this Compact is to facilitate interstate practice of Occupational Therapy with the goal of improving public access to Occupational Therapy services. The Practice of Occupational Therapy occurs in the State where the patient/client is located at the time of the patient/client encounter. The Compact preserves the regulatory authority of States to protect public health and safety through the current system of State licensure.

Utah Code Annotated § 58-42b-102 Section 2 -- Definitions.
----------------------------------------------------------
As used in this Compact, and except as otherwise provided, the following definitions shall apply:

Utah Code Annotated § 58-42b-103 Section 3 -- State participation in the compact.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
(A)  
To participate in the Compact, a Member State shall:

Utah Code Annotated § 58-42b-104 Section 4 -- Compact privilege.
----------------------------------------------------------------
(A)  
To exercise the Compact Privilege under the terms and provisions of the Compact, the Licensee shall:

Utah Code Annotated § 58-42b-105 Section 5 -- Obtaining a new home state license by virtue of a compact privilege.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
(A)  
An Occupational Therapist or Occupational Therapy Assistant may hold a Home State license, which allows for Compact Privileges in Member States, in only one Member State at a time.

Utah Code Annotated § 58-42b-106 Section 6 -- Active duty military personnel or their spouses.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
(A)  Active Duty Military personnel, or their spouses, shall designate a Home State where the individual has a current license in good standing. The individual may retain the Home State designation during the period the service member is on active duty. Subsequent to designating a Home State, the individual shall only change their Home State through application for licensure in the new State or through the process described in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 58-42b-107 Section 7 -- Adverse actions.
--------------------------------------------------------------
(A)  
A Home State shall have exclusive power to impose Adverse Action against an Occupational Therapist's or Occupational Therapy Assistant's license issued by the Home State.

Utah Code Annotated § 58-42b-108 Section 8 -- Establishment of the Occupational Therapy Compact Commission.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
(A)  
The Compact Member States hereby create and establish a joint public agency known as the Occupational Therapy Compact Commission.

Utah Code Annotated § 58-42b-109 Section 9 -- Data system.
----------------------------------------------------------
(A)  
The Commission shall provide for the development, maintenance, and utilization of a coordinated database and reporting system containing licensure, Adverse Action, and Investigative Information on all licensed individuals in Member States.

Utah Code Annotated § 58-42b-110 Section 10 -- Rulemaking.
----------------------------------------------------------
(A)  
The Commission shall exercise its Rulemaking powers pursuant to the criteria set forth in this Section and the Rules adopted thereunder. Rules and amendments shall become binding as of the date specified in each Rule or amendment.

Utah Code Annotated § 58-42b-111 Section 11 -- Oversight, dispute resolution, and enforcement.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
(A)  
Oversight

Utah Code Annotated § 58-42b-112 Section 12 -- Date of implementation of the Interstate Commission for Occupational Therapy Practice and associated rules, withdrawal, and amendment.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
(A)  
The Compact shall come into effect on the date on which the Compact statute is enacted into law in the tenth Member State. The provisions, which become effective at that time, shall be limited to the powers granted to the Commission relating to assembly and the promulgation of Rules. Thereafter, the Commission shall meet and exercise Rulemaking powers necessary to the implementation and administration of the Compact.

Utah Code Annotated § 58-42b-113 Section 13 -- Construction and severability.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
This Compact shall be liberally construed so as to effectuate the purposes thereof. The provisions of this Compact shall be severable and if any phrase, clause, sentence, or provision of this Compact is declared to be contrary to the constitution of any Member State or of the United States or the applicability thereof to any government, agency, person, or circumstance is held invalid, the validity of the remainder of this Compact and the applicability thereof to any government, agency, person, or circumstance shall not be affected thereby. If this Compact shall be held contrary to the constitution of any Member State, the Compact shall remain in full force and effect as to the remaining Member States and in full force and effect as to the Member State affected as to all severable matters.

Utah Code Annotated § 58-42b-114 Section 14 -- Binding effect of compact and other laws.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
(A)  
A Licensee providing Occupational Therapy in a Remote State under the Compact Privilege shall function within the laws and regulations of the Remote State.

Utah Code Annotated § 58-42b-201 Rulemaking authority.
------------------------------------------------------
The division may make rules in accordance with

Utah Code Annotated - Title 58 - Chapter 44a - Nurse Midwife Practice Act
*************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-101 Title.
---------------------------------------
This chapter is the "Nurse Midwife Practice Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-102 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
In addition to the definitions in SectionUtah Code Annotated § 58-44a-102(1): Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act "Administrative penalty" means a monetary fine imposed by the division for acts or omissions determined to constitute unprofessional or unlawful conduct in accordance with a fine schedule established by rule and as a result of an adjudicative proceeding conducted in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-102(2): 58-44a-201 "Board" means the Certified Nurse Midwife Board created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-102(3): (7) "Consultation and Referral Plan" means a written plan jointly developed by a certified nurse midwife, as defined in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-102(4): "Consulting physician" means a physician and surgeon or osteopathic physician:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-102(4)(a): with an unrestricted license as a physician;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-102(4)(b): qualified by education, training, and current practice in obstetrics, gynecology, or both to act as a consulting physician to a nurse midwife practicing under this chapter and providing intrapartum care or prescribing Schedule II-III controlled substances; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-102(4)(c): who is available to consult with a nurse midwife, which does not include the consulting physician being present at the time or place the nurse midwife is engaged in practice.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-102(5): "Individual" means a natural person.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-102(6): "Intrapartum referral plan":
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-102(6)(a): means a written plan prepared by a nurse midwife describing the guidelines under which the nurse midwife will consult with a consulting physician, collaborate with a consulting physician, and refer patients to a consulting physician; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-102(6)(b): does not require the nurse midwife to obtain the signature of a physician on the intrapartum referral plan.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-102(7): "Nurse midwife" means a person licensed under this chapter to engage in practice as a certified nurse midwife.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-102(8): Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act; Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act "Physician" means a physician and surgeon or osteopathic surgeon licensed under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-102(9): 58-31b-102 "Practice as a certified nurse midwife" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-102(9)(a): 58-31b-102 practice as a registered nurse as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-102(9)(b): practice of nursing within the generally recognized scope and standards of nurse midwifery as defined by rule and consistent with professionally recognized preparations and educational standards of a certified nurse midwife by a person licensed under this chapter, which practice includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-102(9)(b)(i): having a safe mechanism for obtaining medical consultation, collaboration, and referral with one or more consulting physicians who have agreed to consult, collaborate, and receive referrals, but who are not required to sign a written document regarding the agreement;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-102(9)(b)(ii): providing a patient with information regarding other health care providers and health care services and referral to other health care providers and health care services when requested or when care is not within the scope of practice of a certified nurse midwife; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-102(9)(b)(iii): maintaining written documentation of the parameters of service for independent and collaborative midwifery management and transfer of care when needed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-102(9)(c): the authority to:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-102(9)(c)(i): elicit and record a patient's complete health information, including physical examination, history, and laboratory findings commonly used in providing obstetrical, gynecological, and well infant services to a patient;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-102(9)(c)(ii): assess findings and upon abnormal findings from the history, physical examination, or laboratory findings, manage the treatment of the patient, collaborate with the consulting physician or another qualified physician, or refer the patient to the consulting physician or to another qualified physician as appropriate;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-102(9)(c)(iii): diagnose, plan, and implement appropriate patient care, including the administration and prescribing of:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-102(9)(c)(iii)(A): prescription drugs;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-102(9)(c)(iii)(B): schedule IV-V controlled substances; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-102(9)(c)(iii)(C): schedule II-III controlled substances in accordance with a consultation and referral plan;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-102(9)(c)(iv): evaluate the results of patient care;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-102(9)(c)(v): consult as is appropriate regarding patient care and the results of patient care;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-102(9)(c)(vi): manage the intrapartum period according to accepted standards of nurse midwifery practice and a written intrapartum referral plan, including performance of routine episiotomy and repairs, and administration of anesthesia, including local, pudendal, or paracervical block anesthesia, but not including general anesthesia and major conduction anesthesia;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-102(9)(c)(vii): manage the postpartum period;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-102(9)(c)(viii): provide gynecological services;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-102(9)(c)(ix): provide noncomplicated newborn and infant care to the age of one year; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-102(9)(c)(x): represent or hold oneself out as a certified nurse midwife, or nurse midwife, or use the title certified nurse midwife, nurse midwife, or the initials C.N.M., N.M., or R.N.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-102(10): 58-1-501; 58-44a-501 "Unlawful conduct" is defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-102(11): "Unlicensed assistive personnel" means any unlicensed person, regardless of title, to whom tasks are delegated by a licensed certified nurse midwife in accordance with the standards of the profession as defined by rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-102(12): 58-1-501; 58-44a-502 "Unprofessional conduct" is defined in Sections


Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-201 Board.
---------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-201(1): There is created the Certified Nurse Midwife Board consisting of four certified nurse midwives and one member representing the general public.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-201(2): 58-1-201 The board shall be appointed and serve in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-201(3): 58-1-202; 58-1-203 The duties and responsibilities of the board are in accordance with Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-201(3)(a): designate one of its members on a permanent or rotating basis to assist the division in reviewing complaints concerning the unlawful or unprofessional practice of a certified nurse midwife; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-201(3)(b): advise the division in its investigation of these complaints.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-201(4): (3) A board member who has, under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-301 Licensure required -- License classification.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-301(1): 58-1-307 A license is required to engage in practice as a certified nurse midwife, except as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-301(2): The division shall issue to individuals qualified under the provisions of this chapter a license in the classification certified nurse midwife.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-301(3): An individual holding a certified nurse midwife license as of July 1, 1998, who cannot document the successful completion of advanced course work approved by the division in collaboration with the board in patient assessment, diagnosis and treatment, and pharmacotherapeutics, may not prescribe and shall be issued a "CNM without prescriptive practice" license.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-301(4): The division shall grant a certified nurse midwife license to any licensed certified nurse midwife currently holding prescriptive authority under any predecessor act on July 1, 1998.

Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-302(1)(c): Title 58, Chapter 31b, Nurse Practice Act at the time of application for licensure hold a license in good standing as a registered nurse in Utah, or be at that time qualified for a license as a registered nurse under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-302(1)(d): have completed:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-302(1)(d)(i): a certified nurse midwifery education program accredited by the Accreditation Commission for Midwifery Education and approved by the division; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-302(1)(d)(ii): a nurse midwifery education program located outside of the United States which is approved by the division and is equivalent to a program accredited by the Accreditation Commission for Midwifery Education, as demonstrated by a graduate's being accepted to sit for the national certifying examination administered by the Accreditation Commission for Midwifery Education or its designee;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-302(1)(e): (1)(d) have passed examinations established by the division rule in collaboration with the board within two years after completion of the approved education program required under Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-302.1(1)(b): consent to a fingerprint background check conducted by the Bureau of Criminal Identification and the Federal Bureau of Investigation regarding the application.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-302.1(2): 53-10-108; (2)(a); 53-10-108 The division shall:

Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-302.1(3): 53-10-108; (2)(b) The Bureau of Criminal Identification shall, in accordance with the requirements of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-302.1(3)(a): (2)(b) check the fingerprints submitted under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-302.1(3)(b): forward the fingerprints to the Federal Bureau of Investigation for a national criminal history background check; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-302.1(3)(c): provide the results from the state, regional, and nationwide criminal history background checks to the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-302.1(4): Title 53, Chapter 10, Part 2, Bureau of Criminal Identification For purposes of conducting a criminal background check required under this section, the division shall have direct access to criminal background information maintained under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-302.1(5): Except for information provided to the applicant, the division may not disseminate outside of the division any criminal history record information that the division obtains from the Bureau of Criminal Identification or the Federal Bureau of Investigation under the criminal background check requirements of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-302.1(6): 58-44a-302; Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act; 58-44a-302(1); (6)(b); Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act

Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-303 Term of license -- Expiration -- Renewal.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-303(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-303(1)(a): Each license issued under this chapter shall be issued in accordance with a two-year renewal cycle established by rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-303(1)(b): A renewal period may be extended or shortened by as much as one year to maintain established renewal cycles or to change an established renewal cycle.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-303(2): At the time of renewal, the licensee shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-303(2)(a): hold a valid certification from the American College of Nurse Midwives Certification Council, Inc.; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-303(2)(b): have met continuing competency requirements defined by the division rule in collaboration with the board.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-304 Continuing education.
------------------------------------------------------
The division in collaboration with the board may establish by rule continuing education requirements for renewal of licensure under this chapter, upon a finding by the division that continuing education requirements are necessary to protect the public health, safety, and welfare.

Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-305 Intern license.
------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-305(1): The division may issue an intern license to an individual who meets all qualifications for licensure except the passing of the qualifying examination if the applicant:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-305(1)(a): graduated from an approved education program within the 12 months immediately preceding the application for licensure;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-305(1)(b): has never before taken the qualifying examination;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-305(1)(c): is registered to take the next qualifying examination; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-305(1)(d): presents a plan acceptable to the division and board under which the applicant will practice under any intern license issued only under the direct supervision of a nurse midwife or physician.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-305(2): An intern license issued under this section expires on:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-305(2)(a): the date of the next qualifying examination immediately following issuance of the intern license if the intern license holder does not sit for that examination;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-305(2)(b): the date the examination results are available if the intern license holder sits for the next succeeding qualifying examination and fails the examination; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-305(2)(c): the date on which a regular license is issued if the intern license holder passes the examination and is otherwise qualified for licensure.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-401 Grounds for denial of license -- Disciplinary proceedings.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Division grounds for refusal to issue a license to an applicant, for refusal to renew the license of a licensee, to revoke, suspend, restrict, or place on probation the license of a licensee, to issue a public or private reprimand to a licensee, and to issue cease and desist orders are in accordance with Section

Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-402 Authority to assess penalty.
-------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-402(1): Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act; Title 58, Chapter 1, Division of Professional Licensing Act After a proceeding pursuant to
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-402(2): The assessment of a penalty under this section does not affect any other action the division is authorized to take regarding a license issued under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-402(3): 58-44a-501(2); (3); (4); 58-44a-503 The division may impose an administrative penalty of up to $500 for any violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-402(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-402(4)(a): The director may collect a penalty that is not paid by:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-402(4)(a)(i): referring the matter to a collection agency; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-402(4)(a)(ii): bringing an action in the district court of the county where the person against whom the penalty is imposed resides or in the county where the office of the director is located.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-402(4)(b): A county attorney or the attorney general of the state shall provide legal assistance and advice to the director in an action to collect a penalty.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-402(4)(c): A court shall award reasonable attorney fees and costs to the prevailing party in an action brought by the division to collect a penalty.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-501 Unlawful conduct.
--------------------------------------------------
"Unlawful conduct" includes:Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-501(1): Title 58, Chapter 31b, Nurse Practice Act engaging in practice as a certified nurse midwife when not licensed or exempted from licensure under this chapter, or engaging in practice as a registered nurse when not licensed or exempted from licensure under this chapter or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-501(2): representing or holding oneself out as a certified nurse midwife, nurse midwife, or identifying oneself by the initials C.N.M. or N.M. when not licensed under this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-501(3): Title 58, Chapter 31b, Nurse Practice Act representing or holding out oneself as a registered nurse or identifying oneself by the initials R.N.  when not licensed under this chapter or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-501(4): using any other title, initials, or any other means indicating that one is licensed under this chapter.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-502 Unprofessional conduct.
--------------------------------------------------------
"Unprofessional conduct" includes:Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-502(1): disregard for a patient's dignity or right to privacy as to the patient's person, condition, possessions, or medical record;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-502(2): engaging in an act, practice, or omission which when considered with the duties and responsibilities of a certified nurse midwife does or could jeopardize the health, safety, or welfare of a patient or the public;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-502(3): failure to confine one's practice as a certified nurse midwife to those acts or practices permitted by law;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-502(4): failure to file or record any medical report as required by law, impeding or obstructing the filing or recording of such a report, or inducing another to fail to file or record such a report;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-502(5): breach of a statutory, common law, regulatory, or ethical requirement of confidentiality with respect to a person who is a patient, unless ordered by the court;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-502(6): failure to pay a penalty imposed by the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-502(7): prescribing a schedule II-III controlled substance without a consulting physician;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-502(8): 76-7-302; 76-7a-201 performing or inducing an abortion in violation of the requirements of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-502(9): 58-44a-102(9)(b)(iii); (9)(a); (9)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-502(9)(a): 58-44a-102(9)(b)(iii) failure to have and maintain a safe mechanism for obtaining medical consultation, collaboration, and referral with a consulting physician, including failure to identify one or more consulting physicians in the written documents required by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-502(9)(b): (9)(a); (9)(a) representing that the certified nurse midwife is in compliance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-502(10): (1); (9); 58-1-501(1) falsely making an entry in, or altering, a medical record with the intent to conceal:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-502(10)(a): a wrongful or negligent act or omission of an individual licensed under this chapter or an individual under the direction or control of an individual licensed under this chapter; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-502(10)(b): (1); (9); 58-1-501(1) conduct described in Subsections


Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-503 Penalty for unlawful conduct.
--------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-503(1): 58-44a-501(1) Any individual who violates the unlawful conduct provisions of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-503(2): 58-44a-501(2); (3); (4) Any individual who violates the unlawful conduct provisions of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-503(3): (4); 58-44a-402; 58-44a-401 Subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-503(4): 58-44a-501 If a licensee has been convicted of violating Section


Utah Code Annotated § 58-44a-601 Parents delivering their children.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
This chapter does not abridge, limit, or change in any way the right of parents to deliver their baby where, when, how, and with whom they choose, regardless of licensure under this chapter.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 58 - Chapter 46a - Hearing Instrument Specialist Licensing Act
******************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-101 Title.
---------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Hearing Instrument Specialist Licensing Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-102 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
In addition to the definitions in SectionUtah Code Annotated § 58-46a-102(1): "Direct supervision" means that the supervising hearing instrument specialist is present in the same facility as is the person being supervised and is available for immediate in person consultation.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-102(2): "Hearing instrument" or "hearing aid" means any device designed or offered to be worn on or by an individual to enhance human hearing, including the device's specialized parts, attachments, or accessories.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-102(3): "Hearing instrument intern" means a person licensed under this chapter who is obtaining education and experience in the practice of a hearing instrument specialist under the supervision of a supervising hearing instrument specialist.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-102(4): "Indirect supervision" means that the supervising hearing instrument specialist is not required to be present in the same facility as is the person being supervised, but is available for voice to voice contact by telephone, radio, or other means at the initiation of the person being supervised.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-102(5): "Practice of a hearing instrument specialist" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-102(5)(a): establishing a place of business to practice as a hearing instrument specialist;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-102(5)(b): testing the hearing of a human patient over the age of 17 for the sole purpose of determining whether a hearing loss will be sufficiently improved by the use of a hearing instrument to justify prescribing and selling the hearing instrument and whether that hearing instrument will be in the best interest of the patient;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-102(5)(c): providing the patient a written statement of prognosis regarding the need for or usefulness of a hearing instrument for the patient's condition;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-102(5)(d): prescribing an appropriate hearing instrument;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-102(5)(e): making impressions or earmolds for the fitting of a hearing instrument;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-102(5)(f): sale and professional placement of the hearing instrument on a patient;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-102(5)(g): evaluating the hearing loss overcome by the installation of the hearing instrument and evaluating the hearing recovery against the representations made to the patient by the hearing instrument specialist;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-102(5)(h): necessary intervention to produce satisfactory hearing recovery results from a hearing instrument; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-102(5)(i): instructing the patient on the use and care of the hearing instrument.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-102(6): "Supervising hearing instrument specialist" means a hearing instrument specialist who:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-102(6)(a): is licensed by and in good standing with the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-102(6)(b): has practiced full-time as a hearing instrument specialist for not less than two years; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-102(6)(c): is approved as a supervisor by the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-102(7): 58-1-501 "Unlawful conduct" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-102(8): 58-1-501; 58-46a-501 "Unprofessional conduct" means the same as that term is defined in Sections


Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-301 License required -- License classifications.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-301(1): 58-1-307; 58-46a-305 A license is required to engage in the practice of hearing instrument specialist or hearing instrument intern, except as specifically provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-301(2): The division shall issue to an individual qualified under the provisions of this chapter a license in the classification of:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-301(2)(a): hearing instrument specialist; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-301(2)(b): hearing instrument intern.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-302 Qualifications for licensure.
--------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-302(1): 63J-1-504 Each applicant for licensure as a hearing instrument specialist shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-302(1)(a): submit to the division an application in a form prescribed by the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-302(1)(b): 63J-1-504 pay a fee as determined by the division pursuant to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-302(1)(c): have qualified for and currently hold board certification by the National Board for Certification - Hearing Instrument Sciences, or an equivalent certification approved by the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-302(1)(d): have passed the Utah Law and Rules Examination for Hearing Instrument Specialists; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-302(1)(e): if the applicant holds a hearing instrument intern license, surrender the hearing instrument intern license at the time of licensure as a hearing instrument specialist.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-302(2): 63J-1-504; 58-46a-302.5 Each applicant for licensure as a hearing instrument intern shall:

Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-302(2)(c): have passed the Utah Law and Rules Examination for Hearing Instrument Specialists; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-302(2)(d): 58-46a-302.5 present evidence acceptable to the division that the applicant, when licensed, will practice as a hearing instrument intern only under the supervision of a supervising hearing instrument specialist in accordance with:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-302(2)(d)(i): 58-46a-302.5 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-302(2)(d)(ii): the supervision requirements for obtaining board certification by the National Board for Certification - Hearing Instrument Sciences, or an equivalent certification approved by the division.

Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-303 Term of license -- Expiration -- Renewal of specialist and intern licenses.

Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-303(1)(a)(ii): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act The division may by rule made in accordance with

Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-304 Continuing professional education.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
As a condition precedent for license renewal each individual licensed under this chapter as a hearing instrument specialist shall complete qualified continuing professional education related to practice of hearing instrument specialist as established by division rule.

Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-305 Exemptions from licensure.
-----------------------------------------------------------
In addition to the exemptions from licensure in SectionUtah Code Annotated § 58-46a-305(1): Chapter 41, Speech-Language Pathology and Audiology Licensing Act an audiologist licensed under the provisions of
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-305(2): Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act; Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act a physician and surgeon licensed under the provisions of
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-305(3): Chapter 70a, Utah Physician Assistant Act a physician assistant licensed under the provisions of


Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-307 Licensee required to prove licensure to commence or maintain action.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A person may not commence or maintain an action in any court of the state for collection or compensation in any amount resulting from performance of acts or practices for which a license is required under this chapter unless that person was properly licensed under this chapter as a hearing instrument specialist at the time there was an agreement made to perform the regulated acts and practices, when the regulated acts and practices were performed, and when the alleged cause of action arose.

Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-401 Grounds for denial of license -- Disciplinary proceedings.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Grounds for refusing to issue a license to an applicant, for refusing to renew the license of a licensee, for revoking, suspending, restricting, or placing on probation the license of a licensee, for issuing a public or private reprimand to a licensee, and for issuing a cease and desist order shall be in accordance with Section

Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-501 Unprofessional conduct.
--------------------------------------------------------
"Unprofessional conduct" includes:Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-501(1): testing the hearing of a patient for any purpose other than to determine whether a hearing loss will be improved by the use of a hearing instrument;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-501(2): failing to make an appropriate referral to a qualified health care provider with respect to a condition detected in a patient examined by a licensee under this chapter if the condition is generally recognized in the profession as one that should be referred;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-501(3): designating a hearing instrument for a patient whose hearing will not be sufficiently improved to justify prescribing and selling of the hearing instrument;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-501(4): making false, misleading, deceptive, fraudulent, or exaggerated claims with respect to practice under this chapter and specifically with respect to the benefits of a hearing instrument or the degree to which a hearing instrument will benefit a patient;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-501(5): failing to exercise caution in providing a patient a prognosis to assure the patient is not led to expect results that cannot be accurately predicted;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-501(6): failing to provide appropriate follow-up care and consultation with respect to a patient to whom a hearing instrument has been prescribed and sold upon being informed by the patient that the hearing instrument does not produce the results represented by the licensee;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-501(7): failing to disclose in writing to the patient the charge for all services and hearing instruments prescribed and sold to a patient prior to providing the services or hearing instrument;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-501(8): failing to refund fees paid by a patient for a hearing instrument and all accessories, upon a determination by the division that the patient has not obtained the recovery of hearing represented by the licensee in writing prior to designation and sale of the hearing instrument;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-501(9): paying any professional person any consideration of any kind for referral of a patient;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-501(10): 58-46a-302.5 failing, when acting as a supervising hearing instrument specialist, to provide supervision and training in hearing instrument sciences in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-501(11): 58-46a-302.5 engaging in the practice as a hearing instrument intern when not under the supervision of a supervising hearing instrument specialist in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-501(12): failing to describe the circuitry in any advertisement, presentation, purchase, or trial agreement as being either "digital" or "analog"; or other acceptable terms as determined by the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-501(13): failing to follow the guidelines or policies of the United States Federal Trade Commission in any advertisement;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-501(14): failing to adhere to the rules and regulations prescribed by the United States Food and Drug Administration as they pertain to the hearing instrument specialist;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-501(15): failing to maintain all equipment used in the practice of a hearing instrument specialist properly calibrated and in good working condition; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-501(16): 58-46a-502; 58-46a-503 failing to comply with any of the requirements set forth in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-502 Additional requirements for practicing as a hearing instrument specialist.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A person engaging in the practice of a hearing instrument specialist shall:Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-502(1): have a regular place or places of business from which the person conducts business as a hearing instrument specialist and the place or places of business shall be represented to a patient and others with whom business is conducted by the street address at which the place of business is located;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-502(2): include in all advertising or other representation the street address at which the business is located and the telephone number of the business at that street address;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-502(3): provide as part of each transaction between a licensee and a patient related to testing for hearing loss and selling of a hearing instrument written documentation provided to the patient that includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-502(3)(a): identification of all services and products provided to the patient by the hearing instrument specialist and the charges for each service or product;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-502(3)(b): a statement whether any hearing instrument provided to a patient is "new," "used," or "reconditioned" and the terms and conditions of any warranty or guarantee that applies to each instrument; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-502(3)(c): the identity and license number of each hearing instrument specialist or hearing instrument intern who provided services or products to the patient;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-502(4): before providing services or products to a patient:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-502(4)(a): advise the patient regarding services and products offered to the patient, including the expected results of the services and products;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-502(4)(b): inform each patient who is being offered a hearing instrument about hearing instruments that work with assistive listening systems that are compliant with the ADA Standards for Accessible Design adopted by the United States Department of Justice in accordance with the Americans with Disabilities Act, 42 U.S.C. Sec. 12101 et seq.; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-502(4)(c): obtain written informed consent from the patient regarding offered services, products, and the expected results of the services and products in a form approved by the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-502(5): refer all individuals under the age of 18 who seek testing of hearing to a physician or surgeon, osteopathic physician, physician assistant, or audiologist, licensed under the provisions of this title, and shall dispense a hearing aid to that individual only on prescription of a physician or surgeon, osteopathic physician, physician assistant, or audiologist;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-502(6): obtain the patient's informed consent and agreement to purchase the hearing instrument based on that informed consent either by the hearing instrument specialist or the hearing instrument intern, before designating an appropriate hearing instrument; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-502(7): if a hearing instrument does not substantially enhance the patient's hearing consistent with the representations of the hearing instrument specialist at the time informed consent was given prior to the sale and fitting of the hearing instrument, provide:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-502(7)(a): necessary intervention to produce satisfactory hearing recovery results consistent with representations made; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-502(7)(b): for the refund of fees paid by the patient for the hearing instrument to the hearing instrument specialist within a reasonable time after finding that the hearing instrument does not substantially enhance the patient's hearing.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-503 Testing period for hearing aids.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-503(1): Any person licensed under this chapter who sells a hearing aid to a consumer shall provide a written receipt or written contract to the consumer.  The written receipt or contract shall provide the consumer with a 30-day right to cancel the purchase if the consumer finds that the hearing aid does not function adequately for the consumer and to obtain a refund if the consumer returns the hearing aid to the seller in the same condition, ordinary wear and tear excluded, as when purchased.  The written receipt or contract shall notify the consumer of the 30-day right to cancel in at least 10 point type.  The 30-day right to cancel shall commence from either the date the hearing aid is originally delivered to the consumer or the date the written receipt or contract is delivered to the consumer, whichever is later.  The 30-day period shall be tolled for any period during which the hearing aid seller, dealer, or fitter has possession or control of the hearing aid after its original delivery.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-46a-503(2): Upon exercise of the right to cancel a hearing aid purchase, the seller of the hearing aid is entitled to a cancellation fee not to exceed 15% of all fees charged to the consumer, including testing, fitting, counseling, and the purchase price of the hearing aid.  The exact amount of the cancellation fee shall be stated in the written receipt or contract provided to the consumer.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 58 - Chapter 47b - Massage Therapy Practice Act
***************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-101 Title.
---------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Massage Therapy Practice Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-102 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
In addition to the definitions in SectionUtah Code Annotated § 58-47b-102(1): 58-47b-201 "Board" means the Board of Massage Therapy created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-102(2): "Breast" means the female mammary gland and does not include the muscles, connective tissue, or other soft tissue of the upper chest.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-102(3): "Homeostasis" means maintaining, stabilizing, or returning to equilibrium the muscular system.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-102(4): "Massage apprentice" means an individual licensed under this chapter as a massage apprentice.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-102(5): "Massage assistant" means an individual licensed under this chapter as a massage assistant.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-102(6): "Massage assistant in-training" means an individual licensed under this chapter as a massage assistant in-training.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-102(7): "Massage therapist" means an individual licensed under this chapter as a massage therapist.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-102(8): Chapter 24b, Physical Therapy Practice Act; Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act; Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act; Chapter 72, Acupuncture Licensing Act; Chapter 73, Chiropractic Physician Practice Act "Massage therapy supervisor" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-102(8)(a): a massage therapist who has at least three years of experience as a massage therapist and has engaged in the lawful practice of massage therapy for at least 3,000 hours;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-102(8)(b): Chapter 24b, Physical Therapy Practice Act a physical therapist licensed under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-102(8)(c): Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act a physician licensed under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-102(8)(d): Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act an osteopathic physician licensed under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-102(8)(e): Chapter 72, Acupuncture Licensing Act an acupuncturist licensed under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-102(8)(f): Chapter 73, Chiropractic Physician Practice Act a chiropractic physician licensed under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-102(9): (9)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-102(9)(a): (9) "Practice of limited massage therapy" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-102(9)(a)(i): the systematic manual manipulation of the soft tissue of the body for the purpose of promoting the therapeutic health and well-being of a client, enhancing the circulation of the blood and lymph, relaxing and lengthening muscles, relieving pain, restoring metabolic balance, relaxation, or achieving homeostasis;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-102(9)(a)(ii): seated chair massage;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-102(9)(a)(iii): the use of body wraps;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-102(9)(a)(iv): aromatherapy;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-102(9)(a)(v): reflexology; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-102(9)(a)(vi): (9) in connection with an activity described in this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-102(9)(a)(vi)(A): the hands;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-102(9)(a)(vi)(B): a towel;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-102(9)(a)(vi)(C): a stone;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-102(9)(a)(vi)(D): a shell;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-102(9)(a)(vi)(E): a bamboo stick; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-102(9)(a)(vi)(F): an herbal ball compress.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-102(9)(b): "Practice of limited massage therapy" does not include work on an acute or subacute injury.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-102(10): (10); 58-73-102; (10); (10); 58-28-307(12); Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act "Practice of massage therapy" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-102(10)(a): the examination, assessment, and evaluation of the soft tissue structures of the body for the purpose of devising a treatment plan to promote homeostasis;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-102(10)(b): the systematic manual or mechanical manipulation of the soft tissue of the body for the purpose of promoting the therapeutic health and well-being of a client, enhancing the circulation of the blood and lymph, relaxing and lengthening muscles, relieving pain, restoring metabolic balance, or achieving homeostasis, or for any other purpose;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-102(10)(c): (10) the use of the hands or a mechanical or electrical apparatus in connection with this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-102(10)(d): the use of rehabilitative procedures involving the soft tissue of the body;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-102(10)(e): 58-73-102 range of motion or movements without spinal adjustment as set forth in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-102(10)(f): the use of oil rubs, heat lamps, salt glows, hot and cold packs, or tub, shower, steam, and cabinet baths;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-102(10)(g): manual traction and stretching exercise;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-102(10)(h): correction of muscular distortion by treatment of the soft tissues of the body;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-102(10)(i): counseling, education, and other advisory services to reduce the incidence and severity of physical disability, movement dysfunction, and pain;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-102(10)(j): (10) activities and modality techniques similar or related to the activities and techniques described in this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-102(10)(k): (10); 58-28-307(12); Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act a practice described in this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-102(10)(k)(i): 58-28-307(12) Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-102(10)(k)(ii): the provisions of this chapter; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-102(10)(k)(iii): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act division rule made in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-102(10)(l): providing, offering, or advertising a paid service using the term massage or a derivative of the word massage, regardless of whether the service includes physical contact.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-102(11): "Soft tissue" means the muscles and related connective tissue.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-102(12): 58-1-501; 58-47b-501 "Unlawful conduct" means the same as that term is defined in Sections

Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-301 Licensure required.
----------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-301(2)(a): represent oneself as a massage therapist, massage apprentice, massage assistant, or massage assistant in-training;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-301(2)(b): represent oneself as providing a service that is within the practice of massage therapy or the practice of limited massage therapy or use the word massage or any other word to describe the services; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-301(2)(c): charge or receive a fee or any consideration for providing a service that is within the practice of massage therapy or the practice of limited massage therapy.

Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-302(5)(a): submit an application in a form prescribed by the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-302(5)(b): 63J-1-504 pay a fee determined by the department in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-302(5)(c): be 18 years old or older; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-302(5)(d): (4)(a)(iv); (4)(b) provide satisfactory evidence to the division that the applicant will practice as a massage assistant in-training under the supervision of a massage therapist for a period of no more than six months for the purpose of satisfying the requirements described in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-302(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-302(6)(a): A massage therapist may supervise at one time up to six individuals licensed as a massage apprentice or massage assistant in-training.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-302(6)(b): A massage therapy supervisor may supervise at one time up to six individuals licensed as a massage assistant.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-302(7): 58-47b-302.1; Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act A new massage therapist, massage apprentice, massage assistant, or massage assistant in-training applicant shall submit to and pass a criminal background check in accordance with Section


Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-302.1 Criminal background check.
-------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-302.1(1): An applicant for licensure under this chapter who requires a criminal background check shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-302.1(1)(a): submit fingerprint cards in a form acceptable to the division at the time the license application is filed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-302.1(1)(b): consent to a fingerprint background check conducted by the Bureau of Criminal Identification and the Federal Bureau of Investigation regarding the application.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-302.1(2): 53-10-108; (2)(a); 53-10-108 The division shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-302.1(2)(a): 53-10-108 in addition to other fees authorized by this chapter, collect from each applicant submitting fingerprints in accordance with this section the fee that the Bureau of Criminal Identification is authorized to collect for the services provided under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-302.1(2)(b): (2)(a) submit from each applicant the fingerprint card and the fees described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-302.1(2)(c): 53-10-108 obtain and retain in division records a signed waiver approved by the Bureau of Criminal Identification in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-302.1(3): 53-10-108; (2)(b) The Bureau of Criminal Identification shall, in accordance with the requirements of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-302.1(3)(a): (2)(b) check the fingerprints submitted under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-302.1(3)(b): forward the fingerprints to the Federal Bureau of Investigation for a national criminal history background check; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-302.1(3)(c): provide the results from the state, regional, and nationwide criminal history background checks to the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-302.1(4): Title 53, Chapter 10, Part 2, Bureau of Criminal Identification For purposes of conducting a criminal background check required under this section, the division shall have direct access to criminal background information maintained under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-302.1(5): The division may not disseminate outside of the division any criminal history record information that the division obtains from the Bureau of Criminal Identification or the Federal Bureau of Investigation under the criminal background check requirements of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-302.1(6): Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act; 58-47b-302(7); (6)(b); Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act

Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-302.1(6)(c): (6)(b) A person whose conditional license is revoked under Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 58-47b-302.1(7): An applicant who successfully completes a background check under this section may not be required by any other state or local government body to submit to a second background check as a condition of lawfully engaging in the practice of massage therapy or the practice of limited massage therapy in this state.
