Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-205(3): 63J-1-504; (4) An applicant for licensure as a social service worker shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-205(3)(a): submit an application on a form provided by the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-205(3)(b): 63J-1-504 pay a fee determined by the department under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-205(3)(c): (4) produce certified transcripts from an accredited institution of higher education recognized by the division in collaboration with the board verifying satisfactory completion of an education and an earned degree as follows:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-205(3)(c)(i): a bachelor's degree in a social work program accredited by the Council on Social Work Education or by the Canadian Association of Schools of Social Work;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-205(3)(c)(ii): a master's degree in a field approved by the division in collaboration with the board;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-205(3)(c)(iii): (4) a bachelor's degree in any field if the applicant:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-205(3)(c)(iii)(A): has completed at least three semester hours, or the equivalent, in each of the following areas:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-205(3)(c)(iii)(A)(I): social welfare policy;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-205(3)(c)(iii)(A)(II): human growth and development; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-205(3)(c)(iii)(A)(III): social work practice methods, as defined by rule; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-205(3)(c)(iii)(B): (4) provides documentation that the applicant has completed at least 2,000 hours of qualifying experience under the supervision of a mental health therapist, which experience is approved by the division in collaboration with the board, and which is performed after completion of the requirements to obtain the bachelor's degree required under this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-205(3)(c)(iv): successful completion of the first academic year of a Council on Social Work Education approved master's of social work curriculum and practicum.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-205(4): (1)(g) The division shall ensure that the rules for an examination described under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-205(4)(a): a foreign born legal resident of the United States for whom English is a second language; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-205(4)(b): an enrolled member of a federally recognized Native American tribe.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-205.5 Continuing education.
-------------------------------------------------------
As a condition for renewal of a license under this part, a social service worker licensee shall, during each two-year licensure cycle, complete qualified continuing professional education, as defined by rule made in accordance with

Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-206 Qualifications for admission to examination.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
All applicants for admission to an examination qualifying an individual for licensure under this part shall, before taking the examination:Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-206(1): submit an application for examination on a form provided by the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-206(2): pay the fee established for the examination; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-206(3): certify under penalty of perjury as evidenced by notarized signature on the application for examination that the applicant:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-206(3)(a): has completed the education requirement and been awarded the earned degree required for licensure; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-206(3)(b): has only one semester, or the equivalent, remaining before the applicant completes the education requirement for earning the degree that is required for licensure.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-207 Scope of practice -- Limitations.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-207(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-207(1)(a): A clinical social worker may engage in all acts and practices defined as the practice of clinical social work without supervision, in private and independent practice, or as an employee of another person, limited only by the licensee's education, training, and competence.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-207(1)(b): A clinical social worker may not supervise more than six individuals who are lawfully engaged in training for the practice of mental health therapy, unless granted an exception in writing from the division in collaboration with the board.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-207(2): 58-60-205(1)(d)(i) To the extent an individual is professionally prepared by the education and training track completed while earning a master's or doctor of social work degree, a licensed certified social worker may engage in all acts and practices defined as the practice of certified social work consistent with the licensee's education, clinical training, experience, and competence:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-207(2)(a): 58-60-205(1)(d)(i) under supervision of an individual described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-207(2)(b): without supervision and in private and independent practice or as an employee of another person, if not engaged in the practice of mental health therapy;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-207(2)(c): including engaging in the private, independent, unsupervised practice of social work as a self-employed individual, in partnership with other mental health therapists, as a professional corporation, or in any other capacity or business entity, so long as he does not practice unsupervised psychotherapy; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-207(2)(d): supervising social service workers as provided by division rule.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-301 Title.
--------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Marriage and Family Therapist Licensing Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-302 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
In addition to the definitions in SectionsUtah Code Annotated § 58-60-302(1): "Assess" means the use of diagnostic procedures, tests, and interview techniques generally accepted as standard in mental health therapy to diagnose any condition related to mental, emotional, behavioral, and social disorders or dysfunctions.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-302(2): 58-60-303 "Board" means the Marriage and Family Therapist Licensing Board created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-302(3): "Practice of marriage and family therapy" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-302(3)(a): the process of providing professional mental health therapy including psychotherapy to individuals, couples, families, or groups;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-302(3)(b): utilizing established principles that recognize the interrelated nature of individual problems and dysfunctions in family members to assess, diagnose, and treat mental, emotional, and behavioral disorders;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-302(3)(c): individual, premarital, relationship, marital, divorce, and family therapy;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-302(3)(d): specialized modes of treatment for the purpose of diagnosing and treating mental, emotional, and behavioral disorders, modifying interpersonal and intrapersonal dysfunction, and promoting mental health; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-302(3)(e): assessment utilized to develop, recommend, and implement appropriate plans of treatment, dispositions, and placement related to the functioning of the individual, couple, family, or group.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-303 Board -- Powers.
------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-303(1): There is created the Marriage and Family Therapist Licensing Board consisting of four marriage and family therapists and one member from the general public.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-303(2): 58-1-201 The board shall be appointed, serve terms, and be compensated in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-303(3): 58-1-202; 58-1-203 The board shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-303(3)(a): 58-1-202; 58-1-203 comply with the provisions of Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-303(3)(b): designate one of its members on a permanent or rotating basis to assist the division in review of complaints concerning unlawful or unprofessional practice by a licensee in the respective profession regulated by the board, and to advise the division with respect to the conduct of investigations of the complaints; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-303(3)(c): disqualify any member from acting as presiding officer in any administrative procedure in which that member has previously reviewed the complaint or advised the division.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-304 License classifications.
--------------------------------------------------------
The division shall issue licenses to individuals qualified under this part in the classification of:Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-304(1): marriage and family therapist; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-304(2): associate marriage and family therapist.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-305 Qualifications for licensure.
-------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-305(1): 63J-1-504; 58-1-203; 58-1-203; 58-60-307; (1)(c); (1)(c); (1)(d); 58-60-307; 58-1-203; Chapter 60a, Counseling Compact; 58-60-103.1; Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act All applicants for licensure as marriage and family therapists shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-305(1)(a): submit an application on a form provided by the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-305(1)(b): 63J-1-504 pay a fee determined by the department under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-305(1)(c): 58-1-203 produce certified transcripts evidencing completion of a masters or doctorate degree in marriage and family therapy from:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-305(1)(c)(i): a program accredited by the Commission on Accreditation for Marriage and Family Therapy Education; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-305(1)(c)(ii): 58-1-203 an accredited institution meeting criteria for approval established by rule under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-305(1)(d): 58-1-203; 58-60-307; (1)(c) have completed a minimum of 3,000 hours of marriage and family therapy training as defined by division rule under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-305(1)(d)(i): 58-60-307 under the supervision of a mental health therapist supervisor who meets the requirements of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-305(1)(d)(ii): (1)(c) obtained after completion of the education requirement in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-305(1)(d)(iii): including a minimum of two hours of training in suicide prevention via a course that the division designates as approved;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-305(1)(e): (1)(c); (1)(d); 58-60-307 document successful completion of not less than 1,000 hours of supervised training in mental health therapy obtained after completion of the education requirement described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-305(1)(f): 58-1-203 pass the examination requirement established by division rule under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-305(1)(g): Chapter 60a, Counseling Compact; 58-60-103.1; Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act if the applicant is applying to participate in the Counseling Compact under

Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-305(2)(b): (1)(d); (e); (2)(b) An individual's license as an associate marriage and family therapist is limited to the period of time necessary to complete clinical training as described in Subsections


Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-305.5 Qualification for licensure before May 1, 2000.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-305.5(1): 58-60-305(1)(c) A person who was licensed under this chapter as of May 1, 2000, may apply for renewal of licensure without being required to fulfill the educational requirements described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-305.5(2): A person who seeks licensure under this chapter before July 1, 2002, need comply only with the licensure requirements in effect before May 1, 2000.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-306 Qualifications for admission to examination.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
All applicants for admission to any examination qualifying an individual for licensure under this part shall:Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-306(1): submit an application on a form provided by the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-306(2): pay the fee established for the examination; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-306(3): certify under penalty of perjury as evidenced by notarized signature on the application for admission to the examination that the applicant has completed the education requirement and been awarded the earned degree required for licensure.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-307 Supervisors of marriage and family therapists -- Qualifications.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-307(1): Each person acting as a supervisor of a marriage and family therapist shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-307(1)(a): have at least two years of clinical experience, since the date of first licensure, as a:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-307(1)(a)(i): clinical mental health counselor;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-307(1)(a)(ii): psychiatrist;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-307(1)(a)(iii): psychologist;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-307(1)(a)(iv): registered psychiatric mental health nurse practitioner;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-307(1)(a)(v): marriage and family therapist; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-307(1)(a)(vi): clinical social worker;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-307(1)(b): either:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-307(1)(b)(i): be approved as a supervisor by a national marriage and family therapist professional organization; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-307(1)(b)(ii): meet the criteria established by rule; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-307(1)(c): provide supervision for no more than six individuals who are lawfully engaged in training for the practice of mental health therapy, unless granted an exception in writing from the division in collaboration with the board.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-307(2): Persons who act as a supervisor without meeting the requirements of this section are subject to discipline for unprofessional conduct.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-308 Scope of practice -- Limitations.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-308(1): A licensed marriage and family therapist may engage in all acts and practices defined as the practice of marriage and family therapy without supervision, in private and independent practice, or as an employee of another person, limited only by the licensee's education, training, and competence.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-308(2): 58-60-305(1)(c); 58-60-307
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-308(2)(a): 58-60-305(1)(c); 58-60-307 To the extent an individual has completed the educational requirements of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-308(2)(a)(i): within the scope of employment as a licensed associate marriage and family therapist with a public agency or a private clinic as defined by division rule; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-308(2)(a)(ii): 58-60-307 under the supervision of a licensed mental health therapist who is qualified as a supervisor under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-308(2)(b): A licensed associate marriage and family therapist may not engage in the independent practice of marriage and family therapy.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-401 Title.
--------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Clinical Mental Health Counselor Licensing Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-402 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
In addition to the definitions in SectionsUtah Code Annotated § 58-60-402(1): 58-60-403 "Board" means the Clinical Mental Health Counselor Licensing Board created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-402(2): "Practice of clinical mental health counseling" means the practice of mental health therapy by means of observation, description, evaluation, interpretation, intervention, and treatment to effect modification of human behavior by the application of generally recognized clinical mental health counseling principles, methods, and procedures for the purpose of preventing, treating, or eliminating mental or emotional illness or dysfunction, symptoms of any of these, or maladaptive behavior.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-403 Board.
--------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-403(1): There is created the Clinical Mental Health Counselor Licensing Board consisting of four clinical mental health counselors and one member from the general public.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-403(2): 58-1-201 The board shall be appointed, serve terms, and be compensated in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-403(3): 58-1-202; 58-1-203 The duties and responsibilities of the board are in accordance with Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-403(3)(a): designate one of its members on a permanent or rotating basis to assist the division in review of complaints concerning unlawful or unprofessional practice by a licensee in the profession regulated by  the board and to advise the division with respect to the conduct of investigations of the complaints; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-403(3)(b): disqualify any member from acting as presiding officer in any administrative procedure in which that member has previously reviewed the complaint or advised the division.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-404 License classifications.
--------------------------------------------------------
The division shall issue licenses to individuals qualified under the provisions of this part in the classification of:Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-404(1): a clinical mental health counselor; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-404(2): an associate clinical mental health counselor.

Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-406 Qualifications for admission to examination.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
All applicants for admission to any examination qualifying an individual for licensure under this part shall:Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-406(1): submit an application on a form provided by the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-406(2): pay the fee established by division rule for the examination; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-406(3): certify under penalty of perjury as evidenced by notarized signature on the application for admission to the examination that the applicant has completed the education requirement and been awarded the earned degree required for licensure.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-407 Scope of practice -- Limitations.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-407(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-407(1)(a): A licensed clinical mental health counselor may engage in all acts and practices defined as the practice of clinical mental health counseling without supervision, in private and independent practice, or as an employee of another person, limited only by the licensee's education, training, and competence.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-407(1)(b): A licensed clinical mental health counselor may not supervise more than six individuals who are lawfully engaged in training for the practice of mental health therapy, unless granted an exception in writing from the division in collaboration with the board.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-407(2): 58-60-305(1)(c); 58-60-102
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-407(2)(a): 58-60-305(1)(c); 58-60-102 To the extent an individual has completed the educational requirements of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-407(2)(a)(i): within the scope of employment as a licensed clinical mental health counselor with a public agency or private clinic as defined by division rule; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-407(2)(a)(ii): 58-60-102 under supervision of a qualified licensed mental health therapist as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-407(2)(b): A licensed associate clinical mental health counselor may not engage in the independent practice of clinical mental health counseling.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-501 Title.
--------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Substance Use Disorder Counselor Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-502 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
In addition to the definitions in SectionsUtah Code Annotated § 58-60-502(1): 58-60-503 "Board" means the Substance Use Disorder Counselor Licensing Board created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-502(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-502(2)(a): "Counseling" means a collaborative process that facilitates the client's progress toward mutually determined treatment goals and objectives.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-502(2)(b): "Counseling" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-502(2)(b)(i): methods that are sensitive to an individual client's characteristics, to the influence of significant others, and to the client's cultural and social context; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-502(2)(b)(ii): an understanding, appreciation, and ability to appropriately use the contributions of various addiction counseling models as the counseling models apply to modalities of care for individuals, groups, families, couples, and significant others.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-502(3): "Direct supervision" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-502(3)(a): a minimum of one hour of supervision by a supervisor of the substance use disorder counselor for every 40 hours of client care provided by the substance use disorder counselor, which supervision may include group supervision;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-502(3)(b): the supervision is conducted in a face-to-face manner, unless otherwise approved on a case-by-case basis by the division in collaboration with the board; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-502(3)(c): a supervisor is available for consultation with the counselor at all times.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-502(4): "General supervision" shall be defined by division rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-502(5): "Group supervision" means more than one counselor licensed under this part meets with the supervisor at the same time.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-502(6): "Individual supervision" means only one counselor licensed under this part meets with the supervisor at a given time.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-502(7): (9) "Practice as a certified advanced substance use disorder counselor" and "practice as a certified advanced substance use disorder counselor intern" means providing services described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-502(8): (10)(a); (b) "Practice as a certified substance use disorder counselor" and "practice as a certified substance use disorder counselor intern" means providing the services described in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-502(9): (10)(a); (b); 58-60-508(2) "Practice as a licensed advanced substance use disorder counselor" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-502(9)(a): (10)(a); (b) providing the services described in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-502(9)(b): screening and assessing of individuals, including identifying substance use disorder symptoms and behaviors and co-occurring mental health issues;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-502(9)(c): treatment planning for substance use disorders, including initial planning, ongoing intervention, continuity of care, discharge planning, planning for relapse prevention, and long term recovery support; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-502(9)(d): 58-60-508(2) supervising a certified substance use disorder counselor, certified substance use disorder counselor intern, certified advanced substance use disorder counselor, certified advanced substance use disorder counselor intern, or licensed substance use disorder counselor in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-502(10): 58-60-102; 58-60-102
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-502(10)(a): "Practice as a substance use disorder counselor" means providing services as an employee of a substance use disorder agency under the general supervision of a licensed mental health therapist to individuals or groups of persons, whether in person or remotely, for conditions of substance use disorders consistent with the education and training of a substance use disorder counselor required under this part, and the standards and ethics of the profession as approved by the division in collaboration with the board.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-502(10)(b): "Practice as a substance use disorder counselor" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-502(10)(b)(i): administering the screening process by which a client is determined to need substance use disorder services, which may include screening, brief intervention, and treatment referral;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-502(10)(b)(ii): conducting the administrative intake procedures for admission to a program;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-502(10)(b)(iii): conducting orientation of a client, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-502(10)(b)(iii)(A): describing the general nature and goals of the program;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-502(10)(b)(iii)(B): explaining rules governing client conduct and infractions that can lead to disciplinary action or discharge from the program;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-502(10)(b)(iii)(C): explaining hours during which services are available in a nonresidential program;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-502(10)(b)(iii)(D): treatment costs to be borne by the client, if any; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-502(10)(b)(iii)(E): describing the client's rights as a program participant;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-502(10)(b)(iv): conducting assessment procedures by which a substance use disorder counselor gathers information related to an individual's strengths, weaknesses, needs, and substance use disorder symptoms for the development of the treatment plan;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-502(10)(b)(v): participating in the process of treatment planning, including recommending specific interventions to support existing treatment goals and objectives developed by the substance use disorder counselor, the mental health therapist, and the client to:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-502(10)(b)(v)(A): identify and rank problems needing resolution;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-502(10)(b)(v)(B): establish agreed upon immediate and long term goals; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-502(10)(b)(v)(C): decide on a treatment process and the resources to be utilized;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-502(10)(b)(vi): monitoring compliance with treatment plan progress;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-502(10)(b)(vii): providing substance use disorder counseling services to alcohol and drug use disorder clients and significant people in the client's life as part of a comprehensive treatment plan, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-502(10)(b)(vii)(A): leading specific task-oriented groups, didactic groups, and group discussions;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-502(10)(b)(vii)(B): cofacilitating group therapy with a licensed mental health therapist; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-502(10)(b)(vii)(C): engaging in one-on-one interventions and interactions coordinated by a mental health therapist;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-502(10)(b)(viii): performing case management activities that bring services, agencies, resources, or people together within a planned framework of action toward the achievement of established goals, including, when appropriate, liaison activities and collateral contacts;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-502(10)(b)(ix): providing substance use disorder crisis intervention services;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-502(10)(b)(x): providing client education to individuals and groups concerning alcohol and other substance use disorders, including identification and description of available treatment services and resources;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-502(10)(b)(xi): identifying the needs of the client that cannot be met by the substance use disorder counselor or substance use disorder agency and referring the client to appropriate services and community resources;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-502(10)(b)(xii): developing and providing effective reporting and recordkeeping procedures and services, which include charting the results of the assessment and treatment plan, writing reports, progress notes, discharge summaries, and other client-related data; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-502(10)(b)(xiii): consulting with other professionals in regard to client treatment and services to assure comprehensive quality care for the client.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-502(10)(c): 58-60-102; 58-60-102 "Practice as a substance use disorder counselor" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-502(10)(c)(i): 58-60-102 the diagnosing of mental illness, including substance use disorders, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-502(10)(c)(ii): 58-60-102 engaging in the practice of mental health therapy as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-502(10)(c)(iii): the performance of a substance use disorder diagnosis, other mental illness diagnosis, or psychological testing.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-502(11): "Program" means a substance use disorder agency that provides substance use disorder services, including recovery support services.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-502(12): "Recovery support services" means services provided to an individual who is identified as having need of substance use disorder preventive or treatment services, either before, during, or after an episode of care that meets the level of care standards established by division rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-502(13): "Substance use disorder agency" means a public or private agency, health care facility, or health care practice that:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-502(13)(a): provides substance use disorder services, recovery support services, primary health care services, or substance use disorder preventive services; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-502(13)(b): employs qualified mental health therapists in sufficient number to:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-502(13)(b)(i): evaluate the condition of clients being treated by each counselor licensed under this part and employed by the substance use disorder agency; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-502(13)(b)(ii): ensure that appropriate substance use disorder services are being given.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-502(14): "Substance use disorder education program" means a formal program of substance use disorder education offered by an accredited institution of higher education that meets standards established by division rule.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-503 Board.
--------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-503(1): There is created the Substance Use Disorder Counselor Licensing Board consisting of:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-503(1)(a): three substance use disorder counselors;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-503(1)(b): three mental health therapists qualified by education or experience to treat substance use disorder and who are currently practicing in the substance use disorder field; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-503(1)(c): one public member.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-503(2): 58-1-201 The board shall be appointed and serve in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-503(3): 58-1-202; 58-1-203 The duties and responsibilities of the board are in accordance with Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-503(3)(a): assist the division in reviewing complaints concerning the unlawful or unprofessional conduct of a licensee; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-503(3)(b): advise the division in its investigation of these complaints.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-503(4): (3) A board member who has, under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-504 License classification.
-------------------------------------------------------
The division shall issue substance use disorder counselor licenses to individuals qualified under this part in the classification of:Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-504(1): licensed advanced substance use disorder counselor;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-504(2): certified advanced substance use disorder counselor;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-504(3): certified advanced substance use disorder counselor intern;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-504(4): licensed substance use disorder counselor;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-504(5): certified substance use disorder counselor; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-504(6): certified substance use disorder counselor intern.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-506 Qualifications for licensure.
-------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-506(1): 63J-1-504; (2); (3); (4); (5); (6); (7); 58-1-203 An applicant for licensure under this part on and after July 1, 2012, must meet the following qualifications:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-506(1)(a): submit an application in a form prescribed by the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-506(1)(b): 63J-1-504 pay a fee determined by the department under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-506(1)(c): (2); (3); (4); (5); (6); (7) satisfy the requirements of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-506(1)(d): 58-1-203 except for licensure as a certified substance use disorder counselor intern and a certified advanced substance use disorder counselor intern, satisfy the examination requirement established by division rule under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-506(2): (2)(b) In accordance with division rules, an applicant for licensure as an advanced substance use disorder counselor shall produce:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-506(2)(a): certified transcripts from an accredited institution of higher education that:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-506(2)(a)(i): meet division standards;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-506(2)(a)(ii): verify the satisfactory completion of a baccalaureate or graduate degree; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-506(2)(a)(iii): verify the completion of prerequisite courses established by division rules;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-506(2)(b): documentation of the applicant's completion of a substance use disorder education program that includes:

Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-506(2)(c): (2)(b) documentation of the applicant's completion of at least 4,000 hours of supervised experience in substance use disorder treatment, of which 2,000 hours may have been obtained while qualifying for a substance use disorder counselor license, that:

Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-507 Qualifications for admission to examination.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
All applicants for admission to any examination qualifying an individual for licensure under this part shall:Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-507(1): submit an application on a form provided by the division; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-507(2): pay the fee established for the examination.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-508 Substance use disorder counselor supervisor's qualifications -- Functions.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-508(1): 58-60-102(7) A mental health therapist supervisor of a substance use disorder counselor shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-508(1)(a): be qualified by education or experience to treat substance use disorders;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-508(1)(b): be currently working in the substance use disorder treatment field;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-508(1)(c): review substance use disorder counselor assessment procedures and recommendations;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-508(1)(d): 58-60-102(7) provide substance use disorder diagnosis and other mental health diagnoses in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-508(1)(e): supervise the development of a treatment plan;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-508(1)(f): approve the treatment plan; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-508(1)(g): provide direct supervision for not more than six persons, unless granted an exception in writing from the board and the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-508(2): A licensed advanced substance use disorder counselor may act as the supervisor of a certified substance use disorder counselor, certified substance use disorder counselor intern, certified advanced substance use disorder counselor, or certified advanced substance use disorder counselor intern if the licensed advanced substance use disorder counselor:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-508(2)(a): has at least two years of experience as a licensed advanced substance use disorder counselor;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-508(2)(b): is currently working in the substance use disorder field; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-508(2)(c): provides direct supervision for no more than six individuals, unless granted an exception in writing from the board and the division.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-509 Confidentiality -- Exemptions.
--------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-509(1): A licensee under this part may not disclose any confidential communication with a client or patient without the express consent of:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-509(1)(a): the client or patient;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-509(1)(b): the parent or legal guardian of a minor client or patient; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-509(1)(c): the authorized agent of a client or patient.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-509(2): (1); Title 26B, Chapter 6, Part 2, Abuse, Neglect, or Exploitation of a Vulnerable Adult; Title 80, Chapter 2, Part 6, Child Abuse and Neglect Reports; Title 78B, Chapter 3, Part 5, Limitation of Therapist's Duty to Warn; 26B-7-206 A licensee under this part is not subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-509(2)(a): Title 26B, Chapter 6, Part 2, Abuse, Neglect, or Exploitation of a Vulnerable Adult; Title 80, Chapter 2, Part 6, Child Abuse and Neglect Reports; Title 78B, Chapter 3, Part 5, Limitation of Therapist's Duty to Warn; 26B-7-206 the licensee is permitted or required by state or federal law, rule, regulation, or order to report or disclose any confidential communication, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-509(2)(a)(i): Title 26B, Chapter 6, Part 2, Abuse, Neglect, or Exploitation of a Vulnerable Adult reporting under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-509(2)(a)(ii): Title 80, Chapter 2, Part 6, Child Abuse and Neglect Reports reporting under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-509(2)(a)(iii): Title 78B, Chapter 3, Part 5, Limitation of Therapist's Duty to Warn reporting under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-509(2)(a)(iv): 26B-7-206 reporting of a communicable disease as required under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-509(2)(b): the disclosure is part of an administrative, civil, or criminal proceeding and is made under an exemption from evidentiary privilege under Rule 506, Utah Rules of Evidence; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-509(2)(c): the disclosure is made under a generally recognized professional or ethical standard that authorizes or requires the disclosure.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-510 Evidentiary privilege.
------------------------------------------------------
Evidentiary privilege for a licensee under this part concerning admissibility of any confidential communication in administrative, civil, or criminal proceedings is in accordance with Rule 506, Utah Rules of Evidence.

Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-511 Experience requirement -- Transition of licensing and experience.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-511(1): 58-60-506(2)(a) Except as otherwise approved in writing by the board and the division, an individual currently licensed as a substance abuse counselor may transition to the substance use disorder counselor license as follows:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-511(1)(a): an individual who documents practice as a substance abuse counselor for six years or longer, by July 1, 2013, may apply for an advanced substance use disorder license;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-511(1)(b): 58-60-506(2)(a) if an individual who has practiced as a substance abuse counselor for less than six years of experience meets the education requirements under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-511(1)(c): the division shall convert the license of an individual who has practiced for less than six years, and who is licensed as a substance abuse counselor, to a substance use disorder counselor license; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-511(1)(d): the division shall convert the license of an individual who is a certified substance abuse counselor, or a certified substance abuse counselor intern, to a certified substance use disorder counselor.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60-511(2): An applicant working toward licensure under division rules in effect before July 1, 2012, who is enrolled in an approved education program, and has completed at least 100 hours of addiction-specific training before July 1, 2012, may be licensed in accordance with division rules.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 58 - Chapter 60a - Counseling Compact
*****************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 58-60a-101 Section 1 -- Purpose.
------------------------------------------------------
The purpose of this Compact is to facilitate interstate practice of Licensed Professional Counselors with the goal of improving public access to Professional Counseling services. The practice of Professional Counseling occurs in the State where the client is located at the time of the counseling services. The Compact preserves the regulatory authority of States to protect public health and safety through the current system of State licensure.

Utah Code Annotated § 58-60a-102 Section 2 -- Definitions.
----------------------------------------------------------
As used in this Compact, and except as otherwise provided, the following definitions shall apply:

Utah Code Annotated § 58-60a-103 Section 3 -- State participation in the Compact.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A. To Participate in the Compact, a State must currently:

Utah Code Annotated § 58-60a-104 Section 4 -- Privilege to Practice.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
A. To exercise the Privilege to Practice under the terms and provisions of the Compact, the Licensee shall:

Utah Code Annotated § 58-60a-105 Section 5 -- Obtaining a new Home State license based on a Privilege to Practice.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A. A Licensed Professional Counselor may hold a Home State license, which allows for a Privilege to Practice in other Member States, in only one Member State at a time.

Utah Code Annotated § 58-60a-106 Section 6 -- Active Duty Military personnel or their spouses.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Active Duty Military personnel, or their spouses, shall designate a Home State where the individual has a current license in good standing. The individual may retain the Home State designation during the period the service member is on active duty. Subsequent to designating a Home State, the individual shall only change their Home State through application for licensure in the new State, or through the process outlined in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 58-60a-107 Section 7 -- Compact Privilege to Practice Telehealth.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A. Member States shall recognize the right of a Licensed Professional Counselor, licensed by a Home State in accordance with Section

Utah Code Annotated § 58-60a-108 Section 8 -- Adverse actions.
--------------------------------------------------------------
A. In addition to the other powers conferred by State law, a Remote State shall have the authority, in accordance with existing State due process law, to:

Utah Code Annotated § 58-60a-109 Section 9 -- Establishment of Counseling Compact Commission.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A. The Compact Member States hereby create and establish a joint public agency known as the Counseling Compact Commission:

Utah Code Annotated § 58-60a-110 Section 10 -- Data System.
-----------------------------------------------------------
A. The Commission shall provide for the development, maintenance, operation, and utilization of a coordinated database and reporting system containing licensure, Adverse Action, and Investigative Information on all licensed individuals in Member States.

Utah Code Annotated § 58-60a-111 Section 11 -- Rulemaking.
----------------------------------------------------------
A. The Commission shall promulgate reasonable Rules in order to effectively and efficiently achieve the purpose of the Compact. Notwithstanding the foregoing, in the event the Commission exercises its Rulemaking authority in a manner that is beyond the scope of the purposes of the Compact, or the powers granted hereunder, then such an action by the Commission shall be invalid and have no force or effect.

Utah Code Annotated § 58-60a-112 Section 12 -- Oversight, dispute resolution, and enforcement.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A. Oversight

Utah Code Annotated § 58-60a-113 Section 13 -- Date of implementation of the Counseling Compact Commission and associated Rules, withdrawal, and amendment.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A. The Compact shall come into effect on the date on which the Compact statute is enacted into law in the tenth Member State. The provisions, which become effective at that time, shall be limited to the powers granted to the Commission relating to assembly and the promulgation of Rules. Thereafter, the Commission shall meet and exercise Rulemaking powers necessary to the implementation and administration of the Compact.

Utah Code Annotated § 58-60a-114 Section 14 -- Construction and severability.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
This Compact shall be liberally construed so as to effectuate the purposes thereof. The provisions of this Compact shall be severable and if any phrase, clause, sentence or provision of this Compact is declared to be contrary to the constitution of any Member State or of the United States or the applicability thereof to any government, agency, person or circumstance is held invalid, the validity of the remainder of this Compact and the applicability thereof to any government, agency, person or circumstance shall not be affected thereby. If this Compact shall be held contrary to the constitution of any Member State, the Compact shall remain in full force and effect as to the remaining Member States and in full force and effect as to the Member State affected as to all severable matters.

Utah Code Annotated § 58-60a-115 Section 15 -- Binding Effect of Compact and other Laws.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A. A Licensee providing Professional Counseling services in a Remote State under the Privilege to Practice shall adhere to the laws and regulations, including scope of practice, of the Remote State.

Utah Code Annotated § 58-60a-201 Rulemaking authority -- State authority over scope of practice.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60a-201(1): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act The division may make rules in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 58-60a-201(2): 58-60a-101; 58-60a-115; 58-60a-101; 58-60a-115 Notwithstanding any provision in Sections


Utah Code Annotated - Title 58 - Chapter 61 - Psychologist Licensing Act
************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-101 Title.
--------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Psychologist Licensing Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-102 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
In addition to the definitions in SectionUtah Code Annotated § 58-61-102(1): 58-61-201 "Board" means the Psychologist Licensing Board created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-102(2): "Client" or "patient" means an individual who consults or is examined or interviewed by a psychologist acting in his professional capacity.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-102(3): "Confidential communication" means information, including information obtained by the psychologist's examination of the client or patient, which is:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-102(3)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-102(3)(a)(i): transmitted between the client or patient and a psychologist in the course of that relationship; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-102(3)(a)(ii): transmitted among the client or patient, the psychologist, and individuals who are participating in the diagnosis or treatment under the direction of the psychologist, including members of the client's or patient's family; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-102(3)(b): made in confidence, for the diagnosis or treatment of the client or patient by the psychologist, and by a means not intended to be disclosed to third persons other than those individuals:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-102(3)(b)(i): present to further the interest of the client or patient in the consultation, examination, or interview;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-102(3)(b)(ii): reasonably necessary for the transmission of the communications; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-102(3)(b)(iii): participating in the diagnosis and treatment of the client or patient under the direction of the psychologist.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-102(4): "Hypnosis" means, regarding individuals exempted from licensure under this chapter, a process by which one individual induces or assists another individual into a hypnotic state without the use of drugs or other substances and for the purpose of increasing motivation or to assist the individual to alter lifestyles or habits.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-102(5): "Individual" means a natural person.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-102(6): "Mental health therapist" means an individual licensed under this title as a:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-102(6)(a): physician and surgeon, or osteopathic physician engaged in the practice of mental health therapy;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-102(6)(b): an advanced practice registered nurse, specializing in psychiatric mental health nursing;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-102(6)(c): an advanced practice registered nurse intern, specializing in psychiatric mental health nursing;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-102(6)(d): psychologist qualified to engage in the practice of mental health therapy;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-102(6)(e): a certified psychology resident qualifying to engage in the practice of mental health therapy;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-102(6)(f): clinical social worker;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-102(6)(g): certified social worker;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-102(6)(h): marriage and family therapist;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-102(6)(i): an associate marriage and family therapist;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-102(6)(j): a clinical mental health counselor; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-102(6)(k): an associate clinical mental health counselor.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-102(7): (6) "Mental illness" means a mental or emotional condition defined in an approved diagnostic and statistical manual for mental disorders generally recognized in the professions of mental health therapy listed under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-102(8): (6); (6) "Practice of mental health therapy" means the treatment or prevention of mental illness, whether in person or remotely, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-102(8)(a): conducting a professional evaluation of an individual's condition of mental health, mental illness, or emotional disorder;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-102(8)(b): (6) establishing a diagnosis in accordance with established written standards generally recognized in the professions of mental health therapy listed under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-102(8)(c): prescribing a plan for the prevention or treatment of a condition of mental illness or emotional disorder; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-102(8)(d): (6) engaging in the conduct of professional intervention, including psychotherapy by the application of established methods and procedures generally recognized in the professions of mental health therapy listed under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-102(9): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-102(9)(a): "Practice of psychology" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-102(9)(a)(i): the practice of mental health therapy by means of observation, description, evaluation, interpretation, intervention, and treatment to effect modification of human behavior by the application of generally recognized professional psychological principles, methods, and procedures for the purpose of preventing, treating, or eliminating mental or emotional illness or dysfunction, the symptoms of any of these, or maladaptive behavior;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-102(9)(a)(ii): the observation, description, evaluation, interpretation, or modification of human behavior by the application of generally recognized professional principles, methods, or procedures requiring the education, training, and clinical experience of a psychologist, for the purpose of assessing, diagnosing, preventing, or eliminating symptomatic, maladaptive, or undesired behavior and of enhancing interpersonal relationships, work and life adjustment, personal effectiveness, behavioral health, and mental health;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-102(9)(a)(iii): psychological testing and the evaluation or assessment of personal characteristics such as intelligence, personality, abilities, interests, aptitudes, and neuropsychological functioning;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-102(9)(a)(iv): counseling, marriage and family therapy, psychoanalysis, psychotherapy, hypnosis, and behavior analysis and therapy;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-102(9)(a)(v): diagnosis and treatment of mental and emotional disorders of disability, alcoholism and substance abuse, disorders of habit or conduct, and the psychological aspects of physical illness, accident, injury, or disability; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-102(9)(a)(vi): psychoeducational evaluation, therapy, remediation, and consultation.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-102(9)(b): An individual practicing psychology may provide services to individuals, couples, families, groups of individuals, members of the public, and individuals or groups within organizations or institutions.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-102(10): "Remotely" means communicating via Internet, telephone, or other electronic means that facilitate real-time audio or visual interaction between individuals when they are not physically present in the same room at the same time.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-102(11): 58-1-501; 58-61-501 "Unlawful conduct" is as defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-102(12): 58-1-501; 58-61-502 "Unprofessional conduct" is as defined in Sections


Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-201 Board.
--------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-201(1): Part 7, Behavior Analyst Licensing Act
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-201(1)(a): There is created the Psychologist Licensing Board consisting of four licensed psychologists, one licensed behavior analyst, and one member from the general public.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-201(1)(b): Part 7, Behavior Analyst Licensing Act The licensed behavior analyst shall participate as a member of the board only for issues relevant to
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-201(2): 58-1-201 The board shall be appointed, serve terms, and be compensated in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-201(3): 58-1-202; 58-1-203 The duties and responsibilities of the board are in accordance with Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-201(3)(a): designate one of its members on a permanent or rotating basis to assist the division in review of complaints concerning unlawful or unprofessional practice by a licensee in the profession regulated by the board and to advise the division regarding the conduct of investigations of the complaints; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-201(3)(b): disqualify a member from acting as presiding officer in an administrative procedure in which that member has previously reviewed the complaint or advised the division.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-301 Licensure required.
---------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-301(1): 58-1-307; 58-1-307(1)(c)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-301(1)(a): 58-1-307 A license is required to engage in the practice of psychology, except as specifically provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-301(1)(b): 58-1-307(1)(c) Notwithstanding the provisions of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-301(2): The division shall issue to a person who qualifies under this chapter a license in the classification of:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-301(2)(a): psychologist; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-301(2)(b): certified psychology resident.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-302 Term of license.
------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-302(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-302(1)(a): The division shall issue each license under this chapter in accordance with a two-year renewal cycle established by division rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-302(1)(b): The division may by rule extend or shorten a renewal cycle by as much as one year to stagger the renewal cycles it administers.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-302(2): At the time of renewal the licensee shall show satisfactory evidence of renewal requirements as required under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-302(3): 58-1-308 Each license expires on the expiration date shown on the license unless renewed by the licensee in accordance with Section


Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-304 Qualifications for licensure by examination or endorsement.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-304(1): 63J-1-504; 58-1-203; 58-1-203; (1)(d); 58-1-203; 58-61-304.1; Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act An applicant for licensure as a psychologist based upon education, clinical training, and examination shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-304(1)(a): submit an application on a form provided by the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-304(1)(b): 63J-1-504 pay a fee determined by the department under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-304(1)(c): 58-1-203 produce certified transcripts of credit verifying satisfactory completion of a doctoral degree in psychology that includes specific core course work established by division rule under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-304(1)(d): 58-1-203 have completed a minimum of 4,000 hours of psychology training as defined by division rule under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-304(1)(e): (1)(d) to be qualified to engage in mental health therapy, document successful completion of not less than 1,000 hours of supervised training in mental health therapy obtained after completion of a master's level of education in psychology, which training may be included as part of the 4,000 hours of training required in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-304(1)(f): 58-1-203 pass the examination requirement established by division rule under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-304(1)(g): 58-61-304.1; Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act consent to a criminal background check in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-304(1)(h): meet with the board, upon request for good cause, for the purpose of evaluating the applicant's qualifications for licensure.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-304(2): 63J-1-504; 58-61-304.1; Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act An applicant for licensure as a psychologist by endorsement based upon licensure in another jurisdiction shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-304(2)(a): submit an application on a form provided by the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-304(2)(b): 63J-1-504 pay a fee determined by the department under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-304(2)(c): not have any disciplinary action pending or in effect against the applicant's psychologist license in any jurisdiction;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-304(2)(d): have passed the Utah Psychologist Law and Ethics Examination established by division rule;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-304(2)(e): provide satisfactory evidence the applicant is currently licensed in another state, district, or territory of the United States, or in any other jurisdiction approved by the division in collaboration with the board;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-304(2)(f): provide satisfactory evidence the applicant has actively practiced psychology in that jurisdiction for not less than 2,000 hours or one year, whichever is greater;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-304(2)(g): provide satisfactory evidence that:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-304(2)(g)(i): the education, supervised experience, examination, and all other requirements for licensure in that jurisdiction at the time the applicant obtained licensure were substantially equivalent to the licensure requirements for a psychologist in Utah at the time the applicant obtained licensure in the other jurisdiction; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-304(2)(g)(ii): the applicant is:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-304(2)(g)(ii)(A): a current holder of Board Certified Specialist status in good standing from the American Board of Professional Psychology;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-304(2)(g)(ii)(B): currently credentialed as a health service provider in psychology by the National Register of Health Service Providers in Psychology; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-304(2)(g)(ii)(C): currently holds a Certificate of Professional Qualification (CPQ) granted by the Association of State and Provincial Psychology Boards;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-304(2)(h): 58-61-304.1; Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act consent to a criminal background check in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-304(2)(i): meet with the board, upon request for good cause, for the purpose of evaluating the applicant's qualifications for licensure.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-304(3): (1)(a); (b); (c); (g); (h); (1)(d); (e); (3)(b)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-304(3)(a): (1)(a); (b); (c); (g); (h) An applicant for certification as a psychology resident shall comply with the provisions of Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-304(3)(b): (1)(d); (e); (3)(b)(i)
