Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-304(3)(b)(ii): (3)(b)(i) The period of time under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-304.1 Criminal background check.
------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-304.1(1): An applicant for licensure under this chapter who requires a criminal background check shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-304.1(1)(a): submit fingerprint cards in a form acceptable to the division at the time the license application is filed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-304.1(1)(b): consent to a fingerprint background check conducted by the Bureau of Criminal Identification and the Federal Bureau of Investigation regarding the application.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-304.1(2): 53-10-108; (2)(a); 53-10-108 The division shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-304.1(2)(a): 53-10-108 in addition to other fees authorized by this chapter, collect from each applicant submitting fingerprints in accordance with this section the fee that the Bureau of Criminal Identification is authorized to collect for the services provided under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-304.1(2)(b): (2)(a) submit from each applicant the fingerprint card and the fees described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-304.1(2)(c): 53-10-108 obtain and retain in division records a signed waiver approved by the Bureau of Criminal Identification in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-304.1(3): 53-10-108; (2)(b) The Bureau of Criminal Identification shall, in accordance with the requirements of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-304.1(3)(a): (2)(b) check the fingerprints submitted under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-304.1(3)(b): forward the fingerprints to the Federal Bureau of Investigation for a national criminal history background check; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-304.1(3)(c): provide the results from the state, regional, and nationwide criminal history background checks to the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-304.1(4): The division may not disseminate outside of the division any criminal history record information that the division obtains from the Bureau of Criminal Identification or the Federal Bureau of Investigation under the criminal background check requirements of this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-305 Qualifications for admission to examination.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
All applicants for admission to any examination qualifying an individual for licensure under this chapter shall:Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-305(1): submit an application on a form provided by the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-305(2): pay the fee established for the examination; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-305(3): certify under penalty of perjury as evidenced by notarized signature on the application for admission to the examination that the applicant:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-305(3)(a): has completed the education requirement under this chapter and been awarded the earned degree required for licensure; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-305(3)(b): has successfully completed the supervised training required under this chapter for licensure.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-306 Continuing education.
-----------------------------------------------------
By rule made under Section

Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-307 Exemptions from licensure.
----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-307(1): 58-61-301; 58-1-307 Except as modified in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-307(2): 58-1-307; Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act; Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act; Chapter 31b, Nurse Practice Act; 58-60-102(5); 58-1-307(1)(b); 53E-6-201 In addition to the exemptions from licensure in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-307(2)(a): Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act; Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act a physician and surgeon or osteopathic physician licensed under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-307(2)(b): Chapter 31b, Nurse Practice Act a registered psychiatric mental health nurse specialist licensed under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-307(2)(c): a recognized member of the clergy while functioning in his ministerial capacity as long as he does not represent himself as or use the title of psychologist;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-307(2)(d): an individual who is offering expert testimony in any proceeding before a court, administrative hearing, deposition upon the order of any court or other body having power to order the deposition, or proceedings before any master, referee, or alternative dispute resolution provider;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-307(2)(e): 58-60-102(5) an individual engaged in performing hypnosis who is not licensed under this title in a profession which includes hypnosis in its scope of practice, and who:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-307(2)(e)(i): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-307(2)(e)(i)(A): induces a hypnotic state in a client for the purpose of increasing motivation or altering lifestyles or habits, such as eating or smoking, through hypnosis;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-307(2)(e)(i)(B): consults with a client to determine current motivation and behavior patterns;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-307(2)(e)(i)(C): prepares the client to enter hypnotic states by explaining how hypnosis works and what the client will experience;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-307(2)(e)(i)(D): tests clients to determine degrees of suggestibility;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-307(2)(e)(i)(E): applies hypnotic techniques based on interpretation of consultation results and analysis of client's motivation and behavior patterns; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-307(2)(e)(i)(F): trains clients in self-hypnosis conditioning;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-307(2)(e)(ii): 58-60-102(5) may not:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-307(2)(e)(ii)(A): engage in the practice of mental health therapy;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-307(2)(e)(ii)(B): 58-60-102(5) represent himself using the title of a license classification in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-307(2)(e)(ii)(C): use hypnosis with or treat a medical, psychological, or dental condition defined in generally recognized diagnostic and statistical manuals of medical, psychological, or dental disorders;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-307(2)(f): 58-1-307(1)(b) an individual's exemption from licensure under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-307(2)(g): an individual holding an earned doctoral degree in psychology who is employed by an accredited institution of higher education and who conducts research and teaches in that individual's professional field, but only if the individual does not engage in providing delivery or supervision of professional services regulated under this chapter to individuals or groups regardless of whether there is compensation for the services;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-307(2)(h): any individual who was employed as a psychologist by a state, county, or municipal agency or other political subdivision of the state prior to July 1, 1981, and who subsequently has maintained employment as a psychologist in the same state, county, or municipal agency or other political subdivision while engaged in the performance of his official duties for that agency or political subdivision;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-307(2)(i): 53E-6-201 an individual licensed as a school psychologist under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-307(2)(i)(i): may represent himself as and use the terms "school psychologist" or "licensed school psychologist"; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-307(2)(i)(ii): is restricted in his practice to employment within settings authorized by the State Board of Education;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-307(2)(j): an individual providing advice or counsel to another individual in a setting of their association as friends or relatives and in a nonprofessional and noncommercial relationship, if there is no compensation paid for the advice or counsel; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-307(2)(k): an individual who is licensed, in good standing, to practice mental health therapy in a state or territory of the United States outside of Utah may provide short term transitional mental health therapy remotely to a client in Utah only if:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-307(2)(k)(i): the individual is present in the state or territory where the individual is licensed to practice mental health therapy;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-307(2)(k)(ii): the client relocates to Utah;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-307(2)(k)(iii): the client is a client of the individual immediately before the client relocates to Utah;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-307(2)(k)(iv): the individual provides the short term transitional mental health therapy to the client only during the 45 day period beginning on the day on which the client relocates to Utah;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-307(2)(k)(v): within 10 days after the day on which the client relocates to Utah, the individual provides written notice to the division of the individual's intent to provide short term transitional mental health therapy remotely to the client; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-307(2)(k)(vi): the individual does not engage in unlawful conduct or unprofessional conduct.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-308 Scope of practice -- Limitations.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-308(1): A psychologist may engage in all acts and practices defined as the practice of psychology without supervision, in private and independent practice, or as an employee of another person, limited only by the licensee's education, training, and competence.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-308(2): An individual certified as a psychology resident may engage in all acts and practices defined as the practice of psychology only under conditions of employment as a psychology resident and under the supervision of a licensed psychologist who is an approved psychology training supervisor as defined by division rule.  A certified psychology resident shall not engage in the independent practice of psychology.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-401 Grounds for action regarding license -- Disciplinary proceedings.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-401(1): (2); 58-1-401 Subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-401(2): The division may not refuse, revoke, suspend, or in any way restrict an applicant or licensee's license under this chapter solely because the applicant or licensee seeks or participates in mental health or substance abuse treatment.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-501 Unlawful conduct.
-------------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter, "unlawful conduct" includes:Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-501(1): practice of psychology unless licensed as a psychologist or certified psychology resident under this chapter or exempted from licensure under this title;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-501(2): 58-61-304(1)(e) practice of mental health therapy by a licensed psychologist who has not acceptably documented to the division his completion of the supervised training in psychotherapy required under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-501(3): representing oneself as or using the title of psychologist, or certified psychology resident unless currently licensed under this chapter.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-502 Unprofessional conduct.
-------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-502(1): 58-61-602 As used in this chapter, "unprofessional conduct" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-502(1)(a): using or employing the services of any individual to assist a licensee in any manner not in accordance with the generally recognized practices, standards, or ethics of the profession for which the individual is licensed, or the laws of the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-502(1)(b): failure to confine practice conduct to those acts or practices:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-502(1)(b)(i): in which the individual is competent by education, training, and experience within limits of education, training, and experience; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-502(1)(b)(ii): which are within applicable scope of practice laws of this chapter; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-502(1)(c): 58-61-602 disclosing or refusing to disclose any confidential communication under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-502(2): "Unprofessional conduct" under this chapter may be further defined by division rule.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-503 Penalty for unlawful conduct.
-------------------------------------------------------------
An individual who commits any act of unlawful conduct as defined in:Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-503(1): 58-61-501(1); (2) Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-503(2): 58-61-501(3) Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-504 Reporting of unprofessional or unlawful conduct -- Immunity from liability.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-504(1): 58-61-102 Upon learning of an act of unlawful or unprofessional conduct as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-504(1)(a): a licensed health care facility or organization in which an individual licensed under this chapter engages in practice;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-504(1)(b): an individual licensed under this chapter; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-504(1)(c): a professional society or organization whose membership is comprised of individuals licensed under this chapter and which has the authority to discipline or expel a member for acts of unprofessional or unlawful conduct.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-504(2): Any individual reporting acts of unprofessional or unlawful conduct by an individual licensed under this chapter is immune from liability arising out of the disclosure to the extent the individual furnishes the information in good faith and without malice.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-601 Evidentiary privilege.
------------------------------------------------------
Evidentiary privilege for psychologists regarding admissibility of any confidential communication in administrative, civil, or criminal proceedings is in accordance with Rule 506 of the Utah Rules of Evidence.

Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-602 Confidentiality -- Exemptions.
--------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-602(1): Title 63G, Chapter 2, Government Records Access and Management Act Notwithstanding
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-602(1)(a): the client or patient;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-602(1)(b): the parent or legal guardian of a minor client or patient; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-602(1)(c): a person authorized to consent to the disclosure of the confidential communication by the client or patient in a written document:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-602(1)(c)(i): that is signed by the client or the patient; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-602(1)(c)(ii): in which the client's or the patient's signature is reasonably verifiable.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-602(2): (1); Title 80, Chapter 2, Part 6, Child Abuse and Neglect Reports; Title 80, Chapter 2, Part 6, Child Abuse and Neglect Reports; Title 78B, Chapter 3, Part 5, Limitation of Therapist's Duty to Warn; 26B-7-206 A psychologist under this chapter is not subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-602(2)(a): Title 80, Chapter 2, Part 6, Child Abuse and Neglect Reports; Title 80, Chapter 2, Part 6, Child Abuse and Neglect Reports; Title 78B, Chapter 3, Part 5, Limitation of Therapist's Duty to Warn; 26B-7-206 the psychologist is permitted or required by state or federal law, rule, regulation, or order to report or disclose any confidential communication, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-602(2)(a)(i): Title 80, Chapter 2, Part 6, Child Abuse and Neglect Reports reporting under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-602(2)(a)(ii): Title 80, Chapter 2, Part 6, Child Abuse and Neglect Reports reporting under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-602(2)(a)(iii): Title 78B, Chapter 3, Part 5, Limitation of Therapist's Duty to Warn reporting under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-602(2)(a)(iv): 26B-7-206 reporting of a communicable disease as required under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-602(2)(b): the disclosure is part of an administrative, civil, or criminal proceeding and is made under an exemption from evidentiary privilege under Rule 506, Utah Rules of Evidence; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-602(2)(c): the disclosure is made under a generally recognized professional or ethical standard that authorizes or requires the disclosure.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-701 Title.
--------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Behavior Analyst Licensing Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-702 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
In addition to the definitions in SectionUtah Code Annotated § 58-61-702(1): "Confidential communication" means information obtained by an individual licensed or registered under this part, including information obtained by the individual's observation of or interview with the client, patient, or authorized agent, which is:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-702(1)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-702(1)(a)(i): transmitted between the client, patient, or authorized agent and an individual licensed or registered under this part in the course of that relationship; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-702(1)(a)(ii): transmitted among the client, patient, or authorized agent, an individual licensed or registered under this part, and individuals who are participating in the assessment or treatment in conjunction with an individual licensed or registered under this part, including the authorized agent or members of the client's or patient's family; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-702(1)(b): made in confidence, for the assessment or treatment of the client or patient by the individual who is licensed or registered under this part, and by a means not intended to be disclosed to a third party other than an individual:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-702(1)(b)(i): present to further the interest of the client or patient in the consultation, assessment or interview;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-702(1)(b)(ii): reasonably necessary for the transmission of the communications; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-702(1)(b)(iii): participating in the assessment and treatment of the client or patient in conjunction with the behavior analyst or behavior specialist.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-702(2): "Licensed assistant behavior analyst" means an individual licensed under this part to engage in the practice of behavior analysis under the supervision of a qualified supervisor, as defined by the division by administrative rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-702(3): "Licensed behavior analyst" means an individual licensed under this part to engage in the practice of behavior analysis.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-702(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-702(4)(a): "Practice of behavior analysis" means the design and evaluation of instructional and environmental modifications to produce socially significant improvements in human behavior and includes the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-702(4)(a)(i): the empirical identification of functional relations between behavior and environmental factors, known as functional assessment and analysis;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-702(4)(a)(ii): interventions based on scientific research and the direct observation and measurement of behavior and environment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-702(4)(a)(iii): utilization of contextual factors, motivating operations, antecedent stimuli, positive reinforcement, and other consequences to help people develop new behaviors, increase or decrease existing behaviors, and emit behaviors under specific environmental conditions.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-702(4)(b): "Practice of behavior analysis" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-702(4)(b)(i): diagnosis of a mental or physical disorder;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-702(4)(b)(ii): psychological testing;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-702(4)(b)(iii): educational testing;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-702(4)(b)(iv): neuropsychology;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-702(4)(b)(v): neuropsychological testing;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-702(4)(b)(vi): mental health therapy;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-702(4)(b)(vii): psychotherapy;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-702(4)(b)(viii): counseling;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-702(4)(b)(ix): biofeedback;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-702(4)(b)(x): neurofeedback;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-702(4)(b)(xi): cognitive therapy;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-702(4)(b)(xii): sex therapy;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-702(4)(b)(xiii): psychoanalysis; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-702(4)(b)(xiv): hypnotherapy.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-702(5): (5)(a)(i) "Registered assistant behavior specialist" means an individual who:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-702(5)(a): is employed:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-702(5)(a)(i): as a professional engaging in the practice of behavior analysis within an organization contracted under a division of the Utah Department of Human Services;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-702(5)(a)(ii): to provide behavior analysis; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-702(5)(a)(iii): on or before May 15, 2015;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-702(5)(b): (5)(a)(i) limits the practice of behavior analysis to the contract described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-702(5)(c): is registered under this part with the division to engage in the practice of behavior analysis under the supervision of a qualified supervisor, as defined by the division by administrative rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-702(6): (6)(a)(i) "Registered behavior specialist" means an individual who:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-702(6)(a): is employed:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-702(6)(a)(i): as a professional engaging in the practice of behavior analysis within an organization contracted under a division of the Utah Department of Human Services to provide behavior analysis; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-702(6)(a)(ii): on or before May 15, 2015;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-702(6)(b): (6)(a)(i) limits the practice of behavior analysis to the contract described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-702(6)(c): is registered under this part with the division to engage in the practice of behavior analysis.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-703 License or registration required.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-703(1): 58-1-307 A license or registration is required to engage in the practice of behavior analysis, except as specifically provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-703(2): The division shall issue to a person who qualifies under this part a license in the classification of:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-703(2)(a): behavior analyst; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-703(2)(b): assistant behavior analyst.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-703(3): The division shall issue to a person who qualifies under this part a registration in the classification of:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-703(3)(a): behavior specialist; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-703(3)(b): assistant behavior specialist.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-703(4): An individual shall be licensed or registered under this part or exempted from licensure under this part in order to engage in, or represent that the individual is engaged in, the practice of behavior analysis.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-704 Term of license or registration.
----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-704(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-704(1)(a): The division shall issue each license under this part with a two-year renewal cycle established by division rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-704(1)(b): The division may by rule extend or shorten a renewal cycle by as much as one year to stagger the renewal cycles it administers.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-704(2): At the time of renewal, the licensed individual shall show satisfactory evidence of renewal requirements as required under this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-704(3): 58-1-308 Each license or registration expires on the expiration date shown on the license unless renewed by the licensed individual in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-704(4): 58-61-705(5)(d); (6)(d)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-704(4)(a): 58-61-705(5)(d); (6)(d) A registration as a registered behavior specialist or a registered assistant behavior specialist:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-704(4)(a)(i): 58-61-705(5)(d); (6)(d) expires on the day the individual is no longer employed in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-704(4)(a)(ii): may not be renewed.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-704(4)(b): The Department of Health and Human Services, or an organization contracted with a division of the Department of Health and Human Services, shall notify the Division of Professional Licensing when a person registered under this part is no longer employed as a registered behavior specialist or a registered assistant behavior specialist.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-705 Qualifications for licensure -- By examination -- By certification.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-705(1): 63J-1-504; 58-1-203 An applicant for licensure as a behavior analyst based upon education, supervised experience, and national examination shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-705(1)(a): submit an application on a form provided by the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-705(1)(b): 63J-1-504 pay a fee determined by the department under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-705(1)(c): produce certified transcripts of credit verifying satisfactory completion of a master's or doctoral degree in applied behavior analysis from an accredited institution of higher education or an equivalent master or doctorate degree as determined by the division by administrative rule;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-705(1)(d): as defined by the division by administrative rule, have completed at least 1,500 hours of experiential behavior analysis training within a five year period of time with a qualified supervisor; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-705(1)(e): 58-1-203 pass the examination requirement established by division rule under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-705(2): 63J-1-504 An applicant for licensure as a behavior analyst based upon certification shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-705(2)(a): without exception, on or before November 15, 2015, submit to the division an application on a form provided by the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-705(2)(b): 63J-1-504 pay a fee determined by the department under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-705(2)(c): provide official verification of current certification as a board certified behavior analyst from the Behavior Analyst Certification Board.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-705(3): 63J-1-504; 58-1-203; 58-1-203 An applicant for licensure as an assistant behavior analyst based upon education, supervised experience, and national examination shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-705(3)(a): submit an application on a form provided by the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-705(3)(b): 63J-1-504 pay a fee determined by the department under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-705(3)(c): 58-1-203 produce certified transcripts of credit verifying satisfactory completion of a bachelor's degree from an accredited institution of higher education and satisfactory completion of specific core course work in behavior analysis established under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-705(3)(d): as defined by the division by administrative rule, have completed at least 1,000 hours of experiential behavior analysis training within a five-year period of time with a qualified supervisor; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-705(3)(e): 58-1-203 pass the examination requirement established by division rule under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-705(4): 63J-1-504 An applicant for licensure as an assistant behavior analyst based upon certification shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-705(4)(a): without exception, on or before November 15, 2015, submit to the division an application on a form provided by the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-705(4)(b): 63J-1-504 pay a fee determined by the department under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-705(4)(c): provide official verification of current certification as a board certified assistant behavior analyst from the Behavior Analyst Certification Board.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-705(5): 63J-1-504 An applicant for registration as a behavior specialist based upon professional experience in behavior analysis shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-705(5)(a): without exception, on or before November 15, 2015, submit to the division, an application on a form provided by the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-705(5)(b): 63J-1-504 pay a fee determined by the department under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-705(5)(c): have at least five years of experience as a professional engaged in the practice of behavior analysis on or before May 15, 2015; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-705(5)(d): be employed as a professional engaging in the practice of behavior analysis within an organization contracted with a division of the Utah Department of Human Services to provide behavior analysis on or before July 1, 2015.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-705(6): 63J-1-504 An applicant for registration as an assistant behavior specialist based upon professional experience in behavior analysis shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-705(6)(a): without exception, on or before November 15, 2015, submit to the division, an application on a form provided by the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-705(6)(b): 63J-1-504 pay a fee determined by the department under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-705(6)(c): have at least one year of experience as a professional engaging in the practice of behavior analysis prior to July 1, 2015; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-705(6)(d): be employed as a professional engaging in the practice of behavior analysis within an organization contracted with a division of the Utah Department of Human Services to provide behavior analysis on or before July 1, 2015.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-706 Continuing education.
-----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-706(1): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act The division may establish administrative rules in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-706(2): 58-61-704 If a renewal cycle is extended or shortened under Section


Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-707 Exemptions from licensure.
----------------------------------------------------------
In addition to the exemptions from licensure in SectionUtah Code Annotated § 58-61-707(1): a psychologist licensed under this chapter, and those acting under the psychologist's authority and direction;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-707(2): a registered behavior specialist under this part;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-707(3): a registered assistant behavior specialist under this part;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-707(4): Chapter 60, Mental Health Professional Practice Act a mental health therapist licensed under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-707(5): a behavior analyst who practices with non-human or non-patient clients or consumers, including applied animal behaviorists;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-707(6): an individual who provides general behavior analysis services to an organization, if the practice of behavior analysis is for the benefit of the organization and does not involve the practice of behavior analysis on an individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-707(7): an individual who teaches behavior analysis or conducts behavior analysis research, provided that the individual does not practice behavior analysis on an individual as part of the teaching or research;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-707(8): an employee of a school district, private school, or charter school who:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-707(8)(a): practices behavior analysis as part of the employee's job description with the school district, private school, or charter school; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-707(8)(b): limits the employee's practice to the employment settings authorized by the:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-707(8)(b)(i): State Board of Education, if the employee is employed by a public school or charter school; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-707(8)(b)(ii): private school employer, if the employee is employed by a private school;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-707(9): a matriculated graduate student in:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-707(9)(a): a mental health field whose activities are part of a defined program of study or professional training; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-707(9)(b): education or applied behavior analysis whose activities are part of a defined program of study or professional training;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-707(10): 58-1-203 a person:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-707(10)(a): who is enrolled in a behavior analysis course sequence approved by the Behavior Analyst Certification Board at an accredited institution of higher education;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-707(10)(b): whose activities are part of a defined program of study or professional training; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-707(10)(c): 58-1-203 who is actively accruing supervision hours as defined by division rule under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-707(11): 58-1-203 a person who:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-707(11)(a): has completed and passed a course sequence approved by the Behavior Analyst Certification Board; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-707(11)(b): 58-1-203 is completing the supervision hours as defined by division rule under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-707(12): 58-1-203; (12)(d); (12)(b); (c) a person who:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-707(12)(a): has completed and passed the course sequence approved by the Behavior Analyst Certification Board;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-707(12)(b): 58-1-203 has completed the supervision hours as defined by division rule under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-707(12)(c): continues working under the supervision of a behavior analyst; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-707(12)(d): (12)(d); (12)(b); (c) is preparing to take the licensing examination or awaiting results of the licensing examination, provided the exemption under this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-707(13): until November 15, 2015, a person who:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-707(13)(a): has completed and passed the Board Certified Behavior Analyst or Board Certified Assistant Behavior Analyst Examination developed by the Behavior Analyst Certification Board; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-707(13)(b): is in the process of applying for a license under this part;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-707(14): an individual providing advice or counsel to another individual in a setting of the individual's association as friends or relatives and in a nonprofessional and noncommercial relationship, if there is no compensation paid for the advice or counsel; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-707(15): 58-1-307(1)(b) an individual exempt under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-708 License and registration denial and discipline.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The division's grounds for refusing to issue a license or registration to an applicant, for refusing to renew the license of a licensed individual or registration of a registered individual, for revoking, suspending, restricting, or placing on probation the license of a licensed individual or registration of a registered individual, for issuing a public or private reprimand to a licensed individual or registered individual, and for issuance of a cease and desist order are under Section

Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-709 Unlawful conduct.
-------------------------------------------------
As used in this part, "unlawful conduct" includes:Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-709(1): practice of behavior analysis unless licensed as a behavior analyst or assistant behavior analyst under this part, registered as a behavior specialist or assistant behavior specialist, or exempted from licensure or registration under this title; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-709(2): representing oneself as or using the title of licensed behavior analyst or licensed assistant behavior analyst unless currently licensed under this part.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-710 Unprofessional conduct.
-------------------------------------------------------
As used in this part, "unprofessional conduct" includes:Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-710(1): using or employing the services of any individual to assist a licensed behavior analyst, licensed assistant behavior analyst, registered behavior specialist, or registered assistant behavior specialist in any manner not in accordance with the generally recognized practices, standards, or ethics of the profession for which the individual is licensed or the laws of the state, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-710(1)(a): acting as a supervisor or accepting supervision of a supervisor without complying with or ensuring compliance with the requirements of administrative rule adopted by the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-710(1)(b): engaging in and aiding or abetting conduct or practices that are false, dishonest, deceptive, or fraudulent;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-710(1)(c): engaging in or aiding or abetting deceptive or fraudulent billing practices;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-710(1)(d): failing to establish and maintain appropriate professional boundaries with a client or former client;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-710(1)(e): engaging in or promising a personal, scientific, professional, financial, or other relationship with a client if it appears likely that such a relationship reasonably might impair the behavior analyst's or registered behavior specialist's objectivity or might harm or exploit the client;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-710(1)(f): engaging in sexual activities or sexual contact with a client with or without client consent;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-710(1)(g): engaging in sexual activities or sexual contact with a former client within two years of documented termination of services;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-710(1)(h): engaging in sexual activities or sexual contact at any time with a former client who is especially vulnerable or susceptible to being disadvantaged because of the client's personal history, current mental status, or any condition that could reasonably be expected to place the client at a disadvantage, recognizing the power imbalance that exists or may exist between the behavior analyst or registered behavior specialist and the client;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-710(1)(i): engaging in or aiding or abetting sexual harassment or any conduct that is exploitive or abusive with respect to a student, trainee, employee, or colleague with whom the licensee has supervisory or management responsibility;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-710(1)(j): exploiting a client for personal gain;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-710(1)(k): using a professional client relationship to exploit a client or other person for personal gain;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-710(1)(l): failing to maintain appropriate client records for a period of not less than seven years from the documented termination of services to the client;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-710(1)(m): failing to obtain informed consent from the client or legal guardian before taping, recording, or permitting third party observations of client care or records;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-710(1)(n): failing to cooperate with the division during an investigation;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-710(1)(o): using the abbreviated title of LBA unless licensed in the state as a behavior analyst;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-710(1)(p): using the abbreviated title of LaBA unless licensed in the state as an assistant behavior analyst;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-710(1)(q): failing to make reasonable efforts to notify a client and seek the transfer or referral of services, according to the client's needs or preferences, when a behavior analyst anticipates the interruption or termination of services to a client;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-710(1)(r): failing to provide for orderly and appropriate resolution of responsibility for client care in the event that the employment or contractual relationship ends, according to the client's needs and preferences;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-710(1)(s): failing to make reasonable steps to avoid abandoning a client who is still in need of services;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-710(1)(t): failing to report conviction of a felony or misdemeanor directly relating to the practice of behavior analysis or public health and safety;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-710(1)(u): failing to report revocation or suspension of certification from the Behavior Analyst Certification Board; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-710(1)(v): failure to confine practice conduct to those acts or practices in which the individual is competent by education, training, and experience within limits of education, training, and experience; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-710(2): other conduct as further defined by administrative rule adopted by the division.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-711 Penalty for unlawful conduct.
-------------------------------------------------------------
An individual who commits any act of unlawful conduct as defined in:Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-711(1): 58-61-501(1) Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-711(2): 58-61-501(2) Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-712 Reporting of unprofessional or unlawful conduct -- Immunity from liability.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-712(1): 58-61-102 Upon learning of an act of unlawful or unprofessional conduct as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-712(1)(a): a licensed health care facility or an organization in which an individual licensed or registered under this chapter engaged in practice;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-712(1)(b): an individual licensed or registered under this chapter; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-712(1)(c): a professional society or organization whose membership individuals licensed or registered under this chapter and that has the authority to discipline or expel a member for acts of unprofessional conduct or unlawful conduct.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-712(2): Any individual who reports acts of unprofessional or unlawful conduct by an individual licensed or registered under this chapter is immune from liability arising out of the disclosure to the extent the individual furnishes the information in good faith and without malice.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-713 Confidentiality -- Exemptions.
--------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-713(1): A behavior analyst or behavior specialist under this chapter may not disclose any confidential communication with a client or patient without the express written consent of:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-713(1)(a): the client or patient;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-713(1)(b): the parent or legal guardian of a minor client or patient; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-713(1)(c): a person authorized to consent to the disclosure of the confidential communication by the client or patient in a written document:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-713(1)(c)(i): that is signed by the client or the patient; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-713(1)(c)(ii): in which the client's or the patient's signature is reasonably verifiable.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-713(2): (1); Title 26B, Chapter 6, Part 2, Abuse, Neglect, or Exploitation of a Vulnerable Adult; Title 80, Chapter 2, Part 6, Child Abuse and Neglect Reports; Title 78B, Chapter 3, Part 5, Limitation of Therapist's Duty to Warn; 26B-7-206 A behavior analyst or behavior specialist is not subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-713(2)(a): Title 26B, Chapter 6, Part 2, Abuse, Neglect, or Exploitation of a Vulnerable Adult; Title 80, Chapter 2, Part 6, Child Abuse and Neglect Reports; Title 78B, Chapter 3, Part 5, Limitation of Therapist's Duty to Warn; 26B-7-206 the behavior analyst or behavior specialist is permitted or required by state or federal law, rule, regulation, or order to report or disclose any confidential communication, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-713(2)(a)(i): Title 26B, Chapter 6, Part 2, Abuse, Neglect, or Exploitation of a Vulnerable Adult reporting under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-713(2)(a)(ii): Title 80, Chapter 2, Part 6, Child Abuse and Neglect Reports reporting under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-713(2)(a)(iii): Title 78B, Chapter 3, Part 5, Limitation of Therapist's Duty to Warn reporting under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-713(2)(a)(iv): 26B-7-206 reporting of a communicable disease as required under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-713(2)(b): the disclosure is part of an administrative, civil, or criminal proceeding and is made under an exemption from evidentiary privilege under Utah Rules of Evidence, Rule 506; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-713(2)(c): the disclosure is made under a generally recognized professional or ethical standard that authorizes or requires the disclosure.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-714 Third party payment for licensed behavior analyst.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Notwithstanding the provisions of SectionUtah Code Annotated § 58-61-714(1): 58-61-702 a licensed behavior analyst as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-714(2): Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act; Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act; Chapter 31b, Nurse Practice Act; Chapter 60, Part 2, Social Worker Licensing Act; Chapter 60, Part 3, Marriage and Family Therapist Licensing Act; Chapter 60, Part 4, Clinical Mental Health Counselor Licensing Act the following, working within the scope of their practice:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-714(2)(a): Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act; Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act a physician licensed under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-714(2)(b): Chapter 31b, Nurse Practice Act an advanced practice registered nurse licensed under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-714(2)(c): a psychologist licensed under this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-714(2)(d): Chapter 60, Part 2, Social Worker Licensing Act a clinical social worker licensed under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-714(2)(e): Chapter 60, Part 3, Marriage and Family Therapist Licensing Act a marriage and family therapist licensed under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-61-714(2)(f): Chapter 60, Part 4, Clinical Mental Health Counselor Licensing Act a clinical mental health counselor licensed under

Utah Code Annotated - Title 58 - Chapter 63 - Security Personnel Licensing Act
******************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-101 Title.
--------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Security Personnel Licensing Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
In addition to the definitions in SectionUtah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(1): "Agreement for services" means a written and signed agreement between a security service provider and a client that:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(1)(a): contains clear language that addresses and assigns financial responsibility;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(1)(b): describes the length, duties, and scope of the security services that will be provided; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(1)(c): describes the compensation that will be paid by the client for the security services, including the compensation for each security officer.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(2): "Armed courier service" means a person engaged in business as a contract security company who transports or offers to transport tangible personal property from one place or point to another under the control of an armed security officer employed by that service.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(3): "Armed private security officer" means an individual:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(3)(a): employed by a contract security company;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(3)(b): whose primary duty is:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(3)(b)(i): guarding personal or real property; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(3)(b)(ii): providing protection or security to the life and well being of humans or animals; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(3)(c): who wears, carries, possesses, or has immediate access to a firearm in the performance of the individual's duties.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(4): 35A-1-102 "Armored car company" means a person engaged in business under contract to others who transports or offers to transport tangible personal property, currency, valuables, jewelry, SNAP benefits as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(5): 35A-1-102 "Armored car security officer" means an individual:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(5)(a): employed by an armored car company;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(5)(b): 35A-1-102 whose primary duty is to guard the tangible property, currency, valuables, jewelry, SNAP benefits as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(5)(c): who wears, carries, possesses, or has immediate access to a firearm in the performance of the individual's duties.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(6): 58-63-201 "Board" means the Security Services Licensing Board created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(7): "Client" means a person, company, or entity that contracts for and receives security services from a contract security company or an armored car company.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(8): "Contract security company" means a company that is engaged in business to provide security services to another person, business, or entity on a contractual basis by assignment of an armed or unarmed private security officer.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(9): 48-3a-102; 16-10a-830; 48-2e-102; 48-1d-102 "Company officer" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(9)(a): 48-3a-102 a governing person, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(9)(b): 16-10a-830 an individual appointed as an officer of an armored car company or contract security company that is a corporation in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(9)(c): 48-2e-102 a general partner, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(9)(d): 48-1d-102 a partner, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(10): 16-10a-102 "Company owner" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(10)(a): 16-10a-102 a shareholder, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(10)(a)(i): is a corporation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(10)(a)(ii): is not publicly listed or traded; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(10)(b): an individual who owns directly, or indirectly through an entity controlled by the individual, 5% or more of the equity of an armored car company or contract security company that is not a corporation.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(11): "Company proprietor" means the sole proprietor of an armored car company or contract security company that is registered as a sole proprietorship with the Division of Corporations and Commercial Code.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(12): "Company trustee" means an individual with control of or power of administration over property held in trust.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(13): "Financial responsibility," when referring to a contract security company, means that a contract security company may only provide security services to a client if the contract security company:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(13)(a): enters into an agreement for services with the client;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(13)(b): maintains a current general liability insurance policy with:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(13)(b)(i): at least an annual $1,000,000 per occurrence limit;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(13)(b)(ii): at least an annual $2,000,000 aggregate limit; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(13)(b)(iii): the following riders:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(13)(b)(iii)(A): general liability;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(13)(b)(iii)(B): assault and battery;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(13)(b)(iii)(C): personal injury;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(13)(b)(iii)(D): false arrest;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(13)(b)(iii)(E): libel and slander;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(13)(b)(iii)(F): invasion of privacy;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(13)(b)(iii)(G): broad form property damage;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(13)(b)(iii)(H): damage to property in the care, custody, or control of the security service provider; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(13)(b)(iii)(I): errors and omissions;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(13)(c): maintains a workers' compensation insurance policy with at least a $1,000,000 per occurrence limit and that covers each security officer employed by the contract security company; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(13)(d): maintains a federal employer identification number and an unemployment insurance employer account as required under state and federal law.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(14): "Identification card" means a personal pocket or wallet size card issued by the division to each armored car and armed or unarmed private security officer licensed under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(15): 53-1-102 "Law enforcement agency" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(16): Title 53, Chapter 13, Peace Officer Classifications "Peace officer" means a person who:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(16)(a): Title 53, Chapter 13, Peace Officer Classifications is a certified peace officer as defined in
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(16)(b): derives total or special law enforcement powers from, and is an employee of, the federal government, the state, or a political subdivision, agency, department, branch, or service of either, of a municipality, or a unit of local government.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(17): "Regular basis" means at least 20 hours per month.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(18): "Responsible management personnel" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(18)(a): a qualifying agent;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(18)(b): an operations manager; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(18)(c): a site manager.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(19): (19)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(19)(a): "Security officer" means an individual who is licensed as an armed or unarmed private security officer under this chapter and who:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(19)(a)(i): is employed by a contract security company securing, guarding, or otherwise protecting tangible personal property, real property, or the life and well being of human or animal life against:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(19)(a)(i)(A): trespass or other unlawful intrusion or entry;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(19)(a)(i)(B): larceny;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(19)(a)(i)(C): vandalism or other abuse;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(19)(a)(i)(D): arson or other criminal activity; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(19)(a)(i)(E): personal injury caused by another person or as a result of an act or omission by another person;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(19)(a)(ii): is controlling, regulating, or directing the flow of movements of an individual or vehicle; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(19)(a)(iii): providing street patrol service.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(19)(b): (19)(b) "Security officer" does not include an individual whose duties include taking admission tickets, checking credentials, ushering, or checking bags, purses, backpacks, or other materials of individuals who are entering a sports venue, concert venue, theatrical venue, convention center, fairgrounds, public assembly facility, or mass gathering location if:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(19)(b)(i): the individual carries out these duties without the use of specialized equipment;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(19)(b)(ii): the authority of the individual is limited to denying entry or passage of another individual into or within the facility; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(19)(b)(iii): (19)(b) the individual is not authorized to use physical force in the performance of the individual's duties under this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(20): "Security service provider" means a contract security company or an armored car company licensed under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(21): "Security system" means equipment, a device, or an instrument installed for:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(21)(a): detecting and signaling entry or intrusion by an individual into or onto, or exit from the premises protected by the system; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(21)(b): signaling the commission of criminal activity at the election of an individual having control of the features of the security system.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(22): "Specialized resource, motor vehicle, or equipment" means an item of tangible personal property specifically designed for use in law enforcement or in providing security or guard services, or that is specially equipped with a device or feature designed for use in providing law enforcement, security, or guard services, but does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(22)(a): standardized clothing, whether or not bearing a company name or logo, if the clothing does not bear the words "security" or "guard"; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(22)(b): an item of tangible personal property, other than a firearm or nonlethal weapon, that may be used without modification in providing security or guard services.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(23): "Street patrol service" means a contract security company that provides patrols by means of foot, vehicle, or other method of transportation using public streets, thoroughfares, or property in the performance of the company's duties and responsibilities.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(24): "Unarmed private security officer" means an individual:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(24)(a): employed by a contract security company;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(24)(b): whose primary duty is guarding personal or real property or providing protection or security to the life and well being of humans or animals;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(24)(c): who does not wear, carry, possess, or have immediate access to a firearm in the performance of the individual's duties; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(24)(d): who wears clothing of distinctive design or fashion bearing a symbol, badge, emblem, insignia, or other device that identifies the individual as a security officer.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(25): 58-1-501; 58-63-501 "Unlawful conduct" means the same as that term is defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-102(26): 58-1-501; 58-63-502 "Unprofessional conduct" means the same as that term is defined in Sections


Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-103 Use of money for education, training, and enforcement.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The director may, with the concurrence of the board, use the money collected under SectionUtah Code Annotated § 58-63-103(1): educating and training licensees under this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-103(2): educating and training the general public or other interested persons in matters concerning the laws that govern the practices licensed under this chapter; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-103(3): enforcing this chapter by:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-103(3)(a): investigating unprofessional or unlawful conduct; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-103(3)(b): providing legal representation to the division when it takes legal action against a person charged with unprofessional or unlawful conduct.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-201 Board -- Duties.
------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-201(1): There is created the Security Services Licensing Board consisting of:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-201(1)(a): two individuals who are officers or owners of a licensed contract security company;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-201(1)(b): one individual who is an officer or owner of a licensed armored car company;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-201(1)(c): one individual from among nominees of the Utah Sheriffs' Association;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-201(1)(d): one individual from among nominees of the Utah Chiefs of Police Association; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-201(1)(e): two individuals representing the general public.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-201(2): 58-1-201; 58-1-201
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-201(2)(a): 58-1-201 The executive director shall appoint board members in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-201(2)(b): 58-1-201 A board member serves in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-201(3): 58-1-202; 58-1-203
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-201(3)(a): 58-1-202; 58-1-203 The board shall carry out its duties and responsibilities in accordance with Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-201(3)(b): The board shall designate one of its members on a permanent or rotating basis to:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-201(3)(b)(i): assist the division in reviewing a complaint concerning the unlawful or unprofessional conduct of a person licensed under this chapter; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-201(3)(b)(ii): advise the division in its investigation of the complaint.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-201(4): (3) A board member who, under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-301 Licensure required -- License classifications.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-301(1): 58-1-307; 58-63-304; 58-63-310 A license is required to engage in the practice of a contract security company, an armored car company, an armored car security officer, armed private security officer, or unarmed private security officer, except as otherwise provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-301(2): The division shall issue to a person who qualifies under this chapter a license in the following classifications:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-301(2)(a): contract security company;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-301(2)(b): armored car company;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-301(2)(c): armored car security officer;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-301(2)(d): armed private security officer; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-301(2)(e): unarmed private security officer.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302 Qualifications for licensure.
-------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(1): 63J-1-504; Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act; 58-63-302.1; Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act; (1)(e); Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act; Title 35A, Chapter 4, Employment Security Act Each applicant for licensure as an armored car company or a contract security company shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(1)(a): submit an application in a form prescribed by the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(1)(b): 63J-1-504 pay a fee determined by the department under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(1)(c): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act have a qualifying agent who:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(1)(c)(i): meets with the division and the board and demonstrates that the applicant and the qualifying agent meet the requirements of this section;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(1)(c)(ii): is a resident of the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(1)(c)(iii): is responsible management personnel or a company owner of the applicant;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(1)(c)(iv): exercises material day-to-day authority in the conduct of the applicant's business by making substantive technical and administrative decisions and whose primary employment is with the applicant;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(1)(c)(v): is not concurrently acting as a qualifying agent or employee of another armored car company or contract security company and is not engaged in any other employment on a regular basis;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(1)(c)(vi): is not involved in any activity that would conflict with the qualifying agent's duties and responsibilities under this chapter to ensure that the qualifying agent's and the applicant's performance under this chapter does not jeopardize the health or safety of the general public;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(1)(c)(vii): is not an employee of a government agency;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(1)(c)(viii): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act passes an examination component established by rule by the division in collaboration with the board and in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(1)(c)(ix): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(1)(c)(ix)(A): demonstrates 6,000 hours of compensated experience as a manager, supervisor, or administrator of an armored car company or a contract security company; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(1)(c)(ix)(B): demonstrates 6,000 hours of supervisory experience acceptable to the division in collaboration with the board with a federal, United States military, state, county, or municipal law enforcement agency;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(1)(d): 58-63-302.1; Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act provide the name, address, date of birth, social security number, fingerprint card, and consent to a criminal background check in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(1)(e): have company officers, company owners, company proprietors, company trustees, and responsible management personnel who have not been convicted of:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(1)(e)(i): a felony; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(1)(e)(ii): a crime that when considered with the duties and responsibilities of a contract security company or an armored car company by the division and the board indicates that the best interests of the public are not served by granting the applicant a license;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(1)(f): (1)(e) document that none of the persons described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(1)(f)(i): have been declared by a court of competent jurisdiction incompetent by reason of mental defect or disease and not been restored; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(1)(f)(ii): currently suffer from habitual drunkenness or from drug addiction or dependence;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(1)(g): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act; Title 35A, Chapter 4, Employment Security Act file and maintain with the division evidence of:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(1)(g)(i): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act comprehensive general liability insurance in a form and in amounts established by rule by the division in collaboration with the board and in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(1)(g)(ii): workers' compensation insurance that covers employees of the applicant in accordance with applicable Utah law;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(1)(g)(iii): registration with the Division of Corporations and Commercial Code; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(1)(g)(iv): Title 35A, Chapter 4, Employment Security Act registration as required by applicable law with the:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(1)(g)(iv)(A): Title 35A, Chapter 4, Employment Security Act Unemployment Insurance Division in the Department of Workforce Services, for purposes of
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(1)(g)(iv)(B): State Tax Commission; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(1)(g)(iv)(C): Internal Revenue Service; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(1)(h): meet with the division and board if requested by the division or board.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(2): 63J-1-504; Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act; Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act; Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act; 58-63-302.1; Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act Each applicant for licensure as an armed private security officer:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(2)(a): shall submit an application in a form prescribed by the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(2)(b): 63J-1-504 shall pay a fee determined by the department under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(2)(c): may not have been convicted of:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(2)(c)(i): a felony; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(2)(c)(ii): a crime that when considered with the duties and responsibilities of an armed private security officer by the division and the board indicates that the best interests of the public are not served by granting the applicant a license;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(2)(d): may not be prohibited from possession of a firearm or ammunition under 18 U.S.C. Sec. 922(g);
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(2)(e): may not have been declared incompetent by a court of competent jurisdiction by reason of mental defect or disease and not been restored;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(2)(f): may not be currently suffering from habitual drunkenness or from drug addiction or dependence;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(2)(g): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act shall successfully complete basic education and training requirements established by rule by the division in collaboration with the board and in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(2)(h): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act shall successfully complete firearms training requirements established by rule by the division in collaboration with the board and in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(2)(i): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act shall pass the examination requirement established by rule by the division in collaboration with the board and in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(2)(j): 58-63-302.1; Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act shall submit to and pass a background check in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(2)(k): shall meet with the division and board if requested by the division or the board.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(3): 63J-1-504; Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act; Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act; 58-63-302.1; Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act Each applicant for licensure as an unarmed private security officer:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(3)(a): shall submit an application in a form prescribed by the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(3)(b): 63J-1-504 shall pay a fee determined by the department under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(3)(c): may not have been convicted of:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(3)(c)(i): a felony; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(3)(c)(ii): a crime that when considered with the duties and responsibilities of an unarmed private security officer by the division and the board indicates that the best interests of the public are not served by granting the applicant a license;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(3)(d): may not have been declared incompetent by a court of competent jurisdiction by reason of mental defect or disease and not been restored;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(3)(e): may not be currently suffering from habitual drunkenness or from drug addiction or dependence;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(3)(f): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act shall successfully complete basic education and training requirements established by rule by the division in collaboration with the board and in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(3)(g): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act shall pass the examination requirement established by rule by the division in collaboration with the board and in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(3)(h): 58-63-302.1; Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act shall submit to and pass a background check in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(3)(i): shall meet with the division and board if requested by the division or board.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(4): 63J-1-504; Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act; Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act; Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act; 58-63-302.1; Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act Each applicant for licensure as an armored car security officer:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(4)(a): shall submit an application in a form prescribed by the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(4)(b): 63J-1-504 shall pay a fee determined by the department under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(4)(c): may not have been convicted of:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(4)(c)(i): a felony; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(4)(c)(ii): a crime that when considered with the duties and responsibilities of an armored car security officer by the division and the board indicates that the best interests of the public are not served by granting the applicant a license;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(4)(d): may not be prohibited from possession of a firearm or ammunition under 18 U.S.C. Sec. 922(g);
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(4)(e): may not have been declared incompetent by a court of competent jurisdiction by reason of mental defect or disease and not been restored;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(4)(f): may not be currently suffering from habitual drunkenness or from drug addiction or dependence;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(4)(g): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act shall successfully complete basic education and training requirements established by rule by the division in collaboration with the board and in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(4)(h): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act shall successfully complete firearms training requirements established by rule by the division in collaboration with the board and in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 58-63-302(4)(i): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act shall pass the examination requirements established by rule by the division in collaboration with the board and in accordance with
