Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-304 License renewal requirements.
-------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-304(1): 58-67-302(1)(i); 58-67-302.8; 58-67-807(4) As a condition precedent for license renewal, each licensee shall, during each two-year licensure cycle or other cycle defined by division rule:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-304(1)(a): complete qualified continuing professional education requirements in accordance with the number of hours and standards defined by division rule made in collaboration with the board;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-304(1)(b): 58-67-302(1)(i) appoint a contact person for access to medical records and an alternate contact person for access to medical records in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-304(1)(c): if the licensee practices medicine in a location with no other persons licensed under this chapter, provide some method of notice to the licensee's patients of the identity and location of the contact person and alternate contact person for the licensee; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-304(1)(d): 58-67-302.8; 58-67-807(4) if the licensee is an associate physician licensed under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-304(2): 58-67-303 If a renewal period is extended or shortened under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-304(3): (3)(a)(ii); Title 76, Chapter 7, Part 3, Abortion; Title 76, Chapter 7a, Abortion Prohibition
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-304(3)(a): An application to renew a license under this chapter shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-304(3)(a)(i): require a physician to answer the following question: "Do you perform elective abortions in Utah in a location other than a hospital?"; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-304(3)(a)(ii): immediately following the question, contain the following statement: "For purposes of the immediately preceding question, elective abortion means an abortion other than one of the following: removal of a dead fetus, removal of an ectopic pregnancy, an abortion that is necessary to avert the death of a woman, an abortion that is necessary to avert a serious physical risk of substantial impairment of a major bodily function of a woman, an abortion of a fetus that has a defect that is uniformly diagnosable and uniformly lethal, or an abortion where the woman is pregnant as a result of rape or incest."
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-304(3)(b): (3)(a)(ii); Title 76, Chapter 7, Part 3, Abortion; Title 76, Chapter 7a, Abortion Prohibition The statement in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-304(4): Title 76, Chapter 7, Part 3, Abortion; Title 76, Chapter 7a, Abortion Prohibition; (3)(a)(i); (3)(a)(i) In order to assist the Department of Health and Human Services in fulfilling the department's responsibilities relating to the licensing of a health care facility and the enforcement of
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-304(4)(a): of the name and business address of the physician; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-304(4)(b): (3)(a)(i) that the physician responded positively to the question described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-304(5): (1)(a); 26B-4-204; 26B-4-219 The division shall accept and apply toward the hour requirement in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-305 Exemptions from licensure.
----------------------------------------------------------
In addition to the exemptions from licensure in SectionUtah Code Annotated § 58-67-305(1): an individual rendering aid in an emergency, when no fee or other consideration of value for the service is charged, received, expected, or contemplated;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-305(2): an individual administering a domestic or family remedy;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-305(3): (3)(a)(i); (3)(a); (3)(a)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-305(3)(a): (3)(a)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-305(3)(a)(i): a person engaged in the sale of vitamins, health foods, dietary supplements, herbs, or other products of nature, the sale of which is not otherwise prohibited by state or federal law; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-305(3)(a)(ii): (3)(a)(i) a person acting in good faith for religious reasons, as a matter of conscience, or based on a personal belief, when obtaining or providing any information regarding health care and the use of any product under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-305(3)(b): (3)(a); (3)(a)(i) Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-305(3)(b)(i): allow a person to diagnose any human disease, ailment, injury, infirmity, deformity, pain, or other condition; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-305(3)(b)(ii): (3)(a)(i) prohibit providing truthful and non-misleading information regarding any of the products under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-305(4): a person engaged in good faith in the practice of the religious tenets of any church or religious belief, without the use of prescription drugs;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-305(5): 26-1-30; 41-6a-523(1)(a)(vi); 53-10-405(2)(a)(vi); 72-10-502(5)(a)(vi); 77-23-213(3)(a)(vi) an individual authorized by the Department of Health under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-305(6): a medical assistant:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-305(6)(a): administering a vaccine under the general supervision of a physician; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-305(6)(b): under the indirect supervision of a physician, engaging in tasks appropriately delegated by the physician in accordance with the standards and ethics of the practice of medicine, except for:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-305(6)(b)(i): performing surgical procedures;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-305(6)(b)(ii): prescribing prescription medications;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-305(6)(b)(iii): administering anesthesia other than for a local anesthetic for minor procedural use; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-305(6)(b)(iv): engaging in other medical practices or procedures as defined by division rule in collaboration with the board;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-305(7): an individual engaging in the practice of medicine when:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-305(7)(a): the individual is licensed in good standing as a physician in another state with no licensing action pending and no less than 10 years of professional experience;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-305(7)(b): the services are rendered as a public service and for a noncommercial purpose;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-305(7)(c): no fee or other consideration of value is charged, received, expected, or contemplated for the services rendered beyond an amount necessary to cover the proportionate cost of malpractice insurance; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-305(7)(d): the individual does not otherwise engage in unlawful or unprofessional conduct;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-305(8): an individual providing expert testimony in a legal proceeding; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-305(9): an individual who is invited by a school, association, society, or other body approved by the division to conduct a clinic or demonstration of the practice of medicine in which patients are treated, if:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-305(9)(a): the individual does not establish a place of business in this state;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-305(9)(b): the individual does not regularly engage in the practice of medicine in this state;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-305(9)(c): the individual holds a current license in good standing to practice medicine issued by another state, district or territory of the United States, or Canada;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-305(9)(d): the primary purpose of the event is the training of others in the practice of medicine; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-305(9)(e): neither the patient nor an insurer is billed for the services performed.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-306 Status of licenses held on the effective date of this chapter.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
An individual holding a current license as a physician and surgeon that was issued under any prior state law is considered to hold a current license in the same classification under this chapter.

Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-401 Grounds for denial of license -- Disciplinary proceedings.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-401(1): (2); 58-1-401; 58-67-503 Subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-401(2): The division may not refuse, revoke, suspend, or in any way restrict an applicant or licensee's license under this chapter solely because the applicant or licensee seeks or participates in mental health or substance abuse treatment.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-402 Authority to assess penalty.
------------------------------------------------------------
The division in collaboration with the board may assess penalties as described in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-403 Revocation of license -- Nondisciplinary.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
Revocation by the division of a license under Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-501 Unlawful conduct.
-------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-501(1): 58-1-501 "Unlawful conduct" includes, in addition to the definition in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-501(1)(a): buying, selling, or fraudulently obtaining, any medical diploma, license, certificate, or registration;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-501(1)(b): aiding or abetting the buying, selling, or fraudulently obtaining of any medical diploma, license, certificate, or registration;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-501(1)(c): substantially interfering with a licensee's lawful and competent practice of medicine in accordance with this chapter by:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-501(1)(c)(i): any person or entity that manages, owns, operates, or conducts a business having a direct or indirect financial interest in the licensee's professional practice; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-501(1)(c)(ii): anyone other than another physician licensed under this title, who is engaged in direct clinical care or consultation with the licensee in accordance with the standards and ethics of the profession of medicine; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-501(1)(d): entering into a contract that limits a licensee's ability to advise the licensee's patients fully about treatment options or other issues that affect the health care of the licensee's patients.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-501(2): Title 31A, Insurance Code; 58-85-103 "Unlawful conduct" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-501(2)(a): Title 31A, Insurance Code establishing, administering, or enforcing the provisions of a policy of accident and health insurance by an insurer doing business in this state in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-501(2)(b): adopting, implementing, or enforcing utilization management standards related to payment for a licensee's services, provided that:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-501(2)(b)(i): utilization management standards adopted, implemented, and enforced by the payer have been approved by a physician or by a committee that contains one or more physicians; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-501(2)(b)(ii): the utilization management standards does not preclude a licensee from exercising independent professional judgment on behalf of the licensee's patients in a manner that is independent of payment considerations;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-501(2)(c): developing and implementing clinical practice standards that are intended to reduce morbidity and mortality or developing and implementing other medical or surgical practice standards related to the standardization of effective health care practices, provided that:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-501(2)(c)(i): the practice standards and recommendations have been approved by a physician or by a committee that contains one or more physicians; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-501(2)(c)(ii): the practice standards do not preclude a licensee from exercising independent professional judgment on behalf of the licensee's patients in a manner that is independent of payment considerations;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-501(2)(d): requesting or recommending that a patient obtain a second opinion from a licensee;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-501(2)(e): conducting peer review, quality evaluation, quality improvement, risk management, or similar activities designed to identify and address practice deficiencies with health care providers, health care facilities, or the delivery of health care;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-501(2)(f): providing employment supervision or adopting employment requirements that do not interfere with the licensee's ability to exercise independent professional judgment on behalf of the licensee's patients, provided that employment requirements that may not be considered to interfere with an employed licensee's exercise of independent professional judgment include:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-501(2)(f)(i): an employment requirement that restricts the licensee's access to patients with whom the licensee's employer does not have a contractual relationship, either directly or through contracts with one or more third-party payers; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-501(2)(f)(ii): providing compensation incentives that are not related to the treatment of any particular patient;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-501(2)(g): providing benefit coverage information, giving advice, or expressing opinions to a patient or to a family member of a patient to assist the patient or family member in making a decision about health care that has been recommended by a licensee;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-501(2)(h): 58-85-103 in compliance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-501(2)(h)(i): obtaining an investigational drug or investigational device;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-501(2)(h)(ii): administering the investigational drug to an eligible patient; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-501(2)(h)(iii): treating an eligible patient with the investigational drug or investigational device; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-501(2)(i): any otherwise lawful conduct that does not substantially interfere with the licensee's ability to exercise independent professional judgment on behalf of the licensee's patients and that does not constitute the practice of medicine as defined in this chapter.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-502 Unprofessional conduct.
-------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-502(1): 58-1-501; 58-67-302.7; 58-67-302.8; Chapter 17b, Part 8, Dispensing Medical Practitioner and Dispensing Medical Practitioner Clinic Pharmacy; Title 26B, Chapter 4, Part 2, Cannabinoid Research and Medical Cannabis; 76-7-302; 76-7a-201; (1)(a); (e); 58-1-501(1) "Unprofessional conduct" includes, in addition to the definition in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-502(1)(a): using or employing the services of any individual to assist a licensee in any manner not in accordance with the generally recognized practices, standards, or ethics of the profession, state law, or division rule;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-502(1)(b): 58-67-302.7; 58-67-302.8 making a material misrepresentation regarding the qualifications for licensure under Section

Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-502(1)(f)(ii): (1)(a); (e); 58-1-501(1) conduct described in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-502(1)(g): performing, or causing to be performed, upon an individual who is less than 18 years old:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-502(1)(g)(i): a primary sex characteristic surgical procedure; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-502(1)(g)(ii): a secondary sex characteristic surgical procedure.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-502(2): 58-85-103; Title 26B, Chapter 4, Part 2, Cannabinoid Research and Medical Cannabis; 26B-4-201; 26B-4-201 "Unprofessional conduct" does not include:

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-503(1): 58-67-501; 58-1-501 Any person who violates the unlawful conduct provisions of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-503(2): (4); 58-67a-1
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-503(2)(a): (4) Subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-503(2)(a)(i): assessing administrative penalties; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-503(2)(a)(ii): taking other appropriate administrative action.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-503(2)(b): 58-67a-1 A monetary administrative penalty imposed under this section shall be deposited into the Physician Education Fund created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-503(3): 58-67-501 If a licensee has been convicted of unlawful conduct, described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-503(4): 58-67-501; 58-67-502; Chapter 1, Division of Professional Licensing Act; Chapter 37, Utah Controlled Substances Act; Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act; (4)(a); (4)(a); Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-503(4)(a): 58-67-501; 58-67-502; Chapter 1, Division of Professional Licensing Act; Chapter 37, Utah Controlled Substances Act; Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act If the division concludes that an individual has violated provisions of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-503(4)(a)(i): issue a citation to the individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-503(4)(a)(ii): attempt to negotiate a stipulated settlement; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-503(4)(a)(iii): Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act notify the individual that an adjudicative proceeding conducted under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-503(4)(b): (4)(a); (4)(a) The division may take the following action against an individual who is in violation of a provision described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-503(4)(b)(i): assess a fine of up to $10,000 per single violation or up to $2,000 per day of ongoing violation, whichever is greater, in accordance with a fine schedule established by rule; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-503(4)(b)(ii): (4)(a) order to cease and desist from the behavior that constitutes a violation of the provisions described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-503(4)(c): An individual's license may not be suspended or revoked through a citation.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-503(4)(d): Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act Each citation issued under this section shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-503(4)(d)(i): be in writing;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-503(4)(d)(ii): Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act clearly describe or explain:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-503(4)(d)(ii)(A): the nature of the violation, including a reference to the provision of the chapter, rule, or order alleged to have been violated;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-503(4)(d)(ii)(B): Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act that the recipient must notify the division in writing within 20 calendar days from the day on which the citation is served if the recipient wishes to contest the citation at a hearing conducted under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-503(4)(d)(ii)(C): the consequences of failure to timely contest the citation or pay the fine assessed by the citation within the time specified in the citation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-503(4)(d)(iii): be served in accordance with the Utah Rules of Civil Procedure.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-503(4)(e): If the individual to whom the citation is issued fails to request a hearing to contest the citation within 20 calendar days from the day on which the citation is served, the citation becomes the final order of the division and is not subject to further agency review.  The period to contest the citation may be extended by the division for cause.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-503(4)(f): The division may refuse to issue or renew or suspend, revoke, or place on probation the license of an individual who fails to comply with a citation after the citation becomes final.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-503(4)(g): The failure of an applicant for licensure to comply with a citation after it becomes final is a ground for denial of license.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-503(4)(h): No citation may be issued under this section after the expiration of one year following the date on which the violation that is the subject of the citation is reported to the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-503(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-503(5)(a): The director may collect a penalty imposed under this section that is not paid by:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-503(5)(a)(i): referring the matter to a collection agency; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-503(5)(a)(ii): bringing an action in the district court of the county where the person against whom the penalty is imposed resides or in the county where the office of the director is located.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-503(5)(b): A county attorney or the attorney general of the state shall provide legal assistance and advice to the director in an action to collect a penalty.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-503(5)(c): A court shall award reasonable attorney fees and costs to the prevailing party in an action brought by the division to collect a penalty.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-601 Mentally incompetent or incapacitated physician.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-601(1): 75-1-201; 26B-5-301 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-601(1)(a): 75-1-201 "Incapacitated person" means a person who is incapacitated, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-601(1)(b): 26B-5-301 "Mental illness" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-601(1)(c): "Physician" means an individual licensed under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-601(2): Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act If a court of competent jurisdiction determines a physician is an incapacitated person or that the physician has a mental illness and is unable to safely engage in the practice of medicine, the director shall immediately suspend the license of the physician upon the entry of the judgment of the court, without further proceedings under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-601(3): 58-1-109; Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act; (4)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-601(3)(a): If the division and a majority of the board find reasonable cause to believe a physician, who is not determined judicially to be an incapacitated person or to have a mental illness, is incapable of practicing medicine with reasonable skill regarding the safety of patients, because of illness, excessive use of drugs or alcohol, or as a result of any mental or physical condition, the board shall recommend that the director file a petition with the division, and cause the petition to be served upon the physician with a notice of hearing on the sole issue of the capacity of the physician to competently and safely engage in the practice of medicine.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-601(3)(b): 58-1-109; Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act; (4) The hearing shall be conducted under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-601(4): Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-601(4)(a): Every physician who accepts the privilege of being licensed under this chapter gives consent to:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-601(4)(a)(i): submitting at the physician's own expense to an immediate mental or physical examination when directed in writing by the division and a majority of the board to do so; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-601(4)(a)(ii): the admissibility of the reports of the examining physician's testimony or examination, and waives all objections on the ground the reports constitute a privileged communication.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-601(4)(b): The examination may be ordered by the division, with the consent of a majority of the board, only upon a finding of reasonable cause to believe:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-601(4)(b)(i): the physician has a mental illness, is incapacitated, or otherwise unable to practice medicine with reasonable skill and safety; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-601(4)(b)(ii): immediate action by the division and the board is necessary to prevent harm to the physician's patients or the general public.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-601(4)(c): Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-601(4)(c)(i): Failure of a physician to submit to the examination ordered under this section is a ground for the division's immediate suspension of the physician's license by written order of the director.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-601(4)(c)(ii): Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act The division may enter the order of suspension without further compliance with
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-601(5): (2); (3); 58-1-108; 58-1-109
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-601(5)(a): (2); (3) A physician whose license is suspended under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-601(5)(b): 58-1-108; 58-1-109 The hearing held under this subsection shall be conducted in accordance with Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-601(6): A physician whose license is revoked, suspended, or in any way restricted under this section may request the division and the board to consider, at reasonable intervals, evidence presented by the physician, under procedures established by division rule, regarding any change in the physician's condition, to determine whether:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-601(6)(a): the physician is or is not able to safely and competently engage in the practice of medicine; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-601(6)(b): the physician is qualified to have the physician's license to practice under this chapter restored completely or in part.

Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-801 Disclosure of financial interest by licensee.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-801(1): Licensees under this chapter may not refer patients, clients, or customers to any clinical laboratory, ambulatory or surgical care facilities, or other treatment or rehabilitation services such as physical therapy, cardiac rehabilitation, radiology services, dispensing optical lens facility, or lithotripsy, in which the licensee or a member of the licensee's immediate family has any financial relationship as that term is described in 42 U.S.C.  1395nn, unless the licensee at the time of making the referral discloses that relationship, in writing, to the patient, client, or customer.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-801(2): (1) The written disclosure under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-802 Form of practice.
-------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-802(1): A physician and surgeon licensed under this chapter may engage in practice as a physician and surgeon, or in the practice of medicine only as an individual licensee; but as an individual licensee, he may be:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-802(1)(a): an individual operating as a business proprietor;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-802(1)(b): an employee of another person;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-802(1)(c): a partner in a lawfully organized partnership;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-802(1)(d): a lawfully formed professional corporation;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-802(1)(e): a lawfully organized limited liability company;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-802(1)(f): a lawfully organized business corporation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-802(1)(g): any other form of organization recognized by the state which is not prohibited by division rule made in collaboration with the board.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-802(2): 58-67-301; 58-68-301 Regardless of the form in which a licensee engages in the practice of medicine, the licensee may only permit the practice of medicine in that form of practice to be conducted by an individual:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-802(2)(a): 58-67-301; 58-68-301 licensed in Utah as a physician and surgeon under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-802(2)(b): who is able to lawfully and competently engage in the practice of medicine.

Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-803(2): (1) Medical records under this section may be maintained by an electronic means if the records comply with Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-804 Consumer access to provider charges.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Beginning January 1, 2011, a physician licensed under this chapter shall, when requested by a consumer:Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-804(1): make a list of prices charged by the physician available for the consumer which includes the physician's 25 most frequently performed:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-804(1)(a): clinic procedures or clinic services;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-804(1)(b): out-patient procedures; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-804(1)(c): in-patient procedures; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-804(2): provide the consumer with information regarding any discount available for:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-804(2)(a): services not covered by insurance; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-804(2)(b): prompt payment of billed charges.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-805 Supervision of cosmetic medical procedures.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-805(1): (2); Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-805(2): Chapter 31b, Nurse Practice Act A physician may delegate to an advanced practice registered nurse with an unrestricted license under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-805(2)(a): prescribes that specific procedure for the patient who is to receive the procedure;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-805(2)(b): ensures that the advanced practice registered nurse performs the procedure under the indirect supervision of the physician; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-805(2)(c): verifies that the advanced practice registered nurse is qualified to perform the procedure by having received at least 50 hours of training specific to the procedure to be performed and the laser to be used.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-806 Representation of medical specialization.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-806(1): (2) A physician may not represent to another person that the physician is certified in a medical specialty or certified by a particular board unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-806(1)(a): the physician includes in the representation the name of:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-806(1)(a)(i): the certification board or entity; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-806(1)(a)(ii): the medical specialty for which the physician is certified; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-806(1)(b): (2) the board or certification entity meets the requirements of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-806(2): (1) A certification entity or board under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-806(2)(a): be included in the American Board of Medical Specialties or an American Osteopathic Association Certifying Board; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-806(2)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-806(2)(b)(i): require an Accreditation Council for Graduate Medical Education or American Osteopathic Association approved postgraduate training program that provides complete training in the specialty or subspeciality; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-806(2)(b)(ii): be certified or had prior certification by the member board of the American Board of Medical Specialties or an American Osteopathic Certifying Board.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-807 Collaborative practice arrangement.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-807(1): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act; (1)(b)(iv)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-807(1)(a): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act The division, in consultation with the board, shall make rules in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-807(1)(b): (1)(b)(iv) The division shall require a collaborative practice arrangement to:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-807(1)(b)(i): limit the associate physician to providing primary care services;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-807(1)(b)(ii): be consistent with the skill, training, and competence of the associate physician;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-807(1)(b)(iii): specify jointly agreed-upon protocols, or standing orders for the delivery of health care services by the associate physician;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-807(1)(b)(iv): provide complete names, home and business addresses, zip codes, and telephone numbers of the collaborating physician and the associate physician;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-807(1)(b)(v): (1)(b)(iv) list all other offices or locations besides those listed in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-807(1)(b)(vi): require at every office where the associate physician is authorized to prescribe in collaboration with a physician a prominently displayed disclosure statement informing patients that patients may be seen by an associate physician and have the right to see the collaborating physician;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-807(1)(b)(vii): specify all specialty or board certifications of the collaborating physician and all certifications of the associate physician;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-807(1)(b)(viii): specify the manner of collaboration between the collaborating physician and the associate physician, including how the collaborating physician and the associate physician shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-807(1)(b)(viii)(A): engage in collaborative practice consistent with each professional's skill, training, education, and competence;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-807(1)(b)(viii)(B): maintain geographic proximity; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-807(1)(b)(viii)(C): provide oversight of the associate physician during the absence, incapacity, infirmity, or emergency of the collaborating physician;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-807(1)(b)(ix): describe the associate physician's controlled substance prescriptive authority in collaboration with the collaborating physician, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-807(1)(b)(ix)(A): a list of the controlled substances the collaborating physician authorizes the associate physician to prescribe; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-807(1)(b)(ix)(B): documentation that the authorization to prescribe the controlled substances is consistent with the education, knowledge, skill, and competence of the associate physician and the collaborating physician;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-807(1)(b)(x): list all other written practice arrangements of the collaborating physician and the associate physician; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-807(1)(b)(xi): specify the duration of the written practice arrangement between the collaborating physician and the associate physician.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-807(1)(c): An associate physician and the collaborating physician may modify a collaborative practice arrangement, but the changes to the collaborative practice arrangement are not binding unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-807(1)(c)(i): the associate physician notifies the division within 10 days after the day on which the changes are made; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-807(1)(c)(ii): the division approves the changes.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-807(2): An associate physician:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-807(2)(a): shall clearly identify himself or herself as an associate physician;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-807(2)(b): is permitted to use the title "doctor" or "Dr."; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-807(2)(c): if authorized under a collaborative practice arrangement to prescribe Schedule III through V controlled substances, shall register with the United States Drug Enforcement Administration as part of the drug enforcement administration's mid-level practitioner registry.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-807(3): 58-67-302; 58-67-302.8; (3)(c)(i)(C)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-807(3)(a): 58-67-302; 58-67-302.8 A physician or surgeon licensed and in good standing under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-807(3)(b): A physician or surgeon may not enter into a collaborative practice arrangement with more than three full-time equivalent associate physicians.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-807(3)(c): (3)(c)(i)(C)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-807(3)(c)(i): No contract or other agreement shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-807(3)(c)(i)(A): require a physician to act as a collaborating physician for an associate physician against the physician's will;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-807(3)(c)(i)(B): deny a collaborating physician the right to refuse to act as a collaborating physician, without penalty, for a particular associate physician; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-807(3)(c)(i)(C): limit the collaborating physician's ultimate authority over any protocols or standing orders or in the delegation of the physician's authority to any associate physician.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-807(3)(c)(ii): (3)(c)(i)(C) Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-807(3)(d): A collaborating physician is responsible at all times for the oversight of the activities of, and accepts responsibility for, the primary care services rendered by the associate physician.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-807(4): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act The division shall makes rules, in consultation with the board, the deans of medical schools in the state, and primary care residency program directors in the state, and in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-807(4)(a): an associate physician shall complete throughout the duration of the collaborative practice arrangement;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-807(4)(b): shall facilitate the advancement of the associate physician's medical knowledge and capabilities; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67-807(4)(c): may lead to credit toward a future residency program.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 58 - Chapter 67a - Physicians Education Fund
************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 58-67a-1 Physicians Education Fund.
---------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67a-1(1): Title 58, Occupations and Professions; Title 58, Chapter 37, Utah Controlled Substances Act There is created an expendable special revenue fund known as the "Physicians Education Fund" to receive and account for revenue and expenditures for making education available to physicians and surgeons, osteopathic physicians and surgeons, and naturopathic physicians, concerning the requirements of
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67a-1(2): Administrative  penalties ordered and collected pursuant to this section shall be deposited in the account.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67a-1(3): The fund shall earn interest and all interest earned on account money shall be deposited into the account.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67a-1(4): The director, with the concurrence of the board, may make distributions from the fund to make available education and training for  physicians and surgeons, osteopathic physicians and surgeons, and naturopathic physicians.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67a-1(5): If the balance in the fund exceeds $100,000 at the close of any fiscal year, the excess shall be transferred to the General Fund.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67a-1(6): The division shall report on the fund annually to the appropriate appropriations subcommittee of the Legislature.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 58 - Chapter 67b - Interstate Medical Licensure Compact
***********************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-101 Title.
---------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Interstate Medical Licensure Compact."

Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-102 Section 1 -- Purpose.
------------------------------------------------------
In order to strengthen access to health care, and in recognition of the advances in the delivery of health care, the member states of the Interstate Medical Licensure Compact have allied in common purpose to develop a comprehensive process that complements the existing licensing and regulatory authority of state medical boards and provides a streamlined process that allows physicians to become licensed in multiple states, thereby enhancing the portability of a medical license and ensuring the safety of patients.  The Compact creates another pathway for licensure and does not otherwise change a state's existing medical practice act.  The Compact also adopts the prevailing standard for licensure and affirms that the practice of medicine occurs where the patient is located at the time of the physician-patient encounter, and therefore, requires the physician to be under the jurisdiction of the state medical board where the patient is located.  State medical boards that participate in the Compact retain the jurisdiction to impose an adverse action against a license to practice medicine in that state issued to a physician through the procedures in the Compact.

Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-103 Section 2 -- Definitions.
----------------------------------------------------------
In this compact:Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-103(1): 58-67b-112 "Bylaws" means those bylaws established by the Interstate Commission pursuant to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-103(2): 58-67b-112 "Commissioner" means the voting representative appointed by each member board pursuant to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-103(3): "Conviction" means a finding by a court that an individual is guilty of a criminal offense through adjudication, or entry of a plea of guilt or no contest to the charge by the offender.  Evidence of an entry of a conviction of a criminal offense by the court shall be considered final for purposes of disciplinary action by a member board.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-103(4): "Expedited license" means a full and unrestricted medical license granted by a member state to an eligible physician through the process set forth in the Compact.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-103(5): 58-67b-112 "Interstate Commission" means the interstate commission created pursuant to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-103(6): "License" means authorization by a state for a physician to engage in the practice of medicine, which would be unlawful without the authorization.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-103(7): "Medical practice act" means laws and regulations governing the practice of allopathic and osteopathic medicine within a member state.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-103(8): "Member board" means a state agency in a member state that acts in the sovereign interests of the state by protecting the public through licensure, regulation, and education of physicians as directed by the state government.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-103(9): "Member state" means a state that has enacted the Compact.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-103(10): "Offense" means a felony, gross misdemeanor, or crime of moral turpitude.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-103(11): "Physician" means any person who:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-103(11)(a): is a graduate of a medical school accredited by the Liaison Committee on Medical Education, the Commission on Osteopathic College Accreditation, or a medical school listed in the International Medical Education Directory or its equivalent;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-103(11)(b): passed each component of the United States Medical Licensing Examination (USMLE) or the Comprehensive Osteopathic Medical Licensing Examination (COMLEX-USA) within three attempts, or any of its predecessor examinations accepted by a state medical board as an equivalent examination for licensure purposes;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-103(11)(c): successfully completed graduate medical education approved by the Accreditation Council for Graduate Medical Education or the American Osteopathic Association;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-103(11)(d): holds specialty certification or a time-unlimited specialty certificate recognized by the American Board of Medical Specialties or the American Osteopathic Association's Bureau of Osteopathic Specialists;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-103(11)(e): possesses a full and unrestricted license to engage in the practice of medicine issued by a member board;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-103(11)(f): has never been convicted, received adjudication, deferred adjudication, community supervision, or deferred disposition for any offense by a court of appropriate jurisdiction;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-103(11)(g): has never held a license authorizing the practice of medicine subjected to discipline by a licensing agency in any state, federal, or foreign jurisdiction, excluding any action related to non-payment of fees related to a license;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-103(11)(h): has never had a controlled substance license or permit suspended or revoked by a state or the United States Drug Enforcement Administration; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-103(11)(i): is not under active investigation by a licensing agency or law enforcement authority in any state, federal, or foreign jurisdiction.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-103(12): "Practice of medicine" means the clinical prevention, diagnosis, or treatment of human disease, injury, or condition requiring a physician to obtain and maintain a license in compliance with the medical practice act of a member state.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-103(13): 58-67b-113 "Rule" means a written statement by the Interstate Commission promulgated pursuant to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-103(14): "State" means any state, commonwealth, district, or territory of the United States.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-103(15): "State of principal license" means a member state where a physician holds a license to practice medicine and which has been designated as such by the physician for purposes of registration and participation in the Compact.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-104 Section 3 -- Eligibility.
----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-104(1): 58-67b-103(11) A physician must meet the eligibility requirements as defined in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-104(2): 58-67b-103(11) A physician who does not meet the requirements of Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-105 Section 4 -- Designation of state of principal license.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-105(1): (1)(a); (1)(b); (1)(c) A physician shall designate a member state as the state of principal license for purposes of registration for expedited licensure through the Compact if the physician possesses a full and unrestricted license to practice medicine in that state, and the state is:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-105(1)(a): the state of primary residence for the physician;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-105(1)(b): the state where at least 25% of the practice of medicine occurs;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-105(1)(c): the location of the physician's employer; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-105(1)(d): (1)(a); (1)(b); (1)(c) if no state qualifies under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-105(2): (1) A physician may redesignate a member state as state of principal license at any time, as long as the state meets the requirements in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-105(3): The Interstate Commission is authorized to develop rules to facilitate redesignation of another member state as the state of principal license.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-106 Section 5 -- Application and issuance of expedited licensure.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-106(1): A physician seeking licensure through the Compact shall file an application for an expedited license with the member board of the state selected by the physician as the state of principal license.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-106(2): Upon receipt of an application for an expedited license, the member board within the state selected as the state of principal license shall evaluate whether the physician is eligible for expedited licensure and issue a letter of qualification, verifying or denying the physician's eligibility, to the Interstate Commission, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-106(2)(a): static qualifications, which include verification of medical education, graduate medical education, results of any medical or licensing examination, and other qualifications as determined by the Interstate Commission through rule, shall not be subject to additional primary source verification where the primary source has already been verified by the state of principal license;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-106(2)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-106(2)(b)(i): the member board within the state selected as the state of principal license shall, in the course of verifying eligibility, perform a criminal background check of an applicant, including the use of the results of fingerprint or other biometric data checks compliant with the requirements of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, with the exception of federal employees who have suitability determination in accordance with U.S. C.F.R. Sec. 731.202; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-106(2)(b)(ii): if the state selected as the state of principal license is Utah:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-106(2)(b)(ii)(A): the member board in Utah shall submit the applicant's fingerprints and any other personal identification information necessary for the performance of the background check to the Bureau of Criminal Identification within the Utah Department of Public Safety; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-106(2)(b)(ii)(B): the Bureau of Criminal Identification shall perform the background check, including submitting the personal identification information to the Federal Bureau of Investigation, and inform the member board of the results; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-106(2)(c): appeal on the determination of eligibility shall be made to the member state where the application was filed and shall be subject to the law of that state.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-106(3): (2); (1) Upon verification in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-106(4): (2); (3) After receiving verification of eligibility under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-106(5): An expedited license shall be valid for a period consistent with the licensure period in the member state and in the same manner as required for other physicians holding a full and unrestricted license within the member state.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-106(6): An expedited license obtained though the Compact shall be terminated if a physician fails to maintain a license in the state of principal licensure for a non-disciplinary reason, without redesignation of a new state of principal licensure.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-106(7): The Interstate Commission is authorized to develop rules regarding the application process, including payment of any applicable fees, and the issuance of an expedited license.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-107 Section 6 -- Fees for expedited licensure.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-107(1): A member state issuing an expedited license authorizing the practice of medicine in that state may impose a fee for a license issued or renewed through the Compact.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-107(2): The Interstate Commission is authorized to develop rules regarding fees for expedited licenses.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-108 Section 7 -- Renewal and continued participation.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-108(1): A physician seeking to renew an expedited license granted in a member state shall complete a renewal process with the Interstate Commission if the physician:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-108(1)(a): maintains a full and unrestricted license in a state of principal license;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-108(1)(b): has not been convicted or received adjudication, deferred adjudication, community supervision, or deferred disposition for any offense by a court of appropriate jurisdiction;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-108(1)(c): has not had a license authorizing the practice of medicine subject to discipline by a licensing agency in any state, federal, or foreign jurisdiction, excluding any action related to non-payment of fees related to a license; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-108(1)(d): has not had a controlled substance license or permit suspended or revoked by a state or the United States Drug Enforcement Administration.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-108(2): Physicians shall comply with all continuing professional development or continuing medical education requirements for renewal of a license issued by a member state.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-108(3): The Interstate Commission shall collect any renewal fees charged for the renewal of a license and distribute the fees to the applicable member board.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-108(4): (3) Upon receipt of any renewal fees collected in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-108(5): Physician information collected by the Interstate Commission during the renewal process will be distributed to all member boards.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-108(6): The Interstate Commission is authorized to develop rules to address renewal of licenses obtained through the Compact.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-109 Section 8 -- Coordinated information system.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-109(1): 58-67b-106 The Interstate Commission shall establish a database of all physicians licensed, or who have applied for licensure, under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-109(2): Notwithstanding any other provision of law, member boards shall report to the Interstate Commission any public action or complaints against a licensed physician who has applied or received an expedited license through the Compact.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-109(3): Member boards shall report disciplinary or investigatory information determined as necessary and proper by rule of the Interstate Commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-109(4): (3) Member boards may report any non-public complaint, disciplinary, or investigatory information not required by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-109(5): Member boards shall share complaint or disciplinary information about a physician upon request of another member board.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-109(6): All information provided to the Interstate Commission or distributed by member boards shall be confidential, filed under seal, and used only for investigatory or disciplinary matters.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-109(7): The Interstate Commission is authorized to develop rules for mandated or discretionary sharing of information by member boards.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-110 Section 9 -- Joint investigations.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-110(1): Licensure and disciplinary records of physicians are deemed investigative.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-110(2): In addition to the authority granted to a member board by its respective medical practice act or other applicable state law, a member board may participate with other member boards in joint investigations of physicians licensed by the member boards.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-110(3): A subpoena issued by a member state shall be enforceable in other member states.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-110(4): Member boards may share any investigative, litigation, or compliance materials in furtherance of any joint or individual investigation initiated under the Compact.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-110(5): Any member state may investigate actual or alleged violations of the statutes authorizing the practice of medicine in any other member state in which a physician holds a license to practice medicine.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-111 Section 10 -- Disciplinary actions.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-111(1): Any disciplinary action taken by any member board against a physician licensed through the Compact shall be deemed unprofessional conduct which may be subject to discipline by other member boards, in addition to any violation of the medical practice act or regulations in that state.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-111(2): If a license granted to a physician by the member board in the state of principal license is revoked, surrendered or relinquished in lieu of discipline, or suspended, then all licenses issued to the physician by member boards shall automatically be placed, without further action necessary by any member board, on the same status.  If the member board in the state of principal license subsequently reinstates the physician's license, a license issued to the physician by any other member board shall remain encumbered until that respective member board takes action to reinstate the license in a manner consistent with the medical practice act of that state.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-111(3): If disciplinary action is taken against a physician by a member board not in the state of principal license, any other member board may deem the action conclusive as to matter of law and fact decided, and:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-111(3)(a): impose the same or lesser sanctions against the physician so long as such sanctions are consistent with the medical practice act of that state; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-111(3)(b): pursue separate disciplinary action against the physician under its respective medical practice act, regardless of the action taken in other member states.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-111(4): If a license granted to a physician by a member board is revoked, surrendered or relinquished in lieu of discipline, or suspended, then any licenses issued to the physician by any other member boards shall be suspended, automatically and immediately without further action necessary by the other member boards, for 90 days upon entry of the order by the disciplining board, to permit the member boards to investigate the basis for the action under the medical practice act of that state.  A member board may terminate the automatic suspension of the license it issued prior to the completion of the 90-day suspension period in a manner consistent with the medical practice act of that state.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-112 Section 11 -- Interstate Medical Licensure Compact Commission.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-112(1): The member states hereby create the "Interstate Medical Licensure Compact Commission."
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-112(2): The purpose of the Interstate Commission is the administration of the Interstate Medical Licensure Compact, which is a discretionary state function.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-112(3): The Interstate Commission shall be a body corporate and joint agency of the member states and shall have all the responsibilities, powers, and duties set forth in the Compact, and such additional powers as may be conferred upon it by a subsequent concurrent action of the respective legislatures of the member states in accordance with the terms of the Compact.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-112(4): The Interstate Commission shall consist of two voting representatives appointed by each member state who shall serve as commissioners.  In states where allopathic and osteopathic physicians are regulated by separate member boards, or if the licensing and disciplinary authority is split between multiple member boards within a member state, the member state shall appoint one representative from each member board.  A commissioner shall be:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-112(4)(a): an allopathic or osteopathic physician appointed to a member board;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-112(4)(b): an executive director, executive secretary, or similar executive of a member board; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-112(4)(c): a member of the public appointed to a member board.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-112(5): The Interstate Commission shall meet at least once each calendar year.  A portion of this meeting shall be a business meeting to address such matters as may properly come before the commission, including the election of officers.  The chairperson may call additional meetings and shall call for a meeting upon the request of a majority of the member states.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-112(6): The bylaws may provide for meetings of the Interstate Commission to be conducted by telecommunication or electronic communication.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-112(7): (4) Each commissioner participating at a meeting of the Interstate Commission is entitled to one vote.  A majority of commissioners shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business, unless a larger quorum is required by the bylaws of the Interstate Commission.  A commissioner shall not delegate a vote to another commissioner.  In the absence of its commissioner, a member state may delegate voting authority for a specified meeting to another person from that state who shall meet the requirements of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-112(8): The Interstate Commission shall provide public notice of all meetings and all meetings shall be open to the public.  The Interstate Commission may close a meeting, in full or in portion, where it determines by a two-thirds vote of the commissioners present that an open meeting would be likely to:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-112(8)(a): relate solely to the internal personnel practices and procedures of the Interstate Commission;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-112(8)(b): discuss matters specifically exempted from disclosure by federal statute;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-112(8)(c): discuss trade secrets, commercial, or financial information that is privileged or confidential;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-112(8)(d): involve accusing a person of a crime, or formally censuring a person;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-112(8)(e): discuss information of a personal nature where disclosure would constitute a clearly unwarranted invasion of personal privacy;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-112(8)(f): discuss investigative records compiled for law enforcement purposes; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-112(8)(g): specifically relate to the participation in a civil action or other legal proceeding.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-112(9): The Interstate Commission shall keep minutes which shall fully describe all matters discussed in a meeting and shall provide a full and accurate summary of actions taken, including record of any roll call votes.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-112(10): The Interstate Commission shall make its information and official records, to the extent not otherwise designated in the Compact or by its rules, available to the public for inspection.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-112(11): The Interstate Commission shall establish an executive committee, which shall include officers, members, and others as determined by the bylaws.  The executive committee shall have the power to act on behalf of the Interstate Commission, with the exception of rulemaking, during periods when the Interstate Commission is not in session.  When acting on behalf of the Interstate Commission, the executive committee shall oversee the administration of the Compact including enforcement and compliance with the provisions of the Compact, its bylaws and rules, and other such duties as necessary.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-112(12): The Interstate Commission may establish other committees for governance and administration of the Compact.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-113 Section 12 -- Powers and duties of the Interstate Commission.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The Interstate Commission shall have the duty and power to:Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-113(1): oversee and maintain the administration of the Compact;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-113(2): promulgate rules which shall be binding to the extent and in the manner provided for in the Compact;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-113(3): issue, upon the request of a member state or member board, advisory opinions concerning the meaning or interpretation of the Compact, its bylaws, rules, and actions;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-113(4): enforce compliance with Compact provisions, the rules promulgated by the Interstate Commission, and the bylaws, using all necessary and proper means, including but not limited to the use of judicial process;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-113(5): 58-67b-112 establish and appoint committees including, but not limited to, an executive committee as required by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-113(6): pay, or provide for the payment of the expenses related to the establishment, organization, and ongoing activities of the Interstate Commission;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-113(7): establish and maintain one or more offices;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-113(8): borrow, accept, hire, or contract for services of personnel;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-113(9): purchase and maintain insurance and bonds;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-113(10): employ an executive director who shall have the power to employ, select, or appoint employees, agents, or consultants, and to determine their qualifications, define their duties, and fix their compensation;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-113(11): establish personnel policies and programs relating to conflicts of interest, rates of compensation, and qualifications of personnel;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-113(12): accept donations and grants of money, equipment, supplies, materials, and services, and to receive, utilize, and dispose of it in a manner consistent with the conflict of interest policies established by the Interstate Commission;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-113(13): lease, purchase, accept contributions or donations of, or otherwise own, hold, improve, or use, any property, real, personal, or mixed;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-113(14): sell, convey, mortgage, pledge, lease, exchange, abandon, or otherwise dispose of any property, real, personal, or mixed;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-113(15): establish a budget and make expenditures;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-113(16): adopt a seal and bylaws governing the management and operation of the Interstate Commission;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-113(17): report annually to the legislatures and governors of the member states concerning the activities of the Interstate Commission during the preceding year, which shall include reports of financial audits and any recommendations that may have been adopted by the Interstate Commission;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-113(18): coordinate education, training, and public awareness regarding the Compact, its implementation, and its operation;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-113(19): maintain records in accordance with the bylaws;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-113(20): seek and obtain trademarks, copyrights, and patents; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-113(21): perform such functions as may be necessary or appropriate to achieve the purposes of the Compact.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-114 Section 13 -- Finance powers.
--------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-114(1): The Interstate Commission may levy and collect an annual assessment from each member state to cover the cost of the operations and activities of the Interstate Commission and its staff.  The total assessment must be sufficient to cover the annual budget approved each year for which revenue is not provided by other sources.  The aggregate annual assessment amount shall be allocated upon a formula to be determined by the Interstate Commission, which shall promulgate a rule binding upon all member states.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-114(2): The Interstate Commission shall not incur obligations of any kind prior to securing the funds adequate to meet the same.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-114(3): The Interstate Commission shall not pledge the credit of any of the member states, except by, and with the authority of, the member state.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-114(4): The Interstate Commission shall be subject to a yearly financial audit conducted by a certified or licensed public accountant and the report of the audit shall be included in the annual report of the Interstate Commission.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-115 Section 14 -- Organization and operation of the Interstate Commission.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-115(1): The Interstate Commission shall, by a majority of commissioners present and voting, adopt bylaws to govern its conduct as may be necessary or appropriate to carry out the purposes of the Compact within 12 months of the first Interstate Commission meeting.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-115(2): The Interstate Commission shall elect or appoint annually from among its commissioners a chairperson, a vice-chairperson, and a treasurer, each of whom shall have such authority and duties as may be specified in the bylaws.  The chairperson, or in the chairperson's absence or disability, the vice-chairperson, shall preside at all meetings of the Interstate Commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-115(3): (2) Officers selected in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-115(4): (4)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-115(4)(a): The officers and employees of the Interstate Commission shall be immune from suit and liability, either personally or in their official capacity, for a claim for damage to or loss of property or personal injury or other civil liability caused or arising out of, or relating to, an actual or alleged act, error, or omission that occurred, or that such person had a reasonable basis for believing occurred, within the scope of Interstate Commission employment, duties, or responsibilities, provided that such person shall not be protected from suit or liability for damage, loss, injury, or liability caused by the intentional or willful and wanton misconduct of such person.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-115(4)(b): (4)(b) The liability of the executive director and employees of the Interstate Commission or representatives of the Interstate Commission, acting within the scope of such person's employment or duties for acts, errors, or omissions occurring within such person's state, may not exceed the limits of liability set forth under the constitution and laws of that state for state officials, employees, and agents.  The Interstate Commission is considered to be an instrumentality of the states for the purposes of any such action.  Nothing in this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-115(4)(c): The Interstate Commission shall defend the executive director, its employees, and subject to the approval of the attorney general or other appropriate legal counsel of the member state represented by an Interstate Commission representative, such Interstate Commission representative in any civil action seeking to impose liability arising out of an actual or alleged act, error, or omission that occurred within the scope of Interstate Commission employment, duties or responsibilities, or that the defendant had a reasonable basis for believing occurred within the scope of Interstate Commission employment, duties, or responsibilities, provided that the actual or alleged act, error, or omission did not result from intentional or willful and wanton misconduct on the part of such person.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-115(4)(d): To the extent not covered by the state involved, the member state, or the Interstate Commission, the representatives or employees of the Interstate Commission shall be held harmless in the amount of a settlement or judgment, including attorney fees and costs, obtained against such persons arising out of an actual or alleged act, error, or omission that occurred within the scope of Interstate Commission employment, duties, or responsibilities, or that such persons had a reasonable basis for believing occurred within the scope of Interstate Commission employment, duties, or responsibilities, provided that the actual or alleged act, error, or omission did not result from intentional or willful and wanton misconduct on the part of such persons.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-116 Section 15 -- Rulemaking functions of the Interstate Commission.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-116(1): The Interstate Commission shall promulgate reasonable rules in order to effectively and efficiently achieve the purposes of the Compact.  Notwithstanding the foregoing, in the event the Interstate Commission exercises its rulemaking authority in a manner that is beyond the scope of the purposes of the Compact, or the powers granted hereunder, then such an action by the Interstate Commission shall be invalid and have no force or effect.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-116(2): Rules deemed appropriate for the operations of the Interstate Commission shall be made pursuant to a rulemaking process that substantially conforms to the "Revised Model State Administrative Procedure Act" of 2010, and subsequent amendments thereto.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-116(3): Not later than 30 days after a rule is promulgated, any person may file a petition for judicial review of the rule in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia or the federal district where the Interstate Commission has its principal offices, provided that the filing of such a petition shall not stay or otherwise prevent the rule from becoming effective unless the court finds that the petitioner has a substantial likelihood of success.  The court shall give deference to the actions of the Interstate Commission consistent with applicable law and shall not find the rule to be unlawful if the rule represents a reasonable exercise of the authority granted to the Interstate Commission.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-117 Section 16 -- Oversight of Interstate Compact.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-117(1): The executive, legislative, and judicial branches of state government in each member state shall enforce the Compact and shall take all actions necessary and appropriate to effectuate the Compact's purposes and intent.  The provisions of the Compact and the rules promulgated hereunder shall have standing as statutory law but shall not override existing state authority to regulate the practice of medicine.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-117(2): All courts shall take judicial notice of the Compact and the rules in any judicial or administrative proceeding in a member state pertaining to the subject matter of the Compact which may affect the powers, responsibilities, or actions of the Interstate Commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-117(3): The Interstate Commission shall be entitled to receive all service of process in any such proceeding, and shall have standing to intervene in the proceeding for all purposes.  Failure to provide service of process to the Interstate Commission shall render a judgment or order void as to the Interstate Commission, the Compact, or promulgated rules.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-118 Section 17 -- Enforcement of Interstate Compact.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-118(1): The Interstate Commission, in the reasonable exercise of its discretion, shall enforce the provisions and rules of the Compact.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-118(2): The Interstate Commission may, by majority vote of the commissioners, initiate legal action in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia, or, at the discretion of the Interstate Commission, in the federal district where the Interstate Commission has its principal offices, to enforce compliance with the provisions of the Compact, and its promulgated rules and bylaws, against a member state in default.  The relief sought may include both injunctive relief and damages.  In the event judicial enforcement is necessary, the prevailing party shall be awarded all costs of such litigation including reasonable attorney fees.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-118(3): The remedies herein shall not be the exclusive remedies of the Interstate Commission.  The Interstate Commission may avail itself of any other remedies available under state law or the regulation of a profession.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-119 Section 18 -- Default procedures.
------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-119(1): The grounds for default include, but are not limited to, failure of a member state to perform such obligations or responsibilities imposed upon it by the Compact, or the rules and bylaws of the Interstate Commission promulgated under the Compact.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-119(2): If the Interstate Commission determines that a member state has defaulted in the performance of its obligations or responsibilities under the Compact, or the bylaws or promulgated rules, the Interstate Commission shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-119(2)(a): provide written notice to the defaulting state and other member states, of the nature of the default, the means of curing the default, and any action taken by the Interstate Commission.  The Interstate Commission shall specify the conditions by which the defaulting state must cure its default; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-119(2)(b): provide remedial training and specific technical assistance regarding the default.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-119(3): If the defaulting state fails to cure the default, the defaulting state shall be terminated from the Compact upon an affirmative vote of a majority of the commissioners and all rights, privileges, and benefits conferred by the Compact shall terminate on the effective date of termination.  A cure of the default does not relieve the offending state of obligations or liabilities incurred during the period of the default.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-119(4): Termination of membership in the Compact shall be imposed only after all other means of securing compliance have been exhausted.  Notice of intent to terminate shall be given by the Interstate Commission to the governor, the majority and minority leaders of the defaulting state's legislature, and each of the member states.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-119(5): The Interstate Commission shall establish rules and procedures to address licenses and physicians that are materially impacted by the termination of a member state, or the withdrawal of a member state.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-119(6): The member state which has been terminated is responsible for all dues, obligations, and liabilities incurred through the effective date of termination including obligations, the performance of which extends beyond the effective date of termination.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-119(7): The Interstate Commission shall not bear any costs relating to any state that has been found to be in default or which has been terminated from the Compact, unless otherwise mutually agreed upon in writing between the Interstate Commission and the defaulting state.
