Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-119(8): The defaulting state may appeal the action of the Interstate Commission by petitioning the United States District Court for the District of Columbia or the federal district where the Interstate Commission has its principal offices.  The prevailing party shall be awarded all costs of such litigation including reasonable attorney fees.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-120 Section 19 -- Dispute resolution.
------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-120(1): The Interstate Commission shall attempt, upon the request of a member state, to resolve disputes which are subject to the Compact and which may arise among member states or member boards.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-120(2): The Interstate Commission shall promulgate rules providing for both mediation and binding dispute resolution as appropriate.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-121 Section 20 -- Member states, effective date and amendment.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-121(1): Any state is eligible to become a member state of the Compact.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-121(2): The Compact shall become effective and binding upon legislative enactment of the Compact into law by no less than seven states.  Thereafter, it shall become effective and binding on a state upon enactment of the Compact into law by that state.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-121(3): The governors of non-member states, or their designees, shall be invited to participate in the activities of the Interstate Commission on a non-voting basis prior to adoption of the Compact by all states.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-121(4): The Interstate Commission may propose amendments to the Compact for enactment by the member states.  No amendment shall become effective and binding upon the Interstate Commission and the member states unless and until it is enacted into law by unanimous consent of the member states.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-122 Section 21 -- Withdrawal.
----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-122(1): Once effective, the Compact shall continue in force and remain binding upon each and every member state, provided that a member state may withdraw from the Compact by specifically repealing the statute that enacted the Compact into law.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-122(2): Withdrawal from the Compact shall be by the enactment of a statute repealing the same, but shall not take effect until one year after the effective date of such statute and until written notice of the withdrawal has been given by the withdrawing state to the governor of each other member state.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-122(3): The withdrawing state shall immediately notify the chairperson of the Interstate Commission in writing upon the introduction of legislation repealing the Compact in the withdrawing state.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-122(4): (3) The Interstate Commission shall notify the other member states of the withdrawing state's intent to withdraw within 60 days of its receipt of notice provided under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-122(5): The withdrawing state is responsible for all dues, obligations, and liabilities incurred through the effective date of withdrawal, including obligations, the performance of which extend beyond the effective date of withdrawal.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-122(6): Reinstatement following withdrawal of a member state shall occur upon the withdrawing state reenacting the Compact or upon such later date as determined by the Interstate Commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-122(7): The Interstate Commission is authorized to develop rules to address the impact of the withdrawal of a member state on licenses granted in other member states to physicians who designated the withdrawing member state as the state of principal license.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-123 Section 22 -- Dissolution.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-123(1): The Compact shall dissolve effective upon the date of the withdrawal or default of the member state that reduces the membership in the Compact to one member state.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-123(2): Upon the dissolution of the Compact, the Compact becomes null and void and shall be of no further force or effect, and the business and affairs of the Interstate Commission shall be concluded and surplus funds shall be distributed in accordance with the bylaws.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-124 Section 23 -- Severability and construction.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-124(1): The provisions of the Compact shall be severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, or provision is deemed unenforceable, the remaining provisions of the Compact shall be enforceable.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-124(2): The provisions of the Compact shall be liberally construed to effectuate its purposes.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-124(3): Nothing in the Compact shall be construed to prohibit the applicability of other interstate compacts to which the states are members.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-125 Section 24 -- Binding effect of Compact and other laws.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-125(1): Nothing herein prevents the enforcement of any other law of a member state that is not inconsistent with the Compact.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-125(2): Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act All laws in a member state, including
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-125(3): All lawful actions of the Interstate Commission, including all rules and bylaws promulgated by the Commission, are binding upon the member states.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-125(4): All agreements between the Interstate Commission and the member states are binding in accordance with their terms.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-67b-125(5): In the event any provision of the Compact exceeds the constitutional limits imposed on the legislature of any member state, such provision shall be ineffective to the extent of the conflict with the constitutional provision in question in that member state.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 58 - Chapter 68 - Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act
***********************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-101 Title.
--------------------------------------
This chapter is the "Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
In addition to the definitions in SectionUtah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(1)(a): "Ablative procedure" means a procedure that is expected to excise, vaporize, disintegrate, or remove living tissue, including the use of carbon dioxide lasers and erbium: YAG lasers.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(1)(b): "Ablative procedure" does not include hair removal.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(2): "ACGME" means the Accreditation Council for Graduate Medical Education of the American Medical Association.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(3): Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act "Administrative penalty" means a monetary fine imposed by the division for acts or omissions determined to constitute unprofessional or unlawful conduct, as a result of an adjudicative proceeding conducted in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(4): "AOA" means the American Osteopathic Association.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(5): 58-68-302.5 "Associate physician" means an individual licensed under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(6): "Attempted sex change" means an attempt or effort to change an individual's body to present that individual as being of a sex or gender that is different from the individual's biological sex at birth.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(7): "Biological sex at birth" means an individual's sex, as being male or female, according to distinct reproductive roles as manifested by:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(7)(a): sex and reproductive organ anatomy;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(7)(b): chromosomal makeup; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(7)(c): endogenous hormone profiles.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(8): 58-68-201 "Board" means the Osteopathic Physician and Surgeon's Licensing Board created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(9): 58-68-302 "Collaborating physician" means an individual licensed under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(10): 58-68-807 "Collaborative practice arrangement" means the arrangement described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(11): (11)(a); (11)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(11)(a): "Cosmetic medical device" means tissue altering energy based devices that have the potential for altering living tissue and that are used to perform ablative or nonablative procedures, such as American National Standards Institute (ANSI) designated Class IIIb and Class IV lasers, intense pulsed light, radio frequency devices, and lipolytic devices and excludes ANSI designated Class IIIa and lower powered devices.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(11)(b): (11)(a); (11)(a) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(12): "Cosmetic medical procedure":
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(12)(a): includes the use of cosmetic medical devices to perform ablative or nonablative procedures; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(12)(b): does not include a treatment of the ocular globe such as refractive surgery.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(13): (13)(a); (13)(a); (13)(a) "Diagnose" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(13)(a): to examine in any manner another person, parts of a person's body, substances, fluids, or materials excreted, taken, or removed from a person's body, or produced by a person's body, to determine the source, nature, kind, or extent of a disease or other physical or mental condition;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(13)(b): (13)(a) to attempt to conduct an examination or determination described under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(13)(c): (13)(a) to hold oneself out as making or to represent that one is making an examination or determination as described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(13)(d): (13)(a) to make an examination or determination as described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(14): 58-68-305(6) "Medical assistant" means an unlicensed individual who may perform tasks as described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(15): "Medically underserved area" means a geographic area in which there is a shortage of primary care health services for residents, as determined by the Department of Health and Human Services.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(16): "Medically underserved population" means a specified group of people living in a defined geographic area with a shortage of primary care health services, as determined by the Department of Health and Human Services.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(17): (17)(a)(i); 58-1-102
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(17)(a): (17)(a)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(17)(a)(i): "Nonablative procedure" means a procedure that is expected or intended to alter living tissue, but is not expected or intended to excise, vaporize, disintegrate, or remove living tissue.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(17)(a)(ii): (17)(a)(i) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(17)(b): 58-1-102 "Nonablative procedure" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(17)(b)(i): 58-1-102 a superficial procedure as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(17)(b)(ii): the application of permanent make-up; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(17)(b)(iii): the use of photo therapy lasers for neuromusculoskeletal treatments that are performed by an individual licensed under this title who is acting within the individual's scope of practice.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(18): 58-67-301; 58-68-301 "Physician" means both physicians and surgeons licensed under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(19): (19)(a)(i); (ii); (19)(b)(ii); (19)(a)(i); 58-68-501(2)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(19)(a): (19)(a)(i); (ii) "Practice of osteopathic medicine" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(19)(a)(i): to diagnose, treat, correct, administer anesthesia, or prescribe for any human disease, ailment, injury, infirmity, deformity, pain, or other condition, physical or mental, real or imaginary, or to attempt to do so, by any means or instrumentality, which in whole or in part is based upon emphasis of the importance of the musculoskeletal system and manipulative therapy in the maintenance and restoration of health, by an individual in Utah or outside of the state upon or for any human within the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(19)(a)(ii): when a person not licensed as a physician directs a licensee under this chapter to withhold or alter the health care services that the licensee has ordered;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(19)(a)(iii): (19)(a)(i); (ii) to maintain an office or place of business for the purpose of doing any of the acts described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(19)(a)(iv): to use, in the conduct of any occupation or profession pertaining to the diagnosis or treatment of human diseases or conditions, in any printed material, stationery, letterhead, envelopes, signs, or advertisements, the designation "doctor," "doctor of osteopathic medicine," "osteopathic physician," "osteopathic surgeon," "osteopathic physician and surgeon," "Dr.," "D.O.," or any combination of these designations in any manner which might cause a reasonable person to believe the individual using the designation is a licensed osteopathic physician, and if the party using the designation is not a licensed osteopathic physician, the designation must additionally contain the description of the branch of the healing arts for which the person has a license, provided that an individual who has received an earned degree of doctor of osteopathic medicine but is not a licensed osteopathic physician and surgeon in Utah may use the designation "D.O." if it is followed by "Not Licensed" or "Not Licensed in Utah" in the same size and style of lettering.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(19)(b): (19)(b)(ii); (19)(a)(i); 58-68-501(2) The practice of osteopathic medicine does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(19)(b)(i): (19)(b)(ii); (19)(a)(i) except for an ablative medical procedure as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(19)(b)(ii): an ablative cosmetic medical procedure if the scope of practice for the person performing the ablative cosmetic medical procedure includes the authority to operate or perform a surgical procedure; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(19)(b)(iii): 58-68-501(2) conduct under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(20): "Prescription device" means an instrument, apparatus, implement, machine, contrivance, implant, in vitro reagent, or other similar or related article, and any component part or accessory, which is required under federal or state law to be prescribed by a practitioner and dispensed by or through a person or entity licensed under this chapter or exempt from licensure under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(21): "Prescription drug" means a drug that is required by federal or state law or rule to be dispensed only by prescription or is restricted to administration only by practitioners.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(22): (22)(a)(i); (ii)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(22)(a): (22)(a)(i); (ii) "Primary sex characteristic surgical procedure" means any of the following if done for the purpose of effectuating or facilitating an individual's attempted sex change:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(22)(a)(i): for an individual whose biological sex at birth is male, castration, orchiectomy, penectomy, vaginoplasty, or vulvoplasty;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(22)(a)(ii): for an individual whose biological sex at birth is female, hysterectomy, oophorectomy, metoidioplasty, or phalloplasty; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(22)(a)(iii): (22)(a)(i); (ii) any surgical procedure that is related to or necessary for a procedure described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(22)(b): "Primary sex characteristic surgical procedure" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(22)(b)(i): surgery or other procedures or treatments performed on an individual who:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(22)(b)(i)(A): is born with external biological sex characteristics that are irresolvably ambiguous;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(22)(b)(i)(B): is born with 46, XX chromosomes with virilization;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(22)(b)(i)(C): is born with 46, XY chromosomes with undervirilization;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(22)(b)(i)(D): has both ovarian and testicular tissue; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(22)(b)(i)(E): has been diagnosed by a physician, based on genetic or biochemical testing, with a sex development disorder characterized by abnormal sex chromosome structure, sex steroid hormone production, or sex steroid hormone action for a male or female; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(22)(b)(ii): removing a body part:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(22)(b)(ii)(A): because the body part is cancerous or diseased; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(22)(b)(ii)(B): for a reason that is medically necessary, other than to effectuate or facilitate an individual's attempted sex change.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(23): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(23)(a): "Secondary sex characteristic surgical procedure" means any of the following if done for the purpose of effectuating or facilitating an individual's attempted sex change:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(23)(a)(i): for an individual whose biological sex at birth is male, breast augmentation surgery, chest feminization surgery, or facial feminization surgery; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(23)(a)(ii): for an individual whose biological sex at birth is female, mastectomy, breast reduction surgery, chest masculinization surgery, or facial masculinization surgery.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(23)(b): "Secondary sex characteristic surgical procedure" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(23)(b)(i): surgery or other procedures or treatments performed on an individual who:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(23)(b)(i)(A): is born with external biological sex characteristics that are irresolvably ambiguous;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(23)(b)(i)(B): is born with 46, XX chromosomes with virilization;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(23)(b)(i)(C): is born with 46, XY chromosomes with undervirilization;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(23)(b)(i)(D): has both ovarian and testicular tissue; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(23)(b)(i)(E): has been diagnosed by a physician, based on genetic or biochemical testing, with a sex development disorder characterized by abnormal sex chromosome structure, sex steroid hormone production, or sex steroid hormone action for a male or female; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(23)(b)(ii): removing a body part:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(23)(b)(ii)(A): because the body part is cancerous or diseased; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(23)(b)(ii)(B): for a reason that is medically necessary, other than to effectuate or facilitate an individual's attempted sex change.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(24): "SPEX" means the Special Purpose Examination of the Federation of State Medical Boards.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(25): 58-1-501; 58-68-501 "Unlawful conduct" means the same as that term is defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-102(26): 58-1-501; 58-68-502 "Unprofessional conduct" means the same as that term is defined in Sections


Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-201 Board.
--------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-201(1): There is created the Osteopathic Physician and Surgeon's Licensing Board consisting of four osteopathic physicians and surgeons and one member of the general public.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-201(2): 58-1-201 The board shall be appointed and serve in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-201(3): 58-1-202; 58-1-203
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-201(3)(a): 58-1-202; 58-1-203 The duties and responsibilities of the board are in accordance with Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-201(3)(b): The board may also designate one of its members on a permanent or rotating basis to:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-201(3)(b)(i): assist the division in reviewing complaints concerning the unlawful or unprofessional conduct of a licensee; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-201(3)(b)(ii): advise the division in its investigation of these complaints.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-201(4): (3) A board member who has, under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-301 Licensure required -- License classifications.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-301(1): 58-1-307; 58-68-305 A license is required to engage in the practice of osteopathic medicine on or for any person in Utah, as an osteopathic physician and surgeon, except as specifically provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-301(2): The division shall issue to a person who qualifies under this chapter a license in the classification of osteopathic physician and surgeon.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302 Qualifications for licensure.
-------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302(1): (2); 63J-1-504; Chapter 67b, Interstate Medical Licensure Compact; 58-68-302.1; Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act; (1)(d); (1)(d); Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act An applicant for licensure as an osteopathic physician and surgeon, except as set forth in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302(1)(a): submit an application in a form prescribed by the division, which may include:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302(1)(a)(i): submissions by the applicant of information maintained by practitioner data banks, as designated by division rule, with respect to the applicant;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302(1)(a)(ii): a record of professional liability claims made against the applicant and settlements paid by or on behalf of the applicant; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302(1)(a)(iii): authorization to use a record coordination and verification service approved by the division in collaboration with the board;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302(1)(b): 63J-1-504 pay a fee determined by the department under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302(1)(c): Chapter 67b, Interstate Medical Licensure Compact; 58-68-302.1; Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act if the applicant is applying to participate in the Interstate Medical Licensure Compact under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302(1)(d): provide satisfactory documentation of having successfully completed a program of professional education preparing an individual as an osteopathic physician and surgeon, as evidenced by:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302(1)(d)(i): having received an earned degree of doctor of osteopathic medicine from an AOA approved medical school or college; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302(1)(d)(ii): submitting a current certification by the Educational Commission for Foreign Medical Graduates or any successor organization approved by the division in collaboration with the board, if the applicant is graduated from an osteopathic medical school or college located outside of the United States or its territories which at the time of the applicant's graduation, met criteria for accreditation by the AOA;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302(1)(e): (1)(d); (1)(d); Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act satisfy the division and board that the applicant:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302(1)(e)(i): (1)(d) has successfully completed 24 months of progressive resident training in an ACGME or AOA approved program after receiving a degree of doctor of osteopathic medicine required under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302(1)(e)(ii): (1)(d); Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302(1)(e)(ii)(A): (1)(d) has successfully completed 12 months of resident training in an ACGME or AOA approved program after receiving a degree of doctor of osteopathic medicine as required under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302(1)(e)(ii)(B): has been accepted in and is successfully participating in progressive resident training in an ACGME or AOA approved program within Utah, in the applicant's second or third year of postgraduate training; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302(1)(e)(ii)(C): Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act has agreed to surrender to the division the applicant's license as an osteopathic physician and surgeon without any proceedings under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302(1)(f): pass the licensing examination sequence required by division rule, as made in collaboration with the board;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302(1)(g): be able to read, write, speak, understand, and be understood in the English language and demonstrate proficiency to the satisfaction of the board, if requested by the board;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302(1)(h): meet with the board and representatives of the division, if requested for the purpose of evaluating the applicant's qualifications for licensure;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302(1)(i): designate:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302(1)(i)(i): a contact person for access to medical records in accordance with the federal Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302(1)(i)(ii): an alternate contact person for access to medical records, in the event the original contact person is unable or unwilling to serve as the contact person for access to medical records; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302(1)(j): establish a method for notifying patients of the identity and location of the contact person and alternate contact person, if the applicant will practice in a location with no other persons licensed under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302(2): (1)(a); (d); (1)(e)(i); (1)(g); (j); (1)(f); (2) An applicant for licensure as an osteopathic physician and surgeon by endorsement who is currently licensed to practice osteopathic medicine in any state other than Utah, a district or territory of the United States, or Canada shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302(2)(a): be currently licensed with a full unrestricted license in good standing in any state, district or territory of the United States, or Canada;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302(2)(b): have been actively engaged in the legal practice of osteopathic medicine in any state, district or territory of the United States, or Canada for not less than 6,000 hours during the five years immediately preceding the day on which the applicant applied for licensure in Utah;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302(2)(c): (1)(a); (d); (1)(e)(i); (1)(g); (j) comply with the requirements for licensure under Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302(2)(d): (1)(f) have passed the licensing examination sequence required in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302(2)(e): not have any investigation or action pending against any health care license of the applicant, not have a health care license that was suspended or revoked in any state, district or territory of the United States, or Canada, and not have surrendered a health care license in lieu of a disciplinary action, unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302(2)(e)(i): the license was subsequently reinstated as a full unrestricted license in good standing; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302(2)(e)(ii): the division in collaboration with the board determines, after full disclosure by the applicant, that:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302(2)(e)(ii)(A): the conduct has been corrected, monitored, and resolved; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302(2)(e)(ii)(B): a mitigating circumstance exists that prevents its resolution, and the division in collaboration with the board is satisfied that, but for the mitigating circumstance, the license would be reinstated;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302(2)(f): submit to a records review, a practice review history, and physical and psychological assessments, if requested by the division in collaboration with the board; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302(2)(g): (2) produce evidence that the applicant meets the requirements of this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302(3): Title 26B, Chapter 2, Part 2, Health Care Facility Licensing and Inspection; (2) An applicant for licensure by endorsement may engage in the practice of medicine under a temporary license while the applicant's application for licensure is being processed by the division, provided:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302(3)(a): the applicant submits a complete application required for temporary licensure to the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302(3)(b): Title 26B, Chapter 2, Part 2, Health Care Facility Licensing and Inspection the applicant submits a written document to the division from:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302(3)(b)(i): Title 26B, Chapter 2, Part 2, Health Care Facility Licensing and Inspection a health care facility licensed under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302(3)(b)(i)(A): invitation of the health care facility; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302(3)(b)(i)(B): the general supervision of a physician practicing at the health care facility; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302(3)(b)(ii): two individuals licensed under this chapter, whose license is in good standing and who practice in the same clinical location, both stating that:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302(3)(b)(ii)(A): the applicant is practicing under the invitation and general supervision of the individual; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302(3)(b)(ii)(B): the applicant will practice at the same clinical location as the individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302(3)(c): (2) the applicant submits a signed certification to the division that the applicant meets the requirements of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302(3)(d): the applicant does not engage in the practice of medicine until the division has issued a temporary license;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302(3)(e): the temporary license is only issued for and may not be extended or renewed beyond the duration of one year from issuance; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302(3)(f): the temporary license expires immediately and prior to the expiration of one year from issuance, upon notification from the division that the applicant's application for licensure by endorsement is denied.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302(4): (3); (3) The division shall issue a temporary license under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302(5): 58-67-302(5)(b)(i); (x) The division may not require  a:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302(5)(a): post-residency board certification; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302(5)(b): 58-67-302(5)(b)(i); (x) a cognitive test when the physician reaches a specified age, unless the test reflects the standards described in Subsections


Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302.1 Qualifications for licensure -- Criminal background check.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302.1(1): Chapter 67b, Interstate Medical Licensure Compact An applicant for participation in the Interstate Medical Licensure Compact under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302.1(1)(a): submit fingerprint cards in a form acceptable to the division at the time the license application is filed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302.1(1)(b): consent to a fingerprint background check conducted by the Bureau of Criminal Identification and the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302.1(2): 53-10-108; (2)(a); 53-10-108 The division shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302.1(2)(a): 53-10-108 in addition to other fees authorized by this chapter, collect from each applicant submitting fingerprints in accordance with this section the fee that the Bureau of Criminal Identification is authorized to collect for the services provided under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302.1(2)(b): (2)(a) submit from each applicant the fingerprint card and the fees described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302.1(2)(c): 53-10-108 obtain and retain in division records a signed waiver approved by the Bureau of Criminal Identification in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302.1(3): 53-10-108; (2)(b) The Bureau of Criminal Identification shall, in accordance with the requirements of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302.1(3)(a): (2)(b) check the fingerprints submitted under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302.1(3)(b): forward the fingerprints to the Federal Bureau of Investigation for a national criminal history background check; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302.1(3)(c): provide the results from the state, regional, and nationwide criminal history background checks to the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302.1(4): Title 53, Chapter 10, Part 2, Bureau of Criminal Identification For purposes of conducting a criminal background check required under this section, the division shall have direct access to criminal background information maintained under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302.1(5): The division may not disseminate outside of the division any criminal history record information that the division obtains from the Bureau of Criminal Identification or the Federal Bureau of Investigation under the criminal background check requirements of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302.1(6): The division may not issue a letter of qualification to participate in the Interstate Medical Licensure Compact until the criminal background check described in this section is completed.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302.5 Restricted licensing of an associate physician.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302.5(1): 58-68-302(1)(a); (c); (1)(d)(i); (1)(g); (j); 58-68-302(1)(d)(i) An individual may apply for a restricted license as an associate physician if the individual:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302.5(1)(a): 58-68-302(1)(a); (c); (1)(d)(i); (1)(g); (j) meets the requirements described in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302.5(1)(b): 58-68-302(1)(d)(i) successfully completes Step 1 and Step 2 of the United States Medical Licensing Examination or the equivalent steps of another board-approved medical licensing examination:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302.5(1)(b)(i): 58-68-302(1)(d)(i) within three years after the day on which the applicant graduates from a program described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302.5(1)(b)(ii): within two years before applying for a restricted license as an associate physician; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302.5(1)(c): is not currently enrolled in and has not completed a residency program.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302.5(2): 58-68-807 Before a licensed associate physician may engage in the practice of medicine, the licensed associate physician shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302.5(2)(a): 58-68-807 enter into a collaborative practice arrangement described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-302.5(2)(b): receive division approval of the collaborative practice arrangement.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-303 Term of license -- Expiration -- Renewal.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-303(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-303(1)(a): The division shall issue each license under this chapter in accordance with a two-year renewal cycle established by division rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-303(1)(b): The division may by rule extend or shorten a renewal period by as much as one year to stagger the renewal cycles the division administers.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-303(2): 58-1-601; 58-68-304(1)(b); (c) At the time of renewal, the licensee shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-303(2)(a): 58-1-601 view a suicide prevention video described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-303(2)(b): show compliance with continuing education renewal requirements; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-303(2)(c): 58-68-304(1)(b); (c) show compliance with the requirement for designation of a contact person and alternate contact person for access to medical records and notice to patients as required by Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-303(3): 58-1-308 Each license issued under this chapter expires on the expiration date shown on the license unless renewed in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-303(4): An individual may not be licensed as an associate physician for more than a total of six years.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-304 License renewal requirements.
-------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-304(1): 58-68-302(1)(i); 58-68-302(1)(j); 58-68-302.5; 58-68-807(4) As a condition precedent for license renewal, each licensee shall, during each two-year licensure cycle or other cycle defined by division rule:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-304(1)(a): complete qualified continuing professional education requirements in accordance with the number of hours and standards defined by division rule in collaboration with the board;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-304(1)(b): 58-68-302(1)(i) appoint a contact person for access to medical records and an alternate contact person for access to medical records in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-304(1)(c): 58-68-302(1)(j) if the licensee practices osteopathic medicine in a location with no other persons licensed under this chapter, provide some method of notice to the licensee's patients of the identity and location of the contact person and alternate contact person for access to medical records for the licensee in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-304(1)(d): 58-68-302.5; 58-68-807(4) if the licensee is an associate physician licensed under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-304(2): 58-68-303 If a renewal period is extended or shortened under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-304(3): (3)(a)(ii); Title 76, Chapter 7, Part 3, Abortion; Title 76, Chapter 7a, Abortion Prohibition
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-304(3)(a): An application to renew a license under this chapter shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-304(3)(a)(i): require a physician to answer the following question: "Do you perform elective abortions in Utah in a location other than a hospital?"; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-304(3)(a)(ii): immediately following the question, contain the following statement: "For purposes of the immediately preceding question, elective abortion means an abortion other than one of the following: removal of a dead fetus, removal of an ectopic pregnancy, an abortion that is necessary to avert the death of a woman, an abortion that is necessary to avert a serious physical risk of substantial impairment of a major bodily function of a woman, an abortion of a fetus that has a defect that is uniformly diagnosable and uniformly lethal, or an abortion where the woman is pregnant as a result of rape or incest."
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-304(3)(b): (3)(a)(ii); Title 76, Chapter 7, Part 3, Abortion; Title 76, Chapter 7a, Abortion Prohibition The statement in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-304(4): Title 76, Chapter 7, Part 3, Abortion; Title 76, Chapter 7a, Abortion Prohibition; (3)(a)(i); (3)(a)(i) In order to assist the Department of Health and Human Services in fulfilling  the department's responsibilities relating to the licensing of a health care facility and the enforcement of
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-304(4)(a): of the name and business address of the physician; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-304(4)(b): (3)(a)(i) that the physician responded positively to the question described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-304(5): (1)(a); 26B-4-204; 26B-4-219 The division shall accept and apply toward the hour requirement in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-305 Exemptions from licensure.
----------------------------------------------------------
In addition to the exemptions from licensure in SectionUtah Code Annotated § 58-68-305(1): an individual rendering aid in an emergency, when no fee or other consideration of value for the service is charged, received, expected, or contemplated;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-305(2): an individual administering a domestic or family remedy;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-305(3): (3)(a)(i); (3)(a); (3)(a)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-305(3)(a): (3)(a)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-305(3)(a)(i): a person engaged in the lawful sale of vitamins, health foods, dietary supplements, herbs, or other products of nature, the sale of which is not otherwise prohibited by state or federal law; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-305(3)(a)(ii): (3)(a)(i) a person acting in good faith for religious reasons, as a matter of conscience, or based on a personal belief, when obtaining or providing any information regarding health care and the use of any product under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-305(3)(b): (3)(a); (3)(a)(i) Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-305(3)(b)(i): permit a person to diagnose any human disease, ailment, injury, infirmity, deformity, pain, or other condition; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-305(3)(b)(ii): (3)(a)(i) prohibit providing truthful and non-misleading information regarding any of the products under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-305(4): a person engaged in good faith in the practice of the religious tenets of any church or religious belief without the use of prescription drugs;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-305(5): 26-1-30; 41-6a-523(1)(a)(vi); 53-10-405(2)(a)(vi); 72-10-502(5)(a)(vi); 77-23-213(3)(a)(vi) an individual authorized by the Department of Health under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-305(6): a medical assistant:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-305(6)(a): administering a vaccine under the general supervision of a physician; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-305(6)(b): under the indirect supervision of a physician, engaging in tasks appropriately delegated by the physician in accordance with the standards and ethics of the practice of medicine, except for:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-305(6)(b)(i): performing surgical procedures;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-305(6)(b)(ii): prescribing prescription medications;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-305(6)(b)(iii): administering anesthesia other than a local anesthetic for minor procedural use; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-305(6)(b)(iv): engaging in other medical practices or procedures as defined by division rule in collaboration with the board;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-305(7): an individual engaging in the practice of osteopathic medicine when:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-305(7)(a): the individual is licensed in good standing as an osteopathic physician in another state with no licensing action pending and no less than 10 years of professional experience;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-305(7)(b): the services are rendered as a public service and for a noncommercial purpose;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-305(7)(c): no fee or other consideration of value is charged, received, expected, or contemplated for the services rendered beyond an amount necessary to cover the proportionate cost of malpractice insurance; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-305(7)(d): the individual does not otherwise engage in unlawful or unprofessional conduct;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-305(8): an individual providing expert testimony in a legal proceeding; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-305(9): an individual who is invited by a school, association, society, or other body approved by the division in collaboration with the board to conduct a clinic or demonstration of the practice of medicine in which patients are treated, if:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-305(9)(a): the individual does not establish a place of business in this state;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-305(9)(b): the individual does not regularly engage in the practice of medicine in this state;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-305(9)(c): the individual holds a current license in good standing to practice medicine issued by another state, district or territory of the United States, or Canada;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-305(9)(d): the primary purpose of the event is the training of others in the practice of medicine; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-305(9)(e): neither the patient nor an insurer is billed for the services performed.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-306 Status of licenses held on the effective date of this chapter.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
An individual holding a current license as an osteopathic physician that was issued under any prior state law is considered to hold a current license in the same classification under this chapter.

Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-401 Grounds for denial of license -- Disciplinary proceedings.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-401(1): (2); 58-1-401; 58-68-503 Subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-401(2): The division may not refuse, revoke, suspend, or in any way restrict an applicant or licensee's license under this chapter solely because the applicant or licensee seeks or participates in mental health or substance abuse treatment.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-402 Authority to assess penalties.
--------------------------------------------------------------
The division in collaboration with the board may assess penalties as described in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-403 Revocation of license -- Nondisciplinary.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
Revocation by the division of a license under Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-501 Unlawful conduct.
-------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-501(1): 58-1-501 "Unlawful conduct" includes, in addition to the definition in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-501(1)(a): buying, selling, or fraudulently obtaining any osteopathic medical diploma, license, certificate, or registration; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-501(1)(b): aiding or abetting the buying, selling, or fraudulently obtaining of any osteopathic medical diploma, license, certificate, or registration;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-501(1)(c): substantially interfering with a licensee's lawful and competent practice of medicine in accordance with this chapter by:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-501(1)(c)(i): any person or entity that manages, owns, operates, or conducts a business having a direct or indirect financial interest in the licensee's professional practice; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-501(1)(c)(ii): anyone other than another physician licensed under this title, who is engaged in direct clinical care or consultation with the licensee in accordance with the standards and ethics of the profession of medicine; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-501(1)(d): entering into a contract that limits a licensee's ability to advise the licensee's patients fully about treatment options or other issues that affect the health care of the licensee's patients.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-501(2): Title 31A, Insurance Code; 58-85-103 "Unlawful conduct" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-501(2)(a): Title 31A, Insurance Code establishing, administering, or enforcing the provisions of a policy of accident and health insurance by an insurer doing business in this state in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-501(2)(b): adopting, implementing, or enforcing utilization management standards related to payment for a licensee's services, provided that:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-501(2)(b)(i): utilization management standards adopted, implemented, and enforced by the payer have been approved by a physician or by a committee that contains one or more physicians; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-501(2)(b)(ii): the utilization management standards does not preclude a licensee from exercising independent professional judgment on behalf of the licensee's patients in a manner that is independent of payment considerations;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-501(2)(c): developing and implementing clinical practice standards that are intended to reduce morbidity and mortality or developing and implementing other medical or surgical practice standards related to the standardization of effective health care practices, provided that:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-501(2)(c)(i): the practice standards and recommendations have been approved by a physician or by a committee that contains one or more physicians; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-501(2)(c)(ii): the practice standards do not preclude a licensee from exercising independent professional judgment on behalf of the licensee's patients in a manner that is independent of payment considerations;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-501(2)(d): requesting or recommending that a patient obtain a second opinion from a licensee;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-501(2)(e): conducting peer review, quality evaluation, quality improvement, risk management, or similar activities designed to identify and address practice deficiencies with health care providers, health care facilities, or the delivery of health care;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-501(2)(f): providing employment supervision or adopting employment requirements that do not interfere with the licensee's ability to exercise independent professional judgment on behalf of the licensee's patients, provided that employment requirements that may not be considered to interfere with an employed licensee's exercise of independent professional judgment include:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-501(2)(f)(i): an employment requirement that restricts the licensee's access to patients with whom the licensee's employer does not have a contractual relationship, either directly or through contracts with one or more third-party payers; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-501(2)(f)(ii): providing compensation incentives that are not related to the treatment of any particular patient;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-501(2)(g): providing benefit coverage information, giving advice, or expressing opinions to a patient or to a family member of a patient to assist the patient or family member in making a decision about health care that has been recommended by a licensee;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-501(2)(h): 58-85-103 in compliance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-501(2)(h)(i): obtaining an investigational drug or investigational device;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-501(2)(h)(ii): administering the investigational drug to an eligible patient; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-501(2)(h)(iii): treating an eligible patient with the investigational drug or investigational device; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-501(2)(i): any otherwise lawful conduct that does not substantially interfere with the licensee's ability to exercise independent professional judgment on behalf of the licensee's patients and that does not constitute the practice of medicine as defined in this chapter.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-502 Unprofessional conduct.
-------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-502(1): 58-1-501; Chapter 17b, Part 8, Dispensing Medical Practitioner and Dispensing Medical Practitioner Clinic Pharmacy; 58-68-302.5; Title 26B, Chapter 4, Part 2, Cannabinoid Research and Medical Cannabis; 76-7-302; 76-7a-201; (1)(a); (e); 58-1-501(1) "Unprofessional conduct" includes, in addition to the definition in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-502(1)(a): using or employing the services of any individual to assist a licensee in any manner not in accordance with the generally recognized practices, standards, or ethics of the profession, state law, or division rule;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-502(1)(b): Chapter 17b, Part 8, Dispensing Medical Practitioner and Dispensing Medical Practitioner Clinic Pharmacy violating the dispensing requirements of
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-502(1)(c): 58-68-302.5 making a material misrepresentation regarding the qualifications for licensure under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-502(1)(d): Title 26B, Chapter 4, Part 2, Cannabinoid Research and Medical Cannabis violating the requirements of
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-502(1)(e): 76-7-302; 76-7a-201 performing or inducing an abortion in violation of the requirements of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-502(1)(f): (1)(a); (e); 58-1-501(1) falsely making an entry in, or altering, a medical record with the intent to conceal:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-502(1)(f)(i): a wrongful or negligent act or omission of an individual licensed under this chapter or an individual under the direction or control of an individual licensed under this chapter; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-502(1)(f)(ii): (1)(a); (e); 58-1-501(1) conduct described in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-502(1)(g): performing or causing to be performed, upon an individual who is less than 18 years old;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-502(1)(g)(i): a primary sex characteristic surgical procedure; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-502(1)(g)(ii): a secondary sex characteristic surgical procedure.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-502(2): 58-85-103; Title 26B, Chapter 4, Part 2, Cannabinoid Research and Medical Cannabis; 26B-4-201; 26B-4-201 "Unprofessional conduct" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-502(2)(a): 58-85-103 in compliance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-502(2)(a)(i): obtaining an investigational drug or investigational device;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-502(2)(a)(ii): administering the investigational drug to an eligible patient; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-502(2)(a)(iii): treating an eligible patient with the investigational drug or investigational device; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-502(2)(b): Title 26B, Chapter 4, Part 2, Cannabinoid Research and Medical Cannabis; 26B-4-201; 26B-4-201 in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-502(2)(b)(i): 26B-4-201 when registered as a qualified medical provider or acting as a limited medical provider, as those terms are defined in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-503 Penalties and administrative actions for unlawful and unprofessional conduct.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-503(1): 58-68-501; 58-1-501 Any person who violates the unlawful conduct provisions of Section

Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-503(2)(a)(i): assessing administrative penalties; or

Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-503(4): 58-68-501; 58-68-502; Chapter 1, Division of Professional Licensing Act; Chapter 37, Utah Controlled Substances Act; Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act; (4)(a); (4)(a); 58-1-401; Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-503(4)(a): 58-68-501; 58-68-502; Chapter 1, Division of Professional Licensing Act; Chapter 37, Utah Controlled Substances Act; Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act If the division concludes that an individual has violated the provisions of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-503(4)(a)(i): issue a citation to the individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-503(4)(a)(ii): attempt to negotiate a stipulated settlement; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-503(4)(a)(iii): Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act notify the individual that an adjudicative proceeding conducted under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-503(4)(b): (4)(a); (4)(a) The division may take the following action against an individual who is in violation of a provision described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-503(4)(b)(i): assess a fine of up to $10,000 per single violation or $2,000 per day of ongoing violation, whichever is greater, in accordance with a fine schedule established by rule; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-503(4)(b)(ii): (4)(a) order to cease and desist from the behavior that constitutes a violation of provisions described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-503(4)(c): 58-1-401 Except for an administrative fine and a cease and desist order, the licensure sanctions cited in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-503(4)(d): Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act Each citation issued under this section shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-503(4)(d)(i): be in writing;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-503(4)(d)(ii): Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act clearly describe or explain:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-503(4)(d)(ii)(A): the nature of the violation, including a reference to the provision of the chapter, rule, or order alleged to have been violated;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-503(4)(d)(ii)(B): Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act that the recipient must notify the division in writing within 20 calendar days from the day on which the citation is served if the recipient wishes to contest the citation at a hearing conducted under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-503(4)(d)(ii)(C): the consequences of failure to timely contest the citation or pay the fine assessed by the citation within the time specified in the citation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-503(4)(d)(iii): be served in accordance with the requirements of the Utah Rules of Civil Procedure.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-503(4)(e): If the individual to whom the citation is issued fails to request a hearing to contest the citation within 20 calendar days from the day on which the citation is served, the citation becomes the final order of the division and is not subject to further agency review.  The period to contest the citation may be extended by the division for cause.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-503(4)(f): The division may refuse to issue or renew or suspend, revoke, or place on probation the license of an individual who fails to comply with a citation after the citation becomes final.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-503(4)(g): The failure of an applicant for licensure to comply with a citation after it becomes final is a ground for denial of a license.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-503(4)(h): No citation may be issued under this section after the expiration of one year following the date on which the violation that is the subject of the citation is reported to the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-503(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-503(5)(a): The director may collect a penalty imposed under this section that is not paid by:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-503(5)(a)(i): referring the matter to a collection agency; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-503(5)(a)(ii): bringing an action in the district court of the county where the person against whom the penalty is imposed resides or in the county where the office of the director is located.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-503(5)(b): A county attorney or the attorney general of the state shall provide legal assistance and advice to the director in an action to collect a penalty.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-503(5)(c): A court shall award reasonable attorney fees and costs to the prevailing party in an action brought by the division to collect a penalty.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-601 Mentally incompetent or incapacitated osteopathic physician.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-601(1): 75-1-201; 26B-5-301 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-601(1)(a): 75-1-201 "Incapacitated person" means a person who is incapacitated, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-601(1)(b): "Licensee" means an individual licensed under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-601(1)(c): 26B-5-301 "Mental illness" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-601(2): Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act If a court of competent jurisdiction determines a licensee is an incapacitated person or that the licensee has a mental illness and is unable to safely engage in the practice of medicine, the director shall immediately suspend the license of the licensee upon the entry of the judgment of the court, without further proceedings under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-601(3): 58-1-109; Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act; (4)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-601(3)(a): If the division and a majority of the board find reasonable cause to believe a licensee, who is not determined judicially to be an incapacitated person or to have a mental illness, is incapable of practicing osteopathic medicine with reasonable skill regarding the safety of patients, because of illness, excessive use of drugs or alcohol, or as a result of any mental or physical condition, the board shall recommend that the director file a petition with the division, and cause the petition to be served upon the licensee with a notice of hearing on the sole issue of the capacity of the licensee to competently and safely engage in the practice of medicine.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-601(3)(b): 58-1-109; Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act; (4) The hearing shall be conducted under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-601(4): Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-601(4)(a): Every individual who accepts the privilege of being licensed under this chapter gives consent to:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-601(4)(a)(i): submitting at the licensee's own expense to an immediate mental or physical examination when directed in writing by the division and a majority of the board to do so; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-601(4)(a)(ii): the admissibility of the reports of the examining physician's testimony or examination, and waives all objections on the ground the reports constitute a privileged communication.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-601(4)(b): The examination may be ordered by the division, with the consent of a majority of the board, only upon a finding of reasonable cause to believe:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-601(4)(b)(i): the licensee has a mental illness, is incapacitated, or otherwise unable to practice medicine with reasonable skill and safety; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-601(4)(b)(ii): immediate action by the division and the board is necessary to prevent harm to the licensee's patients or the general public.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-601(4)(c): Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-601(4)(c)(i): Failure of a licensee to submit to the examination ordered under this section is a ground for the division's immediate suspension of the licensee's license by written order of the director.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-601(4)(c)(ii): Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act The division may enter the order of suspension without further compliance with
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-601(5): (2); (3); 58-1-108; 58-1-109
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-601(5)(a): (2); (3) A licensee whose license is suspended under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-601(5)(b): 58-1-108; 58-1-109 The hearing held under this subsection shall be conducted in accordance with Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-601(6): A licensee whose license is revoked, suspended, or in any way restricted under this section may request the division and the board to consider, at reasonable intervals, evidence presented by the licensee, under procedures established by division rule, regarding any change in the licensee's condition, to determine whether:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-601(6)(a): the licensee is or is not able to safely and competently engage in the practice of medicine; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-68-601(6)(b): the licensee is qualified to have the licensee's license to practice under this chapter restored completely or in part.
