-------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-304(1): 58-1-601 Prior to license renewal, each licensee shall, during each two-year licensure cycle or other cycle defined by division rule:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-304(1)(a): 58-1-601 view a suicide prevention video described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-304(1)(b): complete qualified continuing professional education requirements as defined by division rule made in collaboration with the board.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-304(2): 58-70a-303 If a renewal period is extended or shortened under Section


Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-305 Exemptions from licensure.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-305(1): 58-1-307; (2) In addition to the exemptions from licensure in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-305(2): (1) Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-305(2)(a): that are a part of the education program;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-305(2)(b): that are conducted at an affiliated medical facility under the direct supervision of a:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-305(2)(b)(i): physician associated with the program; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-305(2)(b)(ii): licensed physician assistant associated with the medical faculty; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-305(2)(c): for which the program accepts in writing the responsibility for the student.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-306 Temporary license.
---------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-306(1): 58-70a-302; (2) An applicant for licensure as a physician assistant who has met all qualifications for licensure except passing an examination component as required in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-306(2): 58-70a-302(3)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-306(2)(a): 58-70a-302(3) The applicant shall submit to the division evidence of completion of a physician assistant program as defined in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-306(2)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-306(2)(b)(i): The temporary license shall be issued for a period not to exceed 120 days to allow the applicant to pass the Physician Assistant National Certifying Examination.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-306(2)(b)(ii): The temporary license may not be renewed or extended.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-306(2)(c): A temporary license holder shall work under the direct supervision of a physician.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-307 Collaboration requirements -- Clinical practice experience -- Requirements for independent practice in a new specialty.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-307(1): As used in this section, "collaboration" means the interaction and relationship that a physician assistant has with one or more physicians in which:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-307(1)(a): the physician assistant and physician are cognizant of the physician assistant's qualifications and limitations in caring for patients;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-307(1)(b): the physician assistant, while responsible for care that the physician assistant provides, consults with the physician or physicians regarding patient care; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-307(1)(c): the physician or physicians give direction and guidance to the physician assistant.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-307(2): 58-70a-501(2); (3); (2); 58-70a-501.1(4)(d) A physician assistant with less than 10,000 hours of post-graduate clinical practice experience shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-307(2)(a): 58-70a-501(2); (3) practice under written policies and procedures established at a practice level that:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-307(2)(a)(i): 58-70a-501(2); (3) describe how collaboration will occur in accordance with this section and Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-307(2)(a)(ii): describe methods for evaluating the physician assistant's competency, knowledge, and skills;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-307(2)(b): (2) provide a copy of the written policies and procedures and documentation of compliance with this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-307(2)(c): 58-70a-501.1(4)(d) except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-307(3): 58-70a-501.1(4)(d); (3)(a); 58-70a-501(2); (3)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-307(3)(a): 58-70a-501.1(4)(d) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-307(3)(a)(i): a physician; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-307(3)(a)(ii): a licensed physician assistant with more than 10,000 hours of practice experience in the same specialty as the physician assistant.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-307(3)(b): (3)(a); 58-70a-501(2); (3) The collaborative agreement described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-307(3)(b)(i): 58-70a-501(2); (3) describe how collaboration under this section and Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-307(3)(b)(ii): be kept on file at the physician assistant's practice location; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-307(3)(b)(iii): be provided by the physician assistant to the board upon the board's request.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-307(4): A physician assistant who wishes to change specialties to another specialty in which the PA has less than 4,000 hours of experience shall engage in collaboration for a minimum of 4,000 hours with a physician who is trained and experienced in the specialty to which the physician assistant is changing.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-401 Grounds for denial of license -- Disciplinary proceedings.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-401(1): (2); 58-1-401 Subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-401(1)(a): refusing to issue a license to an applicant;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-401(1)(b): refusing to renew the license of a licensee;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-401(1)(c): revoking, suspending, restricting, or placing on probation the license of a licensee;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-401(1)(d): issuing a public or private reprimand to a licensee; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-401(1)(e): issuing a cease and desist order.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-401(2): The division may not refuse, revoke, suspend, or in any way restrict an applicant or licensee's license under this chapter solely because the applicant or licensee seeks or participates in mental health or substance abuse treatment.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501 Scope of practice.
---------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501(1): A physician assistant may provide any medical services that are not specifically prohibited under this chapter or rules adopted under this chapter, and that are within the physician assistant's skills and scope of competence.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501(2): 58-70a-307 A physician assistant shall consult, collaborate with, and refer to appropriate members of the health care team:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501(2)(a): as indicated by the patient's condition;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501(2)(b): based on the physician assistant's education, experience, and competencies;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501(2)(c): the applicable standard of care; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501(2)(d): 58-70a-307 if applicable, in accordance with the requirements described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501(3): 58-70a-307; (2) Subject to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501(3)(a): shall be determined at the physician assistant's practice, including decisions made by the physician assistant's:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501(3)(a)(i): employer;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501(3)(a)(ii): group;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501(3)(a)(iii): hospital service; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501(3)(a)(iv): health care facility credentialing and privileging system; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501(3)(b): may also be determined by a managed care organization with whom the physician assistant is a network provider.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501(4): A physician assistant may only provide healthcare services:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501(4)(a): for which the physician assistant has been trained and credentialed, privileged, or authorized to perform; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501(4)(b): that are within the physician assistant's practice specialty.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501(5): A physician assistant may authenticate through a signature, certification, stamp, verification, affidavit, or endorsement any document that may be authenticated by a physician and that is within the physician assistant's scope of practice.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501(6): A physician assistant is responsible for the care that the physician assistant provides.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501(7): (7); (7)(a)(i)(A); (B); (c); (e); (7)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501(7)(a): (7); (7)(a)(i)(A); (B) As used in this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501(7)(a)(i): (7)(a)(i)(A); (B) "ALS/ACLS certification" means a certification:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501(7)(a)(i)(A): in advanced life support by the American Red Cross;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501(7)(a)(i)(B): in advanced cardiac life support by the American Heart Association; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501(7)(a)(i)(C): (7)(a)(i)(A); (B) that is equivalent to a certification described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501(7)(a)(ii): "Minimal sedation anxiolysis" means creating a drug induced state:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501(7)(a)(ii)(A): during which a patient responds normally to verbal commands;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501(7)(a)(ii)(B): which may impair cognitive function and physical coordination; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501(7)(a)(ii)(C): which does not affect airway, reflexes, or ventilatory and cardiovascular function.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501(7)(b): (c); (e) Except as provided in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501(7)(c): A physician assistant may perform minimal sedation anxiolysis if the procedure is within the physician assistant's scope of practice.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501(7)(d): A physician assistant may perform rapid sequence induction for intubation of a patient if:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501(7)(d)(i): the procedure is within the physician assistant's scope of practice;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501(7)(d)(ii): the physician assistant holds a valid ALS/ACLS certification and is credentialed and privileged at the hospital where the procedure is performed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501(7)(d)(iii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501(7)(d)(iii)(A): a qualified physician is not available and able to perform the procedure; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501(7)(d)(iii)(B): the procedure is performed by the physician assistant under supervision of or delegation by a physician.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501(7)(e): (7)(b) Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501(7)(e)(i): in an intensive care unit of a hospital;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501(7)(e)(ii): for the purpose of enabling a patient to tolerate ventilator support or intubation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501(7)(e)(iii): under supervision of or delegation by a physician whose usual scope of practice includes the procedure.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501(8): Title 58, Chapter 17b, Pharmacy Practice Act
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501(8)(a): A physician assistant may prescribe or administer an appropriate controlled substance that is within the physician assistant's scope of practice if the physician assistant holds a Utah controlled substance license and a DEA registration.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501(8)(b): A physician assistant may prescribe, order, administer, and procure a drug or medical device that is within the physician assistant's scope of practice.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501(8)(c): Title 58, Chapter 17b, Pharmacy Practice Act A physician assistant may dispense a drug if dispensing the drug:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501(8)(c)(i): Title 58, Chapter 17b, Pharmacy Practice Act is permitted under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501(8)(c)(ii): is within the physician assistant's scope of practice.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501(9): 76-7-302; 76-7a-201 A physician assistant may not perform or induce an abortion in violation of the requirements of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501(10): A physician assistant practicing independently may only perform or provide a health care service that:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501(10)(a): is appropriate to perform or provide outside of a health care facility; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501(10)(b): the physician assistant has been trained and credentialed or authorized to provide or perform independently without physician supervision.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501(11): A physician assistant, while practicing as a physician assistant:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501(11)(a): shall wear an identification badge showing the physician assistant's license classification as a physician assistant;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501(11)(b): shall identify themselves to a patient as a physician assistant; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501(11)(c): may not identify themselves to any person in connection with activities allowed under this chapter other than as a physician assistant or PA.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501.1 Qualifications for a physician assistant specializing in mental health care -- Rulemaking.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501.1(1): (4) A physician assistant specializing in mental health care under this section shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501.1(1)(a): hold a valid license as a physician assistant under this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501.1(1)(b): obtain and maintain a Certification of Added Qualification in psychiatry issued by the National Commission on Certification of Physician Assistants;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501.1(1)(c): complete:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501.1(1)(c)(i): an accredited doctorate level academic program for physician assistants approved by the division in collaboration with the board;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501.1(1)(c)(ii): a post-graduate certificate program for physician assistants to practice within psychiatric and mental health care that is approved by the division in collaboration with the board; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501.1(1)(c)(iii): a post-graduate residency in psychiatry and additional clinical practice or coursework in accordance with requirements approved by the division in collaboration with the board; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501.1(1)(d): (4) complete the clinical practice requirement described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501.1(2): (1)(c)(i); (ii) The division, in collaboration with the board, may approve a program under Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501.1(2)(a): is an accredited doctoral level or post-graduate academic program;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501.1(2)(b): includes at least 1,600 hours of accredited instructional hours that results in:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501.1(2)(b)(i): a doctorate degree or equivalent; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501.1(2)(b)(ii): a graduate level certification in psychiatric mental health; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501.1(2)(c): provides graduate level instruction in:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501.1(2)(c)(i): at least 2 credit hours or equivalent of neuroscience;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501.1(2)(c)(ii): health care law and ethics;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501.1(2)(c)(iii): health care delivery;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501.1(2)(c)(iv): evidence-based mental health medicine;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501.1(2)(c)(v): evidence-based mental health research;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501.1(2)(c)(vi): at least 3 credit hours or equivalent of psychotherapy;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501.1(2)(c)(vii): psychiatric assessment;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501.1(2)(c)(viii): crisis intervention;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501.1(2)(c)(ix): group and family therapy;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501.1(2)(c)(x): suicide risk assessment;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501.1(2)(c)(xi): violence risk assessment;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501.1(2)(c)(xii): at least 3 credit hours or equivalent of psychopharmacology;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501.1(2)(c)(xiii): a comprehensive review of mental disorders as characterized by the current Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, including diagnostic criteria and prevalence; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501.1(2)(c)(xiv): medical and therapeutic management of each condition across the lifespan in diverse populations and in a variety of clinical settings.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501.1(3): (1)(c)(iii); (2)(b); (c); (1)(c) The division, in collaboration with the board, may:

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501.2(1): 58-70a-501.1; 58-70a-501

Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-501.2(4)(b)(ii): under supervision of a physician whose usual scope of practice includes neurostimulation or neuromodulation.

Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-503 Unprofessional conduct.
--------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-503(1): Chapter 17b, Part 8, Dispensing Medical Practitioner and Dispensing Medical Practitioner Clinic Pharmacy; (1)(a); (e); 58-1-501(1); Title 26B, Chapter 4, Part 2, Cannabinoid Research and Medical Cannabis "Unprofessional conduct" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-503(1)(a): violation of a patient confidence to any person who does not have a legal right and a professional need to know the information concerning the patient;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-503(1)(b): knowingly prescribing, selling, giving away, or directly or indirectly administering, or offering to prescribe, sell, furnish, give away, or administer any prescription drug except for a legitimate medical purpose upon a proper diagnosis indicating use of that drug in the amounts prescribed or provided;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-503(1)(c): prescribing prescription drugs for oneself or administering prescription drugs to oneself, except those that have been legally prescribed for the physician assistant by a licensed practitioner and that are used in accordance with the prescription order for the condition diagnosed;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-503(1)(d): in a practice that has physician assistant ownership interests, failure to allow a physician the independent final decision making authority on treatment decisions for the physician's patient;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-503(1)(e): Chapter 17b, Part 8, Dispensing Medical Practitioner and Dispensing Medical Practitioner Clinic Pharmacy violating the dispensing requirements of

Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-507 Volunteer health care services.
----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-507(1): A physician assistant may provide health care services as a volunteer for a charitable organization or at a public or private event, including a religious event, youth camp, community event, or health fair, if the physician assistant:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-507(1)(a): receives no compensation for such services; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-507(1)(b): provides the health care services in a manner that is consistent with the physician assistant's education, experience, and scope of practice.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70a-507(2): 58-70a-501(8) Notwithstanding Subsection


Utah Code Annotated - Title 58 - Chapter 70b - Anesthesiologist Assistant Licensing Act
***************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 58-70b-101 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 58-70b-101(1): Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act; Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act "Anesthesiologist" means an individual who:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70b-101(1)(a): Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act; Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act is licensed under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70b-101(1)(b): has completed a residency program in anesthesiology.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70b-101(2): "Anesthesiologist assistant" means an individual licensed under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70b-101(3): 58-67-201 "Board" means the Physicians Licensing Board created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70b-101(4): "Practice of assisting an anesthesiologist" means personally performing the health care services delegated to the anesthesiologist assistant by the supervising anesthesiologist in accordance with the acceptable medical practice and the American Society of Anesthesiologists' guidance for best practice of anesthesia in a care team model.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70b-101(5): "Supervision standards" means standards established by the division through rule that:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70b-101(5)(a): prohibit an anesthesiologist from supervising more than four anesthesiologist assistants at any one time; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70b-101(5)(b): comply with the rules and regulations for anesthesia service reimbursement created by the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services to the extent that the rules and regulations do not conflict with state law.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-70b-102 Rulemaking.
--------------------------------------------
In accordance with

Utah Code Annotated § 58-70b-201 Board.
---------------------------------------
The board shall regulate anesthesiologist assistants.

Utah Code Annotated § 58-70b-301 Licensure required -- Supervision -- Issuance of licenses.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70b-301(1): 58-1-307 Beginning January 1, 2023, and except as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70b-301(1)(a): a license is required to engage in the practice of assisting an anesthesiologist; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70b-301(1)(b): the practice of assisting an anesthesiologist requires compliance with supervision standards.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70b-301(2): The division shall issue to any individual who qualifies under this chapter a license to practice as an anesthesiologist assistant.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-70b-302 Qualifications for licensure.
--------------------------------------------------------------
Each applicant for licensure as an anesthesiologist assistant under this chapter shall:Utah Code Annotated § 58-70b-302(1): submit an application on a form established by the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70b-302(2): 63J-1-504 pay a fee determined by the division under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70b-302(3): provide satisfactory documentation of having graduated from a program certified by the Commission on Accreditation of Allied Health Education Programs or the commission's successor organization;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70b-302(4): (3) within 12 months of completing the training under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70b-302(5): (4) have the certification described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 58-70b-303 Term of license -- Expiration -- Renewal.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70b-303(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70b-303(1)(a): The division shall issue each license under this chapter in accordance with a two-year renewal cycle established by rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70b-303(1)(b): The division may by rule extend or shorten a renewal cycle by as much as one year to stagger the renewal cycles the division administers.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70b-303(2): Each licensee shall, at the time of applying for renewal, demonstrate compliance with continuing education requirements established through rule by the division in collaboration with the board.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70b-303(3): 58-1-308 Each license automatically expires on the expiration date shown on the license unless the licensee renews the license in accordance with Section


Utah Code Annotated § 58-70b-401 Unlawful conduct.
--------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70b-401(1): An individual commits unlawful conduct by:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70b-401(1)(a): using the title "anesthesiologist assistant" or any other title or designation tending to indicate that the individual is an anesthesiologist assistant unless that individual has a current license as an anesthesiologist assistant issued under this chapter; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70b-401(1)(b): engaging in the practice of assisting an anesthesiologist without being an anesthesiologist assistant.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70b-401(2): An anesthesiologist assistant commits unlawful conduct by engaging in the practice of assisting an anesthesiologist without complying with supervision standards.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-70b-402 Unprofessional conduct.
--------------------------------------------------------
An anesthesiologist assistant commits unprofessional conduct by:Utah Code Annotated § 58-70b-402(1): engaging in any act or practice in a professional capacity which the licensee is not competent to perform through training or experience;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70b-402(2): failing to refer a client to other competent professionals when the licensee is unable or unwilling to adequately support or serve the client;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70b-402(3): failing to maintain the confidentiality of any information received from a client, unless released by the client or otherwise authorized or required by law; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70b-402(4): exploiting a client for personal advantage, profit, or interest.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 58 - Chapter 70c - PA Licensure Compact
*******************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 58-70c-101 Section 1 -- Purpose.
------------------------------------------------------
In order to strengthen access to Medical Services, and in recognition of the advances in the delivery of Medical Services, the Participating States of the PA Licensure Compact have allied in common purpose to develop a comprehensive process that complements the existing authority of State Licensing Boards to license and discipline PAs and seeks to enhance the portability of a License to practice as a PA while safeguarding the safety of patients. This Compact allows Medical Services to be provided by PAs, via the mutual recognition of the Licensees Qualifying License by other Compact Participating States. This Compact also adopts the prevailing standard for PA licensure and affirms that the practice and delivery of Medical Services by the PA occurs where the patient is located at the time of the patient encounter, and therefore requires the PA to be under the jurisdiction of the State Licensing Board where the patient is located. State Licensing Boards that participate in this Compact retain the jurisdiction to impose Adverse Action against a Compact Privilege in that State issued to a PA through the procedures of this Compact. The PA Licensure Compact will alleviate burdens for military families by allowing active duty military personnel and their spouses to obtain a Compact Privilege based on having an unrestricted License in good standing from a Participating State.

Utah Code Annotated § 58-70c-102 Section 1 -- Definitions.
----------------------------------------------------------
In this Compact:

Utah Code Annotated § 58-70c-103 Section 3 -- State Participation in this Compact.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A. To participate in this Compact, a Participating State shall:

Utah Code Annotated § 58-70c-104 Section 4 -- Compact Privilege.
----------------------------------------------------------------
A. To exercise the Compact Privilege, a Licensee must:

Utah Code Annotated § 58-70c-105 Section 5 -- Designation of the State from Which Licensee is Applying for a Compact Privilege.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A. Upon a Licensee's application for a Compact Privilege, the Licensee shall identify to the Commission the Participating State from which the Licensee is applying, in accordance with applicable Rules adopted by the Commission, and subject to the following requirements:

Utah Code Annotated § 58-70c-106 Section 6 -- Adverse Actions.
--------------------------------------------------------------
A. A Participating State in which a Licensee is licensed shall have exclusive power to impose Adverse Action against the Qualifying License issued by that Participating State.

Utah Code Annotated § 58-70c-107 Section 7 -- Establishment of the PA Licensure Compact Commission.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A. The Participating States hereby create and establish a joint government agency and national administrative body known as the PA Licensure Compact Commission. The Commission is an instrumentality of the Compact States acting jointly and not an instrumentality of any one State. The Commission shall come into existence on or after the effective date of the Compact as set forth in Section 11.A.

Utah Code Annotated § 58-70c-108 Section 8 -- Data System.
----------------------------------------------------------
A. The Commission shall provide for the development, maintenance, operation, and utilization of a coordinated data and reporting system containing licensure, Adverse Action, and the reporting of the existence of Significant Investigative Information on all licensed PAs and applicants denied a License in Participating States.

Utah Code Annotated § 58-70c-109 Section 9 -- Rulemaking.
---------------------------------------------------------
A. The Commission shall exercise its Rulemaking powers pursuant to the criteria set forth in this Section and the Rules adopted thereunder. Commission Rules shall become binding as of the date specified by the Commission for each Rule.

Utah Code Annotated § 58-70c-110 Section 10 -- Oversight, Dispute Resolution, and Enforcement.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A. Oversight

Utah Code Annotated § 58-70c-111 Section 11 -- Date of Implementation of the PA Licensure Compact Commission.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A. This Compact shall come into effect on the date on which this Compact statute is enacted into law in the seventh Participating State.

Utah Code Annotated § 58-70c-112 Section 12 -- Construction and Severability.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
A. This Compact and the Commission's rulemaking authority shall be liberally construed so as to effectuate the purposes, and the implementation and administration of the Compact. Provisions of the Compact expressly authorizing or requiring the promulgation of Rules shall not be construed to limit the Commission's rulemaking authority solely for those purposes.

Utah Code Annotated § 58-70c-113 Section 13 -- Binding Effect of Compact.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
A. Nothing herein prevents the enforcement of any other law of a Participating State that is not inconsistent with this Compact.

Utah Code Annotated § 58-70c-201 Rulemaking authority -- State authority over scope of practice.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70c-201(1): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act The division may make rules in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 58-70c-201(2): 58-70c-101; 58-70c-113; 58-70c-101; 58-70c-113 Notwithstanding any provision in Sections


Utah Code Annotated - Title 58 - Chapter 71 - Naturopathic Physician Practice Act
*********************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-101 Title.
--------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Naturopathic Physician Practice Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
In addition to the definitions in SectionUtah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(1): 58-72-102 "Acupuncture" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(2): Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act "Administrative penalty" means a monetary fine imposed by the division for acts or omissions determined to constitute unprofessional or unlawful conduct, as a result of an adjudicative proceeding conducted in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(3): 58-37-2 "Controlled substance" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(4): (4)(a); (4)(a); (4)(a) "Diagnose" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(4)(a): to examine in any manner another individual, parts of an individual's body, substances, fluids, or materials excreted, taken, or removed from an individual's body, or produced by an individual's body, to determine the source, nature, kind, or extent of a disease or other physical or mental condition;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(4)(b): (4)(a) to attempt to conduct an examination or determination described under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(4)(c): (4)(a) to hold oneself out as making or to represent that one is making an examination or determination as described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(4)(d): (4)(a) to make an examination or determination as described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(5): "Local anesthesia" means an agent, whether a natural medicine or nonscheduled prescription drug, which:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(5)(a): is applied topically or by injection associated with the performance of minor office procedures;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(5)(b): has the ability to produce loss of sensation to a targeted area of an individual's body;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(5)(c): does not cause loss of consciousness or produce general sedation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(5)(d): is part of the competent practice of naturopathic medicine during minor office procedures.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(6): "Medical naturopathic assistant" means an unlicensed individual working under the direct and immediate supervision of a licensed naturopathic physician and engaged in specific tasks assigned by the licensed naturopathic physician in accordance with the standards and ethics of the profession.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(7): (8)(d); (7)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(7)(a): (8)(d) "Minor office procedures" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(7)(a)(i): the use of operative, electrical, or other methods for repair and care of superficial lacerations, abrasions, and benign lesions;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(7)(a)(ii): removal of foreign bodies located in the superficial tissues, excluding the eye or ear;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(7)(a)(iii): the use of antiseptics and local anesthetics in connection with minor office surgical procedures; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(7)(a)(iv): (8)(d) percutaneous injection into skin, tendons, ligaments, muscles, and joints with:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(7)(a)(iv)(A): (8)(d) local anesthesia or a prescription drug described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(7)(a)(iv)(B): natural substances.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(7)(b): (7)(a) "Minor office procedures" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(7)(b)(i): general or spinal anesthesia;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(7)(b)(ii): (7)(a) office procedures more complicated or extensive than those set forth in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(7)(b)(iii): procedures involving the eye; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(7)(b)(iv): any office procedure involving nerves, veins, or arteries.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(8): 58-71-203 "Natural medicine" means any:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(8)(a): food, food extract, dietary supplement as defined by the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act, 21 U.S.C. Sec. 301 et seq., homeopathic remedy, or plant substance that is not designated a prescription drug or controlled substance;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(8)(b): over-the-counter medication;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(8)(c): other nonprescription substance, the prescription or administration of which is not otherwise prohibited or restricted under federal or state law; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(8)(d): 58-71-203 prescription drug:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(8)(d)(i): the prescription of which is consistent with the competent practice of naturopathic medicine;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(8)(d)(ii): that is not a controlled substance except for testosterone; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(8)(d)(iii): 58-71-203 that is not any of the following as determined by the federal Food and Drug Administration's general drug category list:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(8)(d)(iii)(A): an anticoagulant for the management of a bleeding disorder;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(8)(d)(iii)(B): an anticonvulsant;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(8)(d)(iii)(C): an antineoplastic;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(8)(d)(iii)(D): an antipsychotic;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(8)(d)(iii)(E): a barbiturate;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(8)(d)(iii)(F): a cytotoxic;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(8)(d)(iii)(G): a sedative;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(8)(d)(iii)(H): a sleeping drug;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(8)(d)(iii)(I): a tranquilizer; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(8)(d)(iii)(J): 58-71-203 any drug category added after April 1, 2022, unless the division determines the drug category to be consistent with the practice of naturopathic medicine under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(9): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(9)(a): "Naturopathic childbirth" means uncomplicated natural childbirth assisted by a naturopathic physician.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(9)(b): "Naturopathic childbirth" includes the use of:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(9)(b)(i): natural medicines; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(9)(b)(ii): uncomplicated episiotomy.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(9)(c): "Naturopathic childbirth" does not include the use of:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(9)(c)(i): forceps delivery;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(9)(c)(ii): general or spinal anesthesia;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(9)(c)(iii): caesarean section delivery; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(9)(c)(iv): induced labor or abortion.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(10): Chapter 73, Chiropractic Physician Practice Act
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(10)(a): "Naturopathic mobilization therapy" means manually administering mechanical treatment of body structures or tissues for the purpose of restoring normal physiological function to the body by normalizing and balancing the musculoskeletal system of the body.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(10)(b): "Naturopathic mobilization therapy" does not mean manipulation or adjustment of the joints of the human body beyond the elastic barrier.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(10)(c): Chapter 73, Chiropractic Physician Practice Act "Naturopathic mobilization therapy" does not include manipulation as used in
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(11): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(11)(a): "Naturopathic physical medicine" means the use of the physical agents of air, water, heat, cold, sound, light, and electromagnetic nonionizing radiation, and the physical modalities of electrotherapy, acupuncture, diathermy, ultraviolet light, ultrasound, hydrotherapy, naturopathic mobilization therapy, and exercise.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(11)(b): "Naturopathic physical medicine" does not include the practice of physical therapy or physical rehabilitation.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(12): "Naturopathic physician" means an individual licensed under this chapter to engage in the practice of naturopathic medicine.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(13): (13)(a) "Practice of naturopathic medicine" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(13)(a): a system of primary health care for the prevention, diagnosis, and treatment of human health conditions, injuries, and diseases that uses education, natural medicines, and natural therapies, to support and stimulate the patient's intrinsic self-healing processes by:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(13)(a)(i): using naturopathic childbirth, but only if:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(13)(a)(i)(A): the licensee meets standards of the American College of Naturopathic Obstetricians (ACNO) or ACNO's successor as determined by the division in collaboration with the board; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(13)(a)(i)(B): the licensee follows a written plan for naturopathic physicians practicing naturopathic childbirth approved by the division in collaboration with the board, which includes entering into an agreement with a consulting physician and surgeon or osteopathic physician, in cases where the scope of practice of naturopathic childbirth may be exceeded and specialty care and delivery is indicated, detailing the guidelines by which the naturopathic physician will:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(13)(a)(i)(B)(I): refer patients to the consulting physician; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(13)(a)(i)(B)(II): consult with the consulting physician;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(13)(a)(ii): using naturopathic mobilization therapy;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(13)(a)(iii): using naturopathic physical medicine;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(13)(a)(iv): using minor office procedures;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(13)(a)(v): prescribing or administering natural medicine;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(13)(a)(vi): prescribing medical equipment and devices, diagnosing by the use of medical equipment and devices, and administering therapy or treatment by the use of medical devices necessary and consistent with the competent practice of naturopathic medicine;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(13)(a)(vii): prescribing barrier devices for contraception;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(13)(a)(viii): using dietary therapy;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(13)(a)(ix): taking and using diagnostic x-rays, electrocardiograms, ultrasound, and physiological function tests;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(13)(a)(x): taking of body fluids for clinical laboratory tests and using the results of the tests in diagnosis;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(13)(a)(xi): taking of a history from and conducting of a physical examination upon a human patient; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(13)(a)(xii): administering local anesthesia during the performance of a minor office procedure;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(13)(b): (13)(a) to maintain an office or place of business for the purpose of doing any of the acts described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(13)(c): to use, in the conduct of any occupation or profession pertaining to the diagnosis or treatment of human diseases or conditions, in any printed material, stationery, letterhead, envelopes, signs, or advertisements, the designation "naturopathic physician," "naturopathic doctor," "naturopath," "doctor of naturopathic medicine," "doctor of naturopathy," "naturopathic medical doctor," "naturopathic medicine," "naturopathic health care," "naturopathy," "N.D.," "N.M.D.," or any combination of these designations in any manner that might cause a reasonable person to believe the individual using the designation is a licensed naturopathic physician.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(14): "Prescribe" means to issue a prescription:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(14)(a): orally or in writing; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(14)(b): by telephone, facsimile transmission, computer, or other electronic means of communication as defined by division rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(15): "Prescription device" means an instrument, apparatus, implement, machine, contrivance, implant, in vitro reagent, or other similar or related article, and any component part or accessory, which is required under federal or state law to be prescribed by a practitioner and dispensed by or through a person licensed under this chapter or exempt from licensure under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(16): "Prescription drug" means a drug that is required by federal or state law or rule to be dispensed only by prescription or is restricted to administration only by practitioners.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(17): 58-1-501; 58-71-501 "Unlawful conduct" means the same as that term is defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-102(18): 58-1-501; 58-71-502 "Unprofessional conduct" means the same as that term is defined in Sections


Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-203 Drug category review.
-----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-203(1): As used in this section, "FDA" means the federal Food and Drug Administration.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-203(2): After April 1, 2022, if the FDA adds a new drug category to the FDA's general drug category list, the division shall determine whether the drug category is consistent with the practice of naturopathic medicine.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-203(3): (2); 58-67-201 To make the determination described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-203(4): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act In accordance with


Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-301 Licensure required -- License classifications.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-301(1): A license is required to engage in the practice of naturopathic medicine, on or for any person in Utah, as a naturopathic physician.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-301(2): The division shall issue to a person who qualifies under this chapter a license in the classification of naturopathic physician.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-302 Qualifications for licensure.
-------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-302(1): (2); 63J-1-504; (1)(c) An applicant for licensure as a naturopathic physician, except as set forth in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-302(1)(a): submit an application in a form prescribed by the division, which may include:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-302(1)(a)(i): submissions by the applicant of information maintained by practitioner data banks, as designated by division rule, with respect to the applicant; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-302(1)(a)(ii): a record of professional liability claims made against the applicant and settlements paid by or in behalf of the applicant;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-302(1)(b): 63J-1-504 pay a fee determined by the department under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-302(1)(c): provide satisfactory documentation of having successfully completed a program of professional education preparing an individual as a naturopathic physician, as evidenced by having received an earned degree of doctor of naturopathic medicine from:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-302(1)(c)(i): a naturopathic medical school or college accredited by the Council of Naturopathic Medical Education or its successor organization approved by the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-302(1)(c)(ii): a naturopathic medical school or college that is a candidate for accreditation by the Council of Naturopathic Medical Education or its successor organization, and is approved by the division, upon a finding there is reasonable expectation the school or college will be accredited; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-302(1)(c)(iii): a naturopathic medical school or college which, at the time of the applicant's graduation, met current criteria for accreditation by the Council of Naturopathic Medical Education or its successor organization approved by the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-302(1)(d): (1)(c) provide satisfactory documentation of having successfully completed, after successful completion of the education requirements set forth in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-302(1)(e): pass the licensing examination sequence required by division rule;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-302(1)(f): be able to read, write, speak, understand, and be understood in the English language and demonstrate proficiency to the satisfaction of the division if requested by the division; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-302(1)(g): meet with representatives of the division, if requested, for the purpose of evaluating the applicant's qualifications for licensure.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-302(2): (2)(b); 58-1-302; 58-1-302; (1); (1)(d); (1)(e); (2); 58-1-302
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-302(2)(a): (2)(b); 58-1-302; 58-1-302; (1); (1)(d); (1)(e) In accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-302(2)(a)(i): 58-1-302 meet the requirements of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-302(2)(a)(ii): (1); (1)(d) document having met all requirements for licensure under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-302(2)(a)(iii): (1)(e) have passed the examination requirements established under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-302(2)(a)(iii)(A): the applicant has not passed in connection with licensure in another state or jurisdiction; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-302(2)(a)(iii)(B): are available to the applicant to take without requiring additional professional education;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-302(2)(a)(iv): have been actively engaged in the practice of a naturopathic physician for not less than 6,000 hours during the five years immediately preceding the date of application for licensure in Utah; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-302(2)(a)(v): meet with representatives of the division for the purpose of evaluating the applicant's qualifications for licensure.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-302(2)(b): (2); 58-1-302 The division may rely, either wholly or in part, on one or more credentialing associations designated by division rule to document and certify in writing to the satisfaction of the division that an applicant has met each of the requirements of this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-302(2)(b)(i): the applicant holds a current license;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-302(2)(b)(ii): the education, experience, and examination requirements of the foreign country or the state, district, or territory of the United States that issued the applicant's license are, or were at the time the license was issued, equal to those of this state for licensure as a naturopathic physician; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-302(2)(b)(iii): the applicant has produced evidence satisfactory to the division of the applicant's qualifications, identity, and good standing as a naturopathic physician.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-303 Term of license -- Expiration -- Renewal.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-303(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-303(1)(a): The division shall issue each license under this chapter in accordance with a two-year renewal cycle established by division rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-303(1)(b): The division may by rule extend or shorten a renewal period by as much as one year to stagger the renewal cycles it administers.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-303(2): At the time of renewal, the licensee shall show compliance with continuing education renewal requirements.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-303(3): 58-1-308 Each license issued under this chapter expires on the expiration date shown on the license unless renewed in accordance with Section


Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-304 License renewal requirements.
-------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-304(1): As a condition precedent for license renewal, each licensee shall, during each two-year licensure cycle or other cycle defined by division rule, complete qualified continuing professional education requirements in accordance with the number of hours and standards defined by division rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-304(2): 58-71-303 If a renewal period is extended or shortened under Section


Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-304.2 Temporary license.
----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-304.2(1): 58-71-302 The division may issue a temporary license to an individual who:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-304.2(1)(a): 58-71-302 meets all qualifications for licensure except completion of the 12 month clinical experience required under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-304.2(1)(b): presents a plan acceptable to the division under which the applicant will practice under the direct supervision of a licensed naturopathic physician, physician and surgeon, or osteopathic physician, who supervises not more than three naturopathic physicians in an approved clinical experience program.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-304.2(2): A temporary license issued under this section expires on the date the licensee completes the clinical experience program, but not more than 18 months from the original date of issue.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-304.2(3): A temporary license under this section may be issued only once to an individual.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-305 Exemptions from licensure.
----------------------------------------------------------
In addition to the exemptions from licensure in SectionUtah Code Annotated § 58-71-305(1): an individual rendering aid in an emergency, when no fee or other consideration of value for the service is charged, received, expected, or contemplated;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-305(2): an individual administering a domestic or family remedy;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-305(3): a person engaged in the sale of vitamins, health foods, dietary supplements, herbs, or other products of nature, the sale of which is not otherwise prohibited under state or federal law, but this subsection does not:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-305(3)(a): allow a person to diagnose any human disease, ailment, injury, infirmity, deformity, pain, or other condition; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-305(3)(b): prohibit providing truthful and nonmisleading information regarding any of the products under this subsection;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-305(4): a person engaged in good faith in the practice of the religious tenets of any church or religious belief, without the use of prescription drugs;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-305(5): (3) a person acting in good faith for religious reasons as a matter of conscience or based on a personal belief when obtaining or providing information regarding health care and the use of any product under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-305(6): 26-1-30; 41-6a-523(1)(a)(vi); 53-10-405(2)(a)(vi); 72-10-502(5)(a)(vi); 77-23-213(3)(a)(vi) an individual authorized by the Department of Health under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-305(7): a naturopathic medical assistant while working under the direct and immediate supervision of a licensed naturopathic physician to the extent the medical assistant is engaged in tasks appropriately delegated by the supervisor in accordance with the standards and ethics of the practice of naturopathic medicine; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-305(8): 58-71-302 an individual who has completed all requirements for licensure under this chapter except the clinical experience required under Section


Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-306 Status of licenses held on the effective date of this chapter.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
An individual holding a current license as a naturopathic physician that was issued under prior Utah law is considered to hold a current license and retains the scope of practice authorized under this title prior to the enactment of this chapter.

Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-401 Grounds for denial of license -- Disciplinary proceedings.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Grounds for division action regarding the following are under SectionUtah Code Annotated § 58-71-401(1): refusing to issue a license to an applicant or refusing to renew the license of a licensee;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-401(2): revoking, suspending, restricting, or placing on probation the license of a licensee;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-401(3): assessing an administrative penalty; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-401(4): issuing a public or private reprimand to a licensee or issuing a cease and desist order.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-402 Authority to assess penalty.
------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-402(1): Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act; Title 58, Chapter 1, Division of Professional Licensing Act After proceeding pursuant to
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-402(2): Assessment of a penalty under this section does not affect any other action the division is authorized to take regarding a license issued under this chapter.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-501 Unlawful conduct.
-------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-501(1): 58-1-501 "Unlawful conduct" includes, in addition to the definition in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-501(1)(a): buying, selling, or fraudulently obtaining, any medical diploma, license, certificate, or registration related to credentials of a naturopathic physician; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-501(1)(b): aiding or abetting the buying, selling, or fraudulently obtaining of any naturopathic physician diploma, license, certificate, or registration.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-501(2): "Unlawful conduct" does not include the good faith expression of informed opinions as to available alternatives to the treatment prescribed or advised by the licensee.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-502 Unprofessional conduct.
-------------------------------------------------------
"Unprofessional conduct" includes:Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-502(1): using or employing the services of any individual to assist a licensee in any manner not in accordance with the generally recognized practices, standards, or ethics of the profession, state law, or division rule; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-502(2): (1); 58-1-501(1) falsely making an entry in, or altering, a medical record with the intent to conceal:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-502(2)(a): a wrongful or negligent act or omission of an individual licensed under this chapter or an individual under the direction or control of an individual licensed under this chapter; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-502(2)(b): (1); 58-1-501(1) conduct described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-503 Penalty for unlawful conduct.
-------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-503(1): 58-71-501; 58-1-501(1)(a); 58-1-501(1)(c) Any person who violates the unlawful conduct provisions of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-503(2): 58-71-402 The division may assess administrative penalties in accordance with the provisions of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-503(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-503(3)(a): The director may collect a penalty that is not paid by:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-503(3)(a)(i): referring the matter to a collection agency; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-503(3)(a)(ii): bringing an action in the district court of the county where the person against whom the penalty is imposed resides or in the county where the office of the director is located.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-503(3)(b): A county attorney or the attorney general of the state shall provide legal assistance and advice to the director in an action to collect a penalty.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-503(3)(c): A court shall award reasonable attorney fees and costs to the prevailing party in an action brought by the division to collect a penalty.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-601 Mentally incompetent or incapacitated naturopathic physician.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-601(1): 75-1-201; 26B-5-303 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-601(1)(a): 75-1-201 "Incapacitated person" means a person who is incapacitated, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-601(1)(b): 26B-5-303 "Mental illness" is as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-601(2): Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act If a court of competent jurisdiction determines a naturopathic physician is an incapacitated person or that the physician has a mental illness and is unable to safely engage in the practice of medicine, the director shall immediately suspend the license of the naturopathic physician upon the entry of the judgment of the court, without further proceedings under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-601(3): 58-1-109; Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act; (4)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-601(3)(a): If the division finds reasonable cause to believe a naturopathic physician, who is not determined judicially to be an incapacitated person or to have a mental illness, is incapable of practicing medicine with reasonable skill regarding the safety of patients, because of illness, excessive use of drugs or alcohol, or as a result of any mental or physical condition, the director shall file a petition with the division, and cause the petition to be served upon the naturopathic physician with a notice of hearing on the sole issue of the capacity of the naturopathic physician to competently and safely engage in the practice of medicine.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-601(3)(b): 58-1-109; Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act; (4) The hearing shall be conducted under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-601(4): Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-601(4)(a): Every naturopathic physician who accepts the privilege of being licensed under this chapter gives consent to:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-601(4)(a)(i): submitting at the physician's own expense to an immediate mental or physical examination when directed in writing by the division to do so; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-601(4)(a)(ii): the admissibility of the reports of the examining physician's testimony or examination, and waives all objections on the ground the reports constitute a privileged communication.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-601(4)(b): The examination may be ordered by the division only upon a finding of reasonable cause to believe:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-601(4)(b)(i): the naturopathic physician has a mental illness, is incapacitated, or otherwise unable to practice medicine with reasonable skill and safety; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-601(4)(b)(ii): immediate action by the division is necessary to prevent harm to the naturopathic physician's patients or the general public.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-601(4)(c): Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-601(4)(c)(i): Failure of a naturopathic physician to submit to the examination ordered under this section is a ground for the division's immediate suspension of the naturopathic physician's license by written order of the director.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-601(4)(c)(ii): Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act The division may enter the order of suspension without further compliance with
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-601(5): (2); (3); 58-1-108; 58-1-109
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-601(5)(a): (2); (3) A naturopathic physician whose license is suspended under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-601(5)(b): 58-1-108; 58-1-109 The hearing held under this subsection shall be conducted in accordance with Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-601(6): A naturopathic physician whose license is revoked, suspended, or in any way restricted under this section may request the division to consider, at reasonable intervals, evidence presented by the naturopathic physician, under procedures established by division rule, regarding any change in the naturopathic physician's condition, to determine whether:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-601(6)(a): the physician is or is not able to safely and competently engage in the practice of medicine; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-601(6)(b): the physician is qualified to have the physician's license to practice under this chapter restored completely or in part.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-701 Immunity provisions apply.
----------------------------------------------------------


Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-801 Disclosure of financial interest by licensee -- Kick-back prohibition.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-801(1): (2); 58-17b-102; 58-17b-102 Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-801(1)(a): 58-17b-102; 58-17b-102 a pharmacy as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-801(1)(b): a retail store, wholesaler, distributor, manufacturer, or facility of any other kind located in this state that is engaged in the sale, dispensing, delivery, distribution, or manufacture of homeopathic remedies, dietary supplements, or natural medicines.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-801(2): (1)(a); (b); (2)(a)(ii)
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-801(2)(a): (1)(a); (b) A naturopathic physician may refer an individual to an entity described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-801(2)(a)(i): the entity's stock is publicly traded and the naturopathic physician owns less than 5% of the entity's outstanding stock; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-801(2)(a)(ii): at the time of the referral, the naturopathic physician discloses in writing that the naturopathic physician or a member of the naturopathic physician's immediate family has an ownership interest in the entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-801(2)(b): (2)(a)(ii) A disclosure described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-801(2)(c): A naturopathic physician shall comply with any applicable federal laws regarding patient referrals and kick-backs that apply to a physician.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-801(3): A naturopathic physician may sell from the naturopathic physician's office homeopathic remedies or dietary supplements as defined in the Federal Food Drug and Cosmetic Act consistent with division rule.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-802 Form of practice.
-------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-802(1): A naturopathic physician licensed under this chapter may engage in practice as a naturopathic physician, or in the practice of naturopathic medicine only as an individual licensee; but as an individual licensee, the naturopathic physician may be:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-802(1)(a): an individual operating as a business proprietor;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-802(1)(b): an employee of another person;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-802(1)(c): a partner in a lawfully organized partnership;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-802(1)(d): a lawfully formed professional corporation;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-802(1)(e): a lawfully organized limited liability company;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-802(1)(f): a lawfully organized business corporation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-802(1)(g): any other form of organization recognized by the state which is not prohibited by rule adopted by division rules.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-802(2): 58-71-301 Regardless of the form in which a licensee engages in the practice of medicine, the licensee may only permit the practice of medicine in that form of practice to be conducted by an individual:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-802(2)(a): 58-71-301 licensed in Utah as a naturopathic physician under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-802(2)(b): who is able to lawfully and competently engage in the practice of medicine.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-803 Medical records -- Electronic records.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-803(1): Medical records maintained by a licensee shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-803(1)(a): meet the standards and ethics of the profession; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-803(1)(b): be maintained in accordance with division rules.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-803(2): (1) Medical records under this section may be maintained by an electronic means if the records comply with Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-804 Insurance coverage not mandated.
----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-804(1): This chapter does not mandate health insurance coverage for naturopathic medical services.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-804(2): 31A-22-618 This chapter does not establish a class of health care providers for the purposes of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-71-804(3): This chapter does not mandate health insurance coverage for the prescription or administration of testosterone by a naturopathic physician.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 58 - Chapter 72 - Acupuncture Licensing Act
***********************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-101 Title.
--------------------------------------
This chapter shall be known as the "Acupuncture Licensing Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-102 Acupuncture licensing -- Definitions.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
In addition to the definitions in SectionUtah Code Annotated § 58-72-102(1): 58-72-201 "Board" means the Acupuncture Licensing Board created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-102(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-102(2)(a): "Injection therapy" means the use of a hypodermic needle, by a licensed acupuncturist who has obtained a clean needle technique certificate from the National Commission for the Certification of Acupuncture and Oriental Medicine (NCCAOM), to inject any of the following sterile substances in liquid form into acupuncture points on the body subcutaneously or intramuscularly:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-102(2)(a)(i): a nutritional substance;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-102(2)(a)(ii): a local anesthetic;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-102(2)(a)(iii): autologous blood, if the licensee holds a current phlebotomy certification to draw blood;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-102(2)(a)(iv): sterile water;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-102(2)(a)(v): dextrose;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-102(2)(a)(vi): sodium bicarbonate; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-102(2)(a)(vii): sterile saline.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-102(2)(b): "Injection therapy" includes using ultrasound guidance to ensure that an injection is only a subcutaneous injection or an intramuscular injection.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-102(2)(c): "Injection therapy" does not include injecting a substance into a vein, joint, artery, blood vessel, nerve, tendon, deep organ, or the spine.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-102(2)(d): "Injection therapy" may not be performed on a pregnant woman or a child under the age of eight.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-102(3): "Licensed acupuncturist," designated as "L.Ac.," means a person who has been licensed under this chapter to practice acupuncture.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-102(4): "Moxibustion" means a heat therapy that uses the herb moxa to heat acupuncture points of the body.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-102(5): (5)(a); (b); 58-28-307(12); 58-73-102
Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-102(5)(a): "Practice of acupuncture" means the insertion of acupuncture needles, the use of injection therapy, and the application of moxibustion to specific areas of the body based on traditional oriental medical diagnosis and modern research as a primary mode of therapy.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-102(5)(b): (5)(a); (b); 58-28-307(12) Adjunctive therapies within the scope of the practice of acupuncture may include:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-102(5)(b)(i): manual, mechanical, thermal, electrical, light, and electromagnetic treatments based on traditional oriental medical diagnosis and modern research;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-102(5)(b)(ii): the recommendation, administration, or provision of dietary guidelines, herbs, supplements, homeopathics, and therapeutic exercise based on traditional oriental medical diagnosis and modern research according to practitioner training; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-102(5)(b)(iii): (5)(a); (b); 58-28-307(12) the practice described in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-102(5)(b)(iii)(A): 58-28-307(12) Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-102(5)(b)(iii)(B): the provisions of this chapter; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-102(5)(b)(iii)(C): division rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-102(5)(c): 58-73-102 "Practice of acupuncture" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-102(5)(c)(i): the manual manipulation or adjustment of the joints of the body beyond the elastic barrier; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-102(5)(c)(ii): 58-73-102 the "manipulation of the articulation of the spinal column" as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-102(6): 58-1-501; 58-72-503 "Unprofessional conduct" is as defined in Sections


Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-103 Rulemaking.
-------------------------------------------
When exercising rulemaking authority under this chapter, the division shall comply with the requirements of

Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-201 Acupuncture Licensing Board.
------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-201(1): There is created an Acupuncture Licensing Board consisting of:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-201(1)(a): four licensed acupuncturists; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-201(1)(b): one member from the general public.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-201(2): 58-1-201 The board shall be appointed and serve in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-201(3): 58-1-202; 58-1-203
Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-201(3)(a): 58-1-202; 58-1-203 The duties and responsibilities of the board shall be in accordance with Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-201(3)(b): In addition, the board shall designate one of its members on a permanent rotating basis to:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-201(3)(b)(i): assist the division in reviewing complaints concerning the unlawful or unprofessional conduct of a licensee; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-201(3)(b)(ii): advise the division in its investigation of these complaints.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-201(4): (3) A board member who has, under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-301 License required -- License classification.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-301(1): 58-1-307; 58-72-304 A license is required to engage in the practice of acupuncture, except as specifically provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-301(2): The division shall issue to a person who qualifies under this chapter a license in the classification of licensed acupuncturist.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-302 Qualifications for licensure.
-------------------------------------------------------------
An applicant for licensure as a licensed acupuncturist shall:Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-302(1): submit an application in a form prescribed by the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-302(2): 63J-1-504 pay a fee determined by the department under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-302(3): meet the requirements for current active certification in acupuncture under guidelines established by the National Commission for the Certification of Acupuncture and Oriental Medicine (NCCAOM) as demonstrated through a current certificate or other appropriate documentation;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-302(4): pass the examination required by the division by rule;
Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-302(5): establish procedures, as defined by rule, which shall enable patients to give informed consent to treatment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-302(6): meet with the board, if requested, for the purpose of evaluating the applicant's qualifications for licensure.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-303 Terms of license -- Expiration -- Renewal.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-303(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-303(1)(a): Each license issued under this chapter shall be issued in accordance with a two-year renewal cycle established by rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-303(1)(b): A renewal period may be extended or shortened by as much as one year to maintain established renewal cycles or to change an established renewal cycle.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-303(2): 58-1-308 Each license automatically expires on the expiration date shown on the license unless renewed by the licensee in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-303(3): Renewal qualifications shall include:
Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-303(3)(a): either documentation of current and active NCCAOM certification; or
Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-303(3)(b): meeting the same professional development requirements as those licensed under this chapter.


Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-304 Exceptions from licensure.
----------------------------------------------------------
In addition to the exemptions from licensure set forth in SectionUtah Code Annotated § 58-72-304(1): 58-1-602; 58-1-602 an individual described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-304(2): Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act; Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act an individual licensed as a physician and surgeon or osteopathic physician and surgeon under
Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-304(3): a commissioned physician or surgeon serving in the armed forces of the United States or other federal agency; and
Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-304(4): Chapter 73, Chiropractic Physician Practice Act a chiropractic physician licensed under


Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-401 Grounds for denial of license -- Disciplinary proceedings -- Resumption of practice.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Grounds for refusal to issue a license to an applicant, for refusal to renew the license of a licensee, to revoke, suspend, restrict, or place on probation the license of a licensee, to issue a public or private reprimand to a licensee, and to issue cease and desist orders shall be in accordance with Section

Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-501 Acupuncture licensee -- Restriction on titles used.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-501(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-501(1)(a): A person practicing as a licensed acupuncturist may not display or in any way use any title, words, or insignia in conjunction with the person's name or practice except the words "licensed acupuncturist" or "L.Ac.".
Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-501(1)(b): When used in conjunction with the person's practice, the term "licensed acupuncturist" or "L.Ac." shall be displayed next to the name of the licensed acupuncturist.
Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-501(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 58-72-501(2)(a): A licensed acupuncturist may not use the term "physician," "physician or surgeon," or "doctor" in conjunction with the acupuncturist's name or practice.
